HEADLINE: 4th-Quarter Net Soared 52% at Dell Computer

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The Dell Computer Corporation reported quarterly earnings yesterday that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates, as the company's strategy of selling computers directly to consumers continued to fuel torrid growth.
Revenue at Dell rose for a 16th consecutive quarter, even as competitors started to emulate its build-to-order strategy. Though both the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company have adopted portions of Dell Computer's business model, their efforts have had little impact on Dell. 
 By selling its machines direct to customers, with no dealers or distributors as middlemen, Dell is able to minimize inventory and maximize return on capital. Compaq Computer and Hewlett-Packard still sell primarily through dealers, but have made steps to reduce inventories by building only machines for which they have orders.
Dell announced its results after the market closed. Shares of Dell closed at $113.1875, up $1.875, a new high, in Nasdaq trading. Dell also announced today that its board has declared a 2-for-1 stock split.
For the fiscal fourth quarter, which ended Feb. 1, Dell reported earnings of $285 million, or 81 cents a diluted share, up 52 percent from $188 million, or 50 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 55 percent, to $3.74 billion, from $2.41 billion in the fourth quarter of the 1997 fiscal year.
"They had astonishing revenue growth," said Charles Wolf, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston. "They obviously were not affected by any competitive strategies of Compaq or Hewlett-Packard. It's proving more of a challenge to implement a build-to-order model than these guys have thought."
Dell said it saw strong revenue gains in the United States, Latin America and Europe. Despite the economic crisis in Asia, Dell said it achieved profitable fourth-quarter results in the Asia-Pacific region, which includes Japan. Revenues in that region exceeded $240 million, a 79 percent increase from a year earlier, the company said.
Michael S. Dell, the chairman and chief executive of Dell Computer, said that the company's outlook for 1998 was positive. He cited pending transitions to new computer chips and reductions in the costs of other components as factors that could continue to drive demand for new machines.
Also, the Microsoft Corporation plans to introduce the updated version of its personal computer operating system, Windows 98, this year.
Dell's direct model allows the company to rapidly pass on lower costs for components like memory chips or disk drives, giving it a further competitive advantage when technology changes.
For the year, Dell had earnings of $944 million, or $2.56 a diluted share, up 82 percent from $518 million, or $1.32 a diluted share, in the 1997 year. Revenue grew 59 percent, to $12.33 billion, from $7.76 billion in the previous year.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Climbs by 52.56 to Reach Its 6th Consecutive High

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
The indefatigable Dow Jones industrial average rose to another record yesterday, as investors shrugged off the conflict with Iraq and Asian economic concerns and took heart from technology earnings.
The industrials gained 52.56 to close at 8,451.06, their sixth consecutive high, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 9.30 points to end at 1,032.06, also a high. While much of this week's rally can be traced to merger frenzy among stocks as varied at Beneficial and, one stock has been particularly active despite no real news: Nike. 
 For Nike investors, the recent run-up amounts to deja vu.
In the last two days, Nike's stock has risen 9 percent, mostly on market rumors that Warren E. Buffett is adding to his 2 percent stake in the company. Of course, Mr. Buffett, one of the country's leading value investors; his holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, and Nike, the maker of athletic apparel and footwear, are not talking.
Much the same thing happened last May. Unconfirmed Buffett-buying rumors lifted Nike's shares 6.4 percent on May 28. But the stock dropped with a thud -- losing more than 13 percent of its value -- the next day when the company warned that earnings for the quarter about to end would fall short of Wall Street estimates.
Wall Street stock analysts are not ruling out a repeat performance in coming days.
Nike's stock rose $3.50 on Tuesday, with 6.5 million shares traded. It opened sharply higher yesterday, but ended the day with a gain of only 25 cents, on slightly less volume, to close at 44 5/8.
While the stock may be cheap by some measures -- it's a far cry from its high of $75.75 reached a year ago -- many analysts warn that sales growth is slowing in the United States and Asia and that inventory is swelling, which means Nike's situation could worsen before it improves.
The company is even considering ways to cut costs, which could include layoffs and reduced spending on advertising and promotions.
For Nike, "I don't see any positive things in the near term," said Maureen Carini, an equity analyst with Standard & Poor's. "In the next six to 12 months, it's not something that earnings-wise is going to take off."
A pickup in sales of "brown shoes," or rugged outdoor styles, as well as increased competition from other manufacturers, like Adidas, has cut into Nike's business. But the most pressing concern is the slowdown in Asia, which represented about 13 percent of fiscal year 1997 sales.
Dwindling demand for Nike's athletic shoes, particularly its higher priced basketball shoes, has led to an inventory buildup, Ms. Carini said. New shoe styles, which could reinvigorate sales, are not expected before early next year, she added.
The company is expected to clear up the domestic inventory buildup without much trouble, using discounted prices and discount outlets. But the excess in Japan, where a buildup is just beginning to appear, will be much more difficult to move.
"Japan doesn't have a factory outlet distribution system, so that presents more challenges for us," said Rick Anguilla, Nike's director of investor relations, who conceded that the company was caught off guard by the weakened Asia sales.
The smaller shoe sizes in Japan make it difficult to distribute the shoes elsewhere, said John Horan, publisher of Sporting Goods Intelligence, an industry newsletter based in Glen Mills, Pa. "Japan is going to be a a serious problem," he said, because it is not clear how big the inventory pileup will be or when demand will return. Japan accounted for about 7 percent of sales last year but was expected to grow rapidly. Nike has already taken a hit. In its fiscal second quarter ended Nov. 30, Nike earned 48 cents a share, below both the 55 cents forecast and the 60 cents recorded in the period a year earlier. Since then, analysts have lowered their estimates, to $2.02 for fiscal year 1998, from the $2.60 previously forecast, and from the $2.68 earned last year.
Nike itself has said in recent weeks that it is "looking at its cost structure based on our outlook for the business," which some analysts take to suggest that a restructuring is imminent.
"Here is a company that was expecting dramatic growth from Asia, and now Asia is shrinking," said Shellly Hale Young, a stock analyst with Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco. Asian sales could be flat, she said, instead of 30 percent higher as previously projected. To cut costs, the company may be forced to restructure, cutting staff as well as advertising and promotional spending, she said.
Nike, which has enjoyed 40 percent sales growth the last three years, must adjust to a slower rate of growth, said Ms. Young, who expects the company to earn about $1.50 a share annually for the next few years. She says the stock should trade at about 25 times its earnings for the coming year. That would put it at about $37 a share.
"Right now the fundamentals of the company are deteriorating," she said. "Until the fundamentals stabilize, I would not be putting money into Nike stock based on a rumor."
Elsewhere in the market yesterday, technology stocks led a modest surge. The Nasdaq composite index gained 12.30 points, to 1,715.73, rebounding from a selloff the previous day.
Dell Computer reported fourth-quarter profits that beat analysts' expectations as revenues rose for the 16th consecutive quarter on strong gains in the United States, Europe and Latin America.
Hewlett-Packard's stock also rose, as investors barely penalized the stock for logging flat fiscal first-quarter earnings on Tuesday that fell slightly below some analysts' forecasts.

HEADLINE: Suharto's Choice as No. 2: Whiz or Loose Cannon?

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 18

 BODY:
He has designed submarines and railway carriages. He believes that economic growth can be engineered by rapidly bouncing interest rates up and down. He likes to refer to his boss, President Suharto, as S.G.S., for Super Genius Suharto.
B. J. Habibie, 61, who is now almost certain to become Vice President next month -- and the potential successor to the 76-year-old President -- is viewed by many here and abroad as Indonesia's loose cannon. A technological whiz, political naif and economic eccentric, he has struck fear into the hearts of international investors. 
 Today, the influential military fell into line behind him as Mr. Suharto's evident choice for the post, after his nomination by all three political parties, despite longstanding antagonism toward him within the armed forces.
Though Mr. Habibie is set to become the constitutional successor to Mr. Suharto, he does not have a strong power base beyond the President himself, and political analysts have raised questions about his ability to hold on to power on his own.
One scenario being discussed here is the possibility that if Mr. Suharto dies or is incapacitated, an electoral assembly would convene to hammer out a succession. There are also suggestions that Mr. Suharto might at some point name another person as his chosen successor.
But there is also a common view that the President has no intention of dying or leaving office before his term is up in 2001 and that the question of succession that obsesses Indonesians is not foremost on his mind.
The nomination appears to reflect the President's stubborn insistence that it is he -- and not the financial markets -- who makes the decisions in Indonesia. It comes at a time when Mr. Suharto is pushing ahead with plans for a fixed currency-exchange rate, over the objections of the International Monetary Fund and the United States.
When Mr. Habibie's name was first floated for Vice President a month ago, investors panicked and the value of the currency, the rupiah, fell 35 percent in one week.
The monetary fund showed its concern when its first deputy managing director, Stanley Fischer, described Mr. Habibie as a man "whose devotion to new ways of doing things is limited."
Many Indonesians also view his ascendancy with alarm. "My own view is that it would be a tragic mistake for him to become Vice President," a political analyst said. He is undeniably brilliant, but impractical, the analyst said.
An American businessman who has dealt with him said: "Habibie is amazing. The guy thinks and talks a mile a minute, and he is quite impressive." But the businessman added, "He loves grand projects that make people feel better but cost a lot of money, and this is a country that can't afford to waste money."
When the monetary fund pressed Mr. Suharto to sign an austerity package last month, one of the wasteful programs it insisted on scrapping was Mr. Habibie's money-losing $2 billion project to build a national aircraft.
Mr. Habibie tends to dismiss his critics as uninformed. "They don't understand," he once said, "and I don't have time to explain what I'm doing to everyone."
Mr. Habibie is known here as "the busiest man in Indonesia" for his energy and his many projects, and political analysts expect him to have a greater impact on the running of the nation than the current Vice President, a low-key former general named Try Sutrisno.
The five-year terms of Mr. Suharto and Mr. Try end next month. Mr. Suharto, who has been in office for 32 years, has said he plans to stay on for a seventh term, which would end when he is 81 years old.
Mr. Habibie's chief asset appears to be his closeness to the President, with whom, by many reports, he shares an almost giddy relationship, demonstrating computer tricks to him and bursting into his office unannounced for long personal discussions.
Their relationship goes back 48 years, to the time when Mr. Suharto was a military commander and virtually adopted the 13-year-old boy when his father died.
Since then, Mr. Habibie has received a doctorate in engineering in Germany, worked for 18 years for a German aircraft manufacturer and joined Mr. Suharto's Government as a personal adviser and then Minister of Research and Technology, his current post.
In this position, he has devoted his energies to what many analysts see as unrealistic projects like the development of a national aircraft, promotion of nuclear power and the purchase for $13 million of used East German warships that were in need of $1 billion in repairs.

HEADLINE: Auto Makers to Buy More From Minority-Owned Companies

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has reached an agreement with the Big Three auto makers to increase their purchases from minority-owned companies by nearly $3 billion by the year 2001, officials from the Administration and the auto makers said today.
According to these officials, representatives of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler will sign an agreement on Thursday committing the auto makers to increase purchases from minority contractors to 5 percent of total procurement from the current 4.2 percent. The amount of contracts is to increase incrementally over three years starting this year. 
 The program, which will increase the amount of contracts from the Big Three auto makers to minority companies to $8.8 billion a year from the current $5.9 billion, comes as programs extending breaks to minorities and women or setting aside contracts for their companies are increasingly coming under attack.
Two years ago, voters in California approved a ballot initiative that forbade granting "preferences" based on race or gender in admission to state colleges and universities, hiring by state agencies and contracting by state departments. A similar referendum will be voted on in Washington State this year.
In addition, court challenges against Federal contracting programs that give preferences to minority-owned companies have been filed -- and in some cases won -- in Federal courts.
In the face of this mood, however, the Clinton Administration is seeking to have three of the country's largest corporations enlarge their affirmative action contracting programs.
Among those affirmative action programs that have been successfully challenged in the courts are those in Richmond, Va., and one run by the Federal Department of Transportation that set specific goals for contracts to go to minorities. But one executive said he did not think this new initiative would be overturned.
"Those were government programs," said this executive, who spoke only on condition that neither he nor his company be identified. "We are private sector and we can do business with whom we want."
The three-year pilot program is scheduled to be announced on Thursday. It is being touted as part of President Clinton's Initiative on Race, though discussions between the auto makers and the Small Business Administration on increasing minority contracting first started three years ago.
In a statement that is to be delivered on Thursday, Judith A. Winston, the executive director of the President's Initiative on Race, said the companies are recognizing "the economic value of reducing the opportunity gap between minority- and majority-owned businesses." The program being announced on Thursday is an expansion of current efforts. Federal law requires that auto makers that sell vehicles to the Government have a program to insure that minority-owned companies are used as suppliers. Each year, General Motors, Ford and Chrysler submit plans to the Small Business Administration outlining their goals for procurement from minority companies.
In recent years, however, the number of minority companies winning contracts from the Big Three auto-makers has been falling because the auto companies have increasingly used what is called "system sourcing," buying whole units, such as an instrument panel from a supplier, rather than individual parts like speedometers or tachometers.
Often minority-owned companies are too small to compete in this kind of business environment.
Under the agreement that will be signed on Thursday, the auto makers want the Federal Government to give them credit for getting prime contractors to buy parts and services from minority subcontractors. The agreement also, for the first time, would let the auto makers count contracts they award to publicly traded companies as long as a member of a minority holds at least 10 percent of the stock and controls the operations of the company. Federal regulations now say that a member of a minority must own 51 percent of the company in order for it to qualify as a minority-owned.
The agreement calls for the auto makers to send at least 10 executives of minority-owned companies to business schools and provide technical assistance to Small Business Administration programs for small, minority-owned businesses.

HEADLINE: CORPORATE BROADWAY -- A special report.;
Gambling on a Trip From 'Ragtime' to Riches

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Garth H. Drabinsky likes to visit the theater he just finished building in Manhattan and watch the crowds stream in to see the musical he just finished producing.
"I stand in the lobby, and I try to look nondescript," he said in a recent interview. "I'm wearing just a sweater and a pair of cords. And so many people have walked over and said, 'Thank you for this gift.' The theater and the show, they call it a gift." 
 Mr. Drabinsky is the president of Livent Inc., the Toronto-based entertainment company. The theater is the opulent Ford Center for the Performing Arts, and the musical is, of course, "Ragtime." And if Mr. Drabinsky's picture of himself is perhaps self-consciously humble, it's a bit incomplete. For the accomplished theater producer is also a high-rolling entrepreneur. And in presenting his new show in his brand-new theater, he is himself the star of a high-stakes epic going on in the wings.
Much of Livent's future depends on "Ragtime," a show he first presented in Toronto 15 months ago and that has cost upward of $12 million to put on in New York. The show represents a bold foray into the relatively new world of corporate theater financing, and it comes with considerable risk.
Should "Ragtime" not become a mega-hit, selling out the house for months, if not years, to come, then the growth of Mr. Drabinsky's highly leveraged, expanding theater empire could be imperiled.
Mr. Drabinsky and Livent are part of what is beginning to look like a corporate takeover of Broadway that is tearing down the old order. The Disney Company, with its productions of "Beauty and the Beast" and "The Lion King" is, of course, a highly visible part of the theater landscape. And less well-known partnerships and joint ventures, like Dodger Endemol Theatricals and Jujamcyn-Pace are also helping to transform the anachronistic live theater business with the resources of contemporary corporations. Still, Livent (pronounced LYE-vent), which operates without partners, remains the world's only publicly held company whose main business is live theater production. If its shows falter, its safety net is small.
Now nine years old, Livent has systematically broadened its range of productions. By now it has presented musicals it has acquired ("Phantom of the Opera," "Kiss of the Spider Woman," "Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat"); it has produced revivals on its own ("Show Boat," "Candide"), and it has made one successful venture into original drama ("Barrymore").
But before "Ragtime," it had not entered the notoriously high-risk arena of original musical production, and that is where the company has staked its future: it has four more new musicals in development. And with "Ragtime," it has leaped in without a shred of wariness. A second production has been running in Los Angeles since last May, will move on to Vancouver in the spring and then open this fall in a theater Mr. Drabinsky is building in Chicago. A third is to open in April in Washington, then tour nationally. A fourth is to open in Sydney, Australia, next year.
To do all this, Livent has borrowed heavily, which means that the success of "Ragtime" will be measured by extraordinary standards. It will not be enough if the show draws an audience simply to pay for itself and turn a profit. Rather, Livent is counting on the New York production to propel the others, and thus to create a "Ragtime" revenue stream to help the company retire its debt and finance future projects.
"Historically, Livent has put on far more restorations of previously mounted shows than newly originated ones, and new productions entail far higher financial risk," said Edward Lawrence, an entertainment industry analyst with Standard & Poor's, the bond rating agency that last fall gave Livent a double B-minus rating, warning investors that as a bond issuer, the company is a risk. In the near future, the agency concluded, the overall outlook for the company is negative.
"Over the next three years there are aspects of the company that could lead to its deterioration," Mr. Lawrence said.
 
Financing
Little Trouble Winning Backers
Mr. Drabinsky's vision is essentially to spurn the long-standing and increasingly enervated methods of financing and producing new shows and to bring sharp-elbowed corporate business practice to an arena where it is more or less untried. What makes the offstage drama particularly interesting is that so far, he has had little trouble winning financial backers.
In the fall, when the company wanted to restructure its debt and floated a $125 million bond offering, it was oversubscribed, despite the Standard & Poor's assessment and an equally ominous one from Moody's, which considered it a high risk. Despite a lagging stock price -- it closed at $8.81 yesterday -- equity analysts have been generally bullish, with Paul Marsh of Cowen & Company recently predicting that shares could rise to $18 by the end of the year.
"What 'Ragtime' means is many things," said Roy Furman, vice chairman of Furman Selz, an underwriter of the bond offering. "First it will be a validation of Garth's uncommon producing style, his unusual taste and vision. Second, it will be a validation of him as an individual, that he was able to build this theater at the same time he's doing the show; that would have drained anybody. And financially it's immense. It's going to be a gold mine."
Mr. Drabinsky has thus far kept all his promises. Last winter, when he announced that he would open the Ford Center by the end of 1997 -- and thus qualify for several million dollars in tax abatements -- there were many skeptics.
The chosen site, owned by the State of New York, a midblock span on West 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues where the Lyric and Apollo Theaters stood, was presumed unsuitable, too small for his plan of a grandly appointed 1,800-seat house. (The only Broadway theater larger is the 1,900-seat Gershwin, less of a theater than a canyon.) He had not given himself enough time or, at $30 million, allotted enough money. But as with many things, Mr. Drabinsky, who is 48, felt differently.
On Dec. 26, the Ford Center opened its doors for the first preview of "Ragtime," which Mr. Drabinsky brought to New York with equal bravado, having spent more than $2 million to advertise it.
 
The Man's Image
Beyond the Big Talk, Attention to Details
This is Mr. Drabinsky's style, big-talking, grandiose, even hubristic. He protests such characterizations, however, preferring to emphasize the personal aspects of theater producing. "At the root of everything is my interest in maintaining harmony in the collaborative process," he said.
But comments about his larger-than-lifeness are hard to avoid, invoked even by those whose loyalty and admiration he has won. He is willing, even eager, to lavish money and braggadocio on projects he deems worthy; his "Show Boat," at upward of $10 million, not including the advertising costs, was almost certainly the most expensive Broadway revival. (It recouped its cost and has toured with three companies.) And his attention to the details of his productions -- he spent a recent day in Chicago overseeing auditions for ensemble roles in the planned production of "Ragtime" there -- is disputed by no one.
Nor is the ambition he has for his business. In less than a decade, Livent has grown from a base of one theater and one show to an expanding empire that by the end of next year will own or operate six theaters; it has already begun a total of 15 productions, 8 of which are active in theaters across the United States and Canada. Five musicals, including one revival, "Pal Joey," are to open between now and the year 2000. The term one hears applied to him, over and over, is "impresario."
"I think there must have been more people like Garth years ago, more impresarios," said E. L. Doctorow, author of the novel "Ragtime," from which the show was adapted. "He certainly defines the term, the ability to organize a series of ambitions and make them come out the way he planned. The bluster is there, no question, but basically, at a very early point I had no doubt that he would do everything he said he would. He promised me there would be no stinting about what he put into the show, and he kept his promise."
Still, as Mr. Drabinsky continues to keep his promises, the questions about how he does it continue to follow him, largely because of his well-established iconoclasm. A large man, shaggy-haired, a little jowly, he walks with a pronounced limp from a boyhood bout with polio that left him, he wrote in his 1994 autobiography, "Closer to the Sun," "with a hunger for life that has never left me." He was a virtual unknown on Broadway when his first New York show, "Kiss of the Spider Woman," won a Tony Award for best musical in 1993.
But he began raising eyebrows in the theater world, and questions about his financial acumen, when he stubbornly kept the show running for months after it began losing money. This was the start of what some Broadway veterans think of as Livent's financial game-playing. They wonder, for instance, why it doesn't include advertising costs when it tallies the cost of a show, as every other producer does. ("Ragtime" is routinely referred to as having cost a mere $10 million.) They wonder about how the company reports its ticket receipts. Livent reported that on the day after "Ragtime" opened in New York, for example, it sold $2.3 million worth of tickets, a huge figure rivaling the $2.7 million achieved in November by Disney's "Lion King."
 
Livent's Method
Delaying Accounting Of What Is Spent
 But Livent's figure, unlike Disney's, included group sales as well as single-ticket buyers; it is single-ticket sales that are generally regarded as the measuring stick of public interest (the actual first-day single-ticket sales figure for "Ragtime" was $964,000, which is high, just not that high). And they wonder about the justification of not including a show's preproduction costs on Livent's profit and loss statements until a show opens. Although it is a legitimate accounting method, they say it sends a cloudy signal about the company's finances.
On Livent's books, the costs of any show are amortized for up to five years after opening night, as long as it continues to run. In other words, there is a presumption, financially speaking, that a show will run for five years. This is actually an incentive to keep a money-losing show, like "Kiss of the Spider Woman," running, because once it closes, all remaining costs must be accounted for. Nearly $100 million that Livent has already spent on productions has not yet appeared on its balance sheets, including the $10 million it cost to develop "Ragtime."
This is a significant number for the following reason. In 1996, the last year for which audited figures are available, the company reported net income of about $8.2 million (11 million Canadian dollars). Even assuming that Livent doubled that last year, it has spent far more than it brought in. Though in corporate terms this is not unusual, particularly for young, expanding companies, in theatrical terms it is unheard of.
This is a subject that infuriates Mr. Drabinsky, who vigorously rebuts that Livent is known for aggressive accounting, arguing that the company is, in fact, conservative. The law allows it to amortize preproduction costs over 5 to 10 years, he said; they presume the strictest approach.
"This is clearly a proper accounting policy," he said. "We're not even talking about legitimacy. Accounting is matching revenue and costs on a proper basis. We're very comfortable with our accounting. We know the company continues to grow in cash flow areas and revenue, and our asset strength is significantly enhanced over where it was last year."
In other words, Mr. Drabinsky's argument is that because the company is growing, its revenue is increasing fast enough to cover these expenditures on the amortized schedule. Mr. Drabinsky, who takes a $1.5 million annual salary, will not divulge his private expectations of how long "Ragtime" will run, but the optimism is in the accounting. His assumption is that "Ragtime" and Livent's forthcoming shows will be successful; this is the hubristic gamble, and it has traditional theater producers and investors scratching their heads, particularly if they are aware of Mr. Drabinsky's history.
In Mr. Drabinsky's previous show business incarnation, he founded Cineplex Odeon, the movie theater chain, beginning with an 18-theater multiplex in Toronto in 1979 and building it into an 1,800-screen empire throughout the United States and Canada. But the rapid expansion, financed with long-term borrowing, brought the company perilously close to bankruptcy; in 1986, he took on a partner, MCA, which resisted his expand-on-debt philosophy. After a fierce battle it ousted him in 1989.
Some questions during litigation in the dispute are similar to those raised now. One concerned a Cineplex Odeon net income report that some analysts viewed as misleadingly positive; another, the company's practice of writing off capital improvements in its theaters over a period that some analysts considered too long.
Mr. Drabinsky left Cineplex Odeon in possession of the company's live entertainment division, consisting of one theater, the Pantages, in Toronto, which he had renovated in spectacular style, and the rights to present one production in it, "The Phantom of the Opera." That was the foundation of Livent, which he and his partner, Myron Gottlieb, took public in 1993. Like Cineplex Odeon, it is also pursuing aggressive expansion on the strength of borrowed money.
Last fall's bond offering left the company with $216.3 million of total indebtedness and $141 million of shareholders' equity. In other words, about 60 percent of the company's worth is borrowed. That is high even for a young company, though not necessarily threatening.
"He honestly believes he was something of a victim at Cineplex Odeon, and he has a huge drive to prove that the mistakes there were not his fault," said Christopher Dixon, an entertainment analyst at Paine Webber who says he thinks Livent's future is bright. "He learned a great deal from that, and he has been using those lessons to prove to the investment community and the entertainment community that they shouldn't have counted him out."
On Broadway, Mr. Drabinsky has operated almost entirely outside the hoary tradition of theatrical producers, refusing, for example, to join the League of American Theaters and Producers, which, among other things, negotiates contracts with theater unions, including Actors' Equity. Livent negotiates its own contracts, and Mr. Drabinsky has angered his fellow producers by lavishing high salaries on actors that they must struggle to match.
 
Setting Standards
A Series of Firsts, Like the $75 Seat
It's a measure of his influence on Broadway that his "Show Boat" was the first to charge $75 for a regular orchestra seat. Much grumbling ensued, but most other musicals eventually followed suit. ("Phantom of the Opera" -- on Broadway, not a Livent show -- has jumped to $80.)
Livent might also be said to have opened Broadway's gates to big business. Long guarded by individual producers who enjoyed power over individual shows and by the theater-owning groups led by the Shubert Organization, which controlled many of those producers and shows through real estate, the theater business had its own arcane and anachronistic system for decades. But Livent -- which arrived on Broadway a year before Disney, in 1993 -- and Disney built theaters of their own. And other theater groups have formed joint enterprises so they can pump more resources into productions.
"I pretty much like Garth," said Michael David, whose company, Dodger Productions, has produced many hit musicals on its own, including "Guys and Dolls" and the King and I." In reaction to competition from Livent and Disney, it recently formed a partnership with a Dutch company, Endemol Entertainment, to produce, among other things, "Titanic" and the upcoming "High Society." "But he's an easy target for people. No question."
Mr. Drabinsky's stated goal, to create a theater company based on the model of the old movie studios, where he would control production, distribution and presentation, is clearly in opposition to the theater's current system, in which producers raise money for individual shows and negotiate with theater owners to have them presented.
And because Livent is publicly held, none of its shows, individually, is accountable to investors; rather, the company has to perform well enough overall to persuade investment banks to lend it money and to safeguard the investment of s stockholders. It shares this advantage with Disney; the difference, of course, is that because of Disney's other profitable interests, it could lose everything it has invested in its two shows, "Beauty and the Beast" and "The Lion King" and barely feel it.
Bankers -- enough of them, anyway -- have bought into Mr. Drabinsky's vision. This is partly, they say, because his previous shows have given them faith in "Ragtime" and Livent's future products and partly because Livent has established concrete assets; in addition to the Ford Center in New York, Livent owns big musical houses in Toronto and Vancouver and is building another one in Chicago and a second, smaller house in Toronto.
"If 'Ragtime' works, with two or three companies generating a stable cash flow that buys them time to develop new work, it's great," said Mr. Dixon of Paine Webber. "If it doesn't, they get revenues out of the theaters."
In any case, no other producers have such a network, and of the major theater-owning groups only Jujamcyn Theaters is as active in development of new work. But unlike Livent, Jujamcyn tends to do so in partnerships with other producers, like Pace Theatricals, the country's largest touring-show presenter. Livent also casts its shows, markets them, builds the scenery and creates the costumes in house. Only Disney, which also declined to join the league, also does all this.
Operating on that scale requires substantial cash flow, and the economics remain murky to Mr. Drabinsky's fellow producers.
"What's always been a great difficulty is figuring out how he's doing it financially," said Paul Libin, producing director of Jujamcyn Theaters. "He's got a lot of people envious of him. A guy borrows $125 million in our business? That's unbelievable."
For his part, Mr. Drabinsky is tired of hearing accusations that he is ego-driven, operating on a financial high wire, interested only in grandiose productions.
He points to "Barrymore," a Livent production of Christopher Plummer's one-man show, and "Parade," a modest-size musical that Livent will open in the fall at the Geary Theater in San Francisco, as evidence that his interest is in producing shows "according to the size the show demands."
"This is not a company that can afford to be, ever, irresponsible about how it approaches its expenditures," Mr. Drabinsky said. "Why are we producing in Canada? It's a dollar that's 45 percent cheaper than an American dollar. It's one advantage we have."
 
'Ragtime'
The Measure Of Success
Which brings the story back to "Ragtime." With all of the advertising, all of the attendant hoopla, Mr. Drabinsky more or less promised his investors that "Ragtime" would be a hit in New York. Is it? By many standard measures, yes. "Ragtime" opened previews with advance ticket sales of $15.2 million -- more than four months' worth of full houses -- and in the week after its opening on Jan. 18 sold $4.3 million worth of tickets. Both figures are extraordinary.
Yet since the opening, the price of Livent stock, which jumped more than 16 percent, from $8.62 to $10 a share between the start of previews and the official opening, has fallen back to $8.81. Why should this be? For one thing, the reviews were unusually split. Many critics and other media figures (notably Rosie O'Donnell, on her television talk show) waxed ecstatic. But several reviewers, including Ben Brantley and Vincent Canby of The New York Times, registered sober disappointment. Naggingly, "Ragtime" has not lived up to box office expectations during its Los Angeles run.
Wall Street has noticed it all. The question about "Ragtime" is not whether it will be a hit but whether it will be a gigantic enough hit. On Broadway the show can earn $800,000 to $900,000 in revenues each week, provided it nearly sells out, but that is never a guarantee. For the first two weeks after opening, 10 percent of the available seats were empty, an ominous sign, with net receipts reported at just over $800,000 a week.
Mr. Drabinsky will not divulge his operating costs, but a fair approximation for a show its size is about $500,000 a week. There are many variables, and he declined to discuss the show's budget, but by ordinary Broadway reckoning, it would take about 40 weeks -- at $800,000 in weekly revenue -- to return the $12 million, including advertising, that it cost to put on the show.
By that time, two more "Ragtime" productions will be up and running, adding to Livent's revenue stream; the cost of each of those productions, Mr. Drabinsky said, will be $8 million, and they will have to sell enough tickets to pay for themselves before turning a profit.
But as the acknowledged chief revenue producer for the company (Livent's other shows, obviously, can aid the cause) it has much else to support, namely debt service and the costs of developing new shows.
Potentially, the four productions of "Ragtime" could bring Livent $4 million to $5 million a week in revenue, more than $1 million in profit. But in the theater business, who knows? "No assurance can be given that the company will be able to successfully evaluate the commercial potential of a theatrical production," the prospectus for last fall's bond offering warned, "and the failure to do so could have a material adverse affect on the company's financial condition or results of operations."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Keep Climbing, Paced by Nike Shares
Stock prices rose again, sending the Dow industrials to their sixth consecutive record. While strong earnings at technology companies have supported the rally, merger activity -- and speculation about possible deals -- has also helped.
The most intriguing of the talk has centered on Nike, whose stock has risen 9 percent in two days amid market rumors that the investor Warren E. Buffett is adding to his 2 percent stake in the company. Page D9. 

While Mr. Buffett has been mum on his reported interest in Nike, he has acknowledged an interest in silver. But since the disclosure two weeks ago that his company, Berkshire Hathaway, had been buying huge amounts of silver, the price, which first rose sharply, has receded. So what is the world's foremost precious commodity? Gold, which has been losing luster? Silver? Air Jordans? Market Place. D10.
 
Treasury Prices Slip a Bit
Treasury securities ended lower despite a report showing that producer prices fell in January, as investors worried that another report, showing a robust housing market, suggested that inflation may not have been banished permanently. The 30-year bond's yield rose to 5.83 percent from 5.79. D9.
 
Evidence Seized in Columbia Case
In the first seizure of evidence from the company since July, Federal law enforcement officials served a new search warrant at Columbia/HCA Healthcare's corporate offices in El Paso, participants in the case said. Federal agents obtained a computer hard drive; it was not immediately clear what was on the drive. D2.
 
No Deal for Christie's
Christie's, the London-based auction house, announced that talks with a consortium led by SBC Warburg Dillon Read about a possible takeover had ended. Christie's put itself on the auction block in December. Talk of a possible deal had been sending Christie's stock sharply higher in recent days. E1.
 
Lucent Plans Stock Split
Lucent Technologies, whose shares have more than tripled since its spinoff from AT&T, said that it would split its stock 2 for 1, lifting the shares again. Lucent also formed a $100 million venture capital fund to invest in wireless, semiconductor and software technologies. D6.
 
Indonesia's Enigmatic No. 2
B.J. Habibie, the potential successor to President Suharto of Indonesia, is considered a technological whiz but an economic eccentric, and his views on how to engineer a rebound in the country have struck fear into the hearts of international investors. A3.
 
Computer Publisher Plans Offering
Ziff-Davis, the computer magazine publisher, expects to raise $460 million through an initial public offering of stock in the United States, Ziff's Japanese parent said. D2.
 
Goldman Seeks an Image Change
Goldman, Sachs, which caters largely to big corporations and rich investors, has hired the same ad agency that does work for Burger King, Compaq and U.P.S. to conduct research on its public image. The move could lead to a multimillion-dollar campaign to raise Goldman's profile among working stiffs and the merely well-to-do, markets that the firm is finding harder to ignore. Advertising. D8.
 
Conference on Light-Truck Safety
Federal highway officials said that they would convene a conference of auto makers and safety experts to analyze what happens when cars collide with light trucks. A12.

HEADLINE: Arrest Is Made in the Killing Of a South Amboy Schoolgirl

 BODY:
A man described by the police as a transient was arrested last night in the bludgeoning death of a 15-year-old New Jersey schoolgirl.
Acting on a phone tip, investigators took the man, Thomahl S. Cook, 24, into custody Monday evening on an outstanding trespassing warrant. After two days of interrogation, Mr. Cook, whose last known address was a rooming house in Somerville, N.J., provided some details of the murder, the police said. 
 The schoolgirl, Katrina Suhan, a freshman at South Amboy High School, was found on Sunday evening in a ravine near a wooded area in Old Bridge, N.J., about 3 miles from her home in South Amboy. She had disappeared early Saturday morning while walking home from a roller rink.
At a news conference last night, the Middlesex County Prosecutor, Robert W. Gluck, said that Mr. Cook beat the teen-ager with a 2 by 4, rocks and his fists behind the Galaxy Diner along Route 9, where her body was found.
Mr. Gluck refused to say whether Mr. Cook had confessed to the murder.
According to investigators, Katrina was repeatedly struck in the head and face. Autopsy results showed that she had not been sexually assaulted, but Mr. Gluck said that she may have been fighting off a sexual assault.
"With the bludgeoning, it's hard to determine which wounds may be defensive," Mr. Gluck said.
Mr. Cook has been charged with murder and will be arraigned sometime today at the Middlesex County Courthouse in New Brunswick, said John T. O'Leary, the Mayor of South Amboy.
The authorities said that Mr. Cook was something of a fixture at the Rollermagic Rink. Though he was a man a little too old for the teenagers who spent their weekends at the rink, the authorities said, the youths were friendly with him. Katrina's friends told the police that she had at least an acquaintance with the unemployed laborer. And Mr. Gluck said that Mr. Cook was seen near the skating rink on Friday night.
Mr. Gluck said he could not provide a motive for the crime, or an explanation of how Mr. Cook carried the girl along Route 9, across the Garden State Parkway and into the grassy ravine three miles from the rink without the aid of a car and without being seen.
The authorities are not ruling out the possibility of an accomplice and are also awaiting the results of forensic tests that could place other people at the scene of the crime. Those results are expected in a few weeks.
Mayor O'Leary said that the tip that led to Mr. Cook's arrest was called to the Somerville police on Monday by someone who was familiar with Mr. Cook and his movements. That person's identity is unknown. Mr. Cook was taken on Monday evening to the Middlesex County Adult Correction Center in New Brunswick, where he is still being held.
"We are outraged that someone could come into our community and pluck a 15-year-old girl off the street and murder her," Mr. O'Leary said last night. "We're not accustomed to that, to living in fear, and I'm not entirely sure that we are ever going to get over this."
The arrest brought some sense of relief to local people who describe their community, located just south of Staten Island across the Raritan River, as a calm and uneventful place where people have come to live to escape big city crime, and the nagging fear that goes with it.
Still, one neighbor said, such horrors are probably never forgotten. "Nothing like this ever happens around here," said Stephen Sciallo, who lives in the same apartment complex as the Suhans. "Everybody is worried for their kids."

HEADLINE: Hot Issue in Northern New Mexico: Fine Print of an 1848 Treaty

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TRUCHAS, N. M.

 BODY:
In a roadside shop filled with weavings and Spanish religious art, tourists browsed unattended recently as the shopkeeper and his friends excitedly talked in a back room about an obscure historical document.
"It's our Bible," Luis H. Sandoval, a retired teacher, said as he thumbed through a copy of the peace treaty signed 150 years ago between Mexico and the United States. "One day, that treaty will allow us to get our land grants studied, to have justice served to our people." 
 On the national level, the Feb. 2 anniversary of the signing of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo passed virtually without notice. Although the treaty allowed the creation of the American Southwest, there were no commemorative stamps and few official speeches.
Facing the possibility of an attack on Iraq, few Americans looked backward to the nation's first war of territorial expansion. The treaty expanded American territory by one-third, adding all or parts of Arizona, California, Colorado, Kansas, New Mexico, Nevada, Oklahoma, Texas, Utah and Wyoming.
Official silence over the treaty anniversary stemmed in part from diplomatic reluctance to offend Mexico, which is now the United States's third-largest trading partner. Many Mexican-Americans in the United States quietly resent a document that cut their ancestral nation in half after the 18-month-long Mexican War.
But here, the 150-year-old treaty is as hot a topic as on Feb. 23, 1848, the day President James Knox Polk sent it to the Senate for ratification. People in this community and others across the region fervently support a Republican-sponsored bill to create a Presidential commission to review claims by thousands of old Hispanic families who say their lands were stolen by corrupt lawyers and local officials in violation of the 1848 treaty.
Adding urgency to action on the measure, the dry, pine-covered hills around here are seeing a low-level guerrilla warfare against the United States Forest Service, owner of much of the disputed land. In recent anonymous actions against the Forest Service, shots have been fired at workers, an office and a radio tower have been bombed and a government truck and barn have been burned.
On a peaceful level, music, dance, poetry, the unveiling of a mural and a series of educational seminars marking the treaty anniversary are to be capped this spring with the public display in Santa Fe, 40 miles south of here, of pages from the original treaty. In Albuquerque, Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, recently posed with beaming Hispanic leaders in front of poster-size replicas of treaty pages.
The treaty mania revolves around land, votes and regional identity. Hispanic residents hope to use the document to wrest from the Forest Service as much as 1.5 million acres that they say were granted to their ancestors, largely by Spain, in the 18th century.
Republicans hope to use the land- grant issue to break a half century of Democratic political control of Northern New Mexico. Already the bill, the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 1997, is creating strange political bedfellows. At the Gingrich news conference, Roberto Mondragon, a longtime Democrat and member of the state's Green Party, gave hearty abrazos to the Speaker and to the bill's sponsor, Representative Bill Redmond, this district's new Republican Congressmen.
"There is an old Spanish proverb: 'If you love me, show me you love me -- don't just tell me,' " Mr. Mondragon said.
Hispanic residents here argue that the treaty, with its clauses stipulating respect for Spanish and Mexican land grants, is a powerful legal lever for winning back lands usurped after the Civil War by "the Santa Fe Ring," a corrupt alliance of American lawyers, judges and territorial governors who manipulated a court system alien to Spanish-speaking farmers. Much of this land, after heavy use by timber and cattle companies, ended up in the hands of the Forest Service in the 1920's and 1930's.
"The United States Government likes to go by paper, crossing the 't's and dotting the 'i's," said Mr. Sandoval, the retired teacher who is a grant claimant. "Well, let's honor the treaty."
He accused American surveyors of illegally lopping off about one-third of the 22,000 acres granted to Truchas families by Spain in 1754. The land is now part of a national forest, he said.
Here and across Northern New Mexico, Hispanic families are seeking return of the land for communal use by descendants of the settler families.
Descendants of Spanish colonists do not share the overall resentment of the treaty routinely expressed by Mexicans and Mexican-Americans.
In this region's four centuries of European settlement, Mexican rule was a brief interlude -- 25 years sandwiched between 223 years of Spanish rule and 152 years of American rule. Numbering in the hundreds of thousands, the clannish descendants of Spanish settlers seldom socialize with recent Mexican immigrants. In Santa Fe, Spain's red and gold colors are more commonly seen than Mexico's green, white and red bunting.
Although the region has some of the poorest counties in the United States, residents here seem content to be on the wealthy side of the border. Indeed, 150 years of American rule in the Southwest has brought such economic success that the Immigration and Naturalization Service now devotes half of its 12,400 agents to preventing illegal immigration from Mexico.
"People in Northern New Mexico are very patriotic Americans," said David Roybal, who organized seminars to educate people on the treaty. "When you find discontent with the treaty, it's when parts relating to the land grants were broken."
Although the Forest Service officially follows a policy of "co-managing" public lands with local Hispanic communities, many rural Hispanic residents say they increasingly feel harassed by Federal employees who demand permits and impose fines for hunting, fishing, swimming, grazing cattle and cutting timber.
"Before, the man in the green truck used to be from the community," David Cordova, a weaver here, said of Forest Service employees. "Now, it is someone who just transferred here from Seattle."
Judging by the dozens of land- grant leaders who carried petitions to Mr. Gingrich's news conference, the bill enjoys wide support. Under the bill, a five-member review commission would study land claims and then forward a report to the President and Congress with recommendations for action. The commission would be modeled after the Indian Land Claims Commission, which paid about $2 billion to Indians who said their lands had been seized in violation of treaties between tribes and the United States. The claimants were paid over a 30-year period ending in 1978.
"This is really an economic development issue," said Michael Quintana, an aide to Representative Redmond. "These people have remained in poverty because their land was taken away from them."
But some environmentalists see the revived land-grant movement as a threat to public lands. The American public would lose hiking, hunting and camping access to large areas, asserts Sam Hitt, president of Forest Guardians, an environmental group.
"A commission would be the first step on a slippery slope toward the privatization of a lot of Northern New Mexico," said Mr. Hitt, who is running in November for state land commissioner on the Green ticket.
At present, he said, American taxpayers subsidize National Forest lands, paying for maintenance of fences, hiking trails, camp sites and for management plans that limit grazing and logging. Hispanic communities would squeeze the most dollars out of their communal lands, leading to rapid degradation, he said.
"It's a sacred text around here," Mr. Hitt lamented of the treaty. "It's insignificant to most Americans. But, in Northern New Mexico, it's a daily topic of conversation."

HEADLINE: Former New York Official To Lead Philadelphia Police

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Reacting to criticism that Philadelphia's police force is ineffective, sometimes corrupt and in dire need of new blood, Mayor Edward G. Rendell reached outside the city today and hired a new police commissioner, John F. Timoney, former first deputy commissioner in New York.
Mr. Timoney, who was second in command on the New York force in 1995 and 1996 and helped carry out many of the street patrol programs and other efforts credited with sharply reducing that city's crime rates, will succeed Richard Neal. 
 Mr. Neal resigned last week to become a private security consultant after struggling for five years to improve the performance of a 7,000-officer force that has been troubled over the years by numerous accusations of brutality, graft and, particularly this year, ineptitude.
The latest accusations of ineptitude, still heard almost daily, stem from widespread dissatisfaction in the city with the police department's limited success in reducing crime rates, particularly the murder rate. Tha murder rate has been dropping sharply in most other major cities, especially New York, and Philadelphia compared unfavorably.
The accusations also come from Philadelphia residents who contend that the police department has been making only a half-hearted effort to rid the city of such everyday nuisances as panhandlers, graffiti and, more seriously, purse-snatchers and petty thieves.
So vocal and widespread has the complaining been that it was threatening to blemish the record of a Mayor whose administration has otherwise been mostly praised for good management of a major American city.
In announcing the appointment of Mr. Timoney to Philadelphia's top police job, which pays $113,000, Mayor Rendell called him "perhaps the best available candidate in the nation to lead the police department here and to reclaim the city's rightful reputation as the best police department in the nation."
"When you review Commissioner Timoney's record," the Mayor continued, "it is clear that he is well-versed in every aspect of police operations and, indeed, that he is a dynamic commander."
Accepting the appointment effective March 9, Mr. Timoney promised results. "I guarantee you that," he said, adding that he would be a "hands-on" commissioner and that Philadelphia police officers and residents would see him on the street day and night, walking the beat with officers and riding with them in their patrol cars.
"I think the next 22 months are going to be a lot of fun," Mr. Timoney said, alluding to the amount of time Mayor Rendell has left to serve in his second and final term.
Mr. Timoney, 49, spent 29 years with the New York Police Department and as first deputy commissioner was instrumental in redeploying its street patrols around the city to increase pressure on criminals, particularly drug dealers and others who victimize homeowners, shopkeepers and other ordinary citizens. That redeployment, police experts say, was a major factor in the strikingly sharp decline in the city's crime rate in recent years.
Mr. Timoney resigned in 1996 when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani chose Fire Commissioner Howard Safir to replace, William J. Bratton, as the Police Commissioner of New York City. Mr. Bratton subsequently became a part-time police adviser to Mayor Rendell and is said by City Hall aides to have been instrumental in getting his former top aide hired.
Mayor Rendell had high praise today for Mr. Neal, a 57-year-old veteran of 36 years on the Philadelphia force who has been hired as a security consultant by Drexel University and the Penn's Landing Corporation, a Philadelphia development group.
Mayor Rendell, who has given some thought to running for Governor and who has repeatedly denied finding Mr. Neal another job to speed his departure and avoid further criticism of the city government, said the Police Commissioner had done good work in carrying out a "comprehensive series of reform and deployment initiatives."
During Mr. Neal's tenure as the city's top police officer, the city has been sorely embarrassed by a scandal involving physical abuse and money shake-downs by some officers -- none of it was ever linked to the commissioner -- and half a dozens officers were eventually convicted and some sent to prison.
The city has never been classified as one of America's more dangerous big cities. But that was not the issue with Mr. Neal's critics, some of whom have an eye on Mayor Rendell's job. What they kept pointing out was that at a time when many major cities were enjoying a steady decrease in crime, in part because of the healthy national economy but also because of innovative and aggressive policing, Philadelphia was a laggard in many areas, with its murder rate especially stubborn.
The critics said the force was a laggard in adopting modern technology, particularly computers. They said the force was poorly trained and equipped. And, most serious of all, they warned that unless the city charter was changed to permit the Police Commissioner to appoint and dismiss all top department managers, the force would remain trapped in a bureaucratic morass.
The Police Commissioner can now appoint and dismiss only his two deputies. The rest of the force is protected by civil service regulations that are often restrictive.
Mayor Rendell, who until recently resisted departmental changes and deflected criticism of the police department, now says he favors a ballot referendum to change the city charter and give the Police Commissioner far broader powers.
Despite the praise and expectations for Mr. Timoney, Richard Costello, the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Fraternal Order of Police, the police union, expressed concern that the morale of the force might be hurt by the choice of an outsider.
"We're disappointed that he wasn't from our ranks," Mr. Costello said.
Michael Nutter, a member of the City Council, said he was concerned that the Mayor did not consult with the Council before making the appointment, given the current mood in the city about the Police Department's performance.
"He should have sought our input for something this big, even though he technically didn't have to," Mr. Nutter said. "Certainly Timoney is facing a big, serious challenge, coming from the outside as he is. The troubles in this Police Department run deep and go way back, for decades."
In the years shortly after World War II, the Philadelphia Police Department was considered one of the most innovative and progressive in the country. It was among the first to aggressively recruit black officers and its city charter was written so as to limit political interference in its day to day management by putting most officers under civil service protection.
Then Frank L. Rizzo, first as Police Commissioner from 1967 to 1971 and as Mayor from 1972 to 1980, advocated a hard line against crime. The eventual result was brutality. Then came incidents of ineptitude, culminating with a police standoff with the radical group Move in which 62 row houses were ignited and 11 people were killed in a black working-class neighborhood in 1985.
In the 1990's six officers were convicted of brutality and graft. During this decade, there were also incidents in which detectives were accused of beating confessions out of suspects, undercover officers were discovered framing innocent people, vice squad members were caught taking payoffs from prostitutes and gamblers, narcotics officers became drug addicts themselves and demanded bribes from dealers and officers turned their dogs loose on people with little or no provocation.
Many other cities have had similar problems, though few have endured the police scandals that have taken place in Philadelphia.
"This is a city in which the culture of policing is often out of whack," said James Fyfe, a former New York police officer who teaches criminology at Temple University here. "It's the only city I've ever been in where even the white people don't like cops. That's a sad commentary. The good news is that now things are at the point where they can do something about it -- if they will."

Mexico Limits Chiapas Travel
The Mexican Government is clamping down on foreigners in the troubled State of Chiapas who show support for the Zapatista guerrillas or monitor events in Indian regions where the rebel movement is active. In recent days, Mexican immigration authorities have ended a longstanding tolerance for foreigners who travel to Chiapas with tourist visas and then participate in Zapatista meetings or marches, or visit villages where the tension between rebel and pro-Government factions is active. Israeli Officials to Visit Jordan
Three top Israeli officials will soon visit King Hussein of Jordan in an effort to repair ties after a report this week on the botched Israeli assassination of a Hamas leader last year in Amman, Israeli public radio reported. The officials are Infrastructure Minister Ariel Sharon, Internal Security Minister Avigdor Kahalani, and Industry and Trade Minister Natan Sharansky. (Agence France-Presse)
 
Police Reforms in Belgium
Belgium announced sweeping changes in its police forces in response to public outrage over a child sex and murder scandal. After a special Cabinet meeting, Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene said that a unified national police force would be created, combining paramilitary gendarmerie and the judicial police. Blaming a rivalry between the forces, two reports harshly criticized them for bungling the hunt for the abductors of four girls found dead in 1996. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Strong Sales in U.S. Lift Honda Earnings

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Despite the economic slowdown throughout Asia, the Honda Motor Company posted a small rise in third-quarter profits as a result of relatively strong car sales in the United States and Europe. Profits for Honda rose 5.3 percent, to 65.2 billion yen ($515 million), in the three months that ended Dec. 31. 
 Honda, Japan's third-largest auto maker, said revenue rose 16.6 percent, to 1.6 trillion yen. Strong sales of its CR-V sport utility vehicle in the United States and Europe fueled the growth, Honda said. Car sales in Japan have slowed since last April, when the Government raised the national sales tax to 5 percent from 3 percent. Honda said it sold 601,000 automobiles in the quarter, up 7.7 percent from 1996.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK STATE;
Delay in State Ruling On a Utility's Rates

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
Niagara Mohawk will have to wait at least a few more days before finding out whether state regulators will approve its plan to revamp its rates.
Yesterday, the State Public Service Commission delayed action on the utility's Power Choice proposal, citing several unresolved issues. It is the second time this month that the commission has put off a decision on the two-year-old plan. 
 The Power Choice plan would reduce rates for large industrial and commercial customers up to 25 percent, which proponents say will in turn stimulate the economy throughout the utility's upstate New York service territory.
Residential and small commercial customers would get rate decreases of less than 3.5 percent, but critics say the bills of almost half the utility's customers would rise because of a planned "customer charge."
Niagra Mohawk has threatened to file for bankruptcy protection if Power Choice is not approved by the commission.
Niagara Mohawk provides gas and electricity to two million customers in upstate New York. The plan to revamp the rates will open competition and allow Niagara Mohawk customers to buy electricity from cheaper sources. In return, Niagara Mohawk would be allowed to branch out into other lucrative business ventures.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Data Reaffirm Good News On Economy

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Reinforcing evidence of a robust economy and nearly nonexistent inflation, the Government reported yesterday that prices paid by manufacturers posted the biggest decline in nearly four years last month while housing construction remained vibrant.
The Labor Department's Producer Price Index, which measures the cost of raw materials and semifinished goods before they reach the consumer, fell seven-tenths of 1 percent last month. 
 A second report, by the Commerce Department, showed construction of new homes and apartments fell slightly in January from December, but the annual rate of construction was still healthy at 1.53 million units.
A 3.7 percent drop in energy prices, the largest since they fell 5 percent in February 1991 with the conclusion of the Persian Gulf war, was responsible for much of the overall drop in producer prices. Food prices also declined, by four-tenths of 1 percent. Even omitting these often volatile components, prices were lower, albeit much more modestly.
And since indexes measuring prices at the crude and intermediate stages of production also declined, analysts said there were few reasons to anticipate a sudden surge in inflation.
In January, the Producer Price Index, excluding food and energy, declined by one-tenth of 1 percent. For the 12 months ending in January, this core rate declined one-tenth of 1 percent as well.
"This is more of the same good news," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Nationsbank Montgomery Securities. "Not only is current inflation on a year-over-year basis basically stable, but the pipeline for inflation suggests there are no mounting pressures."
John M. Galvin, assistant commissioner for industrial prices at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which compiles the producer price data, said that "these are very different numbers we are reporting now than a couple of years ago, that is for sure."
Most analysts had predicted the general trends of the producer price and housing reports. The actual data changed no opinions about the course of monetary policy: most analysts continue to say the Federal Reserve Board will probably leave interest rates unchanged, perhaps for much of the year.
The initial reaction in financial markets was positive, as stocks and bonds rose. As the day progressed, prices came off their peaks. Nevertheless, propelled by a late surge, the Dow Jones industrial average registered its sixth straight record high.
Although the housing starts figures were somewhat weaker in January, the Commerce Department revised the December figures sharply higher. Moreover, the January number represents the fifth straight month that housing starts have run at an annual rate exceeding 1.5 million, regarded as vigorous growth.
"If this is a leading indicator of a downturn, and housing often is, we are not seeing it yet," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
Due to unusually mild weather, housing activity was by far the busiest in the Northeast last month, where starts rose by more than 18 percent. They declined in every other region. However, Mr. Fine and other analysts cautioned against reading too much into the housing figures because winter construction rates can be deceptive.
Economists expect growth to slow as the year progresses and for inflation to remain subdued, largely as a result of the Asian financial crisis. However, the ripple effects of that crisis were not terribly evident in January's producer price figures.
"Falling demand in Asia is one of the things keeping energy prices soft, but it is only one factor," Mr. Galvin from the Bureau of Labor Statistics said. "We made an effort to look for an Asian effect, but we didn't see any real change in our indexes from four to six months ago."
Mr. Galvin said he did learn of anecdotal evidence about steep declines in the export prices of a few relatively esoteric items -- cattle hides and metals like steel scrap -- to the four Asian nations at the epicenter of the crisis. "Suggested prices are really plunging for these commodities, which means that demand is falling," he said.
Such falling demand is expected to result in a widening trade deficit in the United States, which can hurt the economy as exporters reduce production and cut jobs. Still, economists said the expected drag from a bigger trade deficit was likely to be at least partly offset by other helpful consequences of the Asia crisis such as falling interest rates, which would further stimulate demand for housing and household goods.
"All of this means the composition of economic growth will change," Mr. Levy said. "But financial shock absorbers here should work to mitigate the impact of Asia on the American economy."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 20, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Labor Department's report on producer prices in January referred incorrectly to the report's most widely followed index. It measures the prices that manufacturers, farmers and other producers pay for finished goods, not the cost of raw materials and semifinished goods. The index fell seven-tenths of 1 percent last month.

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
The Cars Were Big and Elvis Was Young

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
The year 1950 was a landmark on the march to the millennium. Although halfway marks have limited value for doomsayers, and no one had reason yet to predict that the failure of computer clocks would bring about the fall of civilization, half a century was used up, and experience suggested that the second half was likely to bring some changes. As, in fact, it did.
The beginning of the 50's promised happiness and togetherness for Dick and Jane, their picket fence and the Ford in their future. The war was over and prosperity had already bestowed fedoras and white gloves and a carefully groomed aura of calm security. Harry S. Truman was followed by eight years of Dwight D. Eisenhower, who was rumored to have died early in his term without there being any visible change in his style of governing. 
 There were tremors nonetheless. In 1949, the Soviets exploded an atomic bomb. In 1950, the Korean War began, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy began his war against Communists in America and Charles Schulz introduced "Peanuts," a comic strip dedicated, however sweetly, to insecurity and anxiety. A really good psychic would have predicted that bomb shelters and rock-and-roll could not be far behind.
"Flashback: The Fifties," at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery on the Upper East Side, crowds together 70 black-and-white photographs from that decade, some telling, some amusing, some virtually unknown, almost all American. They make the decade look almost as good as it wished to -- no Korea, no McCarthy, no poverty -- and merely drop a couple of pointed hints that not everything was exactly as it seemed. The darkest hint is Harold Edgerton's photograph of the first microseconds of an atomic bomb explosion, taken at one-100,000,000th of a second, when the cloud was still a great irregular ball pockmarked with darker disks.
John Chancellor once wrote about the 50's that "if you weren't looking for work, black or getting shot at in Korea, it was a very nice time." The car ruled the world, there were two in every garage, and they became make-out parlors with a ticket to the drive-in movie. Mickey Pallas photographed the ur-family of suburbia -- mother, father, son and daughter -- posing in their big Buick convertible before their ranch house and range garage. Louis Faurer framed three black cars with aggressive tailfins in a lightless parking garage where chrome outlines gleamed like private fortunes.
For the most part, celebrities -- lots of them show up here -- were still wholesome and well behaved. During a campaign ride in an open convertible, photographed by Carl Mydans, Jacqueline Kennedy listened avidly while her husband, the Senator, explained something to her and fans cheered. Richard M. Nixon jumped and smiled, as stiff as rigor mortis, for Philippe Halsman's camera. The decade tried hard to keep its image up to snuff, with white polish on its saddle shoes and crab-grass-killer on the lawn.
The gallery flashes back to Elizabeth Taylor's very first wedding (how young she was, how beautiful, how embellished with tulle furbelows), to Hula-Hoops, teen-agers crowding into telephone booths, drive-in restaurants and the crushing elegance of high fashion (which shows up here in some truly classic images). The decade worked hard at conformity: Elliott Erwitt photographed young couples seated at tables in Bermuda, every man absorbed in the identical action of lighting a cigarette for his date.
The near absence of controversy in "Flashback" has some relevance to the state of photography at the time. The Photo League, organized by committed photographers in the 30's to address the social issues of the day, had come under suspicion of being leftist, which it was, and Communist, which a couple of members probably were. Political pressure finally drove the league to disband in 1951, whereupon a pall settled over street photography and the photography of causes.
As American artists, writers and filmmakers fearfully withdrew into abstraction, silence or politically neutral cheeriness, photographers did, too. The burning issues were turned over to the big magazines and the newspapers, which had plenty to do. A trace of their task shows up here in photographs like Arthur Rickerby's of rowdy teen-age white boys at a school in Tennessee, some making obscene gestures, and a black girl, impeccably neat, sitting alone and apart.
A lot of the other material is journalistic in one way or another, not inappropriately, as art photography was still a limited field with a specialized audience. Journalists proved that the rituals of life and love repeat themselves relentlessly in every decade. In George Zimbel's photograph of an Irish dance hall in the Bronx, a lone young man with tousled hair and loosened tie wears an expectant smile, knowing something good will come his way, while at the side five young women stand around morosely, hoping someone will ask them to dance.
Despite Alfred C. Kinsey's best-selling reports, sex was still officially bottled up, under pressure, ready to burst out. Men found a raunchy pleasure or two at the burlesque, which television would soon drive out of business. Garry Winogrand snapped the famous stripper Lili St. Cyr at an uncommonly domestic moment as she knitted pasties backstage, working away in a darkness that almost covered her and a tiny bra that almost did not.
But sex, exhibitionism and an open sense of enjoyment were edging into the mainstream. Not one but three pictures of Marilyn Monroe with her dress blowing up on the subway grating are in this show. Photographers milled about in the background, eager to record a possible sighting of Marilyn's panties for the public's delectation. Then there was Elvis, most memorably here in Alfred Wertheimer's "Kiss," where the young heartthrob laughingly touches tongues with a young woman.
Against the odds, some photographers observed the decade's undertones. The very darkness of certain photographs by Mr. Faurer, Mr. Zimbel, Robert Frank, William Klein and Louis Stettner seems to mirror a mood more felt than openly expressed. Introspection was becoming a photographic approach as well as a subject: Mr. Zimbel observed a well-dressed woman sullenly drinking by herself at a bar, and Mr. Stettner peered through the window of a parked train at a sailor lost in the pensive sadness of a man with no company but his thoughts.
In the decade of togetherness, there were islands of isolation. A very young Diane Arbus portrayed a young woman hopelessly alone on the boardwalk where people gather. Ida Wyman snapped a man in an empty cafe standing by the jukebox in search of some response.
While many Americans experienced their first post-Depression sense of trust in an enticing economic future and splurged with credit cards, that exciting new way to spend, some writers and photographers looked askance at society and materialism. Mr. Frank breached the general rule of contentment with a picture of couples at a formal reception trapped in their cummerbunds and fur capes and stolid expectations. Mr. Klein went him one better, blurring the moneyed types at the Waldorf past recognition, as if to say that their pleasures were indistinct and fleeting and not even photography could preserve them.
These photographers also broke the academic rules of photography, throwing clarity, sharp focus and balanced composition out the window. The lid was about to blow on many of the old social verities. Photography, which recorded the established patterns, would record their breakdown too, and in the 50's it was already devising expressive means to suit new circumstances.
"Flashback: The Fifties" remains at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery, 52 East 76th Street, Manhattan, through March 7.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Louis Stettner's "Penn Station, N.Y." found dark undertones in the 50's. (Bonni Benrubi Gallery, New York City)
