HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
She Smolders, He Fumes: Gee, It's Hot

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
The opening scenes of Volker Schlondorff's juicy film noir, "Palmetto," evoke semitropical rot in southern Florida with such a deliriously sensual appreciation of evil that when the movie eventually runs amok, you can almost forgive it for becoming a shrill, comic self-parody.
The film, adapted from a novel by James Hadley Chase, aspires to out-noir every other film noir that has been lumped under that popular term, including "The Big Sleep" (which it resembles), in plot trickery and steaminess. Like "The Big Sleep," "Palmetto" finally gets lost in a haze of increasingly farfetched plot complications. But unlike its forerunner, it also amps up the horror to such a degree that by the time a character finds himself strung up and dangled over a vat of acid, you will be more inclined to giggle than to hold your breath. 
 At least "Palmetto" should lay to rest any complaints that they don't make screen vamps like they used to. When Elisabeth Shue, wearing a too-tight dress, sidles into the telephone booth of a seedy south Florida bar and ostentatiously "loses" a cash-stuffed purse, the screen begins to sizzle. From her spectacular arrival to a final glimpse that suggests Gloria Swanson's mad descent down a staircase in "Sunset Boulevard," Ms. Shue hams it fabulously, smirking and shimmying and casting tough come-hither looks as scorching as hot coals.
Her character, Rhea Malroux, is the greedy, bored, hot-blooded wife of a wealthy but frail businessman three decades her senior. With her equally seductive stepdaughter, Odette (Chloe Sevigny), she has hatched a fake kidnapping scheme to wrest a quick half-million dollars from the old miser. To help carry it out, she propositions Harry Barber (Woody Harrelson), a bitter unemployed ex-newspaper reporter who has just returned to town. Harry, whose journalism career skidded to a halt after his expose of an extortion scheme involving the local power brokers was blocked from publication, has plenty of reason to fume. His efforts to expose corruption landed him in jail, where he served for two wasted years before his conviction was overturned.
Returning to the scene of the crimes, a Florida seaside town called Palmetto, Harry has resumed his domestic partnership with Nina (Gina Gershon), a sculptor whose career has begun to take off. Once he is seduced into going along with Rhea's scheme (for which he is promised a 10 percent commission), everything that could conceivably go wrong does.
When "Palmetto" is following its main characters' criminal and erotic shenanigans, it is as deliciously over-ripe as you could hope for a film noir set in an area whose sultry climate, real-estate boom and spiritual torpor outclass Los Angeles in glamorous decay. Filled with steamy tropical downpours, shots of dripping palm leaves and glistening cockroaches, the movie makes the most of the location, and after a while you feel the heat and humidity begin to settle over you.
If "Palmetto" is a dramatic leap into pop moviemaking for the director of "The Tin Drum" and "The Handmaid's Tale," it is also a change of pace for Mr. Harrelson. Instead of his usual hyperkinetic wild man, he plays a glowering passive-aggressive whiner. As you sense the character chewing on his own accumulated resentment, Mr. Harrelson makes you understand why Harry, against his better judgment, allows himself to be used by unscrupulous women. Ms. Shue is nearly matched in sinister glamour by Ms. Sevigny, who creates a disturbing portrait of selfish, precociously sophisticated depravity.
Not all the casting is so fortuitous. Ms. Gershon, wasted in the role of Nina, has little to do for most of the film except ask Harry what's bothering him, and when dragged into the action late in the film, she seems befuddled. Michael Rapaport, in a departure from the hearty streetwise roles he usually plays, is badly miscast in the crucial but underdeveloped part of Rhea's lover and co-conspirator, Donnelly. The character's lack of focus throws the movie off balance and makes the story hard to follow.
"Palmetto" begins to go seriously haywire when Harry accepts a job as the police press spokesman for the very investigation that will soon implicate him. It may be a nifty plot device, but it's one too many twists in a story that takes so many hairpin turns it begins to reel from its own desperate desire to be surprising.
"Palmetto" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes violence, strong language, sexual situations and nudity.
 
PALMETTO
 
Directed by Volker Schlondorff; written by E. HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
From Shetl to Fiesta, A Painter's Wanderings

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
It's often better to be a big frog in a small puddle, and so it was for the painter Lasar Segall (1891-1957). Born in the Jewish quarter of Vilnius, Lithuania, he left for Germany at 15, developed an Expressionist style and later migrated to Sao Paulo, Brazil, where he spent the rest of his life. He was a leading light in the development of modern Brazilian art, and he is commemorated by a Lasar Segall museum in Sao Paulo. But as a painter he was uneven and derivative.
The evidence is on view in his first major United States retrospective, at the Jewish Museum. Organized by the David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art at the University of Chicago and the Lasar Segall museum, the show contains a vast 200 paintings, watercolors, drawings and prints, most never exhibited in New York. They range from early works in an Expressionist mode to later Holocaust themes to the vividly stylized evocations of Brazilian life and landscape that are his most interesting legacy. 
 Segall's unusual odyssey is part of his claim to fame. The son of a Torah scribe who occasionally allowed the boy to illuminate the capital letters of manuscripts, he made a surprising leap -- at a tender age -- from his provincial Orthodox community to the worldlier art milieus of Berlin and Dresden. Vilnius, an old center of Jewish culture swept by the winds of Russian revolutionary fervor and anti-Semitism, was obviously a place to leave.
In art schools in the two German cities, he found filtered-down Impressionism the prevailing mode, where his inclination was Expressionism. But teachers in Dresden supported his more emotional style, well suited to his subject, the rigors of shtetl life. The early part of this show is rife with scenes of his hometown. "Vilnius and I" (1910), a strong, Munch-like lithograph in sharply contrasting black and white, shows the artist with furrowed brow, spiffy in a European suit, a backdrop of huddled houses behind him. Munch's influence is also apparent in Segall's 1909 lithograph "Pain," a graphic close-up of a woman's head thrown back, mouth open, as she clutches at her chest.
More Segall's own is "After the Pogrom," a 1912 lithograph depicting a sprawl of bodies on the ground surrounded by tall, crazily angled walls of buildings that lean oppressively in on them. He was apparently the first Jewish artist to depict the organized massacres known as pogroms. But a more avant-garde venture of this period, "Russian Village" (1912), an ungainly meld of Cubism, Futurism and Expressionism with triangular planes, distorted figures and cliche colors, is singularly unimpressive.
In Dresden, Segall gravitated to vanguard artists and honed his Expressionist style. He helped found the Dresden Secession group, and his circle of friends included the painters Lyonel Feininger and Kandinsky, the critic and historian Will Grohmann and the dancer Mary Wigman. He maintained his Russian Jewish identity, but a new emotional urgency gripped him, the plight of local workers and the poor. One of the better works of this period is "Self Portrait II" (1919), a powerful,brooding head of the artist done in Cubist style in ruddy shades of brown.
Another is "Interior of Poor People II" of 1921, a scene of muted browns and milder Expressionist distortion, that shows four melancholic occupants of a room. One, wearing a fedora, looks like Segall. As an evocation of poverty, however, it is not very convincing. The room seems more posh than poor, what with a handsome painting on the wall and decorative objects on a table. "Eternal Wanderers," a 1919 tableau of troubled figures in a cliched but more integrated Cubist-Expressionist style, was among the paintings later confiscated by the Nazis from the Dresden City Art Museum. It was exhibited in the infamous "Degenerate Art" show of 1937 in Munich.
In 1913, Segall had made a successful yearlong trip to Brazil, where he visited siblings and arranged a couple of one-man shows. A decade later, affected by the political unrest, inflation and open anti-Semitism of life in the Weimar Republic, he decided to abandon the career he had established there and emigrate to Brazil.
A thoroughly urban European, Segall was drawn to the primitive and the exotic that Brazil embodied, its lush landscapes, brilliant colors and rich folk traditions. Besides, Sao Paulo was beginning to develop a modern art scene, and his sister, married to an influential businessman, made sure that he was properly introduced. He exhibited almost immediately after his arrival in 1924, and became a Brazilian citizen three years later.
Segall and Brazil were a happy match. His early paintings of Brazilian themes, recording his impressions of the country in a new and lighter vein, are certainly among his best works. He painted black people, coffee and banana plantations, prostitutes of the Mangue district of the city, religious rituals and fiestas. One of his most impressive compositions from this period is "Red Hill" (1926), a highly stylized rendition of a black mother and child looming large against a stagey backdrop of houses, imperial palms and curvaceous clouds. For it, he appropriated and reworked the triangular composition traditional to Brazilian paintings of the Madonna.
Even his slighter vignettes have a catchy narrative or rhythmic vigor to them. A 1929 drypoint etching, "Two Sailors with Companions," appeals with its deliberately klutzy rendition of sailors ill at ease with their restless women. A sharp woodcut of a black man's head and another of black people dancing by moonlight show Segall well in tune with the different beat of Brazilian life..
During the turmoil in Europe of the 1930's and 40's, Segall often commented on the plight of Jews and other victims. In 1937, he produced the prophetic "Pogrom," a well-known painting that depicts a tumble of massacred bodies lying in a field, but other works, like the notebook "Visions of War" (1940-43), with its vignettes of herded prisoners and skeletal figures, are too sketchy and pallid to be convincing.
As Segall aged, his Brazilian work seems to have softened. He did sensuous landscapes of the Brazilian countryside, likening mountains to curves of the body, and he painted benign nature studies, like "Cattle in Forest" (1939), a scene of cows contentedly browsing in a glade of trees, notable for its mix of warm, earthy colors with a muted Expressionist palette. Trees, in fact, as symbols of survival, became an obsessive motif of his later work. Eventually he began to strip them down to bare essentials, and the 1954 "Forest with Glimpses of Sky," a dense lineup of tall trunks, is virtually an abstraction of color and light.
But overall, this crowded retrospective is too large and unselective. It reveals as many of Segall's weaknesses as his strengths.
"Still More Distant Journeys: The Artistic Emigrations of Lasar Segall" is at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, through May 10.

COUNTRY: BRAZIL (97%); LITHUANIA (93%); GERMANY (90%); UNITED STATES (87%); 

STATE: ILLINOIS, USA (87%); NEW YORK, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Observer;
Not the Wine, Stupid

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
Terrible, terrible news!
Rich yuppies are lapping up all the great wines. No price is too steep for a Wall Streeter when his palate craves vinous delight. A restaurant wine bill can run to thousands of dollars when these conspicuous consumers are in the bibulous vein. 
 I have it from The New York Times. I had been searching the paper with prurient eye, seeking Interngate gossip, and I was looking on the bright side, as I always do. "Son," somebody told me back in Nineteen-aught-seven, "always look on the bright side, especially when there isn't any."
Well, there was plenty of bright side to Interngate. First of all, nobody was calling it "Interngate."
Second, it was going to be a good long time before we would again have to listen to politicians run on about "family values." The President's rising popularity had made it clear that most Americans thought "family values" was an issue strictly for saps.
This rosy frame of mind was shattered by the headline at the bottom of Page One: "After Vintage Year, Wall St. Orders the Really Good Stuff."
What followed was as bad as the news can be if you honed your palate on Gallo's jug red before treating it to Romanee-Conti and Leoville-Las-Cases.
These last two have been unaffordable to this complainant for several years, but, being determined to look on the bright side, I have been waiting for a worldwide depression that would bring their prices back down to sensible levels.
With Wall Street now guzzling it in tank-car lots, we can forget about ever tasting such wines again.
The full horror of the situation was encapsulated in two sentences by a wine-wise editor named Thomas Matthews: "I think wine has taken over from the toys of the old days like watches and cars. Wine shows you have money, but it also shows you have taste."
The money results from the big bull market of 1997, which, according to The Times, produced a windfall of several billion -- that's billion, not million -- dollars to be parceled out in bonuses. These range from millions for the big cats to thousands for small fry.
What results from this Wall Street gravy is not always wonderful. As Mr. Matthews noted, the appetite for toys is channeled into goods the spender thinks will show he has good taste as well as plenty of money.
Trophy houses spring up, uglifying beautiful landscapes and boasting of plenty of money and no taste at all. Chris Shipley, head wine man at the "21" Club, says Wall Streeters drink "trophy wines," big red wines with big prices and big names on the labels.
He told of a small party one night drinking five bottles of a wine that cost $1,975 a bottle.
Reading this in the paper brought me close to tears. It is not that I can't afford $1,975 for a bottle of wine. I could by refinancing the mortgage. What crushed me was the suspicion that I couldn't bear to pay that kind of money for a wine, even if I were as rich as a Microsoft vice president.
The problem is, the Great Depression is lodged in my bones. It has crippled my power to find happiness in this era of excess galore. It has left me with a stunted sense of values. I still bend down to pick up pennies. Given a single penny in change at a cash register, I refuse to leave it behind.
We are not talking cheapskate here. We are talking a psyche so warped by the Depression that it is probably unfit to be allowed out in today's economy. It could no more pay $1,975 for a bottle of wine than it could offer $16 billion to buy a competing corporation, if I had a corporation to be competed with.
It is why I don't have a corporation. I am too busy picking up pennies to get a corporation under way.
The Wall Street wine story is especially painful because it reveals me to myself as a small-time penny-picker-upper. I am extremely fond of wine, and have drunk some of these wines now pampering Wall Street digestions. They are excellent.
For an extraordinary occasion I might pay as much as $40 for the best of them, but $250 to $2,000 a bottle? They're not worth it, you Wall Street guys. You can do almost as well for less than $20 a bottle.
But hey, stupid! Wine's not the point.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Blue Chips Take a Breather From Setting Record Highs

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market was generally lower yesterday, ending a blistering run that had repeatedly sent most major indexes to record highs.
 Technology stocks, however, bucked the trend, soaring a day after Dell Computer, a leading maker of personal computers, reported its eighth consecutive quarter of record earnings.
 And so even though the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 75.48 points, or 0.89 percent, to 8,375.58, the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index inched closer to a new high.
Shares of Dell soared 9 9/16 yesterday, to a record 122 3/4, helping lift many technology stocks on optimism that the computer industry would continue to grow in 1998. Investors, who have been heavily buying technology stocks this year, bought into Intel, Microsoft and Sun Microsystems, which trade on the Nasdaq.
As a result, the Nasdaq rose 11.28 points, or nearly seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,727.01, just 18 points off its Oct. 9, 1997, high of 1,745.85. For the year, the index is up 10 percent, far and away the best-performing major indicator.
And even though the broader market slid yesterday, with many more shares falling than rising, Wall Street analysts termed the drop a welcome breather after a surprisingly strong run-up in prices.
Analysts say that the market has been powered in recent weeks by optimism that the Asian economic crisis has eased, and that the American economy remains strong, with few signs of inflationary pressure.
After months of worrisome commentary on the fate of American companies that do business in Asia, analysts are again talking about America's pre-eminent economic position and about a domestic outlook often described as the best of all possible worlds.
Even Barton Biggs, the global strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, who two months ago forecast a "huge brutal hug of a bear market" in 1998, is now talking about the American economy being in a "sweet spot," and about share prices going even higher.
The optimism is reflected in the market's recent performance; until yesterday, the Dow had climbed for six consecutive trading days, and it had risen nearly 550 points, or 7 percent, since the end of January. During that run, the Dow last week topped 8,259.31, the record it had set last Aug. 6, and one that looked awfully distant after the index plunged 554 points, to 7,161.15, on Oct. 27.
The recent gains, which have benefited large companies more than smaller ones, have surprised many analysts, many of whom had forecast share price gains of only 6 percent to 8 percent for the entire year. Already, the Dow is up 5.9 percent on the year, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which slid 3.80 points, to 1,028.28 yesterday, is up 5.96 percent.
"This market is a lot stronger than I had expected," said Charles Pradilla, a market strategist at Cowen & Company. "It's like watching a force of nature. I've been following markets for more than 30 years and I've never seen anything like this."
The gains have come amid a general rally in world stock prices, which have been driven in part by a belief that the world's central banks and the International Monetary Fund have been effective in helping stabilize the Asian situation.
In much of Europe, stock prices have risen between 6 percent and 10 percent, while shares have soared between 12 percent and 40 percent in many parts of Southeast Asia, where stock prices had collapsed at the end of last year. That optimism -- like the earlier pessimism -- leaped across oceans and touched off similar activity in the United States.
"The mood has turned to where people are putting Asia on the back burner," said Alfred Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "We had a lot of pessimism in January, about Asia, Iraq and the President. But the big picture is: This is still a bull market."
Mr. Goldman, however, said he was worried that the market may run into trouble in the months ahead as corporate profits, which have been growing smartly for several years, are slowed by the Asian crisis.
"Emotionally, Asia has had its maximum impact, but fundamentally, it has not," he said. "Analysts' profit projections are still too high."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall Slightly in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices declined modestly yesterday. Trading was light as many investors chose to await next week's appearance of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, on Capitol Hill, as well as an auction of new Treasury notes.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 8/32, to 103 28/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, edged up to 5.85 percent, from 5.83 percent on Wednesday. 
 The market largely shrugged off reports on manufacturing, jobs and trade. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its index on regional business activity fell to 12.8 percent in February from 17.3 in January, only slightly more than market forecasts of 12.5. But its index of orders for new merchandise shot up to 24.2 from 13.3 last month. Elliott Platt, director of research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, saw the Philadelphia Fed report as a mixed bag. The components of the report suggested that economic activity was somewhat stronger than the decline in the general business conditions index would imply, he said. Still, the report's price data continued to indicate that inflation was not a problem for manufacturers.
In another report, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell by 2,000, to 301,000 last week, which showed, Mr. Platt said, that there was no slackening in the labor market.
Gains in the dollar in the foreign exchange market early in the session, along with some short-covering, lifted Treasury prices off their lows. But with Mr. Greenspan scheduled to deliver his semiannual Congressional testimony on the economy, market participants elected to take a cautious approach in strategy.
Also weighing on bonds was concern over the market's ability to absorb new supply. The Treasury plans to auction $26 billion of new two-year and five-year notes. The two-year notes will be sold on Tuesday and the five-year notes on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit For 1997 Hit 9-Year High

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The nation's 1997 trade deficit reached its highest level in nine years, the Government reported today, and a jump in December suggested the deficit would surge again this year because of Asia's financial crisis.
The widening of the annual deficit was more a reflection of the strength of the American economy than an indication of a fundamental problem. But trade tensions at home and abroad could be aggravated in coming months as the deficit expands more quickly and American exporters find it more difficult to sell products and services in Asia. 
 Imports of goods and services exceeded exports by $10.8 billion in December, an increase in the deficit of $2.1 billion compared with November's figures. Economists had expected December's deficit to be about $9 billion.
The monthly figures showed the first tentative signs of Asia's effect on trade patterns. The trade deficit with economically ravaged South Korea, for example, expanded by $300 million in December, to $343 million.
Some analysts said the monthly figures might also signal some general weakening in what has been a strong export performance. Although exports were up $1 billion in December, to $80 billion, the gain came only because of a big jump in shipments of airliners, a notoriously volatile component of trade statistics. Without aircraft, exports in December would have declined.
The figures for January and ensuing months are expected to show sharper declines in American exports to South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand and much of the rest of Asia as companies and consumers there curtail purchases. The strength of the dollar relative to the Asian currencies, which makes Asian goods less expensive in the United States, is also likely to stimulate an increase in imports to the United States, further widening the trade gap.
"The crisis in Asia is just starting to be reflected in the trade statistics," said Stan Shipley, an economist at Merrill Lynch. "We expect an ever enlarging trade deficit in the first half of 1998 as U.S. exports to Asia decline."
For the year, the overall deficit in goods and services totaled $113.7 billion, up from $111 billion in 1996. It was the largest deficit in goods and services trade since the $115.9 billion shortfall in 1988. The deficit peaked at $153.4 billion in 1987.
The deficit in trade of goods alone set a new record of $198.9 billion last year but was offset by a surplus in services trade of $85.2 billion, which was also a record.
Although the deficit edged up last year, it was less than half the size it was in 1987 relative to the size of the economy.
Because the trade deficit for December was higher than the Commerce Department had expected in estimating fourth-quarter growth of 4.3 percent in gross domestic product, economists said they expected the growth rate to be revised sharply downward, to about 3.5 percent.
The trade deficit is the only broad measure of economic performance that has not improved over the last several years. But its deterioration mainly reflects the prosperity of American companies and consumers, enabling them to buy more of what other countries produce.
Clinton Administration officials said today that the rise in the overall deficit had masked a steady increase in exports, one of the primary sources of new jobs and corporate profits. Exports last year grew 10 percent, said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, and exports of manufactured goods grew 13 percent.
Still, Ms. Barshefsky said, the Asia crisis will hurt export growth this year. Economists project that the slowdown in exports could cut as much as a full percentage point off the nation's economic growth rate this year, and labor unions are warning that as many as one million jobs could be at risk as export markets shrink and manufacturers face increased competition from imports.
"The countries of Asia have been a source of strong U.S. export growth in the past, but the sharp decline in economic activity in the region is likely to reduce, at least temporarily, U.S. exports to the region and increase the trade deficit in 1998," Ms. Barshefsky said.
Besides endangering jobs, declining exports could hurt the profitability and stock prices of some companies. But a rise in imports would provide consumers with a broader selection of lower-priced goods and force domestic producers to restrain price increases, thereby helping to control inflation.
The annual figures showed improvement in the nation's trade deficit with Mexico but sharp deterioration in the deficits with Japan and China. The deficit with Japan rose to $55.7 billion last year from $47.6 billion in 1996. The deficit with China rose to $49.7 billion from $39.5 billion. The deficit with Mexico, where the economy has been bouncing back, narrowed to $14.5 billion from $17.5 billion.
The Administration has become increasingly strident in recent months in criticizing Japan for not doing more to stimulate its domestic economy and spur more demand for imports.
At a meeting of finance ministers from the seven largest industrial nations in London this weekend, the United States plans to bring more pressure on Japan to deregulate its economy and open its markets to prevent trade from becoming an even bigger source of friction.
The growing deficits with Japan and China, and the likelihood that the overall deficit will rise this year as Democrats and Republicans prepare for midterm Congressional elections, raise the prospect that trade could become a more potent political issue.
"There's already been a creeping backlash against free trade," said Lawrence Chimerine, chief economist at the Economic Strategy Institute, a research organization.
"It's hard to say where it all will end up," he added.

LENGTH: 367 words

HEADLINE: Yes to Voluntary School Uniforms

 BODY:
Under current policy, parents and administrators at individual New York City schools can vote to require students to wear uniforms. It is entirely a matter of local initiative and choice. That would not be the case under a proposal by the Board of Education president, William Thompson. He would make uniforms mandatory for students up to sixth grade, unless planning teams at the schools vote to opt out of the plan. With Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and others urging schools to generate independent proposals for reform, the Thompson plan sends a coercive message.
The proposal has already spawned threats of lawsuits and divided parents at a time when serious education problems make unified community support more necessary than ever. 
 The Thompson plan would require uniforms for grade school beginning in the fall of 1999. If the policy became mandatory, the city might eventually be required to purchase uniforms for families that could not afford them -- driving up costs at a time when some schools do not have enough books. Under the plan, students who came to school out of uniform would be subject to penalties under the school disciplinary code. New York state courts have ruled against some cases like this in the past.
The new plan appeals to board members who see uniforms as a means of eradicating the economic differences between rich and poor children and controlling student behavior. Some schools have adopted uniform plans voluntarily and have found them salutary. But parents in other schools see uniforms as an infringement on their children's individuality and have refused to participate.
Advocates of the plan argue that schools that do not want to comply can simply vote not to participate. But the current voluntary policy is a better one because it allows schools to address the uniform issue affirmatively, without having to beat back edicts from the central board. The strongest argument against the mandatory uniform plan is that it violates the fundamental premise of the new school governance law, which holds the schools accountable for safety and student performance while letting parents and local administrators run the schools as they see fit.

HEADLINE: Men's Group To Lay Off Entire Staff

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
Only four months after drawing hundreds of thousands of men to a prayer gathering on the Washington Mall, Promise Keepers, the evangelical men's movement, said yesterday that it would lay off its entire 345-person staff on March 31 because of financial problems and rely on volunteers at least temporarily.
Although the move raised immediate questions about the future of an organization that had come to seem a formidable religious force, Promise Keepers said it would not shut down, and would continue plans to hold 19 rallies across the country, beginning in Detroit on May 15. 
 The layoffs follow a decision by the organization's board in September to stop charging an admission fee for the rallies -- two-day events featuring prayer, hymn singing and preaching -- held in sports stadiums and arenas. The $60-a-person fees provided the bulk of the organization's income, covering, for example, 72 percent of its $87 million in expenses in 1996.
Roger Chapman, a Promise Keepers spokesman, said money problems had been widely expected at least since November.
"We've been talking about this for a while, so it was not like a great, big surprise," Mr. Chapman said, adding that the organization had also expected to see donations decline after Christmas, a perennial falloff affecting nonprofit organizations.
Mr. Chapman said that in November, Bill McCartney, the Promise Keepers founder and chief executive, told staff members that if the organization lacked the money to pay some of them, then no one would be paid. Mr. Chapman said he thought Mr. McCartney was telling employees they would face the situation as one.
"It was a coaching philosophy," he said, "sort of to pull the team together."
Mr. McCartney, a former football coach at the University of Colorado, could not be reached for comment. A Promise Keepers statement quoted him as saying he had a "broken heart," but not "a discouraged heart," because he felt hopeful. It said creditors would be paid in full and restaffing would occur when donations allowed.
Promise Keepers, based in Denver, has experienced financial problems before. In July, as it became evident that fewer men were attending the stadium events, the organization reduced its staff to about 360 from more than 400.
The events, at which speakers urge men to be loyal to their wives, loving to their children and devoted to Jesus, drew an average of 50,000 men in 1996. But an average of only 36,000 men turned out for the gatherings last year. The events also drew criticism, most recently from the National Organization for Women, which accused Promise Keepers of promoting male dominance, an accusation the group rejected.
On Oct. 4, Promise Keepers drew several hundred thousand men to its "Stand in the Gap" rally in Washington. But in an interview two weeks later, the president of Promise Keepers, Randy Phillips, said individual donation envelopes, intended to help pay the organization's 1998 costs, did not reach everyone there as planned. The envelopes were put in commemorative Bibles, but many men did not pick them up, because they had taken their own Bibles, he said then.
Throughout its history, Promise Keepers officials have said they believed that the organization's future, including its finances, was in God's hands.
"If you looked at us as you looked at an oil company announcing layoffs, there would be no comparisons," said Steve Ruppe, another spokesman. "The people at Promise Keepers feel called by God to be working here.
"We've just begun to seriously pray and ask for God's leading in this."
Randall Balmer, a professor of religion at Barnard College, said he believed that Promise Keepers was following a familiar trajectory among American religious movements: rapidly growing as a force outside traditional institutions, then losing steam as it became widely known and seemed to be moving closer to the mainstream.
He likened Promise Keepers to a revival or evangelistic meeting, saying, "You have this kind of burst of energy and emotion, and then it dissipates."
Professor Balmer also said he thought the robust national economy sapped a certain protest element from the movement, which he said had appealed to men who felt marginalized in society.

HEADLINE: Island Life Not Idyllic For Youths From U.S.

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Dominican Republic

 BODY:
Drugs. Gangs. Guns. Like many other Dominican immigrants in the New York metropolitan area, the parents of Lizza Santos were distressed by what they saw going on around them. So just before their daughter started high school in September, they sent her to live with her grandparents here while they remained in the United States.
At first, the 14-year-old from Yonkers wasn't sure what to expect. But she soon discovered that at least 20 percent of her 425 classmates at the Santiago Christian School are American-born reverse immigrants like herself, part of a rapidly growing group of what are known as "Dominican Yorks" in local parlance. 
 "I don't want my kid growing up in a drug-infested area where I am always worrying that somebody is going to drive by and shoot him any time he goes out on the street," said Betty Cruz, a vacationing resident of Sunset Park in Brooklyn who was visiting her son Carlos, also a student here. "I wanted him away from all of that, and that's the reason every parent moves kids here."
The New York City Board of Education said it has not compiled figures on the number of students who have transferred to Dominican schools. But educators and Government officials here estimate that as many as 10,000 students from public and parochial schools in the United States, most of them from the New York City metropolitan area, are now enrolled in the country's schools.
Officials also say that the phenomenon, though not new, has grown markedly in the last two or three years. They attribute the increase in part to reforms made to the Dominican Constitution in 1994, broadening the concept of dual citizenship to include people of Dominican ancestry born in the United States, and to a spurt of economic growth that has created new opportunities here.
But they say the example of the country's 44-year-old President, Leonel Fernandez Reyna, also seems to be a factor. Born in the Dominican Republic, Mr. Fernandez was taken to New York by his immigrant mother, a seamstress and nurse's aide, as a third grader, and studied at Emily Dickinson Elementary School, Joan of Arc Middle School and Brandeis High School in Manhattan.
When he was a teen-ager, however, his mother sent him back home to finish high school. The success he has achieved, parents and educators suggest, has encouraged other families to follow suit.
Many of the teen-agers themselves, however, describe the return to their parents' homeland as a wrenching experience. Some do not speak fluent Spanish and many find the food and culture unfamiliar, feel they are missing out on such institutions of American high school life as proms and sports teams and long to return to their families.
"I know I'm getting a better education here, but I really don't get to see my parents, and that makes me feel like moving back up there again," Miss Santos said.
In addition, some chafe at stricter rules imposed by the grandparents, aunts and uncles and godparents with whom they now live. Furthermore, outside the family circle, they are often viewed with suspicion.
"A significant percentage of parents here are afraid to let their children associate with these kids," said Pedro Juan del Rosario, director of the Center for Urban and Regional Studies at the Pontifical Catholic University here. "Parents associate New York Dominicans with social problems such as drugs and with fashion styles that are not accepted here, such as strange haircuts and the use of earrings by boys."
Some schools here openly discriminate against the Dominican Yorks. At the Colegio Padre Fortin, for instance, the handbook spelling out admission requirements states that "students who have lived in the United States in the last three years will not be accepted."
"We have wonderful discipline here, and we don't want them coming from the United States to disrupt things," said Sister Josefina de Jesus, principal of the school's elementary division. "We'll take in the little ones, up to fifth grade, but not the teen-agers, because they don't adapt, don't want to accept the rules of the school, and give us a lot of work."
Even among their peers, the Dominican Yorks encounter some resistance. Many Dominican teen-agers argue that by the nature of their upbringing, the New Yorkers are simply louder, brasher and more menacing than everybody else.
"They think they're better than everybody else just because they have the blue passport," complained Karina Benitez Galindo, a 16 year old sitting with two friends at a Burger King here.
The comments of many of the Dominican Yorks suggest that they view their time here as merely an interlude. "I'd like to go back," said Luis Tavares, 17, who attended Public School 65 in Brooklyn before being sent here for high school. "The day after I graduate, I'm outta here."

HEADLINE: Another Leader of the Navajo Nation Resigns Under a Cloud

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

 BODY:
Three years ago, Albert A. Hale took office as president of the Navajo Nation, promising to end corruption and rancorous internal politics at a reservation the size of West Virginia. Yesterday he resigned under fire for personal and political misdeeds, and apologized to the quarter-million people who live in the nation's largest Indian reservation.
"I am sorry for my shortcomings and the wrongs I may have committed while in office," Mr. Hale said, addressing the tribe in English and Navajo in a broadcast over the tribal radio station. "I ask for your forgiveness and the forgiveness of the Holy People." 
 Mr. Hale, a lawyer and one of a new style of Indian leaders who move freely from White House meetings to United Nations speeches, was one of the most forceful advocates for the rights of tribes as nations within a nation. He had recently suggested that the Navajo, whose 12 million-acre reservation touches New Mexico, Utah and Arizona, close the roads into the reservation for one day as a demonstration of Indian sovereignty.
But in the end, he was facing potential criminal charges from a special prosecutor looking into accusations that he misspent tribal money and that he had a sexual affair while in office. Under the terms of his resignation, hammered out on Wednesday at the Navajo capital in Window Rock, Ariz., the investigation into the money was dropped.
To some people, Mr. Hale's resignation shows that the politics of Indian Country are no different from those of any other part of the country, except that everything is magnified by family links and overt spirituality.
"Albert Hale became the point person for spreading the issue of Indian sovereignty throughout the world, and he was quite effective at it," said Dr. Lee Francis, a Laguna Pueblo Indian who is a professor of Native American Studies at the University of New Mexico. "His resignation says to us throughout Indian Country that we have got to stop shooting ourselves in the foot."
Mr. Hale is the second Navajo leader in the last decade to resign under a cloud. The tribal leader from two terms ago, Peter MacDonald, was convicted by a tribal court in 1992 of bribery and conspiracy charges and sentenced to seven years in jail.
The Navajo have twice rejected casino gambling and, under Mr. Hale, had been trying to build tribal businesses while taking an assertive stance on sovereignty.
"He was a very good leader on sovereignty," said Ron Allen, president of the National Congress of American Indians, "on trying to explain to Congress and the President and the rest of the world that we are Indian governments, not just tribes."
But under Mr. Hale, unemployment on the reservation remained near 30 percent, and nearly 3 out of 10 members still lived in homes without running water or electricity.
"I have seen a lot of suffering," Mr. Hale said after being elected president in 1994. "We have to end that."
The tribe has an aggressive newspaper, The Navajo Times, which recently published articles about Mr. Hale's personal life and about his alleged misuse of a tribal credit card. After the articles surfaced, the Navajo attorney general named a special prosecutor, who for five months has conducted an investigation into accusations that Mr. Hale improperly charged the tribe for more than $52,000 in expenses in 1995 and 1996. The special prosecutor, Fred C. Smith, a lawyer in Santa Fe, N.M., was also looking into complaints that Mr. Hale spent tribal money on the woman with whom his wife has accused him of having an affair.
Mr. Hale, in his resignation statement, seemed to blame political factions for his downfall.
"I have never put a cent of tribal money into my pocket," he said. "Yet, there is a continuing vendetta against me on the basis of my expenses."
He said he was resigning to spare his family further agony.
But Robert E. French, director of the Navajo Nation ethics office, said the evidence was strong.
"It came down to two choices for him," Mr. French said. "He could agree to the charges and resign, facing no further investigation, or stay in office and face criminal charges by the special prosecutor."
In his statement yesterday, Mr. Hale said his push for greater sovereignty had resulted in "new respect for our heritage and our language" both on and off the reservation.
"In the future," he said, "the corn pollen bag and the law school diploma can hang side-by-side on an office wall."
In the Navajo tradition, other tribal leaders yesterday offered spiritual support for Mr. Hale.
"Through our clan system, President Hale is my son," said Kelsey A. Begaye, speaker of the 88-member Navajo Nation Council, the legislative body of the tribe, "and we all know as parents that when our children hurt, we also hurt right along with them. At this time, we all need to remember that we are all Navajo brothers and sisters. We are all united."
Mr. Hale will be replaced by his vice president, Thomas Atcitty, until new elections are held.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Navajo President Albert A. Hale in his office in Window Rock, Ariz., last July. Mr. Hale resigned yesterday, ending an investigation by a special prosecutor into accusations that he misspent tribal money. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Fell 2,000 Last Week

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
New jobless claims edged lower in mid-February, the Government said today, in the latest sign of a strong job market and a strong economy.
The number of new claims for state unemployment insurance fell to 301,000 last week from 303,000 a week earlier. The reading was the lowest since Jan. 24, when new claims stood at 300,000. 
 Claims have hovered between 300,000 and 304,000 for the last four weeks and the four-week average, considered a more accurate barometer of the labor market, fell for the fourth consecutive week, to 302,000 from 308,500.
"As long as the jobless claims can stay close to that 300,000 level it is a very encouraging sign of a very healthy economy," Gary Thayer, senior economist for A. G. Edwards, said.
The latest reading was below the 305,000 in new claims that analysts had forecast.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE ARABS;
Iraq Neighbors Fear a Burden If U.S. Strikes

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 19

 BODY:
To the Pentagon, the term "collateral damage" has long been a euphemism for the loss of civilian life and property. But the phrase has taken on a broader meaning in the Arab world. Today it is used widely, from people in coffee shops to columnists in newspapers, to mean that Americans do not care about Arab lives, governments or economies.
"I feel insulted and baffled when I hear these American generals talk of 'collateral damages' as though it is a few pieces of furniture that will be damaged as they battle that big devil Saddam Hussein," Taher Kanaan, a Jordanian Senator, said in a conversation today, as people sipping coffee at the Intercontinental cafeteria here nodded their agreement. 
 "When this Madeleine Albright talks about her war 'against Saddam,' the attack 'on Saddam,' putting 'Saddam in a box,' does she not understand that Saddam happens to live alongside another 20 million Iraqis," said Lubna Khalil al-Salem, a pharmacist. "What about their lives, their economic conditions, our economic conditions here in Jordan?"
Such concerns are real in this country of five million, which suffered heavily during the Persian Gulf war in 1991. The same is true in other neighboring countries that are allied with the United States, but dread the new costs -- political, social and economic -- that will be exacted if the United States attacks Iraq.
The atmosphere is different from what it was in 1990. For one thing, Iraq has not invaded a country, as it invaded Kuwait. For another, Arab allies that stuck by the United States in the gulf war are keeping their diplomatic distance, at least publicly, with the exception of Kuwait and to a lesser extent Bahrain and Oman.
There is little question that an attack would bring another wave of panicked refugees from Iraq to Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Turkey. And there would be a heavy toll in lost business, flight of capital and growing deficits
In 1990 and 1991 nearly three million people were displaced from Iraq and Kuwait. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Qatar emptied their cash reserves to foot a $120 billion bill for the liberation of Kuwait. Egypt saw an influx of half a million Egyptians evicted from Iraq and a drop in tourism.
But Jordan paid the heaviest price, absorbing some 300,000 Palestinians evicted from Kuwait. And after Iraq was bombed and sanctions imposed, Jordan lost its most lucrative market for food and manufactures.
"If the Americans go through with this strike, our economic situation will be disastrous," said Leila Sharaf, a member of the foreign affairs committee of the Jordanian Senate. "The whole area's political and economic situation will be disastrous. Turmoil will not be confined to Iraq alone. It will spill over here, in the West Bank, among the Kurds in Iran and Turkey."
"When American generals talk of limiting collateral damage from their missiles, do they think of all this social and political upheaval? Do they have solutions for what will transpire, or are we going to be left with the cleaning-up job," she said, her words reflecting the arguments and worries of many decision-makers in the Arab world .
"I fear the Americans are mobilizing forces against them that were not mobilized before," Senator Sharaf said.
Jordan has sought more than a billion dollars in compensation for housing, feeding and moving the last wave of refugees. Countries that made claims to the United Nations have received only a small fraction of what they were seeking; the compensation is to come from the money generated by the oil-for-food program. This time Jordanian officials say they will simply shut the borders to refugees by force of arms.
Jordan and Turkey, another American ally, stand to pay in other ways. A bombing campaign is sure to cut off oil from Iraq to both countries.
Every dawn, scores of trucks loaded with Iraqi oil make their way to Jordan carrying 96,000 barrels of oil. At current prices this is worth $1.3 million a day. But Jordan pays Iraq a third of that amount in the form of manufactured goods under a plan authorized by the United Nations. Jordan, which has a heavy burden of foreign debts, would have to pay full price to replace the daily supply, which is its sole source of oil for producing its electricity, heating its homes and moving its vehicles.
Turkey stands to lose if Iraq cuts off the limited sales permitted under the United Nations oil-for-food program because the oil travels through a Turkish pipeline, bringing in substantial taxes and transit fees.
"If the oil stops, Jordan and Turkey will be big losers," Sherif Ghalib, an economist with the Kuwait-based Gulf Investment Corporation said in a telephone interview.
An attack on Iraq would not be good news for Saudi Arabia or Kuwait, either. Both countries might come under pressure again to help defray the costs of military preparations and movements.
The Saudis have served notice that they will neither allow attacks on Iraq from their territory nor help pay the costs, a Saudi official said, although they probably will supply some logistical assistance that will cost tens of millions of dollars.
Kuwait, which has agreed to allow American planes to stage strikes from bases there, has managed to rebuild some of its foreign currency reserves since the gulf war, but it is certain to dip deeply into them again if it helps pay for an attack.
Even though no hostilities have begun, economic activity in the region is slowing down. Stock markets in the gulf region have fallen. Tourists are canceling plans to visit Jordan, Israel, Egypt and even places as far away as Morocco. And capital is again flowing out of gulf nations.
"Instability and the fear of Iraqi retaliation are affecting investments and the private sector's behavior," Henry Azzam, chief economist for the National Commercial Bank of Jidda, Saudi Arabia, said in a telephone interview.
Political ramifications are palpable too. Jordan, Egypt and the Palestinian Authority have banned all demonstrations in support of Iraq, but demonstrators have hit the streets and campuses anyway. The Jordanian police arrested scores of demonstrators last week.
While Saddam Hussein has lost a great deal of popularity in the streets of Arab countries, there is a conviction that any attack on Iraq is meant not so much to remove him but to humiliate Iraq as a country and a people and as a strategic Arab asset against non-Arab adversaries like Iran, Turkey and Israel.
In an opinion that is overwhelmingly reflected in daily conversations throughout the Arab world, Mohammed Hassanein Heikal, an influential Egyptian political writer and commentator, told the BBC Arabic radio program on Wednesday: "The purpose of the arms inspection regime is no longer to find weapons. They have had seven years to do that. Now they are looking in professors' drawers, invading universities and looking for papers. The purpose is to humiliate, to insult and to break the regime and the people of Iraq."
Another well-known Arab commentator, Hazem Sagiegh of the daily Al Hayat, based in London, wondered the other day whether bringing down the Government of Mr. Hussein could prove far more disastrous that leaving it alone.
"There is no point to an American assault if it does not lead to the collapse of the regime, which pushes us to examine the ability of various Iraqi ethnic, political and popular substitutes to his rule," he said. "Unfortunately, the answer is known."
He asserted that in the last six years Kurdish rebels inside Iraq have proven more adept at fighting one another than Mr. Hussein's leadership, and that the Shiite opposition in the south has shown itself more servile to neighboring Iran.

HEADLINE: Tennis Open Drops Caterer After Food Complaints

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Few tennis fans lucky enough to have attended last year's United States Open finals are likely to remember the score of Patrick Rafter's remarkable victory. Yet fewer fans are probably able to shake the memory of the price of pizza in Flushing.
With $4.50 slices, hamburgers going for $6.75 and service often as slow as a golf game, the food fault was the talk of last summer's Open at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens. 
 Yesterday, the United States Tennis Association said it was replacing its current food service provider. It is likely to bring back the restaurant company that served the Open famously from 1976 to 1995 with such courtside delicacies as quiche, panini and baguettes.
Sportservice Corporation, a Buffalo sports-event caterer that had replaced Restaurant Associates in 1996, will not be returning to the U.S. Open this fall. The company had a seven-year contract to provide food at the Open and had done so for the last two years in an association with two of the biggest names in New York's food firmament: the Joseph Baum & Michael Whiteman Company in Manhattan and Glorious Food, the upscale New York company that caters to society, celebrities and art galleries.
Through the years, the food at the Open has become nearly as legendary as the tennis. "I never went to a sporting event for a meal, yet there's such incredible preoccupation with the food at the Open," said Alan King, the comedian, who has attended the tournament for more than 40 years. "It's as if food is the new sport."
In 1996, the tennis association's decision to replace Restaurant Associates after 19 years generated seismic waves of food-world gossip, thanks to the fame of the restaurant companies involved.
The winners in the 1996 bidding included Sportservice and Mr. Baum, who created the original Windows on the World and refurbished the Rainbow Room. They replaced Restaurant Associates, which first made its mark by starting trend-setting restaurants like the Four Seasons and the Brasserie.
The rejection of Restaurant Associates in 1996 was all the more significant because Mr. Baum was once an executive at Restaurant Associates before he left to head his own company.
The association would not say why it was changing its food providers. "We came to a mutual agreement with Sportservice to terminate the contract," said David Meehan, director of operations for the association, who said the organization was "in serious negotiations" with Restaurant Associates.
"The whole contract proved not to be economically viable for us," said Brenda H. Follmer, a spokeswoman for Sportservice. "We exercised the exit clause in our contract. It was a mutual, amicable parting."
The U.S. Open "is an extraordinarily high-profile corporate event, and so the food contract is important," said Malcolm M. Knapp, who heads an independent restaurant consulting firm that bears his name. "But it's so enormously complex, it's very hard to do well."
Mr. Knapp estimated that food revenues at the Open were $10 million last fall, when the Open attracted 556,000 paying customers during the three-week event, virtually all of whom bought food or drink.
In addition to food courts for tennis fans as well as luxury suites and hospitality tents for corporations, the new tennis center has three exclusive restaurants.
Last year some tennis fans, as well as the holders of corporate boxes and suites, objected to the prices and the service.
"I do a lot of events, and the Open was even more expensive for us than the Olympics or the Super Bowl," said an executive of a large Wall Street brokerage firm. He insisted on anonymity, saying he feared reprisal from the tennis association.
As for the Open's upscale restaurants, "There was a lot of hoopla about how great the food was going to be, but it was squarely average, and the service was horrendous," he added. "It took an hour and a half just to get salad and soup."
Bill Williams, a tennis pro at the Manhattan Plaza Racquet Club who attended the Open for seven days last fall, said: "It was a disaster. The lines were longer than ever, as if they were serving slowly or they hadn't got the logistics right."
Liz Boyle, the event coordinator for the Citizen Watch Company, said that "on our big night, the food wasn't ready on time." More than 200 guests had been invited to a party at the company's hospitality tent. "They ended up lowering our bill," she said.
Another executive from a major Fortune 500 company, who also insisted on anonymity, described a luncheon so interminable that "we finally had to send our clients up to the seats without dessert or coffee, because the service was so below standard."
He added: "I tipped the waiter a minimal $10, and when the credit-card receipt arrived I discovered that the waiter had altered it to $40."
Mr. Meehan of the tennis association acknowledged, "We did receive complaints," adding: "We welcomed them. No one would ever be penalized because they criticized the U.S.T.A. That would never happen."
"We will re-examine every aspect of our food operations," he added, "so we can give our customers superior service next Open."
Ms. Follmer of Sportservice said, "We did hear some complaints toward the beginning of the Open, until we got the kinks out of our operations."
David Emil, a partner of Mr. Baum's, said of Sportservice that "we respect our partner's decision to terminate the relationship," he said, adding, "We found that it was not a profitable operation to run the restaurants alone."
As for Glorious Food, "we have nothing to say until we've been notified by the U.S.T.A.," said W. Sean Driscoll, a partner. "But they told us they were quite pleased with what we did."
Nick Valenti, the chief executive of Restaurant Associates, said his company was negotiating with the tennis association. "Our plan would be to lower some of the prices," he said.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Developers Join in Project on East Side

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
It is just a hole in the ground now, but over the next 15 months, a luxury rental building with 156 apartments will take shape on the southwest corner of 82d Street and First Avenue, the third project on the Upper East Side by one of New York City's newer development teams.
Named Wellington Tower, the building will replace a parking lot and four brownstones with an 18-story structure designed by Hartman-Cox, a firm in Washington. Its lower seven stories will extend along 82d Street, and the tower will rise along the avenue. 
 The $75 million project is being built by Trevor Davis, president of Davis Partners, in a joint venture with Aby Rosen and Michael Fuchs, who head RFR Holding, both Manhattan companies. The partnership gets most of its financing from banks in Germany, where Mr. Rosen and Mr. Fuchs, who were born in Germany, also have real estate interests.
"We thought there would be a new wave of residential construction," Mr. Rosen said, "so we started purchasing sites and targeted the Upper East Side because it is an established and desirable neighborhood with little downside."
They are not alone on the East Side in responding to the improved leasing market. The Related Companies, a large rental developer, is constructing a 22-story, 246-unit building at 230 East 86th Street between Second and Third Avenues. At 150 East 57th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, Bernard Spitzer, a developer and civil engineer, is building a 34-story tower with 145 rentals.
Mr. Rosen and Mr. Fuchs had been acquiring office properties in Manhattan before they joined forces three years ago with Mr. Davis, who was doing commercial development nationally, to pursue residential development. They have since built a 103-unit rental at 300 East 64th Street at Second Avenue and are nearing completion on a 227-unit building at 33d Street and First Avenue. They hope to have about 1,000 apartments built or under way by 2000, Mr. Rosen said. They also are negotiating to buy two additional Upper East Side sites where they could build 480 more units.
The partners are among the few builders constructing rentals without public benefits. These include city-sponsored tax incentives offered to builders to convert office buildings in downtown Manhattan to apartments and tax-exempt bond financing that developers secure through the so-called 80-20 program.
Under that program, the city or the state issues bonds to provide permanent financing to builders, who are also eligible for tax abatement from the city. In exchange, builders must reserve 20 percent of the apartments for low-income tenants. But by not using the program, Mr. Rosen said, the partnership has greater flexibility and an edge over competitors.
He said they also build on sites that do not require special zoning approvals or permits. But their projects have faced local resistance. An example is the high-rise condominium the partners want to build on Third Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets.
There, they have been involved in a tug-of-war with residents and neighbors of the Cottages, eight one-bedroom residences facing a landscaped courtyard that sit behind a row of 1930's storefronts, which now occupy the site. The five residents of the Cottages and tenants in an adjacent building have filed lawsuits to preserve the residences and garden. The lawsuits have not been resolved.
In acquiring land, the partners look for corner sites that have been abandoned or are in the hands of owners who can not or choose not to develop them. They bought the 82d Street site as part of an estate sale.
With land prices rising and available sites dwindling, the task has become more difficult and has started to slow the pace of rental production, brokers said.
Rents for all size apartments on the Upper East and West Sides rose 6 percent over the last year and are higher than at the crest of the market in the late 1980's, said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a rental brokerage concern. Barring any economic change, they should continue to rise, she added.
Construction began on Wellington Tower three weeks ago after the developers relocated four tenants from the brownstones, which were razed along with the parking lot. The building will have a facade of brick with precast stone and concrete details. It will also have high-tech wiring and amenities like a health club and children's playroom.
The apartments will range in size from 450 square feet for the smallest studio to 1,900 square feet for the largest three-bedroom unit. Rents have not been set, but Mr. Rosen said they would be competitive. Average monthly rents for comparable Upper East Side units range from $1,595 to $5,309, according to Feathered Nest.
Leasing is to start next February.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A development team that plans a rental building at 82d Street and First Avenue is putting up this 227-unit tower at 33d Street and First Avenue. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 3 Governors Shifting Focus To Spending

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
A few years ago, the newly elected Republican Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were in the vanguard of the movement to cut state taxes and rein in spending.
But this year, even as lawmakers around the country rush to follow their lead, George E. Pataki of New York, Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and John G. Rowland of Connecticut have changed directions. Rather than talking about fiscal discipline, they are seeking the largest spending increases that their states have seen since before the 1990-91 recession. 
 Blessed with record surpluses, thanks to the Wall Street boom, all three Governors have proposed budgets that would lavish money on education. Mr. Pataki's budget also calls for large increases in spending on medical care for the poor, while Mrs. Whitman's seeks more money for open-space acquisition, aid to cities and public transportation.
Mr. Pataki and Mr. Rowland, who are both up for re-election in November, are following the classic practice of incumbents fattening budgets to please voters. Mrs. Whitman, who barely won a second term -- by law, her last -- in November, faces a different set of political imperatives. She needs to bolster her stature with a public that sent a clear message that tax cuts alone were not enough.
Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Pataki may also be looking ahead, as each has been mentioned for the Republican national ticket in 2000. The enviable combination of tax cuts and spending increases could widen their home-state popularity and that, in turn, would make them more attractive as ticket-balancers.
In favoring education this year, the region's three Governors are joining colleagues nationwide in spending on schools to please voters.
Hal Hovey, the editor of State Policy Reports, a publication that tracks the activities of state governments, said, "At least 35 states will have elementary and secondary school spending that increases faster than the budget as a whole."
Mr. Pataki, who tried to cut education spending in his first two years in office, has called this year for an increase in aid to primary and secondary schools of more than $600 million, along with smaller increases for public colleges and universities. Across the river, Mrs. Whitman has asked for a $540 million increase for education, while a pending court case may force the state to spend still more on schools in poor communities. And although Connecticut has a two-year budget in place, Mr. Rowland has proposed amendments to increase education spending by $87 million in the second year of the plan.
Medicaid, which has also been a target of Mr. Pataki's, will essentially be left untouched this year, guaranteeing a large spending increase as medical costs rise. And the Governor wants to use some of the surplus to pay cash for $450 million in lawmakers' pet projects rather than borrowing the money.
Mrs. Whitman, on the other hand, wants to put $650 million of her state's surplus into a "rainy day" fund, a move that, in the event of an economic downturn, might forestall unpopular budget cuts.
In New York, where the surplus is projected at $1.8 billion, Mr. Pataki has proposed a $71.6 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning on April 1, an increase of 7.2 percent, or almost $5 billion. But he will have to negotiate some compromises: the Democrats who control the State Assembly want a far larger increase for education; the Republican majority in the Senate is calling for more tax-cutting.
Mrs. Whitman's proposal for the fiscal year that starts on July 1 takes advantage of a projected $1 billion surplus to increase spending to $17.9 billion, up 5.4 percent. The Republican-controlled Legislature is expected to approve a budget largely along her lines.
Connecticut has a $180 million surplus. Under the state's two-year budget, it is scheduled to spend $10.5 billion in the fiscal year that begins on July 1, but Mr. Rowland wants to raise that by $400 million, for a 3.5 percent increase over the current fiscal year. He will face a fight with Democrats in the legislature, who say that his plan for a one-time tax rebate favors the wealthy and who want some of the surplus to go into an emergency reserve fund.
In 1994, Mrs. Whitman's first year in office, New Jersey cut taxes more deeply than any other state, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. In Mr. Pataki's first year in office, 1995, New York ranked first in tax cuts and New Jersey was still among the leaders. In 1996, New York was first again, and Connecticut was second.
"In New York and New Jersey especially," said Corinna Eckl, the fiscal program director for the Conference of State Legislatures, "they've had several years of serious tax cuts, so that they are already at a point that a lot of other states are just now approaching with their reductions."
Although analysts expect significant tax cuts in at least half the states in the nation, Mrs. Whitman has not proposed any major new ones.
In New York, several taxes -- notably property and estate taxes -- will continue to drop over the next few years under laws passed last year, and Mr. Pataki has proposed using some of the surplus to put some of those cuts into effect ahead of schedule.
Governor Rowland has abandoned his pledge to eliminate by 2000 the income tax put in place by his predecessor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. Mr. Rowland proposes giving about two-thirds of his state's surplus back to residents, through tax-rebate checks of up to $200 that would be sent out just before he stands for re-election in November. But even that is viewed by budget experts as a fairly cautious move, because it is a one-time measure that would have no effect on future tax collections.
All three Governors benefited politically from the tax increases their predecessors made during the last recession, making it far easier to cut taxes once economic recovery began. Most of the tax-cutting that Mr. Pataki, Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Rowland did in their first years in office was simply rolling back those increases.
In the last three years, the three states have reaped a disproportionately large share of the Wall Street boom, since they are home to many of the nation's stock and bond traders, as well as many wealthy people with heavy investments.
The states' tax structures help, because all three rely heavily on a progressive personal income tax -- one that taxes higher incomes more heavily. Thanks to Wall Street, most of the income growth in the region has been among wealthier people, so it has been taxed in the highest brackets. That means that state tax collections have gone up faster than incomes, producing the huge surpluses.
"The largest windfalls have been to the states, like New York, where the tax structure is most progressive," Mr. Hovey of State Policy Reports said. "In the early 90's, they were seeing the downside to being so heavily tied to the financial markets. Now, they're seeing the upside."

HEADLINE: Murder Suspect Is Held on $1 Million Bail

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 19

 BODY:
A rootless, unemployed 24-year-old man charged with murdering a 15-year-old high school freshman last Saturday was held on $1 million bail today as the authorities pressed a search for others possibly involved in the slaying.
While the suspect, Thomahl S. Cook of Somerville, N.J., stood silently in handcuffs during a court appearance here and as grieving family members and teen-age friends mourned the victim, Katrina Suhan, at her wake in South Amboy, detectives questioned two men who live in a boardinghouse with Mr. Cook and seized items from the car of another resident there. 
 The Middlesex County Prosecutor, Robert W. Gluck, said his staff was still trying to establish how Mr. Cook traveled the 40 miles from the Somerville rooming house Friday night to a roller-skating rink in South Amboy where Miss Suhan spent several hours with friends before she vanished while walking home alone early Saturday morning.
"We've got a gap in the case," Mr. Gluck said after Mr. Cook was arraigned on murder charges. He said that Mr. Cook did not own a car and that detectives were looking for anyone who might have lent him a car or driven him to the rink. Mr. Gluck said detectives were also trying to learn how the young woman was transported to the ravine behind a diner in Old Bridge, about three miles from her home, before she was beaten to death there with a two-by-four and possibly some rocks.
Detectives are also still trying to establish a motive for the crime, Mr. Gluck said. An autopsy has found that Miss Suhan was not sexually assaulted.
Officials and relatives of Miss Suhan also said today that the girl did not know the suspect, even though some reports had said they were acquaintances from the roller rink.
"There is absolutely no truth to rumors that she even knew this guy," Michael Sciavolino, a cousin of Miss Suhan, said after a wake this afternoon. "They go to the same skating rink. That doesn't even make them acquaintances."
About 600 family members, teen-age friends and teachers and school officials paid final respects to Miss Suhan during the wake, held at the Gundrum Home for Funerals in South Amboy. At times this evening, the line of mourners waiting to view her body stretched out the door and onto the front sidewalk.
During Mr. Cook's brief appearance in New Jersey Superior Court, Judge Robert P. Figarotta asked his lawyer, Regina Sauter, a public defender, if she wanted to enter a not guilty plea for him.
"Absolutely," Ms. Sauter said.
Judge Figarotta then continued a $1 million bail that another judge imposed Wednesday night after Mr. Cook's arrest.
The suspect, a slightly built man in green T-shirt and green pants, stood in handcuffs in the jury box and said nothing during the brief proceeding.
The criminal complaint filed here today against Mr. Cook said his arrest was based on a statement he had given to the authorities after they questioned him earlier this week. He was picked up late Monday night after a resident of Somerville called the police there and suggested that Mr. Cook had a role in the murder.
Mr. Gluck declined today to offer details of the statement or say whether Mr. Cook had confessed to the crime. The caller, he said, told the police that Mr. Cook was in the South Amboy area Friday night and "may have been involved," Mr. Gluck said.
Two men at the boardinghouse, Robert Poquette and Richard Rivera, said in interviews early this evening that Mr. Cook had told them last Thursday and Friday that he wanted to get to the South Amboy skating rink, Rollermagic Rink, a popular gathering spot for young people from South Amboy and the working-class communities near it.
Both men said detectives questioned them today and they said they told them they did not know what transportation Mr. Cook used.
Since graduating from high school in Red Bank, N.J., in 1993, Mr. Cook has drifted from town to town and from job to job in central New Jersey. The authorities said they believed he was currently unemployed. He has had minor brushes with the law in the past, officials said, including a charge of trespassing on a boat docked at a marina in Red Bank in 1993.
He served 20 days in jail in 1994 in the case and a warrant was issued for his arrest last January after his repeated failure to pay all of a $250 fine levied against him, officials said.

HEADLINE: Corrections

 BODY:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Labor Department's report on producer prices in January referred incorrectly to the report's most widely followed index. It measures the prices that manufacturers, farmers and other producers pay for finished goods, not the cost of raw materials and semifinished goods. The index fell seven-tenths of 1 percent last month.
