HEADLINE: A District Good Times Forgot;
Once Invincible, Connecticut Congresswoman Faces Tough Fight

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: NEW BRITAIN, Conn.

 BODY:
The withered heart of this once proud Yankee mill town tells the story of Representative Nancy L. Johnson's political troubles.
A red Stanley Works sign shines brightly into the city sky, but a tool factory below has been dark for years. A battleship-size lot is all that remains of a bearing plant that once employed thousands. Even the few living factories are shadows of their former selves, the desolate streets and shuttered buildings nearby as forlorn as a Hopper painting. 
 The region's inability to pull out of its long, slow tailspin while the nation's economy continues to soar has made Ms. Johnson, once considered among Connecticut's most durable and popular politicians, a rare breed: an endangered incumbent.
In an election year when the political ether seems devoid of overarching themes, when neither major party seems able to gain the upper hand and when a strong economy is keeping many voters content, challengers across the country are groping for inspiration and strategies, political analysts say.
Not here. In Connecticut's Sixth Congressional District, which encompasses the state's northwestern corner from Hartford's suburbs to New Britain's industries to the plush lakeside homes of the Berkshires, three Democrats are off and sprinting against Ms. Johnson, an eight-term Republican.
Already, two of the three have raised nearly as much money as the Democratic challenger, Charlotte Koskoff, did in all of 1996, when she lost to Ms. Johnson by just 1,600 votes despite a shoestring budget of $230,000 that kept her from running a single television commercial. Already, three powerful organizations have vowed to help oust the incumbent: the A.F.L.-C.I.O, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and Emily's List, the national fund-raising network for women.
"The last cycle, people believed Nancy couldn't be beaten," said John W. Olsen, president of the Connecticut A.F.L.-C.I.O. "Now there is an opportunity to win."
Not to be outdone, Ms. Johnson, 63, who got her start in politics as a parent advocate, has shifted into campaign gear. She has been tirelessly criss-crossing her district meeting business and constituent groups. From late December until mid-January, she ran campaign-like commercials promoting her role in enacting a health insurance law for children last year. And she has been aggressively raising money, with $450,000 in the bank.
Possibly to offset charges that she is too close to House Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, she has also been wrapping herself in President Clinton's mantle, profusely praising his State of the Union Message in January and splashing cold water on Republican talk of impeaching the President amid allegations that he had a sexual relationship with an intern and then asked her to lie about it.
"Bill Clinton is very important," she told a group of fifth graders at a New Britain school recently. "He and I have been allies on many things. Sometimes party labels aren't that important."
Fueling the Democrats' hopes of biting into the Republicans' narrow 11-vote House majority is the sense among many here that this once unbeatable politician -- before 1996, she routinely won elections with well over 60 percent of the vote -- has become aloof from the gritty problems of her blue-collar district.
Democrats played on that theme two years ago when they accused Ms. Johnson, then the chairwoman of the House ethics committee, of stalling an investigation into Mr. Gingrich. Many Democrats believe the Speaker's conservative views clash with Connecticut sensibilities, andMs. Johnson acknowledges that their broadsides wounded her at the polls.
This time, the Democrats are attacking Ms. Johnson's efforts to promote legislation in 1996 that would have allowed the Stanley Works, among the region's largest employers, to continue marketing tools partially produced overseas as "Made in the U.S.A."
After her measure failed in the Senate, it was reported that Ms. Johnson owned more than $100,000 in Stanley stock, sparking charges of a conflict of interest. (Her husband inherited the stock from his father, who was a Stanley foreman.) But Democrats have framed the issue more in terms of jobs: the policy that Ms. Johnson was trying to protect would have helped Stanley move jobs to Asia, they charged.
"The fact that the district is falling apart doesn't seem to tear at her the way it does others," said Jim Griffin, a Bristol businessman who is running for the Democratic nomination. "There's a sort of 'let them eat cake' aspect to her attitude."
Ms. Johnson denies that vehemently, saying she has worked very hard for local industry.
The other Democrats seeking their party's nomination are Ms. Koskoff, a lawyer and former political science professor at Central Connecticut State University, and State Representative Demetrios Giannaros, an economics professor at the University of Hartford.
For all her obvious political woes, Ms. Johnson may be harder to defeat than the Democrats realize, political analysts say. Charges that she is too comfortable with conservative House leaders may not stick because she is clearly a moderate who has defended poverty programs and abortion rights. They also note that the Democrats may face a bloody primary fight and that Democratic turnout may be down, without a popular President running at the top of the ticket.
"I don't see what the message of a challenger is this year," said Amy Walter, the House analyst for the Cook Political Report, which has rated Connecticut's Sixth District as leaning Republican. "The real issue is: Do people in that district feel she is more responsive? If they feel she got the wake-up call in 1996, and that Congress isn't doing anything bad, well, she'll be tough to defeat."
That view was echoed by Toby Geiger, a United Parcel Service delivery man who greeted Ms. Johnson as "our first woman president" when he saw her on a New Britain street recently. "We like her a lot," said Mr. Geiger, who professed ignorance about the Stanley stock flap. "She's honest and fair. Even Democrats feel that way."
It is sometimes hard to see the seasoned politician in Ms. Johnson. She is earnest almost to a fault, using public appearances to explain dense policy matters to sometimes perplexed audiences. Her large-frame glasses, conservative business suits and short, softly waved hair might seem out of place in a back-room meeting of world-weary politicians. She speaks in a soft, assuring voice that seems ill-suited for making rousing stump speeches.
And unlike so many in her profession, she gets easily flustered. When a New Britain fifth grader asked her recently how much money she makes, her answer -- $133,000 a year -- sent a collective gasp through the room of children. "It is a lot of money," Ms. Johnson said, her face flushing slightly.
But colleagues say her motherly style masks a hard interior that has made her effective on Capitol Hill. "Don't be fooled," said a Connecticut congressional aide. "She's tough as nails."
Ms. Johnson was born and reared in Chicago. Her mother was a high school history teacher and her father a law professor turned Republican state legislator. After graduating from Radcliffe College with a bachelor's degree in art history, she married her college sweetheart and they moved to his hometown of New Britain after he completed his medical degree.
After giving birth to three daughters, she became a leader of the local parent-teacher association, then won a seat in the State Senate, which she held for six years. In 1982, after Representative Toby Moffett, a Democrat, resigned to run for the Senate, she won his seat in a district where Democrats outnumbered Republicans.
Ms. Johnson makes no bones about her closeness to Mr. Gingrich. Though she says Mr. Gingrich has made mistakes, he energized "a stuffy old party" when he joined the leadership, she said. And she proudly defends her efforts to help the Stanley Works.
In 1996, the company and its executives contributed at least $6,000 to her campaign and financed a $1,189 trip for one of her aides to Texas. But that had nothing to do with her efforts to help Stanley, she said.
"My goal in all of this was jobs, good jobs, manufacturing jobs," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, talking to factory workers. Her narrow 1996 victory has Democrats speculating she could be defeated. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
A Chef Who Lost It All Is Finally Off the Streets

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
On good days, when Michael Geda lived on the street, he slept in a cheap motel on the West Side Highway. On bad days, when his panhandling yielded less than the $44 it cost for a room, he rode the A train until dawn. But during his eight months of homelessness, he rarely slept more than a few hours on the train, one of the few lines that remain underground, and warm, along most of their routes. "Either the police harass you or, on bad nights, thieves try to rob you," said Mr. Geda, 61, a thickly bearded man with leaden eyes and hands that never stop fretting. "I don't like to remember this."
There are many things Mr. Geda prefers not to remember, people he will not talk about. Like the son he lost in the Israeli army or the wife who died seven months later. The past, it seems, carries as much pain as the present. 
 Mr. Geda, an unemployed chef, is a ghost of his former self, a man broken by grief. He has a home now, thanks to a garment industry executive and a half-dozen social service agencies that are paying the rent on his Brooklyn apartment. But he has no phone, no friends and, on most days, no money in his pocket. Because he is an illegal immigrant, no one will give him a job; for the same reason, welfare will not help him either.
He spends his days collecting alms in Manhattan's Garment District. When he sees an office or showroom with a mezuza on the door post -- a small scroll of religious text -- Mr. Geda knows the owner is Jewish and likely to help a fellow Jew. It is a shameful existence, he said, "not fit for an animal." But still, he is glad to be off the streets and appreciative of the furniture and clothing he has received from the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty and the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. Both agencies are affiliates of the UJA-Federation of New York and supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Sitting in his apartment in Flatbush yesterday, smoking the last of his cigarettes, Mr. Geda described his journey from Egypt, where he was born and raised, to Israel, where he worked as a chef, and, in 1983, to New York, "where I lost my soul," he said.
He said he never had any desire to leave Israel, but an American friend enticed him with a job, a plane ticket and the promise of easy money. At first, Mr. Geda did well running the kitchens of two kosher delicatessens on Kings Highway that were owned by his friend. But one day the man vanished, the delis closed and Mr. Geda found himself jobless. When his friend disappeared, so did his chance of being sponsored for a green card, and as a result, the $2,000 that Mr. Geda had spent on an immigration lawyer was wasted.
He found work at a restaurant, but a few months later, in 1988, his world fell apart when his 24-year-old son, David, was killed during a training exercise in Lebanon. David's body was never recovered, and the loss -- two weeks before the son's wedding -- was too much for his wife, who died that same year from a heart attack while in Israel, Mr. Geda said.
The years since his wife and son died have been a blur. For a while, he supported himself driving a livery cab, but his car was stolen. After that, diabetes and depression sapped his will to go on. He lived off his savings, and when that ran out, fell into a life of panhandling. "I often begged God to let me die," he said. "But somehow, I survived." He refused to return to Israel, he said, because "there is nothing there for me except more sadness."
Last year, one of the businessmen who gives him weekly handouts inquired about his life. When the man, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, learned that Mr. Geda was sleeping on the subway, he decided he had to do more. "I was shocked at how Michael had suffered," he said. Last summer, the man found Mr. Geda an apartment and called several charities, asking them to pay part of the $500-a-month rent. He also persuaded several of his friends to chip in. "At least we now have a roof over Michael's head," the man said.
When he moved into the apartment last August, Mr. Geda said, he slept an entire week. "I was so hungry for a bed I did not want to get up," he said, revealing a rare smile. These days, his most cherished possession is his lease, which stays tucked deep within the breast pocket of his tattered pin-striped suit.
Gabriela Popovici, a case manager at Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, has been trying to help him track down his initial green card application, which could help him establish legal residence. The agency, another beneficiary of the Neediest Cases Fund, also paid a month of his rent.
Mr. Geda said he wants to remain in New York and is desperate to work. "I would even clean toilets if I had to," he said. "I just want to do something useful, to have someone to talk to during the day."

HEADLINE: Clinton Trip To New Jersey Raises Funds For Democrats

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 19

 BODY:
As President Clinton dined tonight at a $25,000-per-couple fund-raiser in the private home of a major contributor to the Democratic Party, dozens of antiwar protesters demonstrated outside the well-guarded gates of the exclusive Llewellyn Park section of West Orange, chanting, "We don't want a bloody war," and holding signs that urged, "No Bombs, No War Against Iraq."
During his formal remarks at the dinner, in the Georgian mansion of David Steiner, a real estate developer, and his wife, Sylvia, Mr. Clinton did not mention the situation in the Middle East and instead focused on domestic policy issues, reiterating many of the themes of his State of the Union Message last month. But during informal conversation over beef filet and potato terrine, Mr. Clinton said that more could have been done in the 1991 Persian Gulf war to weaken Saddam Hussein. 
"One thing he did say is during the Desert Storm war, if our troops had stayed there another half a day, they really could have disabled Saddam Hussein," Mrs. Steiner said, recounting the conversation at the table where she and her husband sat with the President.
"Of course," Mrs. Steiner said, "the people at our table are very supportive of how he feels about Iraq." The Steiners are staunch supporters of the Democratic Party and of Israel, and Mr. Steiner once was president of the American-Israel Public Affairs Committee, a lobbying group in Washington. Israel has solidly supported the use of military force against Iraq should Mr. Hussein not yield to United Nations weapons inspectors.
Nearly 50 guests were at the dinner, including Senator Frank R. Lautenberg; Representative William J. Pascrell Jr.; James E. McGreevey, a former Democratic candidate for New Jersey governor; Thomas P. Giblin, the state Democratic Party chairman, and Steve Grossman, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee. The event raised more than $400,000 for the party's national committee, which is still about $9 million in debt from the 1996 Presidential campaign.
Over dinner, Mr. Clinton and the Steiners also spoke about Stanford University, where Chelsea Clinton is a freshman and where two of the Steiners' children received their undergraduate educations. "He said his daughter loves Stanford," Mrs. Steiner said. She added that the guests were charmed by the President: "Everyone gets a high meeting him; he's so warm and very likable."
Mr. Clinton's motorcade entered the wooded enclave of Llewellyn Park through a rear entrance and did not pass the demonstrators. "I don't have the time, but I feel it's important," said Richard Franke, 53, of Montclair, who is an anthropology professor at Montclair State University and a member of the New Jersey Green Party. Mr. Franke was standing on a sloping patch of grass holding an antiwar placard, near the driveway of the gated entrance to Llewellyn Park, an affluent enclave where Thomas Edison once lived.
The standoff with Iraq was not the only issue on protesters' minds. Stephen Bauer, 43, a janitor from West Caldwell, carried a sign that said, "Impeach Clinton Now," and gave a phone number, "1-888-LEAVE-DC." Mr. Bauer said that he was part of the North Jersey Impeach Clinton Action Committee and that he disliked the President because of allegations of improper fund-raising by the Democrats.
Across Main Street and on the other side of the political spectrum, Dennis Cassidy, a carpet cleaner from West Orange, said he had come out on a chilly evening because he is a dedicated supporter of Mr. Clinton. "I think he is a great man," he said. "Why do these people want him impeached? He's done a lot of good for this country in the last six years."
Mr. Cassidy said he supported the use of force against Iraq. "I think every country looks to this man to do the job that they don't have the heart to do," he said of Mr. Clinton.
In a 23-minute speech, Mr. Clinton spoke to the dinner guests about his record and about the economy and education. He said he had tried to change the Democratic Party and "caused a little bit of controversy along the way." He spoke about international trade as the last remaining ideological battle within the Democratic Party, although Congressional leaders have said that there will likely be no action on trade legislation this year.
He spoke of the possibilities afforded to the United States as a country where religion and government are separate. "The United States has an unbelievable opportunity to sail against the tide of racial, ethnic and religious conflicts dominating the world," he said. And though he did not mention the money raised tonight, he told them, "I am proud to be a Democrat and I am proud of your support."

HEADLINE: Budgets and Asterisks

 BODY:

To the Editor:
John Cogan (Op-Ed, Feb. 18) might have tempered his criticism of President Clinton's budget proposal had he first reviewed the budgets he helped prepare as a deputy budget director in the Reagan Administration.
Included in the 1981 budget was the "magic asterisk," the footnote in a long table of numbers suggesting that the Reagan budget would be balanced shortly on the basis of "additional savings to be identified later." Shortly turned out to be not two, but almost 20 years and two administrations later, after an accumulation of an additional $3 trillion in national debt. 
 The Clinton budgets have typically included conservative economic assumptions, a crucial element in putting our fiscal house in order. Conditions are more favorable to a resolution of the impending Social Security crisis than they have been in years.
 
DAVID C. SANDAHL
Plainsboro, N.J., Feb. 18, 1998
 
The writer was a civil servant with the Office of Management and Budget from 1978 to 1984.

HEADLINE: Charles Cogen Dies at 94; Led Teachers in New York

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Charles Cogen, the first president of the New York City teachers' union and the leader of a one-day strike in 1960 that won bargaining rights for the city's public-school teachers, died Wednesday. He was 94.
Mr. Cogen died of Parkinson's disease in a retirement home in Washington, family members said. 
 After heading the city's teachers' union, the United Federation of Teachers, he was elected president of its parent, the American Federation of Teachers. As head of those two organizations, Mr. Cogen played a pivotal role in forming a vigorous union and a strong voice for the nation's teachers, who before 1960 rarely had the right to negotiate contracts through collective bargaining.
In 1960, Mr. Cogen spearheaded the first citywide teachers' strike, and two years later, he led a short strike that pressured Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. to agree to salaries and other contract terms that made teachers elsewhere envious.
Mr. Cogen inspired teachers with his fiery speeches and forceful arguments, and under him, the city's teachers won contracts and demonstrated militancy that served as models for teachers around the nation. He did this in an era when many teachers thought it unprofessional to strike and when the leaders of most other unions looked askance at teachers' forsaking their pupils and taking to the streets. In addition, state law then, as it does now, barred walkouts by public employees
Indeed, Mr. Cogen was often attacked for urging teachers to strike, facing accusations that he, and the teachers, were greedy lawbreakers who set a woeful example for American schoolchildren. Defending himself and teacher militancy, he said in a 1959 interview, "Students will have more respect for teachers who stand up and fight for their rights."
Mr. Cogen often related that he developed his love for labor early in this century when he went to union rallies with his father, a garment worker and ardent unionist.
Mr. Cogen called for national education standards to prod all American schools to improve their performance. Three decades ago, he proposed merging the American Federation of Teachers and its larger rival, the National Education Association, which the two unions finally -- and tentatively -- agreed to last month.
"Charlie was an extraordinary leader, truly ahead of his time," said Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers. "He helped win bargaining rights for teachers in New York City, and under his leadership, many other teacher unions secured that right."
Charles Cohen -- he changed his name to Cogen around 1930, family members said -- was born on Manhattan's Lower East Side on Oct. 31, 1903, the son of Joseph and Bessie Cohen.
Mr. Cogen, who said he was shy as a child, went to Boys High School in Brooklyn and won a scholarship to Cornell University, where he majored in economics, graduating in 1924. He became an elementary-school teacher by day in Brooklyn, and at night attended Fordham University Law School, from which he obtained a degree in 1927.
Dissatisfied with teaching conditions, he started practicing law in 1930, intent on being a lawyer for the working man, but after three years of struggling during the Depression, he abandoned the law. During those three years, he obtained a master's degree in economics from Columbia University. In 1930, he married Tess Schnittkramer, a lawyer and educator who became a professor at Pace University.
After leaving the law, Mr. Cogen returned to teaching, taking a "teacher in training" position for $4.50 a day in Queens, with no vacation or tenure. He became a substitute and then a regular teacher, spending 5 years at Grover Cleveland High School in Queens and 13 years at the Bronx High School of Science.
In 1959, he was elected president of the New York City Teachers Guild, a 2,000-member division of the American Federation of Teachers. It was one of the 100 different, competing groupings representing the city's 44,000 teachers.
In March 1960, the Guild merged with the High School Teachers Association to form the United Federation of Teachers, which elected him as its president.
Later that year, the new union asked the New York City Board of Education for recognition as the bargaining agent for the city's teachers. But the board balked, and Mr. Cogen led a one-day strike by 5,500 teachers.
Mayor Wagner appointed a committee to investigate the dispute, and the committee recommended a representation election, in which Mr. Cogen's union bested two rivals to represent all the city's teachers.
When contract talks deadlocked in 1962, the union went on strike and 22,000 teachers walked out. The next day, the strike ended, and the city soon agreed to the the first comprehensive teachers' contract in the nation.
It provided a $1,000 salary increase, establishing a salary scale of $5,300 to $9,970, and it also provided a grievance procedure with binding arbitration. The next year, Mr. Cogen signed another agreement that provided a new wage increase and placed the first limits ever on class size.
Mr. Cogen was elected president of the American Federation of Teachers in 1964. In his four years as president -- he retired in 1968 -- the teachers' federation grew rapidly, as it poured money and energy into organizing drives to attract teachers who were warming up to unionism.
After his retirement, he continued to advise union leaders and served on numerous boards, including the Jewish Labor Committee, Americans for Democratic Action and the United States National Commission for Unesco. He and his wife moved to Washington in 1991. His wife died in 1993 at 89.
Mr. Cogen is survived by 2 sons, Joel, of New Haven, and Edward, of Washington; 4 grandchildren, and 10 great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Sunday at 12:30 P.M. at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles Cogen during a New York City teachers' strike in 1962. (Eddie Hausner/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: North Light In Winter: Sibelius

BYLINE: By James R. Oestreich 

 BODY:
Here are some favorite Sibelius recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $15.99 for a single disk to $25.98 for a two-disk set or $40 for a four-disk package. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)
 
James R. Oestreich
SYMPHONIES NOS. 1-7. -- Finnish Radio Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jukka-Pekka Saraste (Finlandia 4509-99963-2; three CD's). 
 SYMPHONIES NOS. 1, 2, 3, 5; "TAPIOLA"; OTHER WORKS. -- London Symphony Orchestra and unnamed orchestra, conducted by Robert Kajanus (Finlandia 4509-95882-2; three CD's).
"KULLERVO." -- Marianna Rorholm, soprano; Jorma Hynninen, baritone; Los Angeles Philharmonic and Helsinki University Chorus, conducted by Esa-Pekka Salonen (Sony Classical SK 52563; CD).
ORCHESTRAL SONGS. -- Mari Anne Haggander, soprano; Mr. Hynninen, baritone; Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jorma Panula (Bis 270; CD).
VIOLIN CONCERTO. -- Gidon Kremer, violinist; London Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Gennady Rozhdestvensky (with Alfred Schnittke's Concerto Grosso No. 1; RCA Victor 9026-60957-2; CD).
I AM sorry to have missed Colin Davis's performances of several Sibelius symphonies with the London Symphony in December at Avery Fisher Hall. I am sorrier still to have missed Jukka-Pekka Saraste's performances of all seven symphonies with the Finnish Radio Symphony over four days in May 1993 at Philharmonia Hall in St. Petersburg, Russia. But I know that only because Finlandia has documented the occasion with live recordings, economically packaged in a three-disk set.
In general, these versions are more compelling than the studio recordings of symphonies and other orchestral works by Sibelius that Mr. Saraste and the orchestra made for RCA. The conductor shows a consistent involvement and sense of spontaneity here, and the orchestra, not surprisingly, plays with a ready responsiveness to Sibelius's style, at times lean and transparent, at others lush and billowing, yet with never a loss of incisiveness or clarity.
Other recordings of individual symphonies may be preferable to some here. Osmo Vanska's recent version of the Fifth with the Lahti Symphony, cited above by Paul Griffiths, for example, surpasses even Mr. Saraste's in capturing Sibelius's trademark evolutionary process. Still, Mr. Saraste is a reliable guide through these works, and more: a stimulating companion.
Another valuable perspective on several of the symphonies and other works is offered in recordings from 1930 and 1932 by Robert Kajanus, an older friend and drinking companion of Sibelius's. Apart from Sibelius's own remarkable recording of the "Andante Festivo," also cited by Mr. Griffiths, these documents are as close as we can get to the source in terms of Sibelius performance.
Kajanus was also a composer, and, typical of the breed, not a virtuosic conductor. Several of these items are therefore less valuable as finished performances than as models to reopen a range of possibilities in Sibelius performance (with, among other things, more extreme tempos than we are now used to). Still, some of them, like the mercurial reading of the shamefully undervalued Third Symphony, hold up well.
An obvious exception to that slight of conducting composers is Esa-Pekka Salonen, a podium virtuoso indeed, as he shows in a powerful account of the youthful symphonic poem with voices, "Kullervo." Given the present popularity of Sibelius's symphonies, it is surprising that this rich and fascinating work is not better known.
Another superb disk combining orchestra and voices features the fine conductorial hand of Jorma Panula, the guru now in residence at the Carnegie Hall workshop. Not incidentally, it also features the work of two excellent singers, Mari Anne Haggander and Jorma Hynninen, including Mr. Hynninen's stunning rendition of the saga "The Rapids-Shooters' Brides."
Listeners' tastes in the Violin Concerto will run toward their favorite fiddlers. But everyone should appreciate Gidon Kremer's latest version, with Gennady Rozhdestvensky and the London Symphony. Mr. Kremer's seemingly cool sensibility opens into a deep well of subtle warmth and keen intelligence, and thus matches Sibelius's perfectly.

HEADLINE: Paid Maternity Leave Can Punish Workers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "U.N. Surveys Paid Leave for Mothers" (news article, Feb. 16), you point out that the United States is one of only six countries not "requiring paid maternity leave." In contrast, 146 countries mandate such benefits by law. Despite this legal protection, one author of the United Nations study complains that discrimination against pregnant women remains widespread. Why? 
 By making it more costly to employ young women, such misguided laws lead to lower wages and restricted job opportunities for women. Compare the United States' 4.7 percent unemployment rate to those of some more "generous" countries: Canada, 10 percent; Italy, 12 percent, and Spain, 22 percent.
As a woman of childbearing age, I am happy to trade a legally imposed guarantee of paid maternity leave for a greater chance of landing a well-paying job.
 
KAROL BOUDREAUX
Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y.
Feb. 16, 1998
 
The writer is director of programs, Foundation for Economic Education.

HEADLINE: H. Gardner Ackley, 82, Dies; Presidential Economic Adviser

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
H. Gardner Ackley, an economics adviser to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, and a United States Ambassador to Italy, died in Ann Arbor, Mich., on Feb. 12. Professor Ackley, who retired in 1984 after 43 years as a member of the economics department at the University of Michigan, was 82.
Appointed to the President's Council of Economic Advisers by President Kennedy in 1962, Professor Ackley was named chairman of the council in 1964 by President Johnson, serving four years. 
 Although a believer in the Government's ability to manage the economy through fiscal and monetary fine-tuning -- a belief disputed by classical economic theorists -- Professor Ackley did not favor unlimited Government involvement. As chairman of the council, he did not shy away from publicly chastising business and labor for price increases and wage increases exceeding the Government's guidelines, but he said the damage that would be done by the imposition of direct wage and price controls would outweigh that of continued large wage and price increases.
Further, in an interview shortly before becoming president of the American Economics Association in 1982, he defended the Government's role in the economy as constructive, but added, "Substantial further regulation would be a step backward."
Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel laureate and professor emeritus of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said, "He was one of the leading macro-economists of the time." His textbook, "Macroeconomic Theory" (1961), was widely used by graduate students.
But Professor Ackley's finest moment, according to Professor Samuelson, was in telling President Johnson in 1966 that the nation could not afford the escalation of the Vietnam War and the Great Society programs without a tax increase -- an increase that was not enacted until 1968, and for which delay, Professor Samuelson said, "We paid dearly in the inflation of the 1970's."
"He never told the press what he told the President," Professor Samuelson said, "but President Johnson included it in his memoirs. I can't think of a better epitaph than that. It took guts, because usually people tell a President what he wants to hear."
Writing of that incident in 1983, Professor Ackley said the basic responsibility of the Council of Economic Advisers was to provide the President with policy advice based on the best available economic knowledge. The council chairman, he added, "should privately give him his best professional judgments, along with appropriate cautions about the inherent limitations of his knowledge."
Born in Indianapolis on June 30, 1915, H. Gardner Ackley grew up in Kalamazoo, Mich., where his father was a professor of mathematics at Western Michigan University. His mother was a high school Latin teacher. After majoring in history and English at Western Michigan, from which he graduated in 1936, he switched to economics at the University of Michigan to get a fellowship, which he was told was more readily available than fellowships for history or English.
"I also had a general resentment against the Depression," he said, "and felt there must be a way and that economics must be it."
Soon after earning his Ph.D. in 1940, Professor Ackley joined the economics department at the University of Michigan. In 1941 he joined the staff of the Office of Price Administration, beginning an on-again, off-again relationship with official Washington that was to last three decades. His last position was two years as Ambassador to Italy, to which he was appointed in 1968. He had previously spent 1956-57 as a Fulbright scholar in Italy, and 1961-62 there on a Ford Foundation faculty research fellowship.
His other Washington duties included consultant to the Economic Stabilization Agency in 1950 and assistant director of the Office of Price Stabilization in 1951-52, during the Korean War.
Professor Ackley is survived by his wife of 61 years, the former Bonnie Lowry, of Ann Arbor; two sons, David, of Bologna, Italy, and Donald, of Williamsburg, Va.; one sister, Margaret, and five grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: H. Gardner Ackley (The New York Times, 1971)

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: IN KUWAIT;
Little Fear Is Shown By Troops Near Border

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: ABDALI, Kuwait, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Sipping cardamom coffee in his tent just two miles from the Iraqi border, Sgt. Saad Ashban of the Kuwaiti interior forces said he had no fear that an American-led attack on Iraq would put him or his men in danger.
It has been five years now since Sergeant Ashban took up his post at the edge of the demilitarized zone between Iraq and Kuwait. In that time he has watched tensions in the region reach crisis level three times, with the United States sending heavy reinforcements to the emirate in 1994, 1996 and again this year. 
 But perhaps more now than ever before, Kuwaitis appear confident that if Saddam Hussein fails to heed United Nations resolutions, the United States is determined to deliver the kind of military punch that would make it difficult for Baghdad to retaliate against Kuwait.
All around this tiny outpost, buildings reduced to rubble by Iraq's 1990 invasion provide reminders of the destruction then, and the miles of berms and trenches on either side of the border are proof of Kuwait's lingering uncertainties that Baghdad might one day send its troops south again. But on a day when Secretary General Kofi Annan began a last-ditch mission to Baghdad in a bid to persuade Iraq to comply with United Nations demands, the mood among Kuwaiti troops near the border was decidedly relaxed.
"We have a saying in Islam that the Muslim never gets punched twice," Sergeant Ashban said, adding that the 1990 invasion had convinced Kuwait that it could insure its security only with the help of the United States.
To be sure, as the prospect of war has grown nearer, other Kuwaitis have turned somewhat jittery. In the last week there have been long lines at grocery stores, banks and gas stations as people stock up on supplies in case they need to make a run for the Saudi border as so many did eight years ago. Televised announcements offering instructions on how to prepare for an air attack have added to the apprehensions. Fears that Iraq might try to lob chemical or biological weapons toward Kuwait have prompted heavy demand for protective masks, for which private citizens must pay about $200 each.
Special security units have manned roadblocks across Kuwait and new positions outside the American and British embassies.
But today Abdali offered mostly visions of tranquillity. The vast, flat desert, left a delicate green by winter rains, was almost devoid of American and Kuwaiti troops. And the few Kuwaiti soldiers who could be found setting up a position well south of the border expressed no urgency.
"I think they will sort it out today," a Kuwaiti lieutenant who would identify himself only as Ahmed said, referring to the Secretary General's mission to Iraq..
American and Kuwaiti officials have said the devastation wrought by the Persian Gulf war in 1991 and the punishing economic sanctions have almost certainly left Iraqi forces too weak to contemplate retaliating against an American air strike with any kind of ground attack on Kuwait. But in what seems mostly an exercise in reassurance, the United States is sending what officials now say will be a total of 5,000 additional soldiers, marines and airmen to supplement the 1,500-member Army task force that is already here.
There are three dozen American combat planes -- including 12 F-117A Stealth aircraft, six F-16's and 18 A-10 tank-fighting jets -- now in place at Ahmed al-Jaber air base. Eight British Tornado bombers arrived early this week at another Kuwaiti base.
But Kuwaiti officials have expressed sensitivities about visits to those bases by American journalists, so the massing of military might is less apparent to visitors driving around the country than the sheep fattening themselves on fresh grass.
"There's nothing to be afraid of," Sgt. Nawaf Khalaft, another Kuwaiti border guard, said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall as Many Investors Stay on the Sidelines

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell for the second consecutive session in light trading yesterday.
Apprehension about a weekend meeting of finance chiefs of the leading industrial nations and next week's scheduled testimony from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, kept many investors on the sidelines. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 8/32 , to 103 20/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.87, from 5.85 percent on Thursday. Trading volume was about 36 percent below normal for a Friday this quarter, said Govpx, a bond pricing service.
Finance ministers and officials of the Group of Seven nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Canada and Italy -- are meeting this weekend in London. Some market participants were concerned yesterday that the meeting might produce a plan to help the Asian economies. For the Treasury market, which has been supported in recent months by foreign investors fleeing the turmoil on Asian markets, such a plan might stem the flow of money into United States bonds.
Bond investors were also waiting for Mr. Greenspan to give his semiannual testimony to Congress on Tuesday and Wednesday.
Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said he believed that Mr. Greenspan was likely to find vindication in December's widening trade deficit. The trade data, Mr. Chan said, may be a preview of the slowdown awaiting the United States economy because of the problems in Asia.
Still, Mr. Chan said, "The Fed chairman is likely to tell investors that the Fed will not be able to act in a pre-emptive fashion to head off the growth-dampening effects of the Asian crisis due to the ever tightening state of the U.S. labor markets."
The market is also bracing for new supply next week. On Tuesday the Government will sell $15 billion of new two-year notes, on Wednesday $11 billion of five-year notes and on Thursday $12 billion of a new 52-week bill.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.38 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 5.47 percent.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE U.N.;
U.N. Expands Quota for Iraq's Oil Sales

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Security Council today more than doubled the amount of oil that Baghdad will be allowed to sell to buy food, medicine and other goods desperately needed by the 22 million Iraqis living under United Nations sanctions.
The Council voted unanimously for a resolution initiated by Secretary General Kofi Annan on Feb. 2 that raises the current limit of $2 billion in oil sales every six months to $5.2 billion and allows some of the revenue to be used to pay for repairs to Iraq's dilapidated electricity, water and sanitation systems. 
 The resolution acknowledged that "the population of Iraq continues to face a very serious nutritional and health situation" after living with sanctions for seven years. A number of Council members also pointed out that Iraq's full cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors would make it possible for the sanctions to end.
The United States and Britain voted for the resolution, though they have threatened to resort to military force if Saddam Hussein does not comply with a Security Council resolution from 1991 that obliges Iraq to grant total access to the weapons inspectors.
The United States deputy representative, Peter Burleigh, said, "The United States is deeply concerned about the welfare of the Iraqi people, and we want to do everything we can to make sure their basic needs are met."
Several Security Council members complained about Iraq's lack of cooperation in drafting a new distribution plan.
Iraqi officials withheld comment on Mr. Annan's proposal for several days, then rejected portions of it, in part because the distribution of commodities is kept out of their hands, and because repairs to the electrical grid are confined to an area of northern Iraq under Kurdish control.
The Iraqi officials also contend that aging equipment and a lack of spare parts make it impossible to pump as much as $5.2 billion of oil in six months.
The resolution instructs the Secretary General to empanel a group of experts to determine how much oil Iraq can produce.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Under Pressure, Indonesia Halts Currency Plan

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Pressed by foreign governments and by the power of the international marketplace, Indonesia retreated today from a highly criticized plan to strengthen its ravaged currency.
The pullback came in a carefully worded statement from Finance Minister Marie Muhammad, who made clear that the nation would not immediately proceed with the creation of a currency board. 
 President Suharto had embraced the plan as a silver-bullet solution to the country's economic crisis, despite criticism from the United States and other industrial nations that it could backfire and plunge Indonesia into even worse straits. The International Monetary Fund had indicated it might cancel a $40 billion financial rescue package if Mr. Suharto proceeded with the plan.
A currency board would have sought to stabilize the foreign-exchange rate of the Indonesian rupiah, which has lost more than 70 percent of its value since the Asian financial crises began last summer and left many Indonesian debtors unable to repay foreign loans.
The board would have pegged the rupiah's value at an artificial rate of 5,000 to the dollar, nearly twice its current worth, by increasing interest rates and intervening in the markets to buy rupiah with dollars. The I.M.F. and other critics contended that the Indonesian Government lacked the credibility and vast amounts of dollars required to make the plan work.
In a face-saving formulation that nevertheless indicated the power of foreign pressure, Mr. Marie said, "During this process of currency board system preparation, the President is carefully watching developments offshore and onshore."
He added, "In relation to this, the Government will always maintain relations with international institutions including the I.M.F."
The Finance Minister said that work was continuing to set up a framework for a currency board, and analysts said that one could still be put into effect when Indonesia's economy and politics were more stable.
Still, the sense that confrontation has been defused was evident at the I.M.F. in Washington, where officials interpreted the Indonesian statement positively. "I hope now that the currency board seems to be moving off the table -- that we can get back to doing what has to be done in that country," said Stanley Fischer, the fund's deputy managing director.
But Mr. Marie confirmed a retreat that had slowly been emerging in official statements, from early hopes for a quick solution. Such an outcome had been lobbied for aggressively by an American economist here, Steve Hanke. Mr. Hanke, a currency-board enthusiast who appears to have had the ear of Mr. Suharto for the last two weeks, had argued that a board had to be created immediately for it to work its effect on the economy.
His argument was that by artificially setting a rate for the rupiah around double its market value, businesses could begin to repay their debts and the economy could start to function more normally. The statement released today suggested that Mr. Hanke had lost that argument.
Indonesian analysts said the Government's concession to international pressure was a painful acknowledgment that the nation was no longer free to determine its economic policy independently of the will of foreign markets.
"They understand that foreign governments' role is going to be critical because we cannot go it alone," said Jusuf Wanandi, director here of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. "This is a very critical period in which external pressure is a necessity to keep us from heading down the wrong path."
Since the rupiah began its slide in July, Indonesia's economy and politics have increasingly been influenced by foreign investors' sentiments and the dictates of the I.M.F.
When Mr. Suharto announced a budget early in January that was based on optimistic assumptions, the markets reacted with disbelief and the rupiah fell 26 percent in a single day, causing panic buying and calls for the President's resignation.
The following week, Mr. Suharto bowed to the verdict of the markets and signed a tough new austerity package formulated with the guidance of the I.M.F.
But he has seemed to resist the full application of much of the agreement, and the currency-board idea was seen as a new attempt to dodge the tough measures he had agreed to.
Yet one foreign analyst suggested that today's concession was as much a bargain with the I.M.F. as a retreat. Given Indonesia's importance, he said, the concessions must work both ways.
"The most realistic thing was always going to be a compromise," said the analyst, Rajeev Malik, an economist with Jardine Fleming in Singapore. "My own reading is that it was a big game of poker to try and get some concessions out of the I.M.F."
Mr. Malik suggested that President Suharto might be seeking to delay an agreed-upon timetable for eliminating price supports on basic commodities. Rising prices have already caused dozens of riots throughout the country.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tokyo Stimulus Fails to Draw Rave Reviews

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Japan's ruling party today announced its fourth package of economic stimulants in the last four months, but the initiatives ignored bolder steps to improve the economy that have been urged by the United States and other countries.
Analysts said the actions announced today would provide a modest lift for Asia but fell well short of what was needed at home. Japan's reluctance to stimulate domestic demand with big public works projects and tax cuts also set up a potentially awkward confrontation with the United States and other members of the Group of Seven industrialized countries, which are meeting this weekend in London. 
 The only significant economic support was $2.36 billion in emergency loans to other Asian economies, apparently aimed at answering criticism that Japan was not doing enough to help stressed neighbors.
"People were just hoping against hope that they would throw in a bone," said Peter Morgan, senior economist at HSBC Securities Japan Ltd. "There were a lot of false hopes."
American officials have been particularly critical of the reluctance of Japan to aggressively stimulate its economy by putting more money into the pockets of Japanese consumers. On Thursday, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin suggested that tax cuts would be an option for Japan. The Government has already announced a one-time income tax cut worth $15.7 billion, but critics contend a temporary reduction is insufficient.
Today's package, the fourth devised by the Liberal Democratic Party since October, included measures to help ease the difficulty in getting credit and to revive the property market, devastated by a slide in prices that has bankrupted many builders and left banks holding hundreds of billions of dollars in bad loans.
The package would encourage the purchase of second homes and make it easier for banks to divest themselves of property held as collateral for bad loans. The banks would be able to bundle these loans into bonds known as asset-backed securities, which investors and the Government would purchase.
One measure in the package would encourage companies to buy back their stock as a means to help lift the stock market, while another measure would allow banks to revalue their landholdings and fold unrealized profits into their capital base to increase their capital strength.
One element of the package that analysts said was promising was the consideration of changing corporate pension funds so that retirement payments were based more on returns on investment, rather than on a rigid formula.
But the measures failed to excite the Japanese stock market, which fell to a one-month low Wednesday in anticipation of disappointment and has barely moved since. Today the Nikkei 225 index rose 139.76 points, or 0.84 percent, to 16,756.24. In a further reflection of investor disenchantment, the yen fell to a one-month low against the dollar, which rose to 128 yen compared with 126.16 Thursday.
Announcement of the measures came one day before a meeting in London of finance ministers from the Group of Seven countries -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States.
Japan's Finance Minister, Hikaru Matsunaga, is likely to face questions from his counterparts over why the world's second-largest economy is failing to play a significant role in supporting economic growth in its region and around the world.
Japan has been trying to give its economy a lift with as little spending as possible to help reduce its large fiscal deficit.
But Masakazu Sakaguchi, chief of the research division at the Finance Ministry's Budget Bureau, said the Government was also flexible, adding, "Whether additional measures are necessary or not, we need to watch the economy very carefully."
The Government hinted today that it was ready to start drawing up a fiscal stimulus package in the form of a supplementary budget for 1998, according to Kyodo News Service.
It was difficult for the ruling party to financially back its proposals today because the general 1998 budget has not yet been passed by the Parliament. Any special stimulus for the economy would probably come in the form of a supplementary budget, which could only pass after the general budget was approved.

Stock Rally Resumes After One-Day Pullback
The stock market staged a comeback yesterday from a Thursday retreat that ended the Dow Jones industrial average's six-day streak of record highs. The Dow average recovered about half its Thursday loss, closing up 38.36 points at 8,413.94. 
 Broader averages also rose and the Standard & Poor's 500 index managed to close at a record high of 1,034.21, up 5.93 points. The Nasdaq stock market's marginal gain of 1.12 points, to 1,728.13, masked the voracious demand for shares in the initial public offering of Doubleclick, an Internet advertising company that is one of the technology-laden market's newest members. Its shares rose 57 percent from the offering price of $17 to close at $26.75 after trading as high as $31.75 early in the day. D3.
 
Open positions of short sales in stocks, which can be an indication of increased bearishness, rose during the most recent period on both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange. D14
 
Treasury securities fell for the second day in light trading, reflecting apprehension about a weekend meeting of the Group of Seven finance ministers and Congressional testimony scheduled next week for Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond rose to 5.87 percent from 5.85. D3.
 
Theater Deal Scrapped
Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., the Dallas investment firm that has sought to expand its holdings of movie theaters, ended an agreement to buy the United Artists Theater Group for $850 million from an investment group led by Merrill Lynch. Hicks did not explain why it had ended the deal but said the decision would not affect its agreement with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company to buy Regal Cinemas for $1.5 billion. D2.
 
Skepticism on Tokyo Stimulus Plan
Japan's ruling party announced its fourth package of economic stimulants in the last four months, but the initiatives ignored bolder steps to improve the economy that have been urged by the United States and others. D2.
 
Bond Whistle Blower Settles
Michael R. Lissack, a former Smith Barney official who for years has sought to expose what he has called widespread fraud in the municipal bond market, agreed to settle S.E.C. civil charges that he had committed fraud himself when underwriting a municipal bond issue in 1994. D2.
 
Canceled Plane Penalty
General Dynamics and Boeing are entitled to $1.2 billion from the Government for the improper 1991 termination of the A-12 stealth attack aircraft they had been building, a Federal judge ruled. D3.
 
Columbia/HCA Pharmacy Unit Sold
Express Scripts, a leading independent pharmacy benefit management company, is purchasing ValueRx, the pharmacy benefit management unit of Columbia/HCA Healthcare, for about $445 million. D2.
 
Indonesia to Repay Bank Deposits
Indonesia will repay all the deposits stored at the 16 banks that were closed in November, totaling 3.1 trillion rupiah. Finance Minister Marie Muhammad said the deposits would be repaid by the central bank and reimbursed by the Government over 10 years. D2.
 
Hong Kong Credit Rating Falls
Hong Kong's short-term credit rating was cut for the first time in 14 years by Moody's Investors Service, reflecting increased risk faced by the territory's financial markets from Asia's economic crisis. D2.
 
Trade Deal with Taiwan
The United States reached an agreement with Taiwan that will open the domestic Taiwan market to American products and services. The deal will help promote Taiwan's effort to join the World Trade Organization. D3.

HEADLINE: Writer's Troubling Look at Face of Troubled Youth

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
The night she calls "the children's riot," was a turning point for Cristina Rathbone. She was living in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, when she found herself in a liquor store among dusty, overpriced bottles, watching a retarded man flee a beating by a group of prepubescent boys. The man used the store as a sanctuary, and the door was locked against the boys throwing bricks and bottles.
"They were so small," Ms. Rathbone said. "They hadn't started shaving, and they had these high, baby voices. But they were the same boys who called me names as I walked to and from the subway. I realized that I, like a lot of New Yorkers, was becoming afraid of young people. I asked myself, who are these kids?" 
 Ms. Rathbone, a 32-year-old journalist, pursued that question by spending an academic year at West Side High School in midtown Manhattan, exploring the lives of its poor black and Hispanic students. She has turned her interviews and experiences into a book, "On the Outside Looking In: A Year at an Inner City High School" (Atlantic Monthly Press).
"I want to get people who aren't really interested in this subject to read the book," said Ms. Rathbone, who grew up in London, the daughter of an Englishman and a Cuban woman.
"On the Outside" uses pseudonyms to describe West Side's students, who must cope with homelessness, drug-addicted parents, their own children and gang violence.
Ms. Rathbone, a graduate of New York University film school who admits she had never even had a conversation with an inner-city teen-ager before her book project, said she admired the grace and strength of many of the young people as they tried to survive the chaos of their lives. Others bewildered her.
She writes about Lucille, for instance, a girl who had attempted murder at least once. During Ms. Rathbone's first days at West Side, Lucille persuaded Ms. Rathbone to borrow a pair of scissors for her. Although Ed Reynolds, the principal, was able to get the scissors back, Ms. Rathbone recalls "being scared to death," when she found out later that Lucille had intended to use the scissors to stab her mother.
During the year, Ms. Rathbone found herself waiting with a student during a pregnancy test, discovering that another was homeless, and hearing another brag about how much money he made selling chemicals doctored to look like heroin. She also heard their tales of being raped or beaten, as well as their dreams of marriage, finishing high school and learning to drive.
Those were the survivors. Mr. Reynolds told Ms. Rathbone shortly after she arrived about the students he had lost in the previous year. Six were shot, one died of AIDS, one had his leg sliced off by a subway car, running from police officers after a robbery attempt.
Ms. Rathbone, who came to the United States in 1984, said she believed she was well qualified to write about rebellious youth because of her own adolescent escapades. She sold drugs and was kicked out of five London high schools before she found herself in an alternative school where she fit. Because of her Cuban heritage, she was often the lone brown-skinned person in British social circles, she said.
Her sojourn at West Side, she said, made her realize that the difference between herself and the students was the safety net of a family with economic wherewithal (her father was a member of Parliament) and well-defined values.
Ms. Rathbone writes in the book about feeling nauseated as she made the daily subway trip to school, not quite knowing what she would find each day and feeling herself inexorably drawn into the lives of the students. She ended some days with a stiff drink, she recalls, and wondered how much of her own background and feelings she should share with students.
"By the end of nine months, I was fried," said Ms. Rathbone, who lives with her husband, Anton Mueller, a book editor, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. "I could never do what those teachers did. I was really involved with a number of kids, but I hadn't been able to have a visible, sustained effect on any of the kids' lives."
She was able to look at a group of young people and see individuals instead of statistics, she said, as opposed to the reflexive avoidance she practiced before and right after the children's riot. At the same time, Ms. Rathbone said, she came to realize that the complex problem of changing the schools hinged on first changing the social and economic realities of the students' lives.
How, for example, do you convince a 16-year-old girl not to have a baby when both her mother and grandmother were 16 when they had their children? Or how do you convince black and Hispanic young people that they can go as far as their abilities will take them when they don't know anyone who is economically successful?
"Our world is as hallucinatory to them as theirs is to us," Ms. Rathbone said.
For herself, the first step was writing a book that would allow the rest of America to understand who these young people are.
"This was the only way I could do it," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cristina Rathbone, the author of a book about inner city high school students. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL A3-5
 
U.N. Team Discounts Sites As Annan Lands in Baghdad
United Nations experts issued a report in Baghdad that portrayed the Iraqi sites off-limits to weapons inspectors as less threatening than Washington and the disarmament inspectors had indicated. American officials said the report was irrelevant. Secretary General Kofi Annan arrived in Baghdad for talks with Iraqi leaders that were seen as the last chance to avoid an American military strike. A4 

The Security Council more than doubled the amount of oil that Baghdad may sell every six months to pay for food, medicine and some repairs. A4
 
New Figures on NATO Budget
A Pentagon report has found that the direct costs of absorbing Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic into an expanded NATO will be much lower than previously estimated, Clinton Administration officials said. Those critical of plans to enlarge the alliance contended that the new figures were a cynical ploy to muster support for a Senate vote. A3
 
Sinn Fein Expelled for 17 Days
The Irish and British Governments expelled Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., from the Northern Ireland peace talks. The Sinn Fein President, Gerry Adams, called the action "disgraceful." In an effort to stave off violent reactions from Roman Catholics in the north, the suspension was limited to 17 days, provided the I.R.A. did not engage in further violence. Hours later, a bomb exploded in a Protestant village outside Belfast. A3
 
North Korea Rejects Peace Call
North Korea rejected an idea being floated by new South Korean leaders for the United States, Russia, China and Japan to join the two Koreas in issuing a declaration of peace. Kim Jong-pil, the expected prime minister of the incoming South Korean Government, said the declaration was the idea of President-elect Kim Dae-jung, and that his Government would propose it after taking office next Wednesday. (AP)
 
Trucks Roar in Brazilian Park
Hundreds of farmers have invaded a national park in Brazil and illegally built a road near the monumental Iguacu falls that straddle the Brazil-Argentine border, Brazil's environmental agency said. The Government was said to be considering evicting local people by force after receiving news that heavy trucks were crossing the park with goods including agrochemicals. (Reuters)
 
Push for Affirmative Action
The South African Government vowed to press ahead with planned affirmative-action laws. The laws are intended to force companies and government departments to reshape their work forces by hiring blacks and others who were oppressed under white rule and are still underrepresented in many areas of South African life. Though no quota system is planned, opposition parties say that the economy will suffer if skilled white workers lose jobs to less experienced replacements. (AP)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Short-Term Credit Rating Lowered for Hong Kong

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Hong Kong's short-term credit rating was cut yesterday for the first time in 14 years as Moody's Investors Service Inc. warned that the territory's financial markets faced more risk from Asia's economic turmoil. Moody's cut the rating to Prime-2, the first reduction since it assigned a Prime-1 rating to Hong Kong in 1984. The ratings company, based in New York, also cut its long-term Hong Kong outlook to "negative" from "stable." 
 The cuts, which are likely to raise borrowing costs for the Hong Kong Government, companies and consumers, reflect further volatility after Asian currencies tumbled.

HEADLINE: Why Drug Makers Court Consumers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Feb. 17 front-page article missed one important reason why the makers of psychiatric drugs are aggressively courting consumers. A company need not reveal to consumers what most doctors know: that its psychotropic drugs may differ very little from a competitor's drug. 
 For example, there is no reason even a highly educated individual with major depression would know that Prozac, a safe and effective antidepressant, is no more effective or economical than Zoloft or Paxil. The drug manufacturers are clearly banking on the consumers' lack of critical knowledge to gain a competitive edge in a very tight market.
 
RICHARD A. FRIEDMAN, M.D.
New York, Feb. 17, 1998
 
The writer is director of the psychopharmacology clinic at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

HEADLINE: The Accidental Inventor of Today's Capitalism;
Jean-Baptiste Say, No Longer a Villain, Stands Guard Over Free Markets

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
He came of age in the French Revolution. In the spirit of the times, he greatly admired Benjamin Franklin and Thomas Jefferson. And when the Bourbons managed to get their throne back in 1814, a discouraged Jean-Baptiste Say almost emigrated to America. He even wrote to Jefferson, asking how much he would have to pay to purchase a working cotton farm near Jefferson's own Virginia spread.
"I specify the neighborhood of Charlottesville," Say wrote from his home in Paris, "because it is neither so close to the seaports to make the land too expensive, nor so distant as to present the rigors of a new settlement." 
 The Say family -- there were five children -- never came to America. Say considered himself too old, at 47, to go through such a stressful relocation. (Jefferson agreed.) But the economic theory he popularized in a French best seller eventually made the journey. And today a pithy "law of markets" that bears Say's name has become American capitalism's guiding aphorism. It stands as a warning against undue tinkering with markets, even when they are out of whack, as they are now, in Asia, in a particularly Saysian way.
What is arguably the most famous "law" in economics is just five words: "Supply creates its own demand." Build a field and the players will come. Manufacture 10 cars and the buyers will materialize. That is how markets work. Just leave them alone, let them be free, and demand will automatically meet supply at a robust level. The people who make the 10 cars, or supply the metal and parts that go into the cars, earn from their efforts the income to then buy the cars.
Say certainly believed this. So did most of the other great thinkers in the early days of the Industrial Revolution, before recessions and slumps had been recognized as the downside of capitalism or had entered very much into anyone's thinking. In the opening sentence of "The Wealth of Nations," Adam Smith, the father of free market capitalism, laid down virtually the same "law" as Say -- although taking 48 words to make the point.
Say, who died in 1832 at age 65, is one of the stranger figures in economic history. He never actually wrote "supply creates its own demand." His best seller, the "Treatise on Political Economy," published in 1803 -- seven years after Smith's great work -- is full of the concept, but not the famous five words.
"I do not see how the products of a nation in general can ever be too abundant, for each such product (through payment of wages, profits, etc.) provides the means for purchasing another," Say wrote. "The mass of products composes the mass of a nation's wealth, and wealth is no more inconvenient to nations than it is to private persons."
A century after the Frenchman's death, John Maynard Keynes attributed Say's law to Say, and made him famous. It was the Great Depression of the 1930's, and free market concepts were ripe for attack. Supply certainly was not creating its own demand. There was supply, but no buyers. And Keynes singled out Say, making him the foil for his own view of how markets work and the role government should play in keeping markets on track. Keynes was successful, but in making his case, he may have cut a corner or two, perhaps editing Say to suit his needs.
"Before Keynes, the way I would have heard about Say is not that supply creates its own demand but that overproduction is not possible," Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economics, said in an interview. He was a graduate student in 1936, the year that Keynes published his most famous work, "The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money," the book that elevated Jean-Baptiste Say to star villain status.
Mark Blaug, a British economist, agreed. "Say seems to us a tremendously important figure, but it is a case in which Keynes really elevated him," Mr. Blaug said. "What he was was a very good teacher of Adam Smith to French readers. In the 19th century, the French learned their Smith by reading Say. He was mainly a popularizer."
 
In Reality, a Model Of Flexibility
The irony is that of all the early 19th-century thinkers, Say was perhaps the most flexible. David Ricardo and James Mill were more dogmatic in their adherence to what is now known as Say's law of markets. And when Thomas Malthus objected to that law, Ricardo took him on far more than did Say, who could see two sides of an argument.
"If in a society composed of 10,000 families," Say wrote, "5,000 engaged in making crockery vases, and 5,000 in making shoes, this society would undoubtedly have too many vases and too many shoes, and would lack many things no less favorable to its well being. But it is also evident that this inconvenience would arise not from producing too much, but from not producing exactly what is wanted."
Say thought such distortions could occur, but not for long, not when people lack so much of everything. "I live at this moment in one of the richest regions of France," he wrote. "Yet of 20 houses there are 19 in which, on entering them, I see none but the coarsest food, nothing to serve the well being of families, none of the things that the English call comfortable; not enough beds for all members of the family to lie on, not enough furniture for them to sit at ease at their meals; not enough linen, nor of soap, for proper laundering, etc."
Malthus, the gloomiest thinker of his generation, is a pivotal figure in economic history, a sort of early Keynesian. He is most famous for his prediction that the demand for food would outrun the supply. He also argued that the supply of goods could outrun the demand for them, resulting in unemployment among the suppliers. Say eventually found some merit in Malthus's argument, and that angered Ricardo.
"The aphorism attributed to Say probably evolved over the decades after Say's lifetime," William Baumol, a Princeton economist and historian, said. "There is no one villain. But what is becoming increasingly clear to people who write about the history of ideas is that Keynes overstated what Say thought. Say in some sense is a victim of history."
Whatever the case, Ricardo won the great debate with Malthus. But nearly 200 years later, nothing is resolved. The central issue in economics is still this question: Will supply and demand balance on their own at a high enough level to put everyone to work? Or can the balance come at a much lower level, requiring government to step in with job-creating measures?
The 20th century opened with the Saysians in the great majority. From the early 1930's to the early 1980's, Malthus and Keynes, his spiritual descendant, held sway. A "mixed economy" became the standard -- part free market, part government intervention. Since then, however, Say's law has reasserted itself. Ricardo's initial victory is reflected today in deregulation, in the privatization of state enterprises, in the expanding global market and, most recently, in the commentary on the Asian crisis.
The Asian collapse is a result of too much government meddling, modern Saysians argue. The Korean Government, for example, pushed companies to borrow when they should not have borrowed and to manufacture too many cars, semiconductors, steel products and other things when there was no ready market for them. The markets, left to themselves, would have balanced supply and demand at a healthy level and Asia would not be in crisis today, the Saysians hold.
"If business people persist in producing the wrong things, for whatever reason, then you can have a situation where they cannot sell what they make," said Deirdre N. McCloskey, an economic historian at the University of Iowa.
 
Adjustments Made by Keynes
 Still, Keynes made a permanent dent in Saysian thinking. The argument evolved in this fashion:
Supply does create its own demand, as Say maintained, but under limited circumstances. When a farmer comes to market with a basket of eggs, a weaver with a bolt of cloth and a potter with a vase, each is offering his own "income" for sale to the others, in exchange for their incomes. Supply and income are interchangeable, and there cannot be too much supply, because the supply always generates the income to purchase it.
"For professional economists, there is this marvelous appeal of the nicely working model, the clockwork economy in which everything matches everything else," said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics. "If you believe in Say's law, then you can believe that there is no need for public policy, for a government role in the economy. Just stay out of the market's way."
The Saysian model assumes, however, that people accumulate income with the intention of spending it right away, if not on consumer goods, then on investment in a new loom, for instance, or a new factory -- another form of spending, financed through savings. There are other built-in assumptions. Lacking a role of its own, money is mainly a reflection of the value of goods and services. And interest rates adjust to the needs of the marketplace with its automatic matching of supply and demand.
Keynes changed the assumptions. Money, he argued, does have a role, and spending isn't automatic. When people become uncertain, or panicky, they keep their money, their incomes, in their pockets. And investors hold back when they don't anticipate an adequate return on their investments, even if savings are plentiful and interest rates low. Indeed, investment is independent of savings, in Keynes's view, coming first and generating income and savings in its wake.
 
What if Spenders Don't Spend?
 Supply, in any case, exceeds demand when spenders hold back. Prices can drop to offset this reluctance, and supply and demand can once again move into equilibrium. But if prices get so low that they wipe out profits and fail to cover costs, the new equilibrium will foster layoffs, cost-cutting, bankruptcy and unemployment.
Out of this thinking came a role for government. The Federal Reserve's periodic adjustments of the nation's interest rates are a now standardized meddling in the marketplace with the stated intention of promoting full employment, among other goals. And for all the cutbacks in welfare and other public programs, the Federal Government, not the marketplace, is still entrenched as the provider of unemployment pay for the jobless, numerous subsidies for business, and health insurance for the poor and elderly.
Say would have been surprised. Government had become an obstacle for him. While he welcomed the French Revolution and the new freedom it brought, Napoleon was trouble. The two men differed on taxes and tariffs, both of which Napoleon imposed, and on trade, which Napoleon restricted over Say's objections. When Say's famous "Treatise on Political Economy" appeared, Napoleon suppressed it for a while.
The return of Louis XVIII to the throne, after Napoleon's defeat, seemed to promise more government meddling, and a discouraged Say thought of emigration to America. "I would rather live in a free country," he wrote to Jefferson, "and can hardly flatter myself that this country will ever become such."

An article in the Arts and Ideas section on Saturday about the economic theory of Jean-Baptiste Say misstated the number of years between the publication of Adam Smith's "Wealth of Nations" and Say's "Treatise on Political Economy." Smith's book first appeared in 1776, 27 years before Say's treatise, not 7.
