HEADLINE: The Little Project That Couldn't;
Others Learn From a Failed Test in Worker Democracy

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: BOLIVAR, Tenn.

 BODY:
These days, the Harman Automotive Inc. rear-view-mirror factory here may seem like just another industrial casualty as it limps toward a final shutdown at the end of the month.
A quarter of a century ago, though, it was internationally renowned as the site of an audacious experiment in worker empowerment. The sad trail from then to now is filled with lessons about innovation, management and plain old human nature. 
 The Bolivar Project, as Harman's effort to tear down the adversarial walls between workers and management was known, attracted research grants from the Federal Government, leading universities and organizations like the Ford Foundation. The goals, considered revolutionary then, were to grant Harman employees increased job security and safety, recognize them as individuals with varying interests and needs and give them roles in decisions affecting work conditions and training.
So many corporate and labor union honchos trekked to this rural Hardeman County seat 90 miles east of Memphis to see the results that local managers finally set a quota of one group a week to limit the distraction. And Bolivar's early successes -- some carefully exaggerated by its backers -- soon encouraged the Big Three auto makers and others to begin drawing workers into a wide range of decisions formerly reserved for managers.
But while other companies have since absorbed and refined insights gained from the Bolivar (BALL-uh-ver) Project, the Harman plant itself fell victim to a fundamental misreading of how employees, especially managers, would react to the changes.
"I didn't recognize soon enough how critical a role the managers have to play," said Sidney Harman, the former owner and chief executive of Harman International Industries, the conglomerate that owned Harman Automotive when the experiment began. "You don't go anywhere unless you get those guys to passionately sign on."
Lacking the training and, in many cases, the will to lead without commanding, Harman's managers were in over their heads once key groups of workers decided to use their new freedom mainly to create opportunities to leave work early. Mr. Harman, who sold the factory in 1976, was not around to pull the project back to sanity. And the subsequent owners were happy to see it die.
The Bolivar Project started with a chance meeting in 1972 between Mr. Harman and Irving Bluestone, a top official of the United Automobile Workers union. Both men had been called to testify before a United States Senate subcommittee about anger and alienation in the workplace. Mr. Harman, whose company was best known for its Harman-Kardon stereo equipment, bluntly told the panel that the main problem was corporate America's habit of treating employees like replaceable pieces of machinery.
"Are you for real?" Mr. Bluestone, impressed, asked when they were introduced. The two men quickly agreed that Bolivar would make a suitably challenging testing ground for giving workers greater control over their surroundings. The ramshackle factory there had been fashioned by previous owners out of three huge, leaky Quonset huts. With its fiery metal casting lines, it was a hellish environment for many workers, and relations between management and the union were often tense.
By 1975, though, visitors here found eye-opening signs of cooperation. Workers were experimenting with redesigning their jobs to smooth out workloads and limit interruptions that sapped productivity. If they filled their production quotas early, they could attend an ever-changing array of classes right in the factory, from practical courses like welding to more artistic pursuits like sewing and piano lessons. They also had a new credit union, a pioneering stock-ownership plan and a free-wheeling plant newspaper called The Mirror.
Labor relations improved so much that the 1975 contract with the U.A.W. was actually completed four months before the old one was to expire, saving Harman the need to build inventory in case of a strike.
"What an experience to enter a factory where everyone is an adult!" Carla Eugster, an economist and union organizer, gushed in a letter to The Mirror after a visit late in 1975.
The fresh thinking about quality of life in the factory also began to have an effect on the town. Mr. Harman's proposal for an on-site day-care center evolved into a community day-care center at a church. Workers at the factory, more than half of whom were black, presented the community's first interracial gospel concerts.
But the Bolivar Project began disintegrating even as its legend spread. Management's biggest mistake was to agree to let workers who completed their daily production quotas go home early. The new policy, known as "earned idle time," almost immediately created tensions between those, like assemblers and polishers, who could finish three or four hours early by working in teams, and others stuck with jobs operating, say, metal-casting machines that required a human presence for the entire shift.
"We were too idealistic," said Michael Maccoby, a Washington-based consultant who was director of the Harvard University Project on Technology, Work and Character in 1972 when Mr. Harman and the U.A.W. handed him the task of designing and coordinating the Bolivar project.
The employees' freedom to leave also undercut the effort to draw workers into classes that could broaden skills or foster social ties. Worst of all, a shortened workday soon came to be viewed as an entitlement. Supervisors came under pressure to bend rules to let people go home. Some workers began to cut corners on quality or even put false bottoms on boxes so they could pack them with fewer mirrors and appear to meet their quotas early.
As complaints from customers shot up, Harman had to increase its spending on quality control. Absenteeism and false sick claims, which declined in the early years of the project, soared in the 1980's.
"It turned some employees into thieves," Lee Woods, a longtime union activist in the factory, said, referring to the lost working hours.
It also attracted the worst kind of job applicants. "When we hired people, the first question once they got in the factory wasn't 'Which machine should I run?' but 'When can I go home?' " said Martha Cooper, a quality engineer.
Managers whittled away at earned idle time as new technology and other changes provided openings, but it survived in parts of the factory well into the 1990's.
By then, the factory was probably beyond saving, though, and not just because of the project's missteps. As far back as the 1970's, Harman had been slow to move toward the plastic-based technologies that were taking market share from metal mirrors. When it tried to catch up, its marketing efforts were not as deft as those of its rivals, according to many longtime employees.
Some Harman employees say that both the Bolivar Project and the factory were doomed once Mr. Harman sold all of Harman International to Beatrice Foods upon becoming Under Secretary of Commerce in the Carter Administration in 1976. Beatrice was a highly leveraged conglomerate with operations ranging from food to luggage to chemicals. It paid little attention to the automotive group, which it finally sold in 1984 to Harvard Industries, the current owner. And Beatrice, which is now a unit of Conagra Inc., had no interest in the worker-empowerment experiment.
"It was a mistake to sell to them," said Mr. Harman, who bought Harman International's stereo-equipment business back from Beatrice when he left Government in 1979.
To be fair, the project had shown signs of losing momentum before Beatrice took over. Once the project had served the U.A.W.'s goal of persuading the Big Three to negotiate more power sharing with the union, the union's interest in preserving it waned. And though Mr. Harman knew many local managers were not completely on board, the resistance ran deeper than he realized.
"They put on a show when the big boys were down," said Paul Reaves, a plant supervisor from 1972 to 1993 who was one of the most enthusiastic supporters of the project. "They said the right things, but they would admit in the back rooms they hoped it would be discontinued."
The long decline of the Harman factory has occasionally been masked by strong demand when auto sales were booming. But Harvard Industries, which is now in Chapter 11 bankruptcy for the second time this decade, has never had the resources to update the plant thoroughly. Employment, now about 400 as the plant finishes orders and hands off business to former competitors in its last days, was near its peak of 1,250 as recently as 1992.
Would more support and better execution have saved the factory from closing? Not forever -- but that is not the point, according to those who backed the project. Mr. Bluestone, now a labor relations professor at Wayne State University outside Detroit, cited the case of the General Motors factory in Tarrytown, N.Y. It was scheduled to close in the 1970's, but an agreement to install labor relations programs inspired by Bolivar improved operations so much that the factory survived until 1996. "That was a whole generation of jobs," he said.
Moreover, many of today's most praised workplaces reflect values tested in the Bolivar project and refined by experience with product-quality programs imported from Japan in the 1980's. And because of changes Bolivar helped set in motion elsewhere, untold numbers of jobs have been salvaged or made more meaningful. Indeed, worker empowerment has almost become a cliche. At factories throughout the country, it is common to find workers who shut down production lines if defects or hazards appear and operate in teams to parcel out tasks. Some teams even deal directly with customers and suppliers on quality issues, schedule their own vacations and have the final say in hiring decisions affecting their group.
The Boliver project never got that far, Mr. Maccoby said, but its primitive successes reflected its birthdate. "Bolivar," he said, "was the industrial version of the computer built with vacuum tubes."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "Going, but Not Forgotten
The Harman Automotive parts factory in Tennessee, above in 1975 -- the site of a project to give American workers a significant role in making manufacturing decisions -- has reached the end of the line. Its legacy lives on, though, in plants that have adopted similar policies over the years.
 
SENCO PRODUCTS (top) -- Workers at this maker of nails and staples in Cincinnati took on greater responsibility in the early 1990's. Defects and inventory have fallen, production is up, and annual employee turnover is down to 1 percent.
 
ALCATEL NETWORK SYSTEMS (bottom) -- This maker of telecommunications equipment, based in Raleigh, N.C., created employee teams six years ago. Product development time has speeded up, and defect rates are down by 40 percent.
 
MILLER BREWING -- Its plant in Trenton, Ohio, has been run by employees for five years. It has 40 percent fewer workers than comparable breweries and makes 25 to 30 percent more beer per hour than others do.
 
(Photographs by Tom Simon; Jack Corn for The New York Times)

Last year, Industry Week magazine asked 2,800 factory managers to indicate how many employees were given extensive roles in shaping plant policy. More than three-quarters said that employee involvement was modest. Graph shows share of employees involved in running each plant. (Sources: Industry Week; Work in America Institute)

HEADLINE: It Might Take More Than a Village

BYLINE: By Jacques Steinberg; Jacques Steinberg is an education reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:

WAITING FOR A MIRACLE
 Why Schools Can't Solve Our
 Problems -- and How We Can.
 By James P. Comer.
 261 pp. New York:
 Dutton. $24.95. 
 For three decades, James P. Comer has been a field general on the front lines of the battle to improve the nation's schools. The template for school reform that he has helped to develop at Yale -- one in which parents, teachers, administrators and social workers come together to set priorities and to effect improvements -- has been adopted at 650 schools in 28 states. But progress at such schools has often come slowly, if it has come at all, and Comer has reached a sobering conclusion: until society fundamentally alters its approach to education, particularly in its expectations for minority-group children and their families, schools will be able to make only limited gains.
In "Waiting for a Miracle: Why Schools Can't Solve Our Problems -- and How We Can," Comer, a child psychiatrist who is the director of the Child Study Center at Yale, calls on the nation to devise a coordinated approach to support the education of minority-group youngsters by providing their families with better health care, economic opportunities and mechanisms to help stitch together a fabric of community. The paramount question, he writes, is whether Americans have the will to "make the necessary program and policy adjustments to prepare young people from all ethnic and class backgrounds to succeed."
A black man who grew up poor in East Chicago, Ind., and later graduated from Howard University Medical School, Comer devotes a large portion of his book to plumbing his own experience and seeking to understand how he was able to succeed on such a grand scale. He gives much credit to his father, Hugh Comer, a steelworker and janitor, and his mother, Maggie, a domestic worker who had only "a few days" of formal schooling. His parents, he says, worked hard to create a home environment that emphasized education and getting ahead despite the obstacles society might erect in his path. (His parents even gave him the middle name Pierpont, so that the achievements of the financier J. Pierpont Morgan would never be far from his mind.)
Too often, Comer argues, society sends an entirely different message to black youngsters. Their failure to achieve, in school and in life, is attributed to a lack of intelligence or initiative. But while white students and their families can find strength and support in a culture that was transported largely intact from Europe, he observes, the support system for black families is in tatters, a lingering remnant from the days of slavery. "Without assigning blame or being judgmental," Comer writes, "we must acknowledge and address the full effects of past policies and practices and the magnitude of today's task." For inner-city schools to achieve on a high level, Comer argues, the nation must find a way to sustain them with an interlocking network of services that replicates "what my parents brought about for me."
Empowerment zones and other programs intended to spur development in inner-city neighborhoods are a good start, he says, but their focus is too often on "bricks and mortar." What he calls for is a national expansion of programs like one in Baltimore called Step-Up, which provides public housing residents with yearlong apprenticeships in the construction trades, health- and child-care referrals, substance abuse counseling, opportunities to earn high school equivalency degrees and job placement assistance. By getting on their feet, graduates of the program are in a better position to nurture the next generation to make even greater strides, he reasons.
The nation's leaders, he says, should also commit themselves to shoring up the schools themselves by focusing, at least initially, on teacher training. Graduate schools of education, he suggests, could develop a relationship with schools similar to that between medical schools and teaching hospitals, with teacher trainers making periodic rounds to observe and coach teachers in their classrooms.
If there is a weakness in Comer's analysis, it is that in praising the boost he received from his family he minimizes how difficult it can be for the outside world to play a similar role. In seeking to emphasize society's responsibilities, he sometimes glosses over the responsibilities of the individual. Nonetheless, Comer's vast experience in the education reform movement demands that his plea for a sweeping change in mind-set be given serious consideration, especially by those who are only too ready to embrace the quick fixes so often billed as a solution to all of education's problems.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Philadelphia

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS; LAURA MANSNERUS, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, lives in Philadelphia.

 BODY:
Philadelphia has been flinging off old mood problems, and its new self should be brighter than ever in the spring, when parks and row houses are draped in blossoms. But every year, those who can't wait celebrate spring's precursor in the first week of March, the weeklong flower show known as the nation's biggest, best and surely most extravagant.
The 10-acre show is held at the Pennsylvania Convention Center, a newish, hugely ambitious project meant to revive the city's downtown, known here as Center City. Convention Center or no, something worked. Center City has seen such an infusion of restaurants and hotels that Philadelphians are often startled by the new sheen that suddenly appears one day on dowdy spaces they've passed for years. 
 Philadelphia's reclamation is most obvious in Old City, a formerly down-at-the-heels 19th-century commercial district where coffeehouses, bars and supper clubs keep the neighborhood alive into the night.
Still, this is a city largely allergic to newness; almost always, old facades are respected and old habits undisturbed. Philadelphia's anchors -- from Independence Hall to the cavernous Reading Terminal Market to the Tudor boathouses behind the art museum -- have kept their looks over many generations. It all pretty reliably charms Americans from newer places -- which, of course, means almost anyplace.
 
Events
 The flower show, March 1 to 8, is an outsize, giddy occasion that spills far outside the Convention Center. This year's theme, "La Passion du Jardin," is inspiring French-flavored offerings at hotels, restaurants and museums stretching into the suburbs. The main exhibits will include re-creations of the gardens and topiaries at Versailles and the Chateau de Villandry; the garden of a leading French rose breeder; and the gardens at the Rodin Museum in Philadelphia, with some sculpture from its collection. Information: call (800) 611-5960 or check the Web site, www.libertynet.org/flowrsho.
The Convention Center is at 12th and Arch Streets. Tickets, $18 for weekends, $16 weekdays and $15.50 in advance, are available through Ticketmaster offices or www.ticketmaster.com.
Later next month is the city's annual movable feast for foodies, the Book and the Cook Festival. The event, March 20 to 29, pairs cookbook authors and food and wine experts with chefs at about 80 restaurants, where they conduct demonstrations and circulate among diners to answer questions and sign books. Many of the visiting authors will also be at the Book and the Cook Fair, March 27 to 29 at the Convention Center ($15), with food and kitchenware vendors. Information: (800) 537-7676. Some hotels offer weekend festival packages; reservations can be made at (888) 726-6517, and those booking rooms can make dinner reservations at the same time.
A very different sort of exhibition, with appeal for 7-year-olds, paleontologists and many in between, is Dinofest, featuring dinosaurs, fossils and paleontological art. The show, in conjunction with the reopening of the Dinosaur Hall at the Academy of Natural Sciences next month, runs March 27 through April 26 at the Civic Center, 34th Street and Civic Center Boulevard. At a symposium of paleontologists, Stephen Jay Gould will be the keynote speaker. Tickets from Ticketmaster, (215) 336-2000; $15, $10 ages 3 to 12.
The Philadelphia Chamber Music Society has more than a dozen concerts in March and April, with the Mendelssohn Quartet, the Borromeo String Quartet, the pianists Garrick Ohlsson and Jean-Yves Thibaudet, among other performers. All concerts are at the Convention Center Auditorium, 13th and Cherry Streets. For information and tickets ($18 to $20), call (215) 569-8587.
 
Sightseeing
 Independence National Historical Park, the square mile of 18th-century institutions that made up the nation's first capital, is free, 365 days a year. A few sites sometimes overlooked in the rush for the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall: the Second Bank of the United States, 420 Chestnut Street, with its 18th-century portrait gallery (open 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. daily, $2); Carpenters' Hall, 320 Chestnut Street, where the First Continental Congress met in 1774 (open 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesday through Sunday), and the B. Free Franklin Post Office, 316 Market Street (open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily), where you can even do most postal business as usual.
A different history is told in the Italian market (South Ninth Street between Christian Street and Washington Avenue). For decades a scruffy but vibrant center for produce vendors, fishmongers and butchers in the Italian-American heart of South Philadelphia, the market is now spiffing up its storefronts and welcoming new coffeehouses and restaurants.
Good eating can resume just one block east, on South Eighth Street, where almost all the shops are Vietnamese, and the restaurants offer splendid $5 lunches and $10 dinners.
At the northwest corner of Center City, the imposing Philadelphia Museum of Art crowns the Benjamin Franklin Parkway. The museum's backyard is the Azalea Garden, where the flower show, beginning with the first blooms in late April, is free.
From the museum, Kelly Drive follows the Schuylkill River. The drive's southern anchor is Boathouse Row, the string of Victorian clubhouses familiar for their trim of white lights that glow on the river at night.
Winding along Kelly Drive is a 3.5-mile paved path for runners, cyclists and skaters. Walkers are welcome, too; they can all stop at picnic tables or at the sculpture garden, a collection starring Jacques Lipchitz's "Spirit of Enterprise."
 
Where to Stay
 The 200-room Warwick, 1701 Locust Street, (215) 735-6000, (800) 523-4210, fax (215) 790-7766, is one of Center City's originals, on a peaceful block just off Rittenhouse Square. Its Old World demeanor received a recent buffing-up, including the debut of a jacket-and-tie restaurant, the Prime Rib. Doubles are $195 weekdays, $119 weekends. (Prices do not include the 13 percent room tax.)
Penn's View Inn, Front and Market Streets, (215) 922-7600, (800) 331-7634, fax (215) 922-7642, is in the shadow of the glittery Benjamin Franklin Bridge on the Delaware River. It's a trek from the Convention Center but close to Old City's night life and the historic district. The five-story, 40-room inn is on the National Register of Historic Places. Rooms, outfitted with Chippendale furniture and chintz, start at $145.
Budget: The 166-room Holiday Inn Express, 1305 Walnut Street, (215) 735-9300, fax (215) 732-2682, is just a few blocks from the Convention Center and moments from the city's two major theaters, the Forrest and the Walnut Street. Doubles are $120; if you mention the flower show, $95.
The Clarion Suites, 1010 Race Street, (215) 922-1730, (800) 252-7466, fax (215) 922-1730, should be especially convenient for families: all 96 suites have kitchenettes; some have separate bedrooms. It is smack in the middle of Chinatown, so finding a restaurant or take-out isn't a problem. The building, formerly home to the Bentwood Rocking Chair Factory, has much of its original detail, like exposed brick walls and wooden beams in the suites. Suites are $169 (flower show special rate: $159).
Luxury: The 290-room Ritz-Carlton, 17th between Chestnut and Market Streets, (215) 563-1600, fax (215) 567-2822, is nestled next to Liberty One, the glamorous, glass tower that defined the business district's new skyline 10 years ago. The hotel, with comfortable rooms decorated in a traditional style, is an easy walk from the Convention Center. A flower show package is $215 during the week, $185 for Friday or Saturday night, including two passes to the show; otherwise, $189 weekends, $225 weekdays.
The Rittenhouse, in a slightly quieter quarter of Center City, looks out onto Rittenhouse Square, where, later in the spring, the fountain will flow and masses of daffodils and tulips will bloom. The sleek, contemporary hotel, (215) 546-9000, (800) 635-1042, fax (215) 732-3364, with 98 rooms and 37 suites, has flower show packages at $335 weekdays, $295 weekends. Two tickets to the show are included. Regular rates: $190 weekends; $340 weekdays.
 
Where to Eat
 The thoroughly opulent Deux Cheminees, 1221 Locust Street, (215) 790-0200, formal in both its French cooking and its Philadelphian reserve, occupies two 19th-century town houses designed by Frank Furness. It's impossible to think light here; the rack of lamb, for example, is served with a truffle-filled sauce Perigord, the duck breast with a griotte cherry sauce. During flower show week, the restaurant is open for lunch (three courses, $27.50, not including wine, tax or tip); at dinner, presenting flower show tickets will bring a credit of 100 francs ($18) a table. Dinner for two with wine, about $240, with tax and tip.
Striped Bass, 1500 Walnut Street, (215) 732-4444, a centerpiece of Walnut Street's restaurant row, is entirely seafood, starting with the raw bar and Petrossian caviar selection. Dinner for two with wine, about $200, including tax and tip; lunch, $70.
Fork, 306 Market Street, (215) 625-9425, is one of several well-appointed new restaurants in Old City. At this softly lighted brasserie, the menu changes nightly, offering a mix of seafood, lamb chops and steak, duck and chicken, with beautiful side dishes like creamed Brussels sprouts and roasted butternut squash. Dinner for two with wine, tax and tip: about $90.
Monk's Cafe, 264 South 16th Street, (215) 545-7005, a Belgian bistro, is all dark wood and dim lights. Sandwiches (a favorite is chicken and apple sausage) start at $5.75. Understandably popular are the mussels ($8.95 for a sizable bowl, $14.95 for a giant bowl), accompanied by skinny pommes frites. The exhaustive selection of Belgian beers includes a dozen on tap in the back bar. A meal for two with beer, tax and tip: about $50. No reservations.
Chinatown, which all but surrounds the Convention Center, has scores of restaurants. One small, unimposing place -- lace curtains, 10 tables, bring your own beer or wine -- with an impressive kitchen is Shiao Lan Kung, 930 Race Street, (215) 928-0282. The salt-baked squid and the beef dishes are good choices. Open until 3 A.M. Dinner for two with tax and tip: about $25.
The Reading Terminal Market, at 12th and Filbert Streets, has almost anything to go -- cheesesteaks and sumptuous roast pork sandwiches, Chinese and Lebanese food, soul food and trendy food -- in the neighborhood of $5. Seating is at tables in the center of the market or in the Beer Garden. The market is closed at night and on Sunday, but its sit-down restaurant, the Down Home Diner, is open until 9 nightly except Sunday. It is Southern (try the sweet potato chips), generous (the mashed potatoes) and usually costs about $25 for dinner for two.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 30; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: The Gore Guide to the Future

BYLINE: By Richard L. Berke; Richard L. Berke is the national political correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
On the evening of january 14, president clinton summoned his closest advisers to the Yellow Oval Room in the White House family quarters to map out how best to promote the upcoming State of the Union Message.The deliberations turned to a more urgent political matter: how to rescue the Vice President.
Al Gore has been hailed as the most enterprising Vice President in history, but by January, he was looking clumsier than Dan Quayle. For months, Gore had been buffeted by jokes about his mingling with Buddhist nuns with their hands out, his endorsement of a lesbian television character and his off-hand and only partly true suggestion that he and his wife were models for "Love Story." 
 Mindful of Gore's lackluster favorability ratings, the White House pollster Mark Penn turned to the President and his advisers with a brainstorm: On the day after the State of the Union, Gore could accompany Clinton on a triumphal tour of Illinois and Wisconsin. Why not have the Vice President soak up some of the Clinton magic? The President nodded approvingly, and Gore's advisers were absolutely giddy about the prospect. But in the next few days, Clinton's most protective aides resisted: they fretted that the joint outing would detract from the President's role as the great unifier. Finally, the idea was again put to Clinton, who once again endorsed it.
Then The Intern turned the White House upside down. Five days after the Illinois-Wisconsin trip was fixed on the schedule, the White House was thrust into panicked disbelief. Now the very qualities that threatened Gore's ambitions for the Presidency were in demand. Suddenly, it was Clinton who needed Gore to travel with him in a public show of support. Suddenly, Gore's biggest liability, that he was too dull, too much the Boy Scout to be President, had become his biggest asset.
Gore's aides had braced for a yearlong effort to restore the Vice President's popularity. Instead, they found, the recovery was already accomplished. No controlling legal authority? Gore's embarrassing defense of his phone solicitations for donations from the White House had been overshadowed by Clinton's own parsing of words: there is no sexual relationship. Even the most disastrous, if unlikely, scenario for Clinton -- that he will leave office ahead of schedule --would not be so bad for Gore.
In fact, Gore is now perfectly poised for his own run for President in 2000. Week by week for more than a year, he has been quietly transforming the political and policy apparatus of the White House into the most powerful campaign-in-waiting that has ever existed. "You can't be any more disciplined. You can't be any more focused" than the Vice President, says Andrew Cuomo, the Federal housing secretary and a Gore adviser. "You can't work the way he works unless you want this with 100 percent of your being."
The politics of a Gore candidacy arose in virtually every major decision made by the Vice President in the past year. Gore, for instance, insinuated himself into the negotiations over the balanced budget, emerging with measures to help him with vital Democratic constituencies. He has installed a shadow staff that extends into the President's office and the Democratic National Committee. He has forged friendships with elected officials who can help him in 2000, particularly those with similar backgrounds. If you are an up-and-coming politician with a powerful father in politics (Gore's own father was a Tennessee Senator), you're apt to get a call from your new pal, Al. And Gore has made certain that his immersion in policy will advance his Presidential ambitions.
While Gore still lacks the innate political gifts of the man who carried him into the White House, he makes up for it with painstaking planning, discipline and deliberation. That, his friends say, is why he believes he will be the next President. If Clinton, the instinctive political animal, brought the "permanent campaign" to the White House, Gore, the discreet calculator, is keeping it alive -- a point suggested even by his mentor.
"I think that it's a great mistake to understate the political skills of the man with the record he has established in his life," Clinton said in a December interview. Yet in the next breath, the President, not very reassuring, suggested that Gore's strength is other than as a candidate.
"But," Clinton said, "the most important thing is, I think, when people vote for him they don't vote for him because they think he's a great politician. They vote for him because they think he's a committed public servant."
Little did the President know that just a few weeks after that interview, some Democrats would be itching to get off Bill Clinton's wild ride. "Some of the polling I've seen shows that with the next President they don't want to go through this anymore," says Lynn Cutler, a White House official who is close to Gore.
Still, Gore is the Vice President. His power and influence derive from Clinton. So in the months ahead Gore must strike a careful balance. He does not dare distance himself from Clinton, lest he seem disloyal and expedient. Yet he also wants to insulate himself from the actual scandal. And unlike in past controversies, Gore has made clear to White House aides that he does not want to know too much about the scandal or become too involved in mapping strategy. Gore found himself in the uncomfortable position of bringing his own lawyer, Charles Burson, to two meetings where he was briefed about the scandal.
Even when he introduced Clinton at a rally on the trip they made together, Gore's comments were carefully calibrated. It may have been the only time a Vice President's introduction of the President turned out to be what made the evening news. Gore was so enthusiastic he was practically shouting, leaving no doubt about his loyalty. "He is the President of the country," Gore bellowed. "He is also my friend. And I want to ask you now, every single one of you, to join me in supporting him and standing by his side."
But ever the deliberate strategist, rarely the instinctive politician, Gore's introduction was no off-the-cuff expression of support. He cast out to a half dozen advisers, on just how enthusiastic he should be. One suggestion was that he ask the country to stand by Clinton because of his policy accomplishments. Another was to blame unnamed enemies for trying to undermine Clinton. Scribbling the final version himself, alone in his office on Air Force Two on the way to the event in Champaign-Urbana, Ill., he decided not to be a judge or a partisan -- and not to give a character reference. He chose to be a friend, albeit a clever friend: Gore left no doubt about his loyalty, yet avoided any direct mention of the scandal: he knows to avoid leaving material for a sound bite some day in which Gore utters the name Lewinsky. This Vice President will make sure of that.
 
Navobs: Thinking About 2000
Al Gore would have you believe that the next Presidential election is the furthest thing from his mind. Ask him anything related to 2000 and Gore bristles at the impropriety. In this instance, sitting in a brown velvet armchair in his West Wing office, Gore responds to the inquiry with an arched eyebrow and a disappointing glance. "It's premature to speculate," he says. Next question.
But Gore thinks a lot about 2000 these days. Since last spring, he has convened secret meetings of a skeletal campaign operation in the Vice President's residence. (Gore cancelled one of the meetings during the frenzy over the sex scandal; his advisers worried that it might look like Gore was plotting Clinton's overthrow.) At these evening sessions every couple of weeks, participants dissect poll numbers and consider topics like reasons for Gore to travel to vote-rich California. These "residence meetings" are so hush-hush that Ronald Klain, Gore's chief of staff, does not entrust aides to make copies of the agenda. Even on Gore's internal schedule, the gatherings are listed under the code word "Navobs," short for the Naval Observatory, site of the Vice President's house.
Gore insists that the meetings are not exclusively about his Presidential ambitions. Then what are they about? "I don't want to get into them," he snaps. "And other people shouldn't either." But the gatherings are part of an elaborate infrastructure that has helped Gore thrive alongside a President who is awash in controversy in a way that other Vice Presidents, like Hubert Humphrey and Gerald Ford, could not. Just about every corner of the White House is stocked with employees who are as much geared to advancing the Presidential prospects of Gore as they were for Clinton in 1996.
The integration of personnel is highly unusual, given the history of sniping between Presidential and Vice Presidential staffs. Vice President George Bush's chief of staff, Craig Fuller, did not begin attending regular staff meetings in the Reagan White House until the summer of 1988 -- after the Republican primaries. By contrast, Gore's chiefs of staff have been welcome at all major staff meetings for the last five years. "Historically, it was always thought the President's staff saw the Vice President as a reminder that their principal was mortal and there was little if any future for them in the success of the Vice President," says Tom Foley, the Ambassador to Japan and former Speaker of the House. The comfort level between the Clinton and Gore staffs, he says, is "of enormous value and importance" to Gore.
Increasingly, Clinton has allowed Gore to place loyalists in important jobs at the White House, in the Cabinet and at the Democratic National Committee. Gore picked Carol Browner to head the Environmental Protection Agency at the start of Clinton's first term and, after the 1996 campaign, he pressed for Cuomo as Housing Secretary and Franklin Raines to head the Office of Management and Budget.
Many Clinton loyalists in the Administration have been converted to the Vice President's cause. In some cases, those staff members have grown fond of Gore from working closely with him. But the implicit message from Clinton is unequivocal: It would be treacherous to back anyone but Gore for 2000. There was never an official purge, but White House officials who had been viewed as closer to Representative Richard Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader who is likely to challenge Gore, departed after the 1996 election. Even had they stayed, top aides like George Stephanopoulos and Harold Ickes say it is doubtful they would have strayed to another candidate. The result is that there is no one in the White House who supports a possible Gore rival.
Because Gore participates in vetting all major Presidential appointees, his empire extends far beyond his relatively small staff. Erskine Bowles, Clinton's chief of staff, has made special efforts to advance the Vice President's prospects. Few people remember that Bowles was a Gore delegate for President in 1988. At the height of the attacks on Gore's fund raising, Bowles pointedly reminded senior staff members to stick up for Gore in their public statements. (Gore ordered his staff to do the same for Clinton when the Lewinsky scandal erupted.)
White House officials say Bowles was especially aggressive last year in assuring that Gore got his way on an empowerment-zone program and on land acquisition for the Everglades, efforts he can present to inner-city voters, environmentalists and the battleground state of Florida in the 2000 primaries. "During the balanced-budget negotiations, Erskine knew what the Vice President's priorities were," says Klain, Gore's chief of staff, "and made sure they were negotiated as hard as possible."
Consider the contrast with President Reagan's second-term chief of staff, former Senator Howard Baker of Tennessee. Baker and his top aides were partial to Senator Bob Dole over Vice President Bush, who had competed with Baker for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1980. On the eve of the 1988 primaries, Baker gave Dole a White House platform to announce his support for a treaty banning intermediate-range missiles.
Lower-level staff members are also helping Gore. Nicholas Baldick, a deputy in the White House political affairs office, devotes much of his time looking out for Gore in New Hampshire, where the crucial first Presidential primary is held. He has also been tapped to run Gore's newly formed political action committee. The Office of Intergovernmental Affairs is so stocked with the Vice President's friends that it looks like Gore campaign headquarters. The office is especially helpful to Gore because it handles White House outreach to minorities, local officials and other key players in Democratic primaries. After the 1996 election, Gore took responsibility for relations with state and local governments. Says one White House official, "I reminded him that Dukakis got the nomination in '88 because he had all the mayors and all the governors."
Gore's shadow campaign extends to the Democratic National Committee. White House officials say that while there is no formal litmus test, they have made sure that top officials are loyal to Gore or, at the very least, neutral in the Presidential race. Gore was the prime mover in the appointment of Steve Grossman, a longtime ally, as national chairman of the party. The party's general chairman, Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, also must stay officially neutral but has told friends he expects to back Gore. In a little noticed triumph for Gore, party officials last year named Tina Flourney a co-chairwoman of the party's powerful Rules Committee. Flourney is a former assistant to Peter Knight, a longtime Gore confidant. From her position on the committee she can influence important decisions affecting the Democratic primaries and the selection of delegates.
Having devotees in high places helps Gore in many ways. Last year, during planning of the national summit on volunteerism in Philadelphia, White House officials feared that Colin Powell, the event's chairman and a potential political adversary, would overshadow Gore. After delicate negotiations, the outside organizers expanded the Vice President's role so he got an improved speaking time and presided over an event with Powell. It helped that the White House liaisons to the summit were longtime Gore allies, including Bruce Reed, the White House domestic policy adviser.
Gore has expanded his influence in part because so many aides have graduated to the President's staff. Karen Skelton, once Gore's political director, is now Clinton's deputy political director. She is still a regular at Gore's secret residence meetings. Thurgood Marshall Jr., son of the late Supreme Court justice, headed Gore's legislative affairs office and is now secretary of the President's Cabinet, where he is Gore's (and Clinton's) emissary to every Federal agency. Gore even saw to it that Jeff Forbes, a whiz in the obscure but essential art of counting convention delegates, was hired in the legislative affairs office, ready to help Gore when the time comes.
One danger in all the moves is that Gore has depleted his immediate staff of aides who know him well and feel comfortable standing up to him. Only two staffers have known him long enough to address him as "Al" -- Leon Fuerth, his national security adviser, and Kathleen McGinty, who heads the Council on Environmental Quality. The Vice President still turns to a close-knit cadre for advice in discussing strategy for 2000. The attendee list at his residence meetings varies, but core participants include Klain, the 36-year-old former top aide to Janet Reno; three longtime aides who are now lobbyists, Knight, Roy Neel and Jack Quinn; and two other key advisers: former Representative Tom Downey of New York and Robert Squier, his media consultant. Tipper Gore is also an important participant. The meetings are often rescheduled to make sure that she and her chief of staff, Susan Liss, can attend. Another frequent participant is Douglas Schoen, Clinton's chief pollster, and occasionally Mark Penn, Schoen's partner. The only participant with extensive on-the-ground political experience in a Presidential race is a relative newcomer to Gore's inner circle, Michael Whouley, a street-smart operative from Boston who ran Gore's re-election campaign in 1996 and may run the overall campaign in 2000.
Still, the most important member of this shadow campaign is the President, whom more than one Gore aide describes as Gore's de facto campaign manager. When Gore and Lieut. Gov. Buddy MacKay of Florida stood before a cheering crowd at the Florida Democratic convention in Tampa last October, few in the audience knew that Clinton had choreographed the moment days earlier. The President had taken the unusual step of inserting himself in a primary battle by endorsing MacKay in the Democratic primary for Governor. Clinton planned to make the endorsement anyway, but aides say that he moved up the timing to assure that MacKay's supporters would give Gore a rousing reception just as Attorney General Janet Reno in Washington was preparing to extend the TK inquiry into Gore. If Clinton's maneuvers help MacKay become Governor, that could be enormously helpful to Gore in this crucial primary state.
A telling example of the exceptional integration of the Clinton and Gore teams came on that day last month when the Vice President traveled to the University of Illinois to stand with the President. That same day, I called Douglas Sosnik, a White House counselor, to ask about a rumor that Andrew Cuomo was advising Gore to distance himself from the President on the sex scandal. Sosnik said he had heard no such thing. (But he later admitted that he was alarmed enough to interrupt Clinton's game of hearts on Air Force One to tell him of the query.)
Within minutes, Cuomo himself called to say he had been alerted by Tom Downey about the question to Sosnik. Using expletives to emphasize his point, Cuomo denied the rumor. Then Ron Klain called. He insisted that Cuomo had not talked to Gore since the scandal erupted. Then came another call, from Michael McCurry, the White House press secretary, who was in Illinois with the President.
"It's McCurry," he blared cheerily on my answering machine. "All the Clinton brothers are trying to help out our Gore brothers right now and beat you back with a stick." He offered his help in shooting down the story and signed off, "Toodle-oo."
 
Ties That Bind: Clinton and Gore
Worried that Gore might be perceived as keeping distance from Clinton when the sex scandal erupted, White House officials and Gore advisers intentionally doled out tidbits to reporters about the Vice President's energetic role behind the scenes. How Gore called Clinton from the road and offered words of reassurance before the President first spoke to reporters about Lewinsky. The touching moment when Gore consoled Hillary Rodham Clinton with a long embrace at a reception after the State of the Union. His defense of the President at a closed-door meeting of House Democrats.
The scandal aside, navigating between standing on his own and remaining loyal to the President who has become his close friend will be one of Gore's most trying challenges. Gore advisers believe his greatest strengths are his reputation for rectitude and for holding firm on issues he cares about, like the environment. But, they acknowledge, Gore will have to take care not to anger the President by even remotely implying that he lacks some of those qualities. And while Clinton's aides talk about his determination that Gore carry on his legacy, Gore's advisers blanch at the idea that a Gore presidency would simply continue the Clinton agenda. For all his fidelity to the President, they say, Gore is proud of his accomplishments and does not want to be seen as a Clinton puppet.
In a December interview, Gore insisted it would be foolhardy to put distance between himself and Clinton. "I would like to dispel any notion that if I should run for President, one of my strategic objectives would be how to separate myself from President Clinton," he says. "Why would I? I have been by his side every step of the way." Tipper Gore is more emphatic. "I don't anticipate anybody being able to divide the Clintons and the Gores," she says. "Ever."
Indeed, one of Gore's chief appeals is that no on-the-job training would be required: the Vice President could simply move the 18 steps to the Oval Office, rewire the desk for his Compaq Pentium II computer (with built-in television and CD player) -- and take over. But Gore must be mindful that voters not write off his candidacy as Clinton III without the charisma. Even during peace and prosperity (and popularity for the incumbent Reagan Administration), George Bush differentiated himself as "kinder and gentler." So closely identified with Clinton, Gore could not possibly distance himself this directly. But he will have to figure out more subtle ways to offer the electorate the change it always seeks at election time.
The Vice President is not a Clinton clone. Except on a few marquee issues like the environment and investment in the inner city, Gore is usually just to the right of Clinton. He pressed Clinton to sign the welfare reform bill when the President seemed uncertain, for example, and argued for fiscal discipline before the President embraced full-fledged deficit reduction. Gore is also more of a hawk than Clinton. "When we went into Haiti," the President says, "when we went into Bosnia, when 80 percent of the people in a poll said we shouldn't help Mexico and we helped Mexico, he was always on the strong side."
But Gore may find that the requisites of Vice Presidential loyalty hamper his ability to articulate his own identity, particularly as his Democratic challengers intensify their efforts to shape their visions. Gore got a taste of these pressures in trying to satisfy two constituencies -- the President and labor -- when he addressed the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in Pittsburgh in late September, in the heat of the Congressional battle over whether the President should be granted "fast track" authority to negotiate international trade agreements.
Advisers to the Vice President wanted him at least to insert a line in his speech defending the Administration's position on fast track, or telling the labor audience that they did not have to agree on everything. These advisers feared that Gore would appear to be ducking the issue, out of concern that he would get a hostile response from the union audience. But Gore insisted on silence. The pressures on the Vice President were complicated. The President had instructed Gore that he wanted to be the one who took on the powerful labor federation when he spoke at the meeting four days later. So Gore felt he had no alternative. "Clinton wanted to reserve for himself the argument he wanted to make," says McCurry, the White House press secretary, adding that "it would have a little more drama to it" if the Vice President did not challenge labor first.
As 2000 draws nearer, Gore will increasingly find himself in these predicaments. While there is no ill will toward the President for grabbing the attention for himself in Pittsburgh, there is some nervousness in the Gore camp over the degree to which Clinton will insinuate himself into their campaign. Some Gore advisers worry that Clinton may not understand that the Vice President has to wage a far different campaign than the insurgent effort that won Clinton the White House in 1992. Unlike Clinton in that race, they say, Gore cannot survive by squeaking out primary victories, or losing the New Hampshire primary. "Every politician is in love with their own campaign," says a close Gore adviser, referring to Clinton. "But you cannot take the Clinton playbook and say, 'Gore, do all the same things.' " Clinton's decision to designate his successor so early also carries political consequences that will be felt long before candidates even formally announce for 2000 -- both in how Clinton operates as President and how he works with Congress. (Reagan, by contrast, did not endorse Bush until shortly before the Republican convention.) "In no small measure, Clinton now sees the election of Gore as perhaps his primary legacy," says Harold Ickes, the former top aide to Clinton. "That has very profound implications about how the President will conduct himself."
The President risks fracturing the Democratic Party, because several candidates representing varying points of view think that they -- not just Gore -- should have a shot at the nomination. Privately, many Democrats say they resent that Clinton is essentially trying to anoint Gore, who already was from a privileged political background. They also grouse that rather than be liberated since he cannot run anymore, Clinton may feel inhibited on controversial issues like entitlement reform because they could hurt Gore down the line. Exacerbating the tension, some Congressional Democrats suspect that Gore does not want his party to take back the House and Senate in 1998. That way, he, like Clinton in 1996, could win over voters who feel more comfortable with a Democratic White House as a check on a Republican Congress. And if Democrats won the House, the credit would go to Gephardt, who could use it as a launching pad for his own White House ambitions.
For all his efforts to boost Gore, Clinton does not want to cede too much too soon. Asked about instances where he has increasingly assigned high-profile speeches to Gore, Clinton makes clear that he is still running the show. "I'm not consciously doing that anyway," the President says. "I'm still trying to pick and choose the things that I think are most important." While acknowledging that "in the last several months he's been out more than I have," he says that it is because negotiations on Capitol Hill and his knee injury kept him grounded last year.
For all of Gore's hope that he not be drawn into the scandal, some White House officials suggest that the crisis has brought Clinton and Gore even closer. In the interview weeks before the scandal broke, Clinton allowed how he often turns to his Vice President in the roughest times. "In the last five years, when I've had difficulties -- and there have been some," the President says, "I've always encouraged him to be absolutely candid with me and give me his best advice. We have a partnership and we're personal friends and we trust each other enough to be candid."
But friendship notwithstanding, there will inevitably be tense moments between a President who does not want his final years in office mired in scandal -- and a Vice President who cannot afford to soil his own Boy Scout image as he launches his own campaign.
 
Making Friends
When Gore faced the onslaught last year over his fund-raising practices in the 1996 campaign, the Sunday news programs had little luck finding fellow Democrats in Congress who would defend the Vice President publicly. Asked why, Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, laughed. "Warm and fuzzy he's not."
Indeed, while Gore served 16 years in the House and Senate, he was known as a loner and made few deep and lasting personal friendships. But as aptly demonstrated by Clinton, and Bush before him, you need to collect devoted friends -- lots of them -- to become President. Had more Congressional Democrats been willing to defend Gore last year, he may have had some success in countering the withering and prolonged attacks about the legality of his telephone solicitations from the White House.
Knowing that he needs more friends to win the Presidency , Gore has mounted an aggressive effort to expand his relationships. Building that network will help him scare off rivals by amassing the $35 million -- the maximum amount Presidential candidates can spend if they accept Federal subsidies -- he expects to raise for the primaries. But for Gore, unlike Clinton, making friends sometimes seems more like a strategic and deliberate enterprise than a personal imperative. Ask Clinton about New Hampshire, and he launches into a commentary about the coffee shop in Concord and reels off the names of a string of active Democrats in that primary state. Ask Gore, and he discusses Democratic constituencies in analytical terms, like how his message may work in growing high-tech regions of the state.
Gore has been most comfortable cultivating politicians with similar political and personal backgrounds. In many instances, Gore, who is 49, gets on better with the sons than with their fathers, some of whom he collided with during his brash bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988. What better way to win the approval -- and political support -- of the fathers than by wooing the sons?
When Gore was running in the New York primary, Gov. Mario Cuomo condemned his campaign style as "terribly dangerous." But Gore has since become close friends with Cuomo's son, Andrew. "Who remembers that?" the younger Cuomo now says of Gore's 1988 campaign in New York. "2000 will be 12 years ago. In this business, that's three lifetimes ago." Gore's advisers say that as Housing Secretary, Cuomo will be especially helpful in winning over urban voters important in the Democratic primaries. They also believe that with Cuomo's New York connections, Gore will have an easier ride in the state than last time, when he came in a distant third behind Michael Dukakis and Jesse Jackson.
Gore has made a special effort to advise and campaign for Jackson's son, Jesse Jackson Jr., who was elected to Congress from Chicago in 1995. On a recent trip to Chicago, Gore instructed his aides to go out of their way to create a Vice Presidential event in Jackson's district. "When I did my first appearance on 'Meet the Press,' the first call I got was from the Vice President saying I did a great job," says the younger Jackson. Jesse Jackson senior is mulling over running for President again himself. But Gore's advisers say that if the Vice President at least maintains good relations with the family, Jackson will be less likely to attack Gore and erode his support among minorities.
And Gore, well aware that Clinton turned to a corps of veteran politicians in Chicago to help run his 1992 campaign, has also been cultivating a relationship with the sons of the late Mayor Richard Daley. Gore was instrumental in Bill Daley's appointment as Secretary of Commerce. Ever so quietly, Gore has been just as singleminded in establishing a friendship with another Daley son, Mayor Richard M. Daley, and his wife, Maggie. The Vice President and his wife flew to Chicago for what he describes as "a great weekend" last August. The agenda featured no public events -- only schmoozing. The Gores arrived on a Saturday, and kicked off their visit with the Daleys with a boat trip along the Chicago River. That evening the couples went to the Goodman Theater to see "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom." Sunday morning, they went to the House of Blues for breakfast and blues music. The payoff came earlier than even Gore's aides expected. They were stunned last month when Daley became the first big-city Mayor to endorse Gore -- even though the Vice President is at least a year off from announcing his candidacy. "I'm for Al Gore," Daley said off-handedly to a reporter. "I endorse him."
Gore has never been particularly close to the Kennedys. But in a move to build bona fides with liberals, he asked another famous son, Representative Joseph Kennedy of Massachusetts, to formally nominate him at the Democratic convention in 1996. The Vice President has also befriended Representative Harold E. Ford Jr., a young Tennessee Democrat who succeeded his father in 1996. Because of his friendship with Gore, Ford did something few other members would dare do, particularly at age 27. Last December, Ford publicly scolded Gephardt, who heads his caucus, for challenging the President and Vice President in a speech.
The Vice President also saw to it that Colin Powell's son, Michael, was appointed to the Federal Communications Commission last fall, taking in the unusual step of swearing in Powell himself. The gesture may be remembered should Colin Powell think again about running for President.
Gore's new friendship with Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa is the most unexpected. For years, Harkin aides say, the Senator privately referred to Gore as Prince Albert, the moniker created by cartoonist Garry Trudeau mocking the Vice President's pampered upbringing.
That was then. Now Harkin's wife, Ruth, is very close to Tipper Gore. And Harkin said the Vice President looked out for his wife when she was president of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Harkin is returning the favor: he has practically turned over his Iowa campaign operation to Gore -- a treasure, given the importance of the state's caucuses.
 
Policy As Good Politics
Clinton says Gore should not "overabsorb" himself in politics, because his immersion in policy is his most important political strength. "In terms of his future," Clinton says, "his ability to continue to demonstrate that he has accomplished more in the position he has than anyone else who ever had that position in history is by far the most important thing. It's more important than today's headlines or who else is doing what -- or even who else decides to run."
The President says Gore would have "a good leg up" on the Democratic nomination. Head and shoulders would be more accurate. In this century, only two Vice Presidents sought and were denied their party's Presidential nomination: John Nance Garner in 1940 and Alben Barkley in 1952. And neither was very aggressive in harnessing the power of the Vice Presidency as a campaign vehicle.
With Clinton distracted by subpoenas and the drumbeat of relevations, the Vice President has had even greater opportunity to distinguish himself by advancing the White House agenda. Just days after the Intern scandal broke, Gore touted new funding for cancer research, flew to California to announce new jobs "for the 21st century" and announced plans to travel to South Africa next week.
"Bill Clinton is going to turn the Presidency over to Al Gore before he leaves," says Dick Morris, an architect of Clinton's re-election. "Areas where Al Gore makes the decisions -- and the President rubber-stamps -- are science, technology, NASA, telecommunications, the environment, family leave, tobacco, nuclear dealings with the Russians, media violence, the Internet, privacy issues and, of course, reinventing Government. That's about a third of the Administration." In recent months, Gore, who describes Morris as "a brilliant strategist," has claimed other issues. They include a proposed medical bill of rights, expanded after-school care, organ donor transplants, juvenile justice and working with civic organizations to help welfare recipients manage the transition to employment.
While Gore contends that he is driven by policy and not politics, others in the White House say he has gone out of his way to boost himself with important Democratic constituencies. Last year's budget accord had something for everyone: For governors, Gore fought to eliminate the Medicaid per capita cap, which they opposed. For the poor, he made sure that recipients of earned income tax credits got their full benefits. For labor, he won several provisions, including assurances that workfare jobs are covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act. And for mayors, he pushed for the financing of another round of empowerment-zone tax breaks in inner cities and the extension of credits for contaminated urban "brownfields."
"It was a pivotal moment in the year," says Klain, Gore's chief of staff, adding that it was critical that Gore "get recognition for important pieces of the balanced-budget agreement." Another White House official, speaking anonymously, is more blunt: "Gore walked away with blacks, Hispanics, mayors and governors -- all thinking he did them this great service."
With an eye to 2000, Clinton joined Gore last year in blocking a plan by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas intended to streamline applications for public assistance. More than denying a political victory to Bush, a possible contender for the Republican presidential nomination, the move helped Gore woo labor groups. A crucial opponent of the Texas plan was Gerald McEntee, the president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
Gore has focused particularly on the pivotal primaries in Iowa and New Hampshire. Last fall, he managed to unearth $250 million in Federal Medicaid money for New Hampshire that the state did not expect. In Iowa, Gore fought for but failed to convince Congressional Republicans to extend past 2000 a highly lucrative tax credit for producers of ethanol, the corn-based fuel produced in the state.
Gore's highest priority is California, No. 1 in population, political prominence and fund raising. Gore has been attentive to Georgia because its primary comes soon after Iowa and New Hampshire. Florida is also critical because Clinton moved it to the Democratic column in 1996. Gore visits New York frequently, not only because it is a big state and important for fund raising, but because he knows his showing will be compared with his poor showing there in 1988. Gore is also tending to the three Middle Western states so important in both the primaries and the general election: Illinois, Ohio and Michigan.
The Vice President has also become the Administration's No. 1 bestower of bounty from Washington. Whenever Gore arrives in a city, he holds a news conference and with fanfare announces millions in Federal spending. The result, typically, is flattering local coverage, as in Florida recently, when The St. Petersburg Times trumpeted in huge type "Gore Delivers Housing Funds."
 
The Future
Terence McAuliffe, a Washington lawyer who was Clinton's chief fund raiser in the 1996 campaign, is so close to Gephardt that the Congressman was in his wedding and on Christmas morning in 1993 appeared at his door with a golden retriever puppy. Even so, Clinton's aides winced when McAuliffe showed up for a meeting in the Oval Office with a leather binder embossed with Gephardt's name and a Congressional seal. The next day, Klain, Gore's chief of staff, delivered McAuliffe a new binder, this one with the Vice Presidential seal and Gore's name. "Dear Terry," read the note from Klain, according to McAuliffe, "The Vice President specifically asked that I send this gift to you so the next time you're meeting in the Oval, you have the appropriate equipment."
Gore's advisers were so intent on adding McAuliffe's name to the Vice President's Christmas card list last year that he received eight identical cards from Gore. The wooing may pay off: McAuliffe is not expected to run Gore's fund-raising operation, but he is not expected to help Gephardt either. For Gore, that is a coup.
Beneath the friendly courtship is a deep preoccupation, even obsession, about Gephardt at the White House. Gore loyalists view Gephardt as the Vice President's most formidable rival for the nomination because he is popular among liberal constituencies that are important in the primaries, particularly unions. Gephardt has maintained his ties in Iowa since winning the caucuses there in 1988. Most important, no other Democrat has surfaced who seems as committed to taking on Gore. As a result, Gore is increasingly straying from his centrist ideology. "Any time Gephardt sticks his head out," says one Gore aide, "we pound it down."
Fretting about Gephardt, while understandable, seems premature. Every time Gephardt goads the Administration and Gore or his minions react, Gephardt gets more exposure. It could be that Gephardt's presence is good for Gore because it keeps out more appealing, fresh-faced contenders. "Maybe we want Gephardt," acknowledges a close Gore adviser. "You know where he's coming from. He takes up room. It's like the Clinton campaign hoping to get Bob Dole because you know Bob Dole." Perhaps Gore's advisers should heed the lesson from 1984, when former Vice President Walter Mondale devoted his energies to weakening Senator John Glenn of Ohio. Mondale's most threatening rival came out of nowhere: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado.
Yet it seems as though Gore cannot resist. Gore and Gephardt competed brutally in 1988 and the aftertaste lingers. "It's a fundamental competitive thing," says Roy Neel, one of Gore's confidants. Gephardt's advisers, he says, were "furious that Al Gore had come in and destroyed their strategy to be the alternative to Mike Dukakis."
Beyond Gephardt, there is no consensus in the Gore camp over who might pose the biggest threat. They are eyeing former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey because he could run as the clean Government outsider; he is popular with the press and could probably raise enough money to be competitive. Gore advisers are also watching Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska because he has endured Presidential primaries before and may appeal to the same centrist voters that are attracted to Gore. For now, Gore advisers think the possible candidacies of Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and Jesse Jackson may be helpful because they would eat into Gephardt's liberal base. There is the possibility that if further sex-scandal revelations paralyze the Administration, that could embolden others to take on Gore.
The principal goal of Gore's advisers is to discourage competitors and put down any development that could weaken the sense of Gore inevitability. So intent on killing off competition is he that Gore met late last year with Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont and suggested he not to run. The move made the Vice President appear a bit desperate -- and overly preoccupied with the primaries -- given that Dean is Governor of a tiny state (albeit a neighbor to New Hampshire) that lacks the resources to mount a vigorous race. Dean decided not to go forward, citing concerns in his state, while Gore advisers boasted that their effort paid off.
The Vice President's advisers had hoped they could eliminate his primary competition the way the White House did for Clinton in 1996. But many Democrats view Gore as too vulnerable for that to happen. Whatever the field, it will not be enough for Gore to barely cross the finish line; he will need to score big in the early primaries. Gore advisers are particularly concerned about the early Iowa caucuses because the Vice President did not compete there in 1988 and the caucuses, always unpredictable, play to the strengths of campaigns more geared to grass-roots organizing.
As much as Gore wants to win over the liberals who count so much in the primaries, he will have to be careful not to move too far left. To do so runs the standard risk of giving general-election ammunition to Republicans who could portray him as left wing and, worse yet, a panderer.
While his shadow campaign in the White House is of immense value, Gore needs to broaden the scope whom he brings into his orbit. His residence meetings bring together an inbred group of trusted advisers. He lacks a James Carville-style adviser who can develop a compelling message of why Al Gore should be President. Mike Murphy, a Republican image maker, is eager to offer hostile definitions: "Reorganizing Government to fire 2,000 employees, helping the Republicans cut welfare and increasing the Internet bandwidth," Murphy says, "is not a red-hot message to take into the Democratic primaries."
But the biggest danger for Gore is that there will be moments when he has to act swiftly, when he may not have time to consider every possible angle or plot out every strategy -- when he will have no choice but to respond spontaneously, using his instincts and not just his intellect. When he abandoned his usual preparedness and hurried into the White House press room last March, Gore was an utter failure in trying to defend his phone solicitations from the White House. Gore's path to the nomination will not be easy, because his vaunted discipline and preparation cannot always compensate for his weaknesses as a campaigner. "If he makes another big mistake in the near term, people may start saying he's mistake prone," says Tony Podesta, a Democratic strategist who sometimes advises Gore. "Everybody's watching to see how he does with the next bump in the road and how quickly he recovers."
Controversy seems to always send Gore retreating into his shell. Gore's advisers say he was so nervous about being asked about campaign finance that he put off being interviewed for this article for five months, until his fund-raising behavior was essentially cleared by Attorney General Janet Reno. Likewise, he would not consent to even one question about the Lewinsky case.
There is, of course, another scenario entertained by some prominent Democrats, but that is verboten at the White House: that Clinton will be forced to resign, leaving the top job to his loyal No. 2. Hours after the scandal broke, Democrats went as far as to speculate publicly about whom Gore might consider as his Vice President. (The names that kept coming up: Senator Dianne Feinstein of California and Gephardt.) But Gore's advisers feel far more comfortable talking about 2000. Barring an economic collapse, Gore seems destined to be his party's nominee. That perception brings new difficulties: Gore will be the target of choice in the Democratic field. Neel, for one, is bracing for political warfare. "Believe me, it won't only be about Dick Gephardt and Al Gore in 2000," he says. "It'll be about Bob Kerrey and John Kerry. It'll be about Bill Bradley and some other so-called reformer. This is not a friendly process. It is miserably adversarial and often petty. Enemies will be created."
Then, if Gore is lucky, will come the general election. If he makes it that far, the historical odds for Gore are not encouraging, at least until recently. Since Martin Van Buren in 1836, only one sitting Vice President has been elected President: George Bush.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 20; Column 2; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: On Language;
Washing Our Dishes

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
"She was a straight shooter -- and she had great dish," the book agent Lucianne Goldberg told Time magazine about her friend Linda Tripp, who accepted Ms Goldberg's advice to tape-record conversations with Monica S. Lewinsky. To The New Yorker's Jane Mayer, the literary agent explained: "I did it because it's . . .fascinating! I love dish! I live for dish!"
A language column's responsibility is to interpret, without taking sides or making moral judgments, the words churned up in the coverage of a story that has gripped the nation by its belt. What, then, does the noun dish signify? 
 Certainly not its standard English meaning, "a slightly concave plate on which to serve food." From that sense came its colloquial verb usage, to dish it out, meaning not just "to serve" but also "to administer punishment." Also from that sense of a plateful of food -- this time delicious -- comes the old slang usage "she's some dish," a lip-smacking compliment, as well as the adjective dishy, chiefly British, meaning "attractive," first spotted in The Sunday Telegraph in 1961: "He encountered the dishy St. Tropezienne on his holiday."
Nor does the current term, as used by the dish-loving Lucy, find its origin in the British slang verb to dish, meaning "destroy," first noted by the great lexicographer Francis Grose in his 1788 Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue: "He is completely dished up; he is totally ruined." When the conservative Tories stole the legislative clothes of the liberal Whigs by passing the radical reform bill of 1867, the Prime Minister, Lord Derby, delightedly chortled, "Don't you see we have dished the Whigs?"
Focus on the American slang noun, first cited by J. E. Lighter in the Random House Historical Dictionary of American Slang, from Martin P. Levine's 1979 book, "Gay Men": "Calculated camp, packed so that people will think she's bringing them the real 'dish' from the inside." Lighter attributes this synonym for skinny to homosexual lingo, meaning "gossip; spiteful or malicious comments," rooted in a verb citation in Cory & LeRay's 1963 "The Homosexual and Society": "To gossip. . .often used when such gossip involves the person's sexual activities and amative interests."
My own speculation is that the current slang noun is rooted in the alliterative slang phrase to dish the dirt, as used by P. G. Wodehouse in 1964: "He thinks you fall short in the way of dishing the dirt." That uses dirt as "gossip" the way Ernest Hemingway did in "The Sun Also Rises" in 1926: " 'Do you know any dirt?' I asked. 'No.' 'None of your exalted connections getting divorces?' "
Thus, when Ms Goldberg exults, "I love dish!" she expresses her delight in dishing the dirt, which may have a political effect in dishing an American Whig.
 
DROP THAT DIME
"When you hook a wire to somebody," complained Paul Begala, an aide to President Clinton angry at the investigative techniques of the office of independent counsel, " . . . and then you turn and drop the dime in a phone and call the press, that's not the kind of investigation people need."
Most people under 40 would find that reference to a coin baffling. One does not get a dial tone with anything less than a quarter; in Washington and environs, the price of a local call from a coin-operated phone has just gone up to 35 cents. Is the President's defender unaware of the ravages of inflation over the past generation?
No; he was speaking metaphorically, and metaphors do not take seasonal or even generational adjustment. To drop a dime, in underworld lingo, has meant "to inform the police," with the squealing being done over the telephone, often anonymously by the informer, who is referred to by the squealed-upon as a rat, fink, snitch or tipster.
The recipient of the call refers to the fink as a whistle-blower. Different figures of speech for different folks: a bad guy doing good inserts a coin to make a surreptitious call, making himself a dime-dropper, while a good guy blows a piercing whistle, making himself a much-admired (though sometimes prosecuted) whistle-blower.
Mr. Begala has extended the coin metaphor from an informant calling the police to a police source calling the press. In so doing, he takes the shadiness attached to the dime-dropper ratting on his underworld buddies and imputes it to the police source speaking to the press. In his extension, however, the spinmeister has not spoiled the trope by trying to update it by saying something as awkward as "the manipulative investigator dropped a dime plus a quarter to leak to the media." That would spoil the effect.
That's how we intentionally preserve anachronisms. Feel free to have your dialing machine leave a message on my answering machine about all this; it's your nickel.
 
ON 'DIRTY' WORDS
"(Warning: pun ahead)," writes Walter Kirn in Time magazine, and then writes of a Presidential passion for lawyerly phraseology that the writer calls "cunning linguistics." The pun is on cunnilingus, counterpart to fellatio in oral sex.
As the scandal is revealed or rebutted, we are sure to be exposed to words or allusions not previously used in what was once called "mixed company" or in the presence of children. As the dimes are dropped and the dirt gets dished, we should remember that the words themselves are not dirty, but it is the behavior described or accused that can be scandalous or tawdry (from "Saint Audrey," a Norwich church fair at which cheap lace was sold).
Shakespeare's King Henry IV worries that his son, the hot-blooded Prince Hal, is picking up gross terms through his youthful association with the dregs of society, and this carousing might lead to "unguided days/And rotten times." The Earl of Warwick reassures the King, "The Prince but studies his companions/Like a strange tongue." Warwick then extends his word picture, sending a message to those today who feel queasy about salacious terms used to describe actions at the seat of power:
"to gain the language,/'Tis needful that the most immodest word/Be look'd upon and learnt."
