SECTION: Section 2; Page 36; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 327 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Era of Boogie-Woogie as Well as War

BYLINE: By ANITA GATES

 BODY:
WHITE-HAIRED ladies in Mobile, Ala., talk about how wild they were in their youth; the times were so uncertain. A retired Episcopal bishop talks about growing up wealthy in New Jersey, with a large household staff, in a style that doesn't exist anymore. Charles Durning talks about landing in Normandy on D-Day, without his rifle.
The 1940's are rarely examined for anything other than the decade's central event, World War II, and the baby boom that followed it. But the period was one of enormous change that went way beyond wartime needs, as "America in the 40's," a three-hour PBS film on Wednesday night at 8, illustrates. 
 It was a decade of inventions. For the first time, you could write a check with a ballpoint pen (in a store now air-conditioned) to buy nylon stockings, a butane cigarette lighter, cake mix, Dial soap or anything wrapped in cellophane. (Other than the check, all became available between 1940 and 1949.)
It was a time of social upheaval. Young men came home to families who could not possibly understand what they had been through. Many veterans flocked to college, on the G.I. Bill of Rights. And working mothers, who had been acclaimed as heroines for keeping the factories going, were suddenly declared a social problem.
Then there were the songs. "The music of the time was either cheerful and upbeat or sentimental," says Tom Spain, the film's producer. When war breaks out while an economic depression is still lingering, he says, "good cheer and sentiment" are "very important qualities."
More than three dozen hits of the era are part of the film, giving it a vintage music-video feel at times. They include "I Got Rhythm" and "Boogie-Woogie Bugle Boy" (both upbeat), "I'll Be Seeing You," "It's Been a Long, Long Time" and "I'll Be Home for Christmas" (all sentimental). Not to mention "Bring Enough Clothes for Three Days" and "Leave the Dishes in the Sink." (They couldn't all be classics.) ANITA GATES

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Where Nijinsky and Pavlova Did Their First Plies

BYLINE: By ROBERT JOHNSON; Robert Johnson is a dance historian and critic.

 BODY:
RUSSIAN BALLET has fascinated audiences in the West for nearly 100 years, and anyone who wants to know why can find out this week, when a group of young dancers from St. Petersburg arrives at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Starting Wednesday, 65 students of the renowned Vaganova Ballet Academy will appear in four performances with recent graduates who are now stars of the Kirov Ballet.
The Vaganova (pronounced va-GAHN-uh-vah) Academy has generally been regarded as the greatest school of dance in the Western world. Balletomanes touring Russia stop in St. Petersburg to gaze reverentially at the musty classrooms that produced luminous dancers like Vaslav Nijinsky, Anna Pavlova, Rudolf Nureyev, Natalia Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov. For political and economic reasons, pupils in the Vaganova Academy have never before appeared in New York, and they arrive now several years after the appearances of two other acclaimed schools: the Bolshoi Ballet Academy of Moscow and the Paris Opera Ballet School. 
 With the Kirov soloists, the Vaganova students, ages 11 to 17, will perform eight dances, including excerpts from favorites by Marius Petipa like "Giselle," "La Bayadere" and "Don Quixote" as well as "The Little Humpbacked Horse," a rarity little known outside Russia. On Saturday afternoon, the Vaganova corps will present a special program, led by the school's artistic director, Igor Belsky, intended to demonstrate their system of training. They will also perform that day with students from New York City Ballet's School of American Ballet, which was founded by George Balanchine, himself a 1921 graduate of the Vaganova Academy when it was called the Petrograd State Choreographic School. It was renamed the Vaganova Academy in 1957.
This academy was founded in St. Petersburg in 1738, but its present name reflects the genius of a woman who died in 1951. By the time the ballerina Agrippina Vaganova began teaching there in 1921, Russia had acquired a trove of saltatory art and experience. Yet this treasure very nearly disappeared, a casualty of World War I and the Russian Revolution. Vaganova's first great accomplishment was to protect the ballet from destruction.
Her achievement went beyond preservation. During 29 years as teacher of the academy's graduating class, Vaganova used her analytical intelligence to standardize the curriculum. She dissected the classical vocabulary, discovering the mechanics of each step and determining the logic behind combinations. Scrutinizing both muscular and emotional processes, she arrived at what is now referred to as the Vaganova Method. This method distilled the essence of the Russian classical tradition and style that had evolved over the years, synthesizing French, Italian and Russian influences, and the Vaganova syllabus further reflected the athletic demands of 20th-century Soviet choreography.
Blending form with emotion was key. "The goal," said Ms. Makarova, "was to help ballet students develop a sense of movement, using technical exercises as a means to reveal their inner emotional potential."
When Vaganova published her pedagogy in 1934, under the title "Fundamentals of Classical Dance," she helped raise ballet to a new plateau. Vaganova can be compared to Louis XIV's ballet master Pierre Beauchamp, who is credited with standardizing the five positions of the feet. Her book, a milestone similar to Carlo Blasis's 1830 "Code of Terpsichore," established her as a master educator of 20th-century dance.
The academy is still run largely as it was in Vaganova's day, and getting into it is not easy. Examiners choose only 50 students -- 30 girls and 20 boys -- from thousands of hopefuls who present themselves each year, underscoring the fact that ballet in Russia remains a source of national pride in the midst of economic disarray. The average number of students in each classroom, 12, remains the same as when the academy was founded.
Students graduate at age 17 with a baccalaureate degree, which approximates two years at an American college. The curriculum includes a complete course of study in the humanities, with specialized classes in the history of theater, music, art and ballet; acting classes in the Stanislavsky method, and lessons in piano and music theory and appreciation.
Various kinds of dance classes -- historical, character and a mixture of modern and jazz -- supplement the ballet instruction. The young people study pas de deux as a separate subject, and they learn the entire corps de ballet repertory of the Kirov. The academy also offers graduate programs for aspiring teachers, choreographers and ballet accompanists. Everyone who teaches in the school has taken a four-year teachers' program devised by Vaganova.
An awareness of tradition contributes mightily to the students' education. "The most significant thing about the Vaganova School," Ms. Makarova recalled of her time there, "was the daily, unobtrusive feeling of contact with the great ballet of the past, its traditions and unwritten laws."
While Mr. Belsky favors acquainting his charges with contemporary Western choreography, he has no plans to tamper with the school's basic method of teaching, he said. As he pointed out, the present system "gives very good results."
Contributing to these results is the sheer physical rigor of the dance classes. Ms. Makarova characterized the school's atmosphere as one of "life in service of the arts." Mr. Belsky, one of Ms. Makarova's former teachers, described the ambiance more bluntly. "Severity, severity, and again, severity," he said.
The students who will appear at BAM are well aware of their responsibilities in sustaining a major cultural tradition. In their Saturday program, as the pupils take their places at onstage barres, spectators will be able to examine the fine points of the Vaganova style. These include an emphasis on precision and a special vitality that derives from body awareness.Other trademarks are a flexible back, harmonious coordination of the limbs and elegant hand movements. The dancers' sensitivity to musical phrasing relates in part to their preparation for performance in a dramatic repertory. Outstanding members of the graduating class, according to Mr. Belsky, include Alesia Boiko, Irina Golub and Anton Korsakov, all 17 years old.
MEANWHILE, THE Kirov soloists will present their specialties, although one of the most talented, Andrei Batalov, will not make the trip. Diana Vishneva, who got rave reviews for her performance in Balanchine's "Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux" at the New York State Theater last November, is reportedly injured and will also stay home. However, while there has been some confusion about just which members of the Kirov will come to BAM, it looks as if the cool and beautiful Uliana Lopatkina will dance the complete "Shades" act from "La Bayadere," partnered by Igor Zelensky.
David Eden, producer of the BAM event, explained why he wanted the "Shades" scene to conclude the program. As a seemingly endless line of ballerinas enters the stage, each one repeating the steps of the one before her, the image symbolizes Russian ballet tradition itself. "It's about continuity," he said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Insurance Companies;
A New Awakening in Real Estate Investment

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
INSURANCE companies used to be conservative players in the commercial real estate investment game. But many have become more aggressive and are changing their way of doing business.
Prompted by a marketplace flush with public capital, lessons learned from the last recession and changes in how they account for their real estate holdings, insurers in the New York area, as in the nation, are diversifying their portfolios and adding liquidity. And some are cashing out of the game for good, industry experts say. 
 "Those companies still in real estate are there to stay," said Carol D. Nichols, senior managing director at the Manhattan office of the Capital Advisers Group, the investment arm of Insignia/ESG, the national brokerage company. "They understand the competition with Wall Street so they are pro-actively managing their balance sheets, paying closer attention to their assets and liabilities and broadening their array of investment vehicles."
And they, like other investors, "are using real estate to produce higher returns on their investments," added Kim E. Mowers, a senior vice president at the Stamford office of Grubb & Ellis, another national real estate brokerage.
To that end insurers are reducing the amount of properties they would normally hold over a long period by selling them to or swapping them for stock in deep-pocketed companies like real estate investment trusts. In turn, they are investing in more liquid as well as higher yielding forms of real estate.
"The advantage is they can stay in real estate and can get out quickly too, "said Mr. Mowers.
Over the last 18 months insurers have sold 48 properties totaling 7.6 million square feet in the New York region, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage.
The greatest number of properties -- 22, totaling 2.9 million square feet -- were in New Jersey, followed by Fairfield County, with 10, totaling 1.5 million square feet. Nine of the properties totaling 2.25 million square feet were in Manhattan. In the same period, insurers bought three properties totaling 859,365 square feet.
Recent sales include three office towers in downtown Manhattan -- 44 Wall Street, 61 Broadway and 67 Broad Street, sold respectively by New York Life Insurance Company, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, both in Manhattan, and Principal Financial Group of Des Moines, which sells and acquires properties for the Principal Mutual Life Insurance Company.
The selling continues. The Newark-based Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest life insurer, expects to close soon on its sale of Prudential Business Campus, an 875,357-square-foot office park with land for 1.4 million more square feet, straddling Parsippany and East Hanover, N.J. Prudential co-owns the campus with US West Real Estate of Englewood, Colo.
THE sale is part of Prudential's plan to reduce by mid-1999 the $5.5 billion in real estate it directly owns. "We are selling some, converting some to REIT shares and investing some in higher yielding investments," said David Twardock, senior managing director in charge of general account real estate investments at Prudential.
"The market is deep and there is no shortage of capital or buyers," he said.
REITs are among the most aggressive buyers, underscoring the trend toward public ownership of real estate. Indeed, Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, among the nation's largest REITs, is said to be the top contender for Prudential Business Campus.
"It's a game of musical chairs with assets going from one holder to another," said Douglas H. Haynes, president of Alexander Summer, a brokerage in Paramus, N.J. "What happened was the arrival of public capital to a closed cowboy industry and insurers are learning to play in the new game."
But what is the impact on the market?
"It's all healthy," said Andrew J. Merin, executive managing director at the Financial Services Group of Cushman & Wakefield. Insurers are diversifying, which is good for their business and good for the market since the liquidity will give temper the often volatile real estate market, said Mr. Merin .
But, he cautioned, "with the lack of quality office product in the region everyone is looking at development."
"While there is enough demand this year I'm not sure there will be in 2000," he said.
For insurers the focus today is on diversification, liquidity and opportunity. In the past they would provide mortgages on or invest money in properties and hold them as long-term investments. Then they would either refinance or sell those properties and start the process over.
One of the risks is if the market misbehaves. "Insurance companies took back a lot of properties in the late 80's and early 90's and needed the market to turn around in order to sell," said Michael Berman, vice president at LaSalle Partners, a real estate service and investment firm in Manhattan. "By the mid-90's the market was coming to them."
Last September New York Life sold 44 Wall Street for $23.5 million. The insurer, which had a $170 million real estate portfolio in the region prior to the sale, had taken back the property through foreclosure. The buyer, a Manhattan partnership of Murray Hill Properties and CS First Boston, will retain the 300,000-square-foot, 45 percent occupied building, as offices.
In December, Principal Financial sold the mostly vacant 640,000-square-foot 67 Broad Street for $45 million to Greystone, a Manhattan-based partnership, which may use it for residential or office use or both. Earlier last year, it also sold a 1.2-million-square-foot industrial building in South Plainfield, N.J. Nationwide, Principal sold 4.8 million square feet of commercial space last year for a total $260 million.
The hope is to do twice that or more this year, said John N. Urban, Principal's director of asset management. "We funnel the money back into growing lines of businesses and less risky forms of real estate," he said, noting that his company has turned an investor's eye to the New York City and northern New Jersey markets.
Some insurers that sell to REITs want to take at least part of their payment in REIT shares.
LAST year Prudential sold $2.4 billion of its hotels and office buildings and developable land, including two Hilton hotels, one in Parsippany and another in Newark. The figure includes a Times Square site at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street that it has under contract to the Rudin Organization and Reuters American Holdings, who plan to build a headquarters for the British media giant.
In 1996 Prudential sold its site at the southeast corner of Broadway and 43d Street to the Durst Organization, whose building is in construction.
Part of Prudential's payment for last year's sales was nearly $300 million in REIT shares, Mr. Twardock said, noting that if the market sours "we can just sell the stock" rather than trying to sell a building.
The company also retains development rights in some of its properties and invests sale proceeds in what Mr. Twardock describes as higher yielding assets, includingwarehouses in China. "There are opportunities as well as risks, but we do not see our vision changing," he said.
Metropolitan Life in the last two years sold half of its $14 billion portfolio. Along with 61 Broadway the properties included a 600,000-square-foot office complex in Woodbridge, N.J.
"We were heavy on offices so we wanted to reposition our portfolio and gain a better balance of different properties," said Tricia Curtin-Munley, investment manager at the company. "We are moving things out quicker, rather than holding them for the long-term."
The goal is to maximize returns, not build up REIT shares, Ms. Curtin-Munley said, even though in some instances her company has taken REIT shares in partial payments. She said the company is catching its breath before it starts buying again.
Meanwhile, Chubb Insurance Company, in Warren, N.J., has left the field. Last year it sold 8.2 million square feet of space, the bulk of its commercial portfolio. The buyer -- a joint venture among Paine Webber, Morgan Stanley and Gale & Wentworth, a real estate firm in Florham Park, N.J. -- paid $700 million for the properties, most in north Jersey.
"It's a real estate and capital market play," said Mark R. Yeager, president of Gale & Wentworth's commercial group, referring to the insurers' selling spree. The market is healthier, but "this is not nirvana," he said, adding that the market would eventually ebb.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 22; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1300 words

HEADLINE: A LA CARTE;
Building the Island's Most Lavish Restaurant

BYLINE: By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM 

 BODY:
THE story behind Louis XVI, the most lavish restaurant to open on the Island in years, is as distinctive as the restaurant itself.
The restaurant was built, furnished and staffed with money made at two diners and at a family restaurant on Main Street in Patchogue. The modest profit from thousands of simple dishes served over two decades at the Harborside, in Patchogue, and the Expressway and Royal Oak diners in Hauppauge and Bellport, paid for the fancy period interior columns and fine art from Paris, the glistening crystal chandeliers and, most of all, the staff recruited from three- and four-star restaurants of Manhattan. 
 No doubt because the road leading to Louis XVI was such a long and winding one, Jimmy Boboris, its manager and part-owner, moved cautiously and carefully. Mr. Boboris's brother George and cousin Constantine Demas, are the other owners.
The waterfront property, once a hotel, then a modest Italian restaurant, was purchased five years ago. Construction began a year later when the entire site was raised seven feet to lessen the chances of incursions from the Great South Bay. It was the first of many upgrades.
Mr. Boboris, who had worked at a luxury restaurant in Athens before coming to this country, made progress slowly. Remembering all the time it took to accrue the funds necessary to proceed, he waited for a favorable, local economic climate necessary to support a major elegant dining establishment.
Over the four years he, along with his partners, hired architects and interior decorators, supervised construction, visited Paris to acquire authentic Louis XVI art and furnishings and, most of all, used the contacts they had had made during 25 years in the restaurant business to recruit a professional staff and lure them to Patchogue.
To assist in this endeavor, he hired Antoine Bouterin as a consultant. Mr. Bouterin, whom Mr. Boboris calls his "insurance policy," earned his culinary spurs at Le Perigord in Manhattan, before opening Bouterin's on the East Side. His primary task was to find an outstanding executive chef for Louis XVI, and he delivered. He invited Jean-Claude Teulade, the sous chef at Le Cote Basque, to visit Patchogue.
An ebullient Frenchman, with a dark, dramatic Dali-style mustache, he liked what he saw, and, promised a free hand, he signed on. He moved his family from Manhattan and fell in love with Patchogue.
When asked why he gave up the glamour of the city for Long Island, he replied, "Here I am the chef, I can decide, I can do what I want." Mr. Teulade, who has worked at Maxim's, Tour d'Argent and the Eiffel Tower Restaurant in Paris, also noted that although the kitchen was the same size as the one at Le Cote Basque, it served 100 diners while the one in the city had to provide for 250 people.
When Mr. Teulade was told to buy the best ingredients available, he made his mother in Toulouse his prime source of supply. She regularly sends him packages of spices, herbs and other difficult-to-find foodstuffs.
Mr. Boboris and Mr. Bouterin became a two-man, headhunting company. The few restaurant people one of them did not know, the other did. They then invited Andy Kormendi, a sophisticated Budapest-born captain from Aureole in Manhattan, to take a look. He reacted in a big way, saying, "I couldn't believe this was happening in Patchogue and thought, wouldn't it be great to be on the ocean and see sunsets instead of the buildings across the street?"
He became the maitre d'hotel and used his connections and experience at Aureole, Bouley, Chantilly, the Russian Tea Room and Maxwell's Plum to advantage. Working with Mr. Boboris, he enticed another captain from Aureole, a waiter from Bouley and an up-and-coming pastry chef from Chantilly to come aboard.
He also trained the wait staff from the ground up, stating, "Every other restaurant I went to was set. Here I had a bigger role with a free hand to hire help and set up systems."
Mr. Kormendi, who is also a consultant at Placido Domingo's restaurant in Manhattan, worked for weeks on the basics: how to line up tables, how to put a tablecloth on, when to remove plates, silverware placement and how to handle and clean stemware without breaking it.
Meanwhile, Mr. Boboris was hiring two well-known Island chefs, Blake Verity from Panama Hatties as a sous chef and Joseph Felicetta of Fusion Grille and Octopus Garden as a captain. Although both men are looking for their own restaurants, they lend an important, if temporary, Island perspective to Louis XVI.
From the beginning, the restaurant's owners and chefs agreed that its menu would be a conservative, middle-of-the-road, rather than cutting-edge affair, that it would be main line. not nouveau or nouvelle French.
Mr. Boboris explained: "There are so many different types of French restaurants in the city and so few here. We can't be too specialized, wild or way out. We also don't want to intimidate our customers with a lot of French terms. There is no snobbery here. And so the friendly, familiar French menu lists such traditionals dishes as escargot, rack of lamb, pheasant, lobster and creme boule."
The clientele at Louis XVI requests at least four or five orders of caviar a night, (at a supplement of $35) and specials like farm-raised rabbit are very popular. So future menus (there will be four or five a year) will offer still more adventurous dishes.
The future also holds plans for dining outside in a tent or beside European-style gardens on an outdoor waterside deck. There is also the possibility of a private dock for hungry boatsmen.
Before any of that, the second of the high-ceilinged dining rooms that will cater special events must be opened. The methodical Mr. Boboris is, as usual, in no hurry. Despite the fact that the unopened room represents almost half of his enterprise, "maybe April, maybe May," he said.
"We have a good thing going here now. We don't want to change that. We will be sure we're ready before we move."
 
Wine Tastings
Le Petit Bijou, on Sunrise Highway in Lynbrook (764-5858), is presenting predictions for 1998 at a psychic wine dinner on Tuesday at 7 P.M. Each course of its $50 meal will be accompanied by predictions from Zoe and Claudia, two psychics. Palm reading, astrology, tea-leaf reading and crystal balls will be used throughout the evening. The main course is Lapseng-souchong smoked duck with an orange miso jus, and jasmine rice griddle cake paired with a Tarapaca Chilean reserve merlot.
Bobby Van's Restaurant, in Bridgehampton (537-0590), is holding a $55 fine arts and food festival next Sunday at 6 P.M. The evening will start with a four-course meal with wines from Palmer Vineyard. Live jazz will be supplied by Andy Boracci and his combo. Art is being furnished courtesy of the Sundance Gallery.
On Thursday, La Marmite, 234 Hillside Avenue, Williston Park (746-1245), will be holding a winter wine tasting and dinner featuring the wines of Robert Mondavi. Dinner will be accompanied by the operatic sounds of Michael Crouse, a tenor, and Maria Guariglia, a soprano. Cocktails begin at 6:30 P.M. The evening costs $85. The menu includes a second course of Mediterranean John Dory filet wrapped in lettuce in a light beurre blanc sauce.
Catalina Seafood Company Restaurant, 135 Old Country Road, Carle Place (741-4141), is holding a series of winter California wine dinners on Tuesday evenings at 7:30 P.M. Each dinner features wines from a different California winery. The evening includes unlimited wine as well as a three-course meal with dessert. Wine experts will be on hand to answer questions and discuss the featured wines. A pre-paid reservation of $45 a person is required. This Tuesday will be devoted to Cambria chardonnay, pinot noir, syrah and sangiovese.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1524 words

HEADLINE: As Crisis Nears, Affordable Units Of Housing Lag

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
IN Westchester, one of the wealthiest counties in the United States, more than 12 percent of the households -- 38,400 -- live in deficient and overcrowded housing. Still, six years after the Board of Legislators called for 5,000 units of affordable housing by the turn of the century, little is being accomplished toward that goal, a study by an independent advisory group has found.
What is more, the shortage of affordable housing is quickly reaching crisis proportions, making Westchester inhospitable to many working-class families, according to the advisory group, the Westchester County Housing Opportunity Commission. 
 "This is hardly a popular subject in Westchester," George Raymond, the commission's chairman, said recently, adding that only 19 of Westchester's 43 municipalities have adopted resolutions endorsing affordable housing.
And even among communities supporting the concept in principle, many have yet to build any affordable units. With only 270 new affordable units being added each year to the current stock of 2,500, it seems unlikely that the county will attain the goal of the Board of Legislators by 2000, he said.
County Executive Andrew J. Spano, however, is of a different mind. Westchester's poor record notwithstanding, he announced on Tuesday that he would meet the 5,000-unit objective within four years -- by the end of his first term. "We have to set our goals high," he said.
Mr. Spano said he favored using available housing stock in areas where land for new development is in short supply. He vowed to review the municipalities that had not adopted resolutions and start a campaign to educate the public in those localities.
The 19 communities that have adopted policies favoring affordable housing are the cities of Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and Peekskill, the towns of Eastchester, Greenburgh, Mamaroneck, New Castle and Ossining and the villages of Ardsley, Briarcliff, Croton-on-Hudson, Dobbs Ferry, Elmsford, Hastings-on-Hudson, Irvington, Mamaroneck, Ossining, Rye Brook and Tarrytown.
Examples of successful ventures are the Hommocks Park Apartments in Mamaroneck, which contains market-rate and affordable rentals, and the Arch Condominiums in Sleepy Hollow, which has six affordable ownership units.
The county gives money and technical assistance to sponsors of low- and moderate-income housing, often working in partnership with developers, housing organizations, community and church groups and Federal and state agencies, Lawrence C. Salley, the Deputy Planning Commissioner, said.
Since 1991, the Planning Department has partly paid for more than 429 units of ownership housing and more than 655 units of rental housing in various municipalities. Yet, despite the help available, the resistance to affordable housing continues, Mr. Salley said.
"Without local acceptance, it is extremely difficult," Mr. Salley said. "There are a lot of unfounded myths, like affordable housing will decrease property values, when in fact, the contrary has been documented."
Nowhere has the unwelcomeness of affordable housing been seen more clearly in recent months than in fierce zoning and housing battles in Scarsdale.
With 5,500 homes and 16,000 residents, Scarsdale has done nothing to meet goals set by the commission. The village's poor record has prompted Jeanne Richman, a resident and Chairwoman of the County Planning Board, to call for "at least some small percentage to show that we care."
She continued: "Every community has people who need affordable housing, and Scarsdale has them too. We should not export our problems to other communities."
Meetings about building affordable units for the elderly and allowing so-called accessory apartments in Scarsdale have recently ended in heated arguments. Mrs. Richman explained that even though accessory apartments would not officially be classified as affordable housing, they would probably be "within the reach of those who otherwise might not be able to afford to buy a house here."
But the apartment issue, like that of affordable housing, has engendered intense opposition.
"This type of housing, often the mark of a neighborhood in transition, always proliferates in declining neighborhoods, such as parts of Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, the Bronx and Brooklyn, even the north end of White Plains, etc.," Ralph W. Kern, a resident, wrote in a letter to the village's Board of Trustees last fall.
In some communities, the issue of affordable housing has been so controversial that projects have not made it past the drawing board. In Harrison in 1993, a plan to provide affordable housing for 28 families was halted in the face of fears that the units would degrade property values. In Eastchester, a proposal for 60 units was dropped for similar reasons.
Sometimes, racial bias fuels the opposition, with municipalities worrying that blacks, residents of Hispanic descent and other minority groups who qualify for affordable housing will degrade a neighborhood, said Winston A. Ross, regional director for the Westchester chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
In North Salem in the late 1980's, town officials rezoned 63 acres of lakefront property to prevent the building of 184 town houses and some affordable units on the site. The builder sued the town in 1987 for eliminating the multifamily housing, claiming the ordinance was unconstitutional -- a claim that was upheld first by State Supreme Court in White Plains, then by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court and finally by the State Court of Appeals in Albany. In 1990 the State Court of Appeals invalidated North Salem's ordinance against multifamily housing and ordered the town to allow the builder to proceed. But since then the builder has sold most of the lakefront property and is not going to build.
An earlier case, Berenson v. Town of New Castle, filed in State Supreme Court in White Plains in 1975, determined that local zoning must balance "the local desire to maintain the status quo within the community and the greater public interest that needs be met." Despite these litigations, the Housing Opportunity Commission reports that Westchester has continued to lag in confronting the problem of "a huge imbalance between household incomes and housing prices and rents." The report cited statistics showing that 150,000 residents, or 17.5 percent of the county's population, are so strained economically that they must feed themselves through food stamps, soup kitchens and food pantries.
Many residents, according to the report, pay an excessive share of their incomes for shelter -- "often at the expense of other basic life necessities."
The report also stated that many municipalities in Westchester "are especially vulnerable" to lawsuits because the county has officially established both the regional need for affordable housing and each municipality's allocation, based on the land area of the community, growth in employment and the number of overcrowded units, among other factors. Scarsdale, for example, should provide 135 units of affordable housing by 2000, White Plains 245 and Cortlandt, 137, according to the Housing Opportunity Commission's allocation plan.
One legal challenge, involving a builder who was suing Cortlandt, was resolved last month in State Supreme Court in White Plains. The court, ruling that the town's zoning was unconstitutional, not only ordered Cortlandt to rezone to allow the developer to build multifamily and affordable units but also approved the Housing Opportunity Commission's allocation of units in the county's various municipalities.
Still, the slowness to develop affordable housing is most likely to continue, in part because builders have recently been lured away by a thriving luxury-housing market, said Rose Noonan, executive director of the Housing Action Council, a nonprofit technical assistance organization, which helps developers, communities and other nonprofit groups build affordable housing.
"Five years ago, the game was affordable housing because the market was down," said Bill Balter, a co-owner of Wilder Balter Partners in Elmsford, a real estate developer. "Clearly there's a profit in the affordable housing business, but not the kind of profit of luxury market-rate housing."
Despite community resistance and economic pressures, there have been some happy endings, most recently in White Plains.
"We're on our way toward finally becoming a success story," said Thor H. Anderson, president of Shore, which stands for Sheltering the Homeless Is Our Responsibility.
After years of objections from neighborhood associations, the volunteer organization will finally put its shovel in the ground this spring for seven town house units for middle-income earners, with each unit containing a rental apartment for the formerly homeless.
Mr. Salley also cited as success stories 22 rental units in Irvington, 120 assisted-living units for the elderly in Peekskill, 62 two-family, owner-rental units in Yonkers and 10 similar units in New Rochelle.
"There are a lot of good things in the works," he said.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Americans Are Heeding The Call of the Loon

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
The Canadian "loonie" has been attracting Americans in record numbers. Canadian currency -- which has a loon pictured on the one-dollar coin -- is trading near its all-time low, having dropped nearly 10 percent in value over the last year.
In British Columbia, bookings by American skiers at Whistler, a resort area north of Seattle, are running more than 60 percent ahead of last year, the Whistler Resort Association said. At Casino Windsor, across the river from Detroit, 150 extra employees have been hired to handle the increase in American gamblers. Same-day car trips -- an indicator of cross-border shopping -- reached a 17-year record of 2.1 million in November, the most recent month for which Government statistics are available. 
 At recent rates, $100 would buy about 143 Canadian dollars, before banks add on exchange fees. At the consumer rate available last week at American Express offices in New York City, for example, $100 bought $138 Canadian. A year ago, $100 would have bought $129 Canadian at Amex.
The Asian financial crisis combined with low interest rates in Canada are the main reasons for the loonie's swoon, as Canadian headline writers put it. The Asian turmoil has prompted investors to take money out of those countries, seeking financial security elsewhere. They have preferred the United States dollar to Canada's because of higher interest rates in the United States.
With Canadian unemployment at about 9 percent, about twice that in the United States, and virtually no inflation, the Canadian central bank sees no reason to raise interest rates. So, the favorable exchange rate for Americans headed north seems likely to continue for a while. STEVE LOHR

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Strategies For Selling A Co-op

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
WHILE the basic strategy for selling an apartment is the same as that for selling a single-family house -- accentuate the positive and, if possible, eliminate the negative -- community living often makes some additional strategies necessary.
"It doesn't occur to most people that when they're selling their apartment, they're selling their building as well," said David Kuperberg, president of Cooper Square Realty in Manhattan. "And in any sale first impressions are critical." 
 One of the best ways to sell a house, for example, is to enhance its "curb appeal" by trimming the lawn, sweeping the porch and putting a fresh coat of paint on the front door. And while apartment owners can do little about the entrance to their building, Mr. Kuperberg said, they should still consider the impact of curb appeal on potential buyers.
"You have to look at your building with fresh eyes," Mr. Kuperberg said. "Watch how the staff reacts when someone walks in the door. Is the doorman friendly? Does the staff have clean uniforms? Is the lobby clean and neat? All these things make an impression on a potential buyer."
Frequently, Mr. Kuperberg said, people become unaware of things they encounter every day. A color scheme in the lobby that was trendy a decade ago may be tacky today if one were to take the time to look at it. Lobby furniture that is dated, dusty or even dirty may be ignored by residents who see it every day but rarely use it. An elevator that is prone to bouncy stops or starts may be merely quirky to long-time residents, but terrifying to those unprepared for such eccentricities.
"These are the things a buyer will see before he even gets inside your apartment," Mr. Kuperberg said. While it might seem that such matters are beyond the control of individual shareholders, he said, that is not the case.
Mr. Kuperberg explained that board members had the responsibility to make sure that the building is both properly maintained and well managed. If a board lives up to its responsibilities apartments in the building should command high sale prices, he said. And that should be sufficient incentive for boards and managing agents to cooperate with shareholders who make legitimate requests.
"Lobby the board to fix up the common areas," he said. "Be prepared to approach the board members with specific, reasonable suggestions that work to everyone's benefit."
In many cases, real estate experts say, purchasing decisions are based as much upon emotion as they are upon economics -- with the initial "feeling" that a potential buyer gets when entering a home or apartment inevitably coloring subsequent impressions.
Accordingly, they say, the look and feel of an apartment when a potential buyer walks through the door constitutes the seller's first and best opportunity to capture the buyer's attention.
"One of the most important and least expensive things you can do to make an apartment appealing is to wash the windows," said Enid Hamlin, director of advertising and public relations for Lawrence Properties in Manhattan.
Even windows that frame less-than-perfect views will look better if they are clean, Ms. Hamlin said. Often, she said, it is possible to block out uninspiring views or maintain privacy -- while still allowing light into an apartment -- by using curtains or shades on the bottom half of the window and leaving the top unobstructed.
In addition, Ms. Hamlin said, it never hurts for a seller who knows that an apartment will be shown that day to leave the curtains open, the shades up, the lights on and have fresh flowers on the table and music playing softly in the background.
"Seeing an apartment for the first time should be almost like a theatrical experience," she said. "And you want to set the scene as nicely as possible."
In fact, every expert interviewed pointed out that the initial "feel" of an apartment is of extraordinary significance to most buyers -- a point overlooked by many sellers.
"You would be shocked at how many times we go in to show an apartment and the beds aren't even made," said Barbara Fox, president of Fox Residential Group in Manhattan.
Ms. Fox said that when her office takes a sales listing, the seller is provided with a checklist of things to be addressed to present an apartment in the best light possible. One of the most important things a seller can do, she said, particularly in situations where the size of an apartment is limited, is to keep clutter to a minimum.
"Put everything you don't need into storage," she said, adding that elimination of clutter in a cramped apartment is so important that it would even be worthwhile to rent outside storage space if space isn't available in the building. And sellers should avoid the temptation, she said, of eliminating clutter in rooms by transferring it to closets.
"The more cluttered a closet is the smaller it looks," she said, adding that ample closet space is often a major issue for buyers.
Ms. Fox also pointed out that furniture and appliances should be cleaned and polished and floors should be washed and waxed or vacuumed. In apartments that do not have much natural light, she said, lamps should have the brightest bulbs that can safely be used and should be on when a prospective buyer enters an apartment.
Moreover, she said, sellers should be prepared to deal with problems in their apartment they may not even realize exist.
"Smells are always a downer," Ms. Fox said. "Things like cat litter boxes, cigarette smells and cooking odors are hardly ever noticed by the people who live with them." Accordingly, she said, potpourri, scented candles or room deodorizers should be used judiciously to eliminate offensive odors.
"Cookies in the oven work even better," Ms. Fox said. "Even if you don't think you have an odor problem in your apartment, it doesn't hurt to assume that you do."
Marjorie Hilton, president of Marjorie Hilton Interiors, an interior design consultant in Manhattan, said that it is often possible to enhance the look of an apartment at modest expense.
Refinishing a wood floor, for example, is relatively inexpensive, yet a freshly sanded and polyurethaned floor can completely transform the look of an apartment -- even making a small apartment look larger.
"Even in carpeted apartments, the first question a buyer will ask is: 'What's under the carpet?' " Ms. Hilton said.
Other relatively inexpensive improvements that pay significant dividends, she said, are a fresh coat of paint on the walls, regrouting of bathroom tiles, repair of leaking faucets and replacement of any older fluorescent light fixtures -- often found in bathrooms and kitchens -- with incandescent ones.
While it might be argued that things like dirty windows, clutter, cramped closets and exotic cooking odors are not likely to dissuade an interested buyer from making an offer on an appropriately priced apartment in a well-managed building, their impact is never entirely overlooked.
"We sort of like it when people haven't done what they're supposed to do to make everything clean and nice when they're selling their apartment," said Peter Bell, president of Balch Realty, a "buyer's-only" broker based in Westchester. "It gives us something to negotiate to get our buyer a lower price."

HEADLINE: For a Los Angeles 'Suburb,' Steps to Recovery

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN 

DATELINE: VAN NUYS, Calif.

 BODY:
A $75 MILLION complex that will combine a shopping center with an industrial park is rising here on the former site of a General Motors Corporation automobile plant.
The project, which is called The Plant, is expected to regenerate most of the 3,000 jobs lost when the car maker closed its plant five years ago in this San Fernando Valley community of the City of Los Angeles. 
 City officials also hope that it will provide a spark to ignite new development in a depressed pocket of a region that looks more like a suburb than part of a huge city.
The 370,000-square-foot shopping center, which its developers say is 95 percent preleased, will include a 16-screen movie theater designed with automotive-factory-themed decor. Completion of the 35-acre project, called the Van Nuys Center at The Plant, is expected this summer.
On an adjoining 33-acre site, the same developers -- a partnership of The Voit Companies of Woodland Hills and The Selleck Group of Westlake Village, both in California -- plan to build 600,000 square feet of industrial space.
It will be the largest such development in the San Fernando Valley in 20 years, according to the developers.
Ricon Corporation, a maker of wheelchair lifts for buses and trains that is currently based in neighboring Pacoima, has leased a 150,000-square-foot building now under construction and scheduled for completion in October.
Although the company could have found less expensive space outside of the Valley, Ricon wanted to stay in the region, where nearly all of its 300 employees live, according to William Hinze, a company vice president in charge of sales.
"We believe that the cost of rehiring and retraining new employees more than offsets any advantages we would get by moving out of the Valley," Mr. Hinze said.
The Plant is one of several projects, including an expanded civic center on Van Nuys Boulevard, that represent an attempt to redevelop and redefine a "first ring suburb" of the Los Angeles core that has traversed the cycle of boom, development and decay.
The San Fernando Valley is a 250-square-mile area of Los Angeles that lies north of the Santa Monica Mountains. About 1.3 million people live there in such communities as Tarzana, Sherman Oaks, Encino and Studio City.
In the 40's through the 60's, housing tracts quickly replaced fields of orange trees. Bing Crosby's recording of "San Fernando Valley," with its evocation of care-free living in a mild climate, was a Top 10 hit in 1943.
The Valley was a "prototype of American suburbia," said Robert Voit, president and chief executive of The Voit Companies. "It was a place where one developer could build hundreds of homes that all looked alike."
BUT the Valley has also become a center of industrial and office development and the former bedroom community became an increasingly mature community where people both live and work.
With its many quiet neighborhoods of ranch houses and neat lawns, the Valley retains much of its suburban character. Now the suburban frontier of Los Angeles has expanded far beyond the Valley to the Santa Clarita and Antelope Valleys to the north, and Ventura County to the west.
Meanwhile, the Valley itself "has become older and taken on the characteristics of an urban area," Mr. Voit said.
Home buyers in search of traditional suburban amenities, such as comparatively low home prices and lighter traffic, now leapfrog the Valley for more distant places. In turn, the Valley is increasingly a "move up" community for upwardly mobile Latino and Asian immigrant households.
But the Valley is not a move-up area for industry. Many of its industrial buildings, built primarily in the 60's and 70's, are considered out of date, and few new sites are available for construction. As a result, many businesses are leaving the area for newer, larger buildings in Santa Clarita Valley and Ventura County.
The lack of reinvestment in the Valley's industrial areas has resulted in urban decay. In the early 90's, the area surrounding the former General Motors plant had the highest crime rate in the city, recalled Los Angeles City Councilman Richard Alarcon, who represents Van Nuys.
THE redevelopment of Van Nuys has a personal meaning for Dan Selleck, the president of Selleck Development Group, co-developer of The Plant, who was born and raised in the community.
"The lack of reinvestment in that part of the Valley has really been a sad thing to see," he said. "I went on a sixth-grade field trip to the G.M. plant in the 60's. I had numerous friends whose parents worked there."
Later, he said, "I cruised Van Nuys Boulevard as a teen-ager."
After the auto plant closed in 1993, Councilman Alarcon said, his goal was to restore manufacturing jobs to the area. Shortly after closing the plant, Mr. Alarcon said, representatives of General Motors approached him to seek his aid in rezoning the site from industrial to commercial retail, in the belief that a site zoned for retail would command a higher price.
"I simply refused," the Councilman recalled. G.M. representatives, he said, "walked away very angry." About a month later, he added, "they came back and said, 'Can we negotiate?' "
In January 1994, while the Councilman and G.M. representatives were still holding talks, the Van Nuys area was jolted by the Northridge earthquake. (The epicenter of the quake lay a few miles to the northwest.) The San Fernando Valley was particularly hard hit, and the Federal Government soon made funds available for rebuilding.
One source of funds, a $30 million grant from the Federal Economic Development Agency, put an ace in Mr. Alarcon's hand. About $4 million of the grant was earmarked for site improvements at the former G.M. plant. The improvements included widening Van Nuys Boulevard, the main approach to the future shopping center, as well as creation of new road through the center of the property where industrial buildings would be situated.
These improvements would make the site more valuable, Mr. Alarcon recalled telling G.M. representatives. In the end, G.M. agreed to a formula that would rezone about a third of the 100-acre site for retail and another third for industrial development.
G.M. contributed an additional five acres for another pet project of Mr. Alarcon -- a new police and fire station. The auto maker remains on a 27-acre site, where it continues to operate a car-testing facility.
For Mr. Voit of The Voit Companies, rebuilding Van Nuys is a major occupation. Five miles south of The Plant on Van Nuys Boulevard, Voit is at work on a $45 million civic project known as the Marvin Braude Constituent Service Center, a 200,000-square-foot branch of City Hall. The project includes a new master plan for courtyards to connect the center with existing structures in the civic center complex.
Mr. Voit said that the renewal of the civic center, the traditional political center of the Valley, along with the redevelopment of the former G.M. site, are symbols of hope for the newest residents.
Those residents, he said, are coming from abroad, or other parts of Los Angeles, "and they feel very hopeful about the Valley, much as their predecessors felt who are leaving the Valley."
"We are trying to capture some of that hope" in those new projects, he said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Pfizer Reaches Across the Thames for More Space

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
PFIZER'S CENTRAL RESEARCH operation in Groton will soon straddle the Thames River with a new $150 million project that will give it 400,000 square feet of research and laboratory space on the waterfront in New London.
The 24-acre project will rise on the site of a former linoleum factory that has been vacant for more than a decade. For their part, Connecticut and the city will invest $58.5 million in revitalizing the neighborhood, including the creation of a new state park to include the Revolutionary War-era Fort Trumbull. The fort is now surplus Federal property. 
 Dr. George H. Milne Jr., head of Pfizer Central Research, said construction of the international pharmaceutical corporation's project should begin in the spring, with completion in about two years. Initially it will employ 1,300 people with a payroll of about $129 million, but employment will increase to 2,000 within five years.
Dr. Milne said Pfizer now spends about half its yearly $2 billion research budget in southeastern Connecticut. He added that it had made a commitment to grow through the development of new drugs.
The New London Development Corporation, which worked to bring Pfizer into the city, has won state grants for improvements in the area that will bring even more development, said Dr. Claire Gaudiani, president of both the development group and Connecticut College, in New London.
"My vision is that over a five-year period we'll see a dramatic improvement in our tax base, a dramatic improvement in the number of jobs at all kinds of levels and a dramatic increase in people enjoying downtown New London," Dr. Gaudiani said.
"There will be spinoff from Pfizer," said Mayor Lloyd H. Beachy of New London. "There's going to be a lot of people and companies who are going to say, 'I want to be across the street from Pfizer.' The question is going to be, how are we going to get the right people in there, who will really add to the mix?"
He said he expected homes for the people who will work at the new Pfizer research center, shops, restaurants and service-oriented businesses capitalizing on the increased traffic in the area.
"To me, the really significant thing is how many cities the size of New London have an opportunity to develop an area that takes in 45 or 50 acres just a stone's throw from their downtown," Mr. Beachy said.
The state will provide up to $12.5 million for the development corporation to purchase up to 70 properties in the neighborhood for related development, and the group is working with four real estate brokers in New London. Susan Howard, a broker with US Properties in New London, said there had been strong interest in the project.
"There's going to be a lot of new development, new people coming in," said Ms. Howard. "I'm getting calls from Chicago and New York and Boston already. I was stunned at how quickly the word spread."
THE site that Pfizer will purchase is known locally as the New London Mills property, for the factory that used to occupy it. Over the years a number of projects have been proposed there, most recently the OceanQuest marine science educational center. All have fallen through.
Pfizer brings a strong record to New London. Over the last decade it has never stopped developing its 137-acre Groton site, which today has 75 buildings and is that town's largest taxpayer, providing $7.5 million a year in revenue to the city.
Deborah Pasquale, of Connecticut United for Research Excellence, which promotes the biotechnology and medical industries in the state, said drug research was an increasingly important component of the state's economy.
A study last year showed 12 percent of all domestic pharmaceutical research and development spending in the nation came to Connecticut, up from 10 percent a year earlier. "That didn't even include the Pfizer expansion, or the additional growth going on at the Bayer Corporation in West Haven," she said. "I think in this year you're going to see continued healthy growth on the large company side, and on the small company side."
Ms. Pasquale said there were seven small biotechnology companies in the state now, many of them spinoffs from the Yale University and University of Connecticut research laboratories, and Yale is looking to spin off four more very shortly.
"To go from seven to 11 in one leap would be pretty amazing," he said. "The key ingredient for success at any of these companies, obviously, is good science, but having proximity to a large pharmaceutical company like Pfizer doesn't hurt at all."
Paul B. Begin, group director, facilities management for Pfizer, said the proximity of the New London property to the Groton research center was one of the keys to its selection. "A visual tie of the two campuses is an important feature, so the employees at both can feel connected," Mr. Begin said.
He said Pfizer had decided to take the New London site because of city and state commitments to proceed with other projects to enhance the area, such as a $20 million restoration of Fort Trumbull, a $19 million environmental assessment and cleanup of the factory property and $7 million of improvements to the sewage treatment plant in the area so odors are eliminated. "All of those things, we feel, are positive signs that we're going to have some good neighbors," Mr. Begin said.
AS recently as five years ago, he said, there would have been no incentive for Pfizer to consider building laboratory space anywhere else in the region, because it would have hindered the work at the Groton site. But since then communications technology has evolved to the point where a property across the river will, in many respects, be as close as a building across the campus. Moreover, the Pfizer research organization has grown to the point where it can consider breaking off the clinical research laboratories from the development laboratories, which will stay in Groton.
"They need to be tied back to the Groton laboratories, but a good portion of their work is focused outward, so it doesn't have to be as close to the Groton operation," Mr. Begin said. "We want them to still feel that they're part of the organization, the team."
Brian Kowalchuk, an architect with CUH2A of Princeton, N.J., the firm that has designed the last five expansion projects on the Groton campus, said there were a number of special site considerations for the New London property. One is the fact that it has three "front doors" -- the waterfront, New London's downtown and the southern New London residential areas.
"We want to make sure each of them have a nice view," Mr. Kowalchuk said. "It's important to think about how people will get to the site and what they will see as they approach it."
Pfizer also considers its buildings one of the amenities that help it attract and retain top scientists, Mr. Kowalchuk said, so they have to be more than merely functional. His initial plans call for a series of linked buildings so employees can walk inside from one to another. "It's important not to have barriers between people, that you encourage connections," Mr. Kowalchuk said. "But it's important that you break it down so it doesn't look like one giant megabuilding, so it has the feel of a research campus."
John C. Markowicz, head of the South East Area Regional Economic Development agency, said biotechnology was considered one of the growth areas for the region primarily because of the presence of Pfizer, and the expansion into New London is expected to attract a number of smaller businesses that want to do clinical research for the giant drug firm.
"They run the gamut from small mom-and-pops to companies that employ hundreds of people," Mr. Markowicz said.
He noted that most of the offices in the area around the new Pfizer site were built by military contractors who wanted to take advantage of proximity to the former Navy weapons center. When the center moved to Newport, R.I., many of those companies followed. "It's entirely possible that we have a similar opportunity here," Mr. Markowicz said, to bring in those companies that want to be near Pfizer. But these are companies in the health field which is not as cyclical as defense, and because of the aging population have a healthy future, he added.
"Our plan is to do what we can to bring in companies that will complement Pfizer, not to compete with it," he said. "But there are a lot of opportunities to do that."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In a Tight Market, Monmouth Beckons Office Users

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FOR the last 25 years the 723,000-square-foot office building set on 40 acres along Tinton Avenue in the Monmouth County community of Tinton Falls was leased by the Army for its communications and electronics command center.
But over the last two years the Army has relocated most of its operation to nearby Fort Monmouth, leaving a huge block of space in its wake.
In that time, 85 percent of the space in the seven-story building has been vacated and the rest will be vacant by midyear. But a developer who bought the building for $9.5 million in December is planning to invest $40 million to $45 million more to renovate it for commercial occupancy. 
 The developer, the Matrix Development Group of Cranbury, is betting that with large areas of quality space in limited supply throughout the county, as in the rest of the 11-county northern and central New Jersey market, the building will draw tenants.
Area brokers agree, adding that the project underscores the fact that the one-time seasonal resort of Monmouth County is emerging from its recessionary doldrums and edging toward a new round of growth.
As the markets in suburban communities to the north continue to tighten, they add, businesses are starting to look southward to Monmouth County because of lower rents, the availability of labor and housing and convenient access -- about 60 miles from Manhattan.
With a total of 6.8 million square feet of space Monmouth County has one of the state's smallest office markets, much of it concentrated in its eastern sector. Historically, the county has attracted, and continues to attract, smaller companies. But it has a group of large, well-established corporate tenants and some like AT&T, also have renewed their commitment to the county.
Since AT&T split into three separate companies in September 1995 it and Lucent Technologies, the equipment manufacturing business it spun off, have been swapping space at the five buildings in Monmouth County they shared.
One result of all that shuffling is that AT&T is renovating an 836,000-square-foot structure and building four adjacent structures with a total of 1 million square feet, at a 262-acre corporate campus off Laurel Avenue near exit 114 of the Garden State Parkway in Middletown. The site, which could accommodate another million square feet, will serve as the main research and development complex for AT&T.
Paul E. Giannonne, a principal of Jacobson, Goldfarb & Tanzman Company LLC, a Woodbridge-based commercial real estate brokerage, said that over the last two years tenants expanding in or relocating to the county had increased their appetite for space. That has enabled the market to absorb much of the supply left over from the mid-80's building boom, reducing the amount of available space on the market to 550,000 square feet, said Mr. Giannone.
Much of what is left of that space is expected to be leased in the next 18 months, Mr. Giannonne said. The market then should be able to handle the addition of the former Army building in Tinton Falls, which he said had pushed the countywide vacancy rate at the start of the year to 17 percent from 8.2 percent prior to its purchase.
Jonathan B. Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization, another commercial real estate brokerage in Woodbridge, said that excluding the Tinton Falls building there were only two blocks of space of 50,000 to 120,000 square feet available in the entire county. That fact, he said, is beginning to spur the construction of new buildings constructedfor specific tenants.
As an example, he pointed to the 138,000-square-foot building under way along Industrial Way West, off Route 35 in Eatontown. It is being built by the Townsend Group of Towson, Md., the property owner, for TSSL Laboratories, the research and development arm of TYCO Submarine Systems Ltd., based in Morristown. Schultz represented Townsend in the transaction.
The need for more space prompted TYCO Submarine Systems, which designs, manufactures and installs undersea cable systems that transmit data, to move its research and development operations out of its current space in Holmdel, said Cheryl McCantz, a TYCO spokeswoman.
TYCO considered several sites within a 10-mile radius of Holmdel, "but none met both our physical and geographic needs," Ms. McCantz said. She added that she expected the research and development division to initially occupy 120,000 square feet in the building by February 1999. The remaining space will be used to meet the division's expansion needs.
MOST brokers agree that, in the short term, such build-to-suit deals will account for much of the construction activity in the county. One reason is that while average rental rates are increasing they are not yet at a point to justify speculative construction, said Jerry Richter, a senior director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage. At the end of 1997, his firm put the average rental rate for Class A space in the county at $23.87 a square foot, up from $18.07 the same time in 1996.
While there is some speculative construction going on in the state, Mr. Richter noted that the number of large blocks of available quality space of 200,000 square feet or more can be counted on one hand. There are at least a half a dozen companies looking for such space at any given time, he added.
For Matrix, this presents an opportunity to accommodate large users in its Tinton Falls building. Its financial partner in the project is AEW Capital Management of Boston. "We don't see this just as a Monmouth County redevelopment project because with its size, location and flexible floor plan we can draw tenants from the tristate region," said Kenneth A. Griffin, a partner at Matrix. The building -- designed as four separate wings and with 100,000-square-foot floors -- is equidistant from exits 105 and 109 of the Garden State Parkway, accessible to rail and ferry service to Manhattan and "in the middle of the excellent labor and housing market that Monmouth County affords," said Mr. Griffin
Plans for the structure, which was built in 1973, call for stripping it to its steel skeleton, redoing the interior and upgrading all mechanical systems. The building also will be given a new yet-to-be determined facade to replace its current nondescript one and the property, now mostly a sea of blacktop, will be extensively landscaped. The work, to begin by midyear, will be done in phases and is expected to be completed in six months.
Mr. Griffin said the building will be targeted to tenants needing 100,000 square feet of space or more. But he said that after at least a third of the building had been leased to large users his company would consider dividing the space into smaller areas.
But what the company thinks will give the project a significant advantage, said Richard F.X. Johnson, another Matrix partner, is that even with extensive renovations the space can be delivered faster and at a lower cost than new construction. Mr. Johnson said that new Class A space in the state rents for $27 to $31 a square foot on a gross basis, which includes taxes and operating costs. He said he expects rented at the Tinton Falls building to be $6 to $8 a square foot lower.
Tinton Falls welcomes the redevelopment because "it means a tremendous ratable for the borough," said Anthony J. Muscillo, its Business Administrator. The former owner, Stanwick/Cecom LLC of Dallas, filed a tax appeal that was settled for $1 million, Mr. Muscillo said. But, he added, "the borough wins in the long-term" because when redeveloped the building will bring in $1 million in taxes a year.
The renovation plan is also welcome, Mr. Muscillo said, because it takes a building that is something of a white elephant and turn it around.
