LENGTH: 2471 words

HEADLINE: Summer Rentals: The Prices Are Holding Steady

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

 BODY:
LAST year when Sotheby's rented out a 1900's oceanfront estate in East Hampton, L.I., for $200,000 for the month of August, the company considered it a record for the area. Then, a couple of weeks ago, the estate's owner called Frank Newbold, head of Sotheby's East Hampton office, and said he had negotiated a deal himself for this summer.
"I've just had an offer for $400,000, and I want to thank you," Mr. Newbold said the owner had told him. The offer was for the entire season, but the owner explained that he would not have had the nerve to ask so much had the property not rented for such a high fee last year. 
 "Actually, we're getting a little used to breaking records," said Mr. Newbold, who has been in the realty business in the Hamptons for nearly 20 years. "Every time we think we've reached a new peak, along comes a price that breaks the barrier again."
While stories like that might make renters with thinner wallets cringe, the good news is that such phenomenal increases are limited to very high-end properties, usually expansive homes on or near the ocean. Overall in the Northeast, summer rental fees in beach areas seem to be holding steady this year or going up 5 to 10 percent. "I would say our prices are about the same as last year," said Patricia Garrity, an agent with Allan M. Schneider Associates in Southampton, L.I.
Closer to New York City, Wayne Roth, a broker with Fire Island Real Estate of Ocean Beach, L.I., agreed. A two- to three-bedroom house there has remained about $10,000 for the season (well below prices in the Hamptons, he noted), going up into the mid $30,000's for an property on the ocean or the bay with four or five bedrooms.
Mr. Roth said that his properties were about 90 percent booked by mid-February -- "the earliest we've ever accomplished that."
While demand has been strong in the Hamptons, brokers are quick to stress that there is still plenty of inventory left in vacation-oriented communities in the metropolitan area and beyond.
And the range of prices in which these houses or condominiums can be leased varies greatly.
It is possible to spend $500 a week for a cottage on Cape Cod, or $1,500 for a week in a three-bedroom unit near the boardwalk in Ocean City, N.J., or $100,000 for a month in a waterfront homestead in Martha's Vineyard.
Price is dictated by distance from the water, the time of vacation and the size of the property, with amenities playing an ever-increasing role in determining value.
Every year, brokers say, there seems to be a tendency for people who can plan summer vacations early to shop ever earlier for their vacation housing. Sometimes the reports of this phenomenon discourage shoppers prematurely.
Unlocking the door to a three-story farmhouse a block from downtown Southampton, Ms. Garrity used the house as an example of what happened last year. "This house normally rents in December or January," she said. "Last year, it did not rent until April, and the price had been dropped from $45,000 to $40,000 for the season." This year, the owner listed the seven-bedroom, three-and-a-half bath house, with a pool, at $42,000 for the season.
"She was very concerned about the appropriate price to get a good tenant early and to be done with it," Ms. Garrity said. She succeeded -- the house has been rented.
But, brokers added, there is little room for negotiation in price this year, and most homeowners are getting what they ask.
"Every house I've done this year has been full price," Ms. Garrity said.
While it is hard to make generalities about areas as diverse as Ocean City, N.J., and Southampton, a few trends seem common. Renters are shopping earlier, properties at the high end are filling up quickly and strong sales up and down the East Coast have depleted the stock of prime properties in some areas.
"We still have places left if you're not locked into a time period and if you're not set on the high-end amenities," said Grayce Kelleher, an agent at Chris Clemans & Company in Cape May, N.J., a quaint Victorian town at the tip of the Jersey Shore.
But for the selective, it may be more difficult. By early February, she said, it was already getting tough to find precisely what callers wanted.
"It's getting hard and it's going to get much harder," said Ms. Kelleher, who fielded 24 calls about rentals in a two-hour period on the first Friday of February. "When the caller has specific weeks and requirements I may only have two or three properties to offer them."
While the Presidents' Day weekend used to signal the start of rental shopping in many beach communities, that trend is shifting. On Cape Cod, for example, some brokers are starting in November and asking people to reconfirm.
"This is our second year of that," said Beth Hardy Sparrow, rental department coordinator with John C. Ricotta & Associates in Chatham, Mass.
Ms. Sparrow said the early bookings had depleted portions of the company's inventory, particularly waterfront properties -- some of which increased 50 percent in rental price in the last three years, compared with 5 to 20 percent for less expensive properties in the same time period.
"It's getting a little bit pricey here," Ms. Sparrow said, explaining that rents start at about $700 a week for a cottage and go up to about $10,000 a week for a waterfront home. "A family able to get something really nice for $1,000 a week finds themselves settling for something a little more cottagey."
However, she emphasized that there were still plenty of quality listings available, although they "do tend to be further from the water and more of a walk to town."
But because the Cape has so many diverse communities, there is a wide variety in price.
In Eastham, Mass., Mary Carey, a rental agent with Anchor Real Estate, said homes were booking up quickly, with prices ranging from $500 a week for an efficiency to $3,200 a week for a three-bedroom waterfront house on the bay.
"People have learned that if they want to get the best choice they need to reserve early," she said, adding that by the end of January her office had booked half the total number of last year's rentals, a third of the bookings from repeat tenants who had made their reservations last summer.
In Avalon, N.J., long considered a summer destination for residents from Philadelphia's upscale Main Line, shopping started in October and November, said Randy Leiser of the Avalon Real Estate Agency, which also handles properties in neighboring Stone Harbor, N.J.
"It's coming earlier this year than it ever has," said Mr. Leiser.
He said that in addition to the early rentals, the rental season was getting longer.
"Many people are opting to take a week in June or September," he said. "The other thing that's beginning to happen is that our rental rates have gotten higher, and as a result we're seeing more and more investors return to the market.
While in the early 90's rent increases were modest, at a "few percentage points a year," Mr. Leiser said, "in the last two to three years many of them have gone up 10 and 15 percent."
"The ones that are able to raise the rates that much are the nicest ones," he said, "the largest -- the closer to the beach the better -- three or more bedrooms, central air and nice comforts."
He gave as an example a four-bedroom, four-bath house at 177 61st Street in Avalon, which sits one house back from the beach. Known as an "upside down house" because the living area is on the top and bedrooms on the bottom, it rented for $4,800 a week last year between mid-July and mid-August. This year it is listed at $5,200 a week during that period.
"And it's going to fill up," said Mr. Leiser, estimating that the company's listings were 50 to 60 percent booked.
For the most part the increasing prices at the upper tiers of the market result from the dynamics of supply and demand. But, agents said, increasingly those inventories are being affected by sales.
"The sales market has been so strong that a lot of houses that used to be available for rent are no longer available," Ms. Garrity said. "Houses that supplied the best value in the rental and sales market were sold."
ON a sunny Friday in early February, the streets of Southampton were quiet as Ms. Garrity previewed a range of homes for rent in the area. For $21,000 there was a quaint three-bedroom cottage on Wooley Pond in Southampton Shores, available for the season. A three-bedroom, two-and-a-half bath shingle cottage with pool two blocks from the ocean near Southampton's estate section runs $36,000 for the season.
At $70,000 for the season there was a five-bedroom, two-and-half-bath contemporary with pool and clay tennis court in Water Mill. Moving up the scale (and actually into Southampton's estate section) there was a Stanford White classic on 2.3 acres with pool at $120,000 for the season.
But as prices move upward, brokers say, it makes sense to consider buying. "If you pay $70,000 in rent and get a nice house, wouldn't you just put $70,000 on a house and just buy it?" she said.
With a strong economy and Wall Street generating tidy profits, the answer to that question seems to have been a resounding yes. Prime properties -- in most cases that means oceanfront or water views -- are being sold. And in many cases, the buyers aren't renting out.
"There was a period of time back in the summer when we were tracking our sales," said Mr. Leiser in Avalon. "Out of every 10 properties sold, six or seven were not going back on the rental market, so you can see what that does to the inventory."
Still, brokers are quick to stress that new listings are constantly coming on the market and new development is creating new properties. But renters may have to be flexible when it comes to location and amenities.
"For the discerning tenant it's a tight market," Ms. Garrity said. "There aren't as many options."
But amenities is one area where demands have been increasing, brokers said. "I would say that the biggest change in the rental market over the last few years has been that more and more tenants are demanding more and more amenities," said Ms. Sparrow in Chatham.
Just a few years ago, she said, it was easy to rent those quintessential Cape Cod cottages with no washer, dryer or dishwasher.
"Today tenants are demanding that homes be equipped with those amenities plus microwave, newer color televisions and VCR's," she said, adding that there were also increased requests for fax machines and second phone lines.
In Nantucket, Mass., Penny Dey at Congdon & Coleman said she had seen a similar trend. Not that long ago, she said, "a little peeling paint didn't matter."
"Now people who are coming here are more particular about amenities," she said.
While high-end properties generally rent by the month, Ms. Dey said she was also seeing a trend to one-week rentals. She said she had also started to see people from the Hamptons gravitate to Nantucket, where prices -- although high -- are lower.
A three- or four-bedroom house, a quarter mile from the beach, runs about $3,000 a week, she said, with a basic two-bedroom cottage in Siasconset would be about $1,000 a week.
At the high end, she mentioned a five-bedroom home just west of Nantucket with direct waterfront access. Just finished, it is full of amenities and rents for $15,000 a week, but will be held for a full-month rental at $60,000.
"They want to come to Nantucket because the Hamptons are getting too crowded and too expensive," Ms. Dey said. "And of course there's a fear here we're going to turn into the Hamptons."
IN the Berkshires and Vermont, which are not at all like the Hamptons, prices and demand are about the same as last year, brokers said.
"In the Berkshires the rental market is more of an afterthought," said Joseph Carini, president of Wheeler and Taylor Real Estate in Great Barrington, Mass. "People don't usually buy houses with the clear intention of renting them for part of the year, but some folks do."
Mr. Carini said that rents ranged from $3,500 to as much as $20,000 a month.
For $4,000 a month, a renter can get a three-bedroom, two-bath house about 10 miles from the Tanglewood Music Center. At four times that amount, Mr. Carini said, a renter can get a 10-bedroom mansion with four-and-half baths in Stockbridge, just a short distance from Stockbridge Bowl and Tanglewood.
"You can actually hear the music wafting over," he said.
Most properties book by the month, he said, noting that "most people who want to visit for a week or two are better advised to consider bed and breakfasts."
There's still plenty of time and inventory, he said, with the rental market not picking up until March.
In Vermont, where the ski season is still going strong, real estate companies have barely thought of summer.
"We're buried in snow," said Judy Findeisen, a rental specialist with Martin Associates in Killington. She said the summer rental season generally started in March and is "there to be accommodating."
"Summer rentals are usually not difficult to come by, and the price is less than in the winter," she said.
Many Vermont renters are Floridians escaping the summer heat who book condominiums, she said. At one upscale Killington condo, which has a restaurant, sports center and indoor pool, rents start at $1,000 a month for a two-bedroom unit.
Her most expensive home -- a six-bedroom, three-and-a-half bath home on a peninsula in the Killington area, runs $1,600 a week. House rentals start at about $700 a month.
Despite increasing demand for properties in the Adirondacks, prices have generally stayed even with last year, said Denise Bujold, a rental specialist in the Saranac Lake office of Rob Grant & Associates. However, she too reported a strong demand for larger high-end homes.
She said prices ranged from $750 a week for a one- or two-bedroom cottage on a small lake (not Lake Placid or Saranac Lake) to $4,000 a week for a large (five- to eight-bedroom) home on one of the larger lakes with amenities such as modern kitchens, fireplaces, Jacuzzis and perhaps even a boat.
While Ms. Bujold estimated that about 40 percent of her properties were booked, she said she "wouldn't discourage someone even as late as June."
But for those planning a beach vacation, it may be a good idea to pick up the phone. "This year it's like everybody in the whole world wants to come here," said Carlotta Whirty, rental manager at Lila Delman Real Estate in Narragansett, R.I.
"I have people who would spend $20,000 a month if they could get something on the water," she said, adding that she has increasingly heard the phrase "money is not an object."
If that sounds as if it would make life easy for a rental agent, don't believe it, Ms. Whirty said. "I have to turn them down," she said. "That's hard."

LENGTH: 2530 words

HEADLINE: Ask How Many, Don't Ask Why

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Phil Arkow has 2,000 dog license tags. He has one dog. There is no entirely satisfactory explanation for this wide discrepancy, which keeps getting worse. Before he is done, it is Mr. Arkow's stated purpose to gather thousands more tags but remain with the single dog.
Mr. Arkow understands that this may seem abnormal. He can live with that. "Collectors are crazy," he shrugged as he sifted through his beloved assemblage of tags. "I don't think there is any logical reason for any of this." 
 The dog tags represent his own idiosyncratic take on collecting stamps or baseball cards or Elvis memorabilia. It has its appeal. By and large, the tags are free. It has its drawbacks. The dog tags are, well, dog tags.
"When you get into it, they're as fascinating as stamps or coins," he said. "There are oddities. There are errors. People specialize. Some want tags with their birth year. Some want tags with a certain lucky number. My goal is to get one tag from each community that issues them. There are 30,000."
Mr. Arkow, a bespectacled man with a quizzical look, describes himself as "50 going on 15." He keeps his dog tags stashed in the attic of his home in Stratford. His wife, Melody, doesn't get it. Spouse apathy (if not outright derision) is not uncommon in collector households.
After all, the inner logic of amassing dog tags undoubtedly escapes much of the population, who at best see it as esoteric and at worst as majestically idiotic. Does an Alma, Mich., dog tag have any real value to anyone but an Alma, Mich., dog, or the pet's owner?
Yet Phil Arkow finds a kind of peace in dog license tags, just as Melvin Goldberg does in items that were manufactured during the American occupation of Japan and just as Willard Carey does in sugar packets. They are among thousands of people who care deeply about things like toothpick holders, infant feeders, cocktail napkins, beer cans, citrus labels, church bulletins, foreign plastic bags, cuff links, wine corks or 45-RPM record players.
Few can relate in any comprehensible form why they do what they do. When pressed, many collectors give up on studied explanations and simply recite the theory that they were born with some sort of instinct to accumulate objects. They speak of how when they come across two of something they get this nagging itch to look for a third.
Most obsessed collectors belong to a national club devoted to appreciators of their chosen obsession. There is a club for almost every collectible, from spark plugs to swizzle sticks. They receive newsletters. They learn the arcane histories of their beloved treasures. They discover colleagues with whom they can communicate, visit, swap objects. A dog tag collector cannot commune with a soap wrapper man; they need their own kind.
 
DOG TAGS
2,000 Items So Far For a Grand Total of $2
Phil Arkow was all smiles at the door of his suburban home. He had just returned from his job as a communications director for a foundation in Philadelphia.
At his dining table, he proudly showed some of his tags (besides dog tags, he has a few dozen of the far rarer cat tags). "This is probably the oddest one in my collection," he said. It was from 1973, issued by the town of Minden, and it was in the shape of Texas. Minden, however, is in Nebraska.
"There are a lot of different tags shaped as fire hydrants," he said. "They've been accused of being sexist."
"Look at this," he went on. He held up a tag from Manitou Springs, Colo. It was a dog tag in the shape of a cat. "Maybe they got two for the price of one if they took the cat design," he said.
As he combed through his tags, he was polite in remarking, "You don't have to act like you're interested in this."
Mr. Arkow entered this world from the related universe of license plates. As a youngster he collected license plates he found on the side of the road. When he got older and bought his own house, he decorated the study not with artwork but with license plates. Then he heard about dog tag collections.
This was in the mid-1970's, when he was working for a humane society in Colorado Springs. The bulk of the dogs brought in, by owners giving up their pets, bore tags that they no longer needed. "So I got them, so to speak, first paw," he said. If he was going to collect something, and he felt he ought to, dog license tags were a more suitable fit. He sold most of the 200 license plates he had accumulated and got to work on dog tags.
When he travels, Mr. Arkow makes a point to drop in on local animal shelters. Many of them have had visits from tag collectors before, so they graciously leave a bowl of expendable tags on the counter at the entrance. Some people arm themselves with metal detectors and scour yards for tags, especially construction sites when a foundation is being laid and the lot has been dug up. Or they buy them at flea markets.
"I refuse to buy them," Mr. Arkow said. "I'm cheap. I think I bought one tag in a moment of weakness, a 1913 tag from Cripple Creek, Colo. I sprang for $2. I liked it because it was in the shape of an elongated dog biscuit."
From time to time, he speaks at meetings of dog catchers and, while in their company, often manages to arrange to get some tags from the catchers.
There is one rather obvious way to acquire dog tags, although it carries morally repugnant overtones, which is to simply remove them from submissive dogs while their owners are not looking.
Did he know anyone who swiped a tag off a dog?
"I did," he said right back. "It was about 10 years ago on the beach in Mexico. A dog came up to me and I figured I needed a Mexican dog tag more than he did."
A few times, Mr. Arkow has attended the annual convention of dog tag collectors. Once he met a guy who had 30,000 tags. He traveled around with them in a safe.
Many tag collectors hunt for other objects as well, most commonly license plates, police badges, railway tokens and key chains. "They seem to be interested in small things made out of metal," said Mr. Arkow, who says he does not share this broader metallic interest, his past dalliance with license plates notwithstanding.
Others range farther afield. "I met one dog tag collector," he said, "who said he was one of only 12 people in the world to go to all 3,130 county courthouses. He collected going to county courthouses."
Mr. Arkow spoke without condescension. He also collects sand. Each time he and his wife are at a new beach, they stow some sand in a small bottle, label it and add it to their stockpile. They know of no other sand collectors, but that doesn't inhibit them. They have about 200 sand samples.
"Now and then we say we'll pour it all together and have a clam bake," Mr. Arkow said. "Or maybe grow our own island."
 
NOT THAT O.J.
Anything Goes If It Has the Mark
Melvin Goldberg is a physician in Clifton who has never been to Japan and has no interest in visiting the country. Yet he has 5,000 items that were made in Japan. Not just made in Japan, he will hastily point out. Made in occupied Japan.
He darts in and out of flea markets and garage sales and flips objects upside down in hope of seeing the "Mark." The Mark is everything, either the M.I.O.J. Mark ("Made in Occupied Japan") or the O.J. Mark ("Occupied Japan"). The Mark confirms that the object was made for export to the United States during the years that the American forces occupied Japan after World War II. That covers seven years, from 1945 to 1952.
Something like 50,000 different objects were made by the Japanese during the years that they began to rebuild their capsized economy. Many of them carried one of two other marks -- "Japan" and "Made in Japan" -- but those are of no interest to Dr. Goldberg, because he has no way of proving that they were actually made during the all-important occupation years. He and fellow collectors talk of "going O.J. hunting" and of being "O.J. collectors," sometimes feeling the need to clarify by adding that they are not referring to a Mr. Simpson.
About 400 people belong to an Occupied Japan Club, including Dr. Goldberg and two Japanese people living in Japan. The club holds a biennial convention and publishes a bimonthly newsletter called, "The Upside Down World of an O.J. Collector." The title alludes to the practice of upending objects to look for the Mark.
O.J. items range from the emphatically utilitarian to the decorative: hammers, fishing rods, cigarette lighters, tablecloths, clocks, lamps, porcelain figurines, toys, cameras, umbrellas, snow cone makers.
"I don't know exactly how many objects I have, but I always say I have 5,000 items," Dr. Goldberg said of his prodigious collection. "I have a lot of duplicates. You know those little packages of sewing needles? I have 990 packages of them. I bought them from some guy at a flea market. I got them all for $10. He didn't even ask why I wanted them. He just wanted to sell the needles."
He has innumerable porcelain figurines and small toys. He has a mess of cigarette lighters, complete sets of china, settings for 8 and for 12. He has lamps and plaques and miniature cameras. He has jewelry, celluloid dolls, harmonicas, a disappearing coin trick, rubber erasers, Christmas ornaments, a pin with the Lone Ranger on it and another one with Hopalong Cassidy. He has drill bits and buttons.
It was an offhand remark that got Dr. Goldberg going. "I was with my wife-to-be and future in-laws in Virginia at a flea market in 1971," he said. "My father-in-law-to-be saw these figurines from occupied Japan. He had been an antiques dealer, and he said, 'This is a good thing to collect.' I bought three ceramic figurines for $5, and that got me started."
His original intent was to gather the objects as an investment. Discerning the possibility of the pieces eventually escalating in value and in part funding his retirement, he bought them with his contributions to his pension plan. In the mid-1980's, the law changed and one could no longer invest pension money in collectibles. Dr. Goldberg kept on buying the occupied Japan objects. He likes collecting them.
Dr. Goldberg got many of his items for little money. There are so many more collectors now, as well as a raft of books showing objects and estimating values, and prices have shot up. Some objects are estimated to be worth in the hundreds of dollars and a few at more than $1,000.
He has also started collecting objects made in occupied Germany. They are harder to find. Fewer years were involved. Occupation troops prowled Germany only between 1945 and 1949.
The objects bear stamps like "Made in Germany U.S. Zone" or "Made in Germany British Zone." Dr. Goldberg has about 200 items so far. He has a hammer and tool set, a decanter, some toy cars, a bracelet. He has a book that was published in Frankfurt in 1948. It is printed in Polish. Dr. Goldberg had a Polish patient translate the title, then lost interest. The book is about metallurgical engineering.
 
SUGAR
Ants and Moisture Are the Big Threats
For Willard Carey, the beginning was a Jersey restaurant, a kid's birthday party. He never saw it coming.
In 1948, when he was seven years old, he was invited with some gambolling classmates to a friend's birthday celebration at Pal's Cabin, a restaurant in West Orange.
"Being jerks, everyone filled their pockets with sugar packets," he explained. "I took them home and put them in a shoe box. Then I had two shoe boxes. Then I had three shoe boxes."
He got older but the urge persisted. He is up to five shoe boxes, something like 3,000 packets and another 300 sugar cubes. He has them from airlines, country clubs, hotels, restaurants cheap and expensive. He has them from Tahiti, France, Switzerland. He has some from Africa.
Music advanced his collection. When he was in first grade, he took up the drums, and when he got out of college, he played with a 16-piece band until the age of 42. That got him into a lot of hotels and restaurants, repositories of sugar.
"All the time I travel and whenever I'm in a restaurant, the first thing I do is look at the sugar bowl," he said. "I always take just two -- one for a backup or to trade. I've never been a hog, not since that first time."
Collecting sugar packets is low budget. Then again, no one envisions a collection being auctioned off at Christie's. Only about 300 people are thought to be avowed packet collectors.
Some sugar maniacs look to complete sets -- all the islands of Hawaii or all Marriott hotels or all the airlines. In years past, there was a series of packets with the Presidents on them, another with famous athletes, another with frontier characters. Some collectors concentrate on cubes. Others limit their holdings to packets from places where they have eaten. Mr. Carey is less specific. "I just go for volume," he said.
In recent years, Mr. Carey has noticed a pronounced decline in this country in distinction in packets. In the interest of saving pennies, many restaurants seem content to offer generic packets with no colorful illustrations and no name on them beyond Domino. "It makes it hard on us," he sighed.
He lives in South Plainfield and works as operations support manager for gas for Public Service Electric & Gas in Newark. He has a network of about 10 co-workers who know of his packet devotion. They make it a point to retrieve sugar for him on their own excursions.
Mr. Carey's wife, Phyllis, does not think much of his compulsion. She did not marry her husband for his sugar. To her, sugar is sugar, a staple commodity.
To her relief, he does not engage dinner guests much in sugar conversation. "There's not that much to talk about," he said.
Generally, the protocol is for packet collectors to drain the sugar packets to ward off invasion by ants and moisture. Mr. Carey had been derelict. He kept them fully packed on a shelf above his workbench. "It wasn't until last year that I brought all the boxes out of the basement," he said. "I was lucky. Not one was attacked."
Using a surgical scalpel, he spent several weekends at his kitchen table carefully slitting each packet along its crease and emptying the sugar.
He has no good explanation for why he collects something that most people are content to add to their coffee. "You tell me," he said. "I can't tell you why I do it."
He thought a moment, and then said, "My grandmother in Scotia, N.Y., collected salt and pepper shakers. She had like 500 of them. I couldn't tell why she did that. She couldn't either."
He has no incurable sweet tooth. He takes his coffee with two sugars. "That's probably too much," he allowed.
Did he ever try to meditate on why he did it?
He replied evenly, "I've had more important things to think about, like cutting the grass."
Sugar remains his solitary extracurricular pursuit. "I once thought of collecting keys," he said. "But then I realized, what would I have -- a bunch of keys."
As much as the sugar packets mean to Mr. Carey, he is at a loss to know what future value his collection might have. Who would inherit it? Where would it ultimately wind up? "After I go," he said, "my collection will probably end up in the garbage."

HEADLINE: R & R;
Not Quite Gone, Far From Forgotten: Newark, Capital of Jazz

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
In the early part of the century, Newark was known as a "ticklers town." The great black jazz piano players had to come and play in the clubs in the section called the Coast on their way to greatness. None other than Duke Ellington said in his memoirs that in the 1920's, one of the best places to hear black music was Newark.
In clubs with names like Conertons, Bill Buss's Saloon and Randolphs, jazz that was every bit as vibrant and lavishly original as anything heard across the river in New York City was being played here in the narrow strip running from Lincoln Park north to Branford Place Park and west of Broad Street to Washington Street. 
 On Saturday night, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center offers a glimpse of that time and its music in "The Lost Jazz Shrines of Newark." Conceived and developed by the Newark poet and essayist Amiri Baraka, the multi-media program will use memorabilia and photographs from Mr. Baraka's collection and others to illustrate musical and vocal performances by the 15-piece New Arkestra, made up largely of local jazz performers. The program is based on Mr. Baraka's research and rendering in dramatic readings of the life of Willie (the Lion) Smith, an early composer and jazz great whose proficiency in stride piano was considered by many to transcend that of the better-known James P. Johnson and Fats Waller.
The program in Newark, sponsored by Absolut Vodka and the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, is one of nine around the country intended to highlight the cities, areas, clubs and informal spaces that nurtured jazz and its creators from its beginning. Maurine Knighton, executive director of the Brooklyn arts center 651, who helped develop the idea, said some common strains had emerged from city to city as the organizers looked at the evolution of jazz shrines.
"There were formal sites like clubs and ballrooms, but there were informal sites as well, like community centers, Masonic halls and churches," she said, noting that the venues were as wildly improvised as the music itself. "People had a proprietary sense about the music, and they held it close and very dear."
The other cities planning programs commemorating their jazz shrines are New York, Washington, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Chicago, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Mo., and San Antonio, Tex. In New York, three programs will highlight locations in Brooklyn, Greenwich Village and Harlem.
Mr. Baraka said Willie (the Lion) Smith was a regular on the New York jazz scene from the 1920's until his death in 1974. But his career started in Newark, where he grew up and, as a teen-ager, began playing in the saloons, brothels and "buffet flats" -- homes where music was played and food was sold -- of the city's tenderloin district just before and after World War I. It was a time when there was entertainment around the clock, and the first thing a new club or saloon would do when it opened was to have a ceremony built around throwing away the key to the place.
For the Newark program, Robert Banks, 68, a local pianist and organist who learned his craft from musicians influenced by "the Lion," will play many of the pieces Smith wrote and performed in the old days.
He describes the style of playing Smith popularized as an up-tempo style that relied on a heavy stride -- left-handed playing that spanned all six and half octaves -- and a lot of countermelody and syncopation. Mr. Banks said one of Smith's signature pieces was "Fingerbuster," a fast-moving piece in which the pianist must demonstrates skill in moving rapidly up and down the entire keyboard.
Unlike most musicians, Smith's nickname had nothing to do with his playing; it came from his service in World War I as an artilleryman. For 49 days straight, he manned a howitzer alone on the front lines in France, prompting his colonel to call him "a lion with that gun."
Mr. Baraka said neighborhoods like the Coast thrived in good economic times but suffered during the Depression, when many clubs and close. But the jazz venues never entirely disappeared, and new places cropped up in the 1930's and 40's as the clubs spread west into the Central Ward and stride gave way to swing. There, clubs with names like Jumping Jive, Lloyds Manor and the Orpheum featured headliners including Newark's own Savoy Sultans, who spiced their performance by dancing while they played and passing their instruments around without missing a beat.
As recordings replaced live performances as the major vehicle for the spread of jazz or any other music, the clubs disappeared. But even today, Newark maintains three or four jazz venues that still attract top performers.
In an effort to spread the word about Newark's jazz history, Mr. Baraka and the Performing Arts Center are planning on expanding the program to look at different eras in the city's jazz evolution and staging performances by the New Arkestra of the music of those periods at local clubs.
"We wanted to take it out into the communities so that people can see what a rich musical history the city has," said Stephanie S. Hughley, the center's vice president for programming. "We hope we can translate some of the enthusiasm of those times."
"The Lost Jazz Shrines of Newark," Saturday at 7:30 P.M. in the Victoria Theater, New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark. Tickets: $15 and $20. Information: (888) 466-5722.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Prescribing a Fiscal Pill For a Long-Term Cure

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey is awash in cash.
Because of the economic boom, state budget officials estimate there will be $1.3 billion in additional tax revenues over the next 18 months. That is on top of the state's $550 million budget surplus, sitting in a "rainy day" fund that has gone untouched this year. 
 So why didn't Governor Whitman recommend giving more of this money back to taxpayers when she outlined her new budget earlier this month?
After all, voters made it abundantly clear last fall that they were not happy about paying the highest property taxes in the nation. And cutting taxes is not a new concept for Mrs. Whitman. Keeping her 1993 campaign promise to cut income tax rates thrust her onto the national political stage and spurred states across the country to follow her lead.
Yet, in her new $17.95 billion budget, Mrs. Whitman proposed a spending increase of almost $1 billion for the fiscal year starting July 1. That's a 5.4 percent increase over this year's budget, the single largest spending increase since she took office four years ago.
Mrs. Whitman did propose one new tax cut. She wants to eliminate the sales tax on long-distance calls made within the state, which would save consumers and businesses about $24 million a year. However, a $24 million tax cut represents only 1.3 percent of the state's $1.8 billion projected budget surplus.
Defending her approach, Mrs. Whitman notes that she and lawmakers have already cut taxes 17 times since 1994. The state's tax-cutting record, she says, has helped create the economic boom that is pouring more money into the state's coffers. She argues that her budget "honors our commitment to use taxpayers' dollars wisely."
Governor Whitman is not alone in recommending higher spending over tax cuts this year. State spending is rising at about the same pace across the country, and two-thirds of the nation's governors are Republican. In New York, Governor George E. Pataki, a Republican who is running for re-election this year, has proposed an 8.5 percent spending increase over this year's budget.
Also, Mrs. Whitman is not exactly going on a spending spree. She is not recommending any sweeping new programs. More than half of the billion-dollar increase is earmarked for public schools, and school districts are complaining that it is not enough. Another $61 million increase is proposed for the state's community colleges and state universities to help hold the line on tuition.
Other spending increases include $29 million for New Jersey Transit to avoid bus and transit fare increases this year; $15 million to build bike paths throughout the state; $25 million to help cities reclaim abandoned buildings, and $50 million for a down payment on the Governor's pledge to help preserve open space and farmland. Mrs. Whitman also called for putting aside $650 million into next year's "rainy day" fund, giving the state a large cushion.
The Governor insists that her budget offered plenty of relief for property-tax payers by raising school spending and slightly increasing municipal aid.
But municipal aid did not rise significantly. Most of the increase for public schools covers pension costs for teachers, not classroom supplies.
The absence of any "direct" property relief is giving Democrats plenty of fodder to present themselves as fiscal conservatives. By portraying themselves as tax cutters, they are trying to erase voters' memories that they supported former Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase.
State Senator Wayne R. Bryant, a Democrat from Camden, has called on the Governor to use about $400 million of the surplus to expand the homestead rebate program. Until 1992, the program provided rebates, up to $500 annually, for families earning less than $100,000. Now, the program covers only families earning less than $40,000, as well as senior citizens and disabled individuals. The rebate checks now are no more than $90.
"Governor Whitman went on television three months ago to tell New Jerseyans that she heard their cries for property tax relief 'loud and clear,' " Mr. Bryant said, referring to a Whitman advertising spot during the waning days of last fall's campaign. "The Governor can effectively respond to the public's demand for solutions by putting tax rebate checks into the hands of working families."
There is no doubt that a rebate check would be welcomed in every New Jersey household. But voters want more than a $90 check in the mail. They want sweeping changes in the property tax system that will significantly lower their tax burden. That means relying more on state dollars and less on local property taxes to cover the cost of public schools.
Before even considering such changes, New Jersey would first need to get its own fiscal house in order. Under the direction of a new state treasurer, James A. DiEleuterio Jr., this is the first budget in four years that is not riddled with risky fiscal maneuvers. In this budget, the Governor is proposing to spend no more than what the state takes in. At the same time, the budget sets $650 million into the rainy day fund.
Putting the state on firm fiscal footing does not give much comfort to tax-weary homeowners. But, in the end, it is the only way that New Jerseyans can one day get the level of property tax relief that they are demanding.

HEADLINE: The World;
A Firm Friend Starts to Waver

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL

 BODY:
FROM the time Turkey sent soldiers to fight alongside Americans in the Korean War, leaving more than 700 of them buried in the cold Korean earth, this country has been one of the United States' closest allies.
When the United States needed territory on which to build spy stations for monitoring the Soviet Union, Turkey provided it. When it sought an air base in the eastern Mediterranean, Turkey made one available. When it was looking for allies in the Persian Gulf War and support for the embargo against Iraq, Turkey proved reliable even as it lost billions of dollars in trade. 
 In return, the United States has stood firmly behind Turkey. Huge amounts of American weaponry have flowed to the Turkish army, and criticism of Turkish human rights abuses is always more muted in Washington than it is in European capitals.
In recent days, however, this long friendship has shown signs of stress. American plans to bomb Iraq have brought to the surface doubts that have been spreading here since the end of the cold war.
According to a public opinion survey conducted last week for a leading Istanbul newspaper, 63 percent of Turks oppose the plans to bomb Iraq. Even public figures who have supported the United States in the past are expressing fears that such a campaign could trigger new instability in a region that has become increasingly volatile lately.
"There is a greater feeling of concern about what America is doing than I have seen here since we joined NATO 50 years ago," said Cuneyt Akalin, a professor of political science at Galatasaray University in Istanbul. "Politicians who are expressing reservations about the American plan for bombing are winning a lot of public sympathy. Saddam is certainly a bad guy, but there is a lot of concern about why the Americans are going after him so hard at this moment. If he strikes against Israel and Israel reacts, there will be real chaos."
 
Tensions Nearby
Professor Akalin cited other tensions in the region -- instability in the nations of the Caucasus and between Israel and the Palestinians. "People in Turkey who used to take refuge in NATO and the United States now think that maybe we should become more friendly with Russia," he said. "A lot of big questions are in the air."
Turkish fears are based in part on a sense that a bombing campaign against Iraq could create trouble in unpredictable ways for the entire region. More specifically, Turks remember that the 1991 gulf war left them with big problems -- the loss of revenues from a pipeline that once took Iraqi oil across Turkey to the Mediterranean, the sudden arrival of one million Kurdish refugees from Iraq and economic collapse in southeastern provinces that had relied on over-the-border trade with Iraq.
The gulf war also led to creation of a Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq that has become a sanctuary for anti-Turkish guerrillas. Many Turkish politicians fear that if there is another round of conflict, the enclave could become a full-fledged Kurdish state.
Seeking to calm these fears, the United States Ambassador to Turkey, Mark Parris, summoned Turkish journalists to a briefing at which he asserted that maintaining Iraq's territorial integrity is "the bedrock of U.S. policy toward Iraq." He added, "We would not support establishment of any separatist entities with respect to Iraq or anywhere else."
Nonetheless, even Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz, a pro-American figure who is a close ally of the Turkish military, is worried about what might happen in the wake of an attack. "Turkey has reason to be alarmed," Mr. Yilmaz told reporters who accompanied him on a state visit to Ukraine. "We are still very concerned about the possibility of a Kurdish state emerging in the region. It wouldn't necessarily come from an American plan. After an attack, things may develop spontaneously."
 
Clamping Down
Fears that bombing Iraq could lead to new assertiveness by Kurds have already pushed the Government into action at home. Police officers have raided offices of the only legal Kurdish political party, arresting important leaders on charges of plotting separatism. It was perhaps the first political fallout from the American attack, unfolding even before the first bomb has fallen.
Even Turks who do not believe that a Kurdish state will emerge after the expected bombing of Iraq wonder if the United States has measured all the possible consequences.
"We know the military objective, which is to destroy weapons of mass destruction," said Sukru Elekdag, a former Turkish ambassador to the United States. "But what will be the broader political effect? We don't know. Either the Americans are not telling the Turks what they envision, or they haven't thought about it. Either way it's very bad.
"There is no sympathy in this country for Saddam, and Turks feel generally that his weapons of mass destruction should be eliminated," Mr. Elekdag said. "But we have to look beyond the war. The subsequent situation should not be worse than present conditions. There could be chaos or confusion, which would encourage Iran to take advantage of the situation by attacking Iraq, or any number of other possibilities.
"If the United States withdraws now without getting some important results, it would be seen as a paper tiger, which would be bad for Turkey and the whole area. But there is no urgency at this moment. Saddam is not about to use his weapons, so the United States can afford to be a little more patient."
Another close observer of Turkish foreign policy, Soli Ozel, a professor of international relations at Bilgi University in Istanbul, recalled that many Turks supported the United States only grudgingly during the gulf war. He said support is even weaker now.
"As the days pass, more and more people are thinking that the Americans are not right this time," Mr. Ozel said. "There are so many negative possibilities, and we don't have the sense that the Americans have thought them through."

HEADLINE: Kiss, Kiss, Dar-leeng, Where Do You Want to Go?

BYLINE: By DAVID COLMAN 

 BODY:
ON a Friday afternoon, as other travel agents were shutting down early for the long Presidents' Day weekend, the call came. Could the Frenchway Travel agency get the models Kate Moss and Naomi Campbell from Cape Town to Havana by that Monday? They absolutely had to be there for a photo shoot for Harper's Bazaar.
In a flash, Esther Tavor, an owner of the agency, was on the case. "Don't tell me no -- I tell you that is not acceptable," she said tersely over the telephone to an airline representative, her heavy French accent blending parfaitement with the cigarette smoke and smell of espresso wafting through the office. The wheels of Frenchway were turning. 
 The world, encircled by thousands of leagues of topographical lines, may be a big place. But it is not nearly so unfathomable to the women of Frenchway, an agency on the eighth floor of a modest office building at 11 West 25th Street in Chelsea. With the tactical prowess and sang-froid of generals at war, Ms. Tavor and Yael Choukroun -- sisters, French natives and the agency's founders and owners -- are experts at dealing with one of the more formidable threats to world peace: the fashion emergency.
The agency's style-in-overdrive ethos was palpable even to a Federal Express man, who was there to pick up some last-minute parcels. "Wait, darling," another Frenchway operative said, her voice somewhere between a coo and a bark. "One minute."
For the record, "darling," one of the commoner words around Frenchway, is pronounced dar-LEENG. The agency, started 13 years ago, has a staff of 11, all of them women. "One man in here, and forget it," Ms. Tavor said with a dismissive gesture and a roll of her eyes, as though the presence of a member of the opposite sex would undermine the agency's motto: "We do it . . . with passion. . . ."
That passion has built quite a following in the fashion industry: the designers Thierry Mugler and Azzedine Alaia; agencies like Wilhelmina Models, Next Management and Women Model Management; photographers like Mario Testino and Peggy Sirota, and the magazines German Elle and French Vogue. In fact, 70 percent of Frenchway's clients are from the fashion industry.
"If I've got a girl going from New York to London to Paris to Miami and back to New York, and a day to pull it together, they can get it -- for a great price," said May Au, an agent and booker with Women Model Management, which represents Ms. Moss. "I don't know how, but they do."
Ms. Tavor chalks it up to pit bull-like persistence, honed by years of dealing with modeling agencies and countless crises, not to mention constant cancellations. "When someone cancels, we don't get upset," she said. "It's models -- you can't do anything about it."
But she and Ms. Choukroun have learned that when it comes to models, there are some things they can do. One is to make sure that the models are not booked on the last flight of the day. If they miss an early flight, "there is always another one," Ms. Tavor said. "Very important." She said she has found that booking models onto seemingly more fashionable European carriers, like Air France or British Airways, is a good carrot to get the models on the plane.
Another precaution is to make sure that the agency knows which models fly in economy (those just starting out), business (those on their way up) and first class (those recognizable by first name alone).
"There are girls who won't do a shooting if they have to fly economy," Ms. Tavor said, declining to match names with classes.
The socialite and designer Diane Von Furstenberg has even had a dress flown by Frenchway. Last year, she called Frenchway from Paris, desperate to get a dress to her overnight from New York, recalled Ms. Tavor, who was able to find a model in transit to entrust with the precious cargo.
For some, the agency's allure is not just Teutonic efficiency but its Gallic laissez-faire. "They call you darling, you can hear them smoking on the phone," said Kristen Vallow, an art director for the photographer David LaChapelle. "It's like you're already in France."
Ms. Vallow said she recently called the agency to get a last-minute ticket to Rio de Janeiro for New Year to meet her prospective in-laws. "They just said, 'Darling, I love it!' " she said. "It actually changed the way I thought about my trip. It seemed fabulous and madcap to be going to Rio, instead of going to Brazil to meet my fiance's parents for the first time."
Like any travel agency, Frenchway can book a flight for anyone who calls. But it may not be totally at your service: if one wants to book a flight to some humdrum locale far in advance, for example, the agency would just as soon see the business go elsewhere.
"For me, personally, if it's not an emergency, I'm not interested," Ms. Tavor said. "I need the challenge. If you call me for a ticket in two months, it will only irritate me."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Cold Water For the Hot-Fund Strategy

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON

 BODY:
HOT funds, it seems, can burn investors.
Two prominent editors of mutual fund newsletters have stumbled into problems recently by trying to use a strategy that relies on picking so-called "hot hands," or fund managers who have done extremely well the previous year. 
 The idea behind the strategy is that a top-performing fund in one year will continue to outperform rivals because it is already aligned with the market's current favorite stocks. As of late, however, that has just not happened.
"I've come a cropper recently -- it doesn't work all the time," said one of the editors, Sheldon Jacobs of the No-Load Fund Investor newsletter, published in Irvington, N.Y.
And Daniel Wiener, editor of the Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors, based in Potomac, Md., avoided a bad pick last year only by sidestepping the fund his system chose.
Both men said their systems had produced above-average long-term returns. The No-Load Fund Investor made its first pick using the strategy in 1992, though Mr. Jacobs said he tested how the approach would have worked back to 1975. Over the last 22 years, he said, his picks, theoretical and actual, have advanced an average of 23.0 percent annually, compared with 15.2 percent for the average fund.
Mr. Wiener has made his picks since he began the newsletter seven years ago. He said that in that time they had delivered annualized returns of 18.2 percent, compared with 14.0 percent for the Vanguard Index 500 fund, which mirrors the Standard & Poor's 500 index of large-capitalization stocks.
The strategy hinges on the premise that market trends that benefit a particular fund don't necessarily stop come year-end. "If you think about it, there's no reason that because the year changes from December to January that a particular investment style or strategy suddenly goes out of favor," Mr. Wiener said.
But many investment professionals reject the notion that investors can produce above-average results simply by choosing last year's best performers. Burton Malkiel, professor of economics at Princeton University, said: "While there have been certain periods when you could isolate that kind of persistence, the persistence is not persistent. It completely falls apart during other periods, and the bottom line is that there is no way an investor can gain above-average performance simply by buying funds that have had recent good performance."
A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J., had a briefer interpretation. "There are no hot hands -- just different lengths of market phases," Mr. Lipper said.
Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Wiener don't advocate betting the rent money on the strategy; both advise investors to put only a small part of their stock market allocation into hot-hands funds.
Their systems are similar: They limit their selections to diversified domestic equity funds, rejecting sector and international funds as too volatile. Then they choose the previous year's top performer from among their respective data bases. Mr. Jacobs follows 373 no-load funds fitting this description; Mr. Wiener limits himself to funds managed by the Vanguard Group. The funds are sold the following January and replaced with new winners.
The notion that market trends persist beyond the end of a year enjoys some academic support. In a recent article in The Journal of Finance, Mark Carhart, a University of Southern California economist, reported on research into common stocks that found a pattern of price increases persisting into a second year.
"I call it the one-year momentum effect, and it's robust in the United States and in most markets of the world," said Mr. Carhart, currently on leave to work at Goldman Sachs Asset Management. "What's happening is that there's some information about the company that has come out and it hasn't been fully discounted in the price of the stock, so it continues to drift upward abnormally for another year."
While the tactic seems simple, it has proved troublesome to implement. In 1996, Mr. Jacobs recommended Wasatch Mid Cap, which had spurted 58.8 percent, or almost twice the average increase for stock funds in his universe the previous year. The fund was heavily concentrated in technology stocks, however, and collapsed during a correction in the sector. It returned only 3.6 percent, versus 18.6 percent for the average equity no-load fund in his universe.
Worried that his purely mechanistic approach had failed, in 1997 Mr. Jacobs rejected his computer's choice, Warburg Pincus Small Cap Value fund, and instead chose the Robertson Stephens Partners fund, which had returned 43.3 percent the previous year. Partners was bearish, and so was Mr. Jacobs. The fund lagged behind the average by 4.5 percentage points last year. (The Warburg fund, as it happened, posted almost identical results.)
This year, Mr. Jacobs has recommended Safeco Growth No Load, which surged 50.0 percent last year. Two funds with better records, American Heritage and Oakmark Select, were rejected because they were "nondiversified," he said.
Mr. Wiener also tinkered with his system last year, though for a different reason. He said the best eligible Vanguard fund of 1996 had been the Windsor fund, which gained 26.4 percent. Windsor, however, is closed to new investors. So he urged his subscribers to hold onto Vanguard Windsor II, which they already owned because it had been the previous year's pick.
Fortunately for his readers, Windsor II trounced its sibling, returning 32.4 percent, versus 22.0 percent for Windsor. His recommendation this year is Vanguard Primecap, which spurted 36.8 percent last year.
Jumping into hot funds can cause investors to incur additional costs. For investors outside of tax-deferred accounts, successful positions will create capital gains that have not been held long enough to qualify for the lowest tax rate, now applicable only after 18 months.
Nevertheless, investors are drawn to hot funds. Consider this year's picks: Safeco said assets of its Growth No Load fund had swelled 40.2 percent, to $895.2 million, in the first six weeks of this year. Primecap's assets jumped 7.9 percent in January, to $8.84 billion.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Dodge Ram Quad Cab;
A Grand Slam in the Door Wars

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB 

 BODY:
TRUCKS are the big thing, and the biggest-selling trucks are large indeed. Americans bought nearly three million pickups last year, about two-thirds of them "full sized" -- an understatement given how hefty these haulers have become.
The extent of the pickup phenomenon cannot be fully appreciated in urban areas of the East Coast, where the trucks lined up at stoplights are likely to be graffiti-tagged delivery vans or squeaky-clean sport utilities. Away from the coasts, across the vast expanse where Paul Harvey is on the radio and chicken-fried steak is on the breakfast menu, the pickup seems well on its way to supplanting the family car. 
 On a couple of a long-haul trips across the Plains, I conducted an informal survey: On a stretch of Interstate 80 west of Des Moines, 7 of every 10 vehicles I met were pickups, most of them full-size. On Highway 75 north of Topeka, Kan., it was 6 out of 10.
Across the heartland, there are new faces behind truck windshields: small-business owners, lawyers, insurance agents, women who look suspiciously like soccer moms. Footloose guys in their 20's, who might once have aspired to Formula Firebirds, are buying sporty trucks as their first new cars.
These people feel at home in the dude-ranch cabins, where soft cowhides, power windows and CD players have replaced bare metal and barely padded seats. But the frosting on the pickup was the extended cab, a 1974 breakthrough from Ford that was copied throughout the industry. With extra space behind the front seat, there is room for two or three children -- adults, even, if they're good sports -- and a secure place for shopping bags, tool boxes or sales sample kits. And you can still pick up a sofa or a ton of concrete blocks on the way home. Extended cabs now account for 61 percent of full-size pickup sales, up from 17 percent in 1989.
But the early extra-cab pickups had a problem: using the extra space meant tilting forward a heavy truck seat, a particularly daunting exercise for children. For 1996, General Motors offered a solution, a small third door, and Ford followed suit when it redesigned its F-150 for 1997.
Chrysler skipped the three-door party to plan the next premiere, and for 1998 its beefy Dodge Ram -- the pickup that looks like a Peterbilt -- is available with four doors. This could be the start of something bigger. Just as four-door models took sport utility vehicles out of the woods and into the car pools, multiple doors are bound to broaden the appeal of pickups even further.
Dodge has this market to itself, but not for long. Having missed the shift to four-door mini-vans, Ford is determined not to make the same mistake in trucks, where it leads the market. By year-end, it will offer four doors for each of its light-truck lines -- on its big Super Duty models next month, on the compact Ranger in May, and on the full-size F-150 and F-250 pickups in the fall.
G.M. is behind, but it will eventually offer four doors on its all-new Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra pickups, due this summer.
Of course, pickups with four conventional doors, called crew cabs, have been around a while. These are heavy-duty work trucks with two full bench seats and, generally, few other amenities. The Ram Quad Cab is not like that: It can be had with all the frills, and its extra doors are junior-sized, hinged at the rear and latching into the full-size front doors. The front door must be open before the back door can be unlatched.
As in the two-door Club Cab, there is a full-width seat in the rear, with three seat belts, two shoulder belts and a bottom cushion that flips up for more storage space. The front seats have integrated safety belts that stay out of the way.
My test vehicle was a Ram 1500 Series with a six-and-a-half-foot bed, four-wheel drive, a 5.2-liter V8 and a five-speed manual transmission. The window sticker totaled $28,885, bolstered by $6,000 in options.
The rear doors proved useful, making it possible to load items on one side and retrieve them from the other -- although the pickup's width makes this harder than one might expect. And there was an annoying hitch: If the front seat is all the way back on its track, or slightly reclined, the backrest blocks the latch for the back door. The seat then has to be moved to reach the latch -- an awkward, two-hand operation -- which seems to defeat the purpose of adding a door to avoid having to move a seat.
Even with family-friendly access, the appearance of the big Dodge is intimidating, and therein lies much of its appeal. While no one paid attention to the previous Ram, the macho redesign of 1994 has not just tripled sales, it made this truck a conversation piece wherever guys with calloused hands lean against fenders and chew on toothpicks. Drive one past a construction site and it turns heads like a supermodel. That was especially the case with the bold, black test truck, which seemed about as big as the Death Star and at least that menacing.
Big pickups also appeal because of the seemingly infinite ways they can be personalized; you need the math skills of Will Hunting to total the configurations. For starters, there are 32 combinations of cabs (standard, Club Cab, Quad Cab), cargo beds (6.5 or 8 feet) and engines (3.9-liter V6, 5.2-liter V8, 5.9 liter V8, 5.9-liter turbo-diesel in-line 6, 8-liter V10). You can have the basic ST, the fancy Laramie SLT or the drab-as-Monday-morning Work Special.
There are four wheelbases (118.7, 134.7, 138.7 or 154.7 inches), four transmissions, two transfer cases, 23 tire and wheel combinations, three gas tanks, half a dozen axle ratios and a universe of possible trailer-towing capacities. You can order the Snow Plow Prep Group, the Sport Appearance Group or the Super Sport Truck Group. There's a Camper Special, a Trailer Tow Preparation Group and a Travel Convenience Group.
Like many vehicles, the extended Ram is bigger than most people need it to be. The appeal is undeniable in the wide-open spaces of, say, Montana, but is less logical in the precincts of, say, Mamaroneck. Although the test truck was relatively small -- the 2500 Series is really big, especially with the long bed -- it was a handful in New York.
A good thing: It is among the few vehicles that Manhattan cab drivers actually fear. A bad thing: Its width (80 inches) makes it difficult or impossible to navigate streets lined with double-parked delivery trucks. A funny thing: Its length (nearly 19 feet) makes parallel parking a spectator sport.
With no load, the suspension dances over potholes and hops over rough patches. On a trip to Connecticut, the Ram handled, well, like a big truck. The steering is light and feels in touch with the road, but high-speed cornering is obviously not the point.
The 5.2-liter V8 has more horsepower this year (230, up from 220). The engine's 300 foot-pounds of torque were evident at the low end but somewhat lacking at midrange. Even this relatively small engine will spin the rear tires easily if four-wheel drive is not engaged. The long-throw shifter felt much like those of farm trucks I drove in the 70's, and I missed third gear several times before I got a feel for it.
The Federal mileage rating for the test truck was 13 in town, 17 on the highway. An indicator light tells you when to upshift for the best economy.
Even with a four-wheel anti-lock system, a $500 option, the brakes had a pickup's usual tentative feel. G.M. promises much better brakes on its new models; if it delivers, and its rivals are forced to catch up, it will have performed a valuable service.
The cabin is cavernous, and a new instrument panel includes dual air bags, plus a key-operated switch to deactivate the passenger bag if a child seat is in use. The controls are oversized and convenient. Chrysler's cruise control buttons are still among the best around, situated on the steering wheel with an indicator light on the dash.
The front seats -- split in a 40-20-40 pattern with an armrest/bin in the middle -- were too hard and upright. The backrests recline, but the mechanism is clunky. And the headrests appear to be of little benefit to anyone much taller than 6 feet. There are two power outlets and two generous cup holders. One is ingenious, with a slide that adjusts the diameter to fit any cup.
The jumbo storage compartment under the center armrest is also inspired, with spaces for a laptop computer, a mobile phone, cassettes and small items. The lid is firm enough to serve as a desk, and at a width of 15 inches, is almost as big as one.
 
INSIDE TRACK: An open-and-shut case for the practical pickup.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Until Ed McMahon Calls, They Need to Slice Debt

SERIES: FRESH START: A periodic look at the crossroads of personal finance.

BYLINE: By PAUL SWEENEY

 BODY:
TWICE a month, Elizabeth Genel sits down at the dining table in her seaside condominium to face a small mountain of bills. Fortified with a Pop Tart and a Diet Coke, she makes short work of the stack, reducing it to nothing in 60 minutes flat. At the same time, unfortunately, she also levels the family checking account.
When the checks come in, "there's $4,000 or so in the bank," she said. But after the bill-paying sessions, "there's only $100." 
 The big bills are not only from the holidays or some special expenses. For Ms. Genel and her husband, Mark Nyman, a lawyer, much of the monthly outflow goes to large long-term debt. Indeed, the couple, who are both 31 and live in Milford, Conn., are more than $450,000 in the hole. If they had a theme song, it might come from the bumper sticker, "I owe, I owe, it's off to work I go."
"I wish that Ed McMahon would knock on the door with a check," Mr. Nyman said.
They clearly have high earnings potential. Both earned law degrees at the University of San Diego in 1994, and Mr. Nyman practices family law in Stamford, Conn., earning a salary in the high five figures.
Ms. Genel shunned the law and took a job in retail cosmetics, a field she knew. Simultaneously, she researched the possibility of operating her own cosmetics shop and makeup salon. Her husband, who is also a certified public accountant with experience at Price Waterhouse, wrote a business plan that won them a bank's backing.
In October, Ms. Genel's dream became a reality when the couple opened up JD's Cosmetic Essentials on the Post Road in Westport, Conn. The shop -- named for her unused law degree -- sells fragrances, soaps and toiletries that are unavailable elsewhere in Connecticut, she said, and hard to find even in New York and Boston. Although Ms. Genel is not yet drawing a salary, the store is paying its bills, she added, including the salaries of two part-time employees.
But the couple's big debts seem to overshadow their professional progress. Their largest liability, with an 8 percent average annual rate of interest, is $172,000 in combined education loans. Ms. Genel jokes that the only benefit she can show from law school is her marriage to Mr. Nyman. "It was an expensive dating service," she said.
Then come the store debts: a $100,000 bank loan, at 10 percent interest and secured in part by the couple's home, and $30,000 borrowed interest-free from their families. Since Ms. Genel left her former job and started the boutique, the couple have also run up their Visa and Mastercard balances, which had already ballooned during their school years. The balances now stand at more than $25,000, at an average interest rate of 14.5 percent. Finally, the condominium carries a $135,000 mortgage, with a variable rate that is now 8 percent.
The grand total: $462,000 in personal and business debt.
Nor does the couple have much in savings. Mr. Nyman's 401(k) account at work has $13,000, 75 percent of it invested in the Fidelity Stock Selector fund, which is a quantitative fund, and 25 percent in Fidelity Emerging Growth.
The couple worry that they may never escape from debt -- or be able to retire. Ms. Genel wonders if they will even be able to afford the two children they both want. And there are plenty of small reasons, too, to wrestle down the debt.
"I want to buy a package of Milano cookies without feeling guilty," Ms. Genel said.
Indeed, the couple have little leeway for luxuries. Each month, they pay $237 on their car -- nothing fancy, a Nissan Altima -- and about $380 on their health, life, car and home insurance. Add in food, phone, utilities and gasoline, and there is little left for fun: Entertainment usually means watching TV at home. To splurge, they eat out a couple of times a month, but one-time expenses, like the $600 for Ms. Genel's root canal last year, can endanger even that luxury.
One of their few extras is Ms. Genel's health club membership, at $400 a year.
How to rein in their debt? The New York Times asked Karen Altfest, vice president at L. J. Altfest Company, a financial planning firm in Manhattan, to make some recommendations.
On paper, Ms. Altfest said, the couple's situation looked very troubling, among the most extreme cases of indebtedness that she could recall.
She was initially dubious about Ms. Genel's business venture, too. By opening a cosmetics shop, Ms. Altfest said, the couple had not only undertaken an uncertain enterprise and saddled themselves with added debt, but they had also lost Ms. Genel's regular paycheck.
Upon meeting Ms. Genel, however, Ms. Altfest was impressed with her confidence and ambition. "Whatever you've got, I'm buying," Ms. Altfest said. But while Ms. Genel's qualities may enhance her chances, Ms. Altfest advised strict limits on the venture: If the store is not paying Ms. Genel $50,000 to $60,000 in salary within three years, it should be shuttered and she should find a regular job.
The planner also gave her imprimatur to the couple's notion of selling the condominium. Although they would no longer be building home equity, the move to an apartment would save $400 a month on the $1,400 they now pay for mortgage and condo fees.
Losing the tax deduction for mortgage interest will not be too costly for now, Ms. Altfest said, because the start-up costs for the shop will minimize their income taxes.
After selling the condo for about $200,000 and paying off the mortgage, the couple should use the remaining $65,000 to pay off their credit-card debt, which carries the highest interest rate. Then, Ms. Altfest recommended, they should either tear up the plastic or put it in the back of a drawer.
The couple might use the rest of the condo profits to reduce their business loan, an idea to which Ms. Altfest did not object.
But Ms. Altfest said that, as the couple's income grew, they must maintain a tight rein on spending. "Pretend that you're earning the same income," Ms. Altfest said. "You should do that until you've made a big impact on the debt."
As for children and retirement, Ms. Altfest thought that both were possible -- but only if the couple saved regularly while retiring debt. "It's hard to save for the future when you don't have the past cleaned up yet," the planner noted, but parenthood and retirement are costly.
Financial advisers offer many tips for helping the savings habit take root. For example, they say, make your savings a monthly "bill," just like the rent. Put the savings where it would be costly to raid, like a retirement account or certificate of deposit that has an early-withdrawal penalty. Or designate particular income -- say, Ms. Genel's salary, or Mr. Nyman's every fourth paycheck -- for savings.
Mr. Nyman strongly agrees with the need to save. "It blows my mind to see clients who make a lot of money but don't have any assets," he said.
Even with a rigorous financial regimen, however, the couple will need 10 to 15 years just to pay off their student loans and, more generally, may have to work into their 70's to realize the other goals, Ms. Altfest said.
But Ms. Genel was upbeat. "I never thought we could do it," she said. "These numbers are so huge. It's nice to hear from a professional that there is hope."
Ms. Altfest had other advice for the couple, including the need to write wills. Ms. Genel took this counsel seriously, but she could not resist teasing her husband.
"Here, honey, you can have all my debt," she said.

HEADLINE: COPING;
The Re-education of Philip Reed

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
ONE day last month, determined to buy locally in his new neighborhood, Philip Reed, a fresh member of the City Council, walked across East 116th Street from his office and ordered a sandwich at the back of a narrow little deli. The man behind the counter said he could make no sandwiches because there had been no bread delivery that day.
Never shy with advice, Mr. Reed explained how easy and profitable it would be to cross the street to the local supermarket and buy a few loaves. Writ small, it was exactly the kind of economic connections he wants to help make in the Eighth District, which includes chunks of East Harlem, the Upper West Side and the South Bronx. 
 A few days later, when Mr. Reed returned, the man again told him there had been no bread delivery, thus no sandwiches. Mr. Reed, not uncharacteristically, began shouting, "You are either on drugs or selling drugs because you are an idiot."
He stormed out. If the man was on drugs, Mr. Reed thought, he would have to find social service agencies to get him clean. If he was selling drugs, he would have to get the police to drive him out of business.
"Is that the first thing you need to do here?" I asked.
"First thing, I need a carpet on
this floor," he said, "so when I make calls I don't sound like I'm shouting in an echo chamber."
We were sitting at a table in his large, bright, spare office, eating fried fish from up the block. The carpet -- like the sandwich story -- is both a reality and a metaphor. Mr. Reed, who turned 49 yesterday, has spent most of his political life as advocate and agitator on discrimination, housing, H.I.V. issues. Suddenly, his words have more "weight and consequence." He is learning procedure, organization and diplomacy all at once. He can change people's lives.
"I can't pop off as much, I have to think through the issues," he said. "I'm having a ball. People actually ask me what I think. I've gotten a new lease on life, a renewal. It's a cliche, but the Lord works in mysterious ways. She has a plan for me."
On January 20, 1997, the day of President Clinton's second inauguration, Mr. Reed ended 18 months of chemotherapy for multiple myeloma, a bone-marrow cancer so ferocious it was just as easy to allow people to believe he had AIDS. (He was diagnosed as H.I.V.-positive in 1981.) He decided to replay his dream of elective office -- he had been defeated in races for the State Senate and the City Council -- and he called his campaign "Dead Man Running."
Despite nasty racial politics -- he was smeared as an anti-Latino candidate -- he won overwhelmingly.
"Trounced was the word your paper used," he said. "TROUNCED." His face twisted, his voice dropped. "And now you can hear the people saying, 'He may be queer but he opened his only office in East Harlem. Not on the West Side, but here with us!' "
Mr. Reed, quick-silver smart, funny, cocky, emotional, profane, is very West Side. Born of an interracial romance and marriage that fell apart around their birth, he and his twin sister were raised by their mother and stepfather, both white, in an upper-middle-class Manhattan world of civil rights activism, prep schools, the Vineyard. Mr. Reed dropped out of Ohio Wesleyan and received conscientious objector status during the Vietnam War. He spent 10 years in San Francisco, as a salesman for Otis Elevator and a radical gay political activist. He returned to New York 20 years ago, coming into politics here through a neighborhood block association. He left Otis to run a service program in Brooklyn for people with H.I.V.
Last year, he was receiving $1,300 a month in disability payments, slowly coming back to life after the chemo treatments. He had nothing to lose. He was ready to run again.
"Most of my friends are dead," he said. Tears came as quickly as had the laughter. "There are big holes in me. My life has knocked a certain amount of the arrogance out of me. I've been unemployed and disabled, and I did nothing wrong. I've had to shop for the cheaper can of food. Okay, how do we move beyond that? As an individual, as a community?
"How do we get gentrification to come north of 96th Street, and monitor who gets something out of it? How do we make that Hispanic cultural strip on East 106th Street into a tourist destination? How do we make sure that people on welfare who get jobs don't lose health insurance? How do we stop politicians from driving a wedge between Hispanics and African-Americans?"
He stopped, and twisted into his comic's posture. "You come back in six months. I might have answers. I will surely have a carpet on the floor."
