SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 817 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks

BYLINE: By NOELLE KNOX

 BODY:
ILLEGAL drugs are a big problem for Garry M. Ritzky: too many of his job applicants use them. Mr. Ritzky, risk and human resources director for Turner Brothers Trucking Inc., a transportation and oil services company in Oklahoma City, is having a hard time finding candidates who are clean of cocaine, marijuana and heroin.
"We have an oil pipe operation that uses unskilled laborers, and we're seeing more positive drug tests," he said. "We had three last week." The number of positive drug tests among applicants for low-skilled jobs at Turner Brothers has doubled in the last year, Mr. Ritzky added. 
 Such evidence, while mostly anecdotal, runs counter to the decline in positive drug tests that most businesses have seen the last decade. Yet with the unemployment rate at a 25-year low and the economy continuing to grow, more human resource managers say they are starting to see a small but disturbing increase in the number of job applicants who fail screening for drug and alcohol abuse.
One reason for that increase, they say, is that as the supply of potential employees continues to shrink, those with drug and alcohol problems probably represent a larger portion of the labor pool. Some also say a number of products now available to beat drug tests are encouraging some job applicants to take chances. And marijuana, they say, is again in vogue.
According to a study released late last year by the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse, 16 percent of unemployed people used illicit drugs in 1994. When the data were collected, unemployment was at 6.1 percent. Today, with unemployment at 4.7 percent, qualified job seekers are harder to find.
"Employers are finding it harder to find people who are not using drugs," said James G. Lipari, public health adviser for the Federal Government's Center for Substance Abuse Prevention. "Since there are more employers using testing and other prevention means, there are more people who are unemployed for that reason, which makes the pool of unemployed who are using drugs great."
But these apparent trends are not yet reflected in the data. When drug testing first became widespread, in the late 1980's, about 18 percent of the tests showed signs of drug use, according to SmithKline Beecham Clinical Laboratories, one of the nation's largest drug-testing labs. That number, which represents mostly screening of applicants and a small amount of tests for workers already on the job, fell steadily, to 8.8 percent in 1991, and then began to decline more slowly. In 1996, about 5.8 percent of the tests showed signs of drugs.
"Over the past 10 years, we've seen a dramatic decrease in positive tests," said Thomas Johnson, a spokesman for SmithKline Beecham. The lab is expected to release the results for 1997 in the next few weeks.
"Early indications are that they will continue to decline," Mr. Johnson said.
One drug that is coming back, however, is marijuana. Of the people who failed the SmithKline drug test in 1996, almost 60 percent had traces of marijuana in their urine. That is up from 52 percent from 1995.
Marijuana use was in the spotlight two weeks ago when the Canadian snowboarder Ross Rebagliati had his Olympic gold medal withdrawn after he failed a drug test. Mr. Rebagliati said he had not smoked marijuana since April 1997 and that any residue in his urine was from second-hand smoke. With somewhat less-than-clear Olympic rules on the penalty for marijuana use, he was later allowed to keep the medal.
The accuracy of drug tests has been questioned by groups including the Society for Human Resource Management, based in Alexandria, Va. It says data provided by companies like SmithKline Beecham, while accurately reflecting a downward trend, must be taken with a grain of salt. "Some people have since learned to beat the system," said Barry K. Lawrence, a spokesman for the society.
Several companies advertise on the Internet, for example, selling products to cover up traces of drugs in urine or hair. One company, Test Clean Drug Testing Solutions in Oklahoma City, boasts that its product, Klear, which can be bought for as little as $30, "is the smallest most potent, undetectable urine purifier sold today."
Mr. Johnson of SmithKline acknowledged, "It's like a cat-and-mouse game." But, he said, laboratories are catching on and are starting to test for those adulterants as well.
Most experts agree that drug testing has cut drug and alcohol abuse in the workplace, but its greatest impact is on casual users.
"It eliminated use among individuals who could stop, who had more at stake and didn't want to lose that," said Ellen Weber, director of national policy for the Legal Action Center, a nonprofit group based in New York that is involved in drug, alcohol and H.I.V. employment issues. "Drug testing, in my mind, was never an effective tool for people who are dependent on drugs."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1191 words

HEADLINE: The World: Present Tense;
Oh, To Be Young, Charismatic and Centrist in Germany

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
IF there is one message that has been drummed home to Germans, as much by foreigners as by their own postwar leaders, it is that the past must never be suppressed. But are Germans -- or, at least, their politicians -- suppressing the present?
Even at the most obvious level, this land of 82 million people confronts enough deep-rooted problems to support the view that it stands, slightly bewildered, at a crossroads. Choosing which road to take is not so clear-cut. 
 Unemployment is nudging towards the five million total associated with the joblessness that helped loft Hitler to power in 1933. (Even the wording on some jobless protesters' banners is uncannily reminiscent of similar placards in the early 1930's.) Indeed, joblessness -- particularly among young people in the depressed former East Germany -- is a driving force behind an alarming wave of neo-Nazism.
The euro, Europe's soon-to-come single currency, is set to replace the German mark, the emblem of postwar prosperity, stability and economic power. And, perhaps most fundamentally, Germany is caught between the opposing strains of the American-style marketplace and the older reflexes of the welfare state.
So what have Germany's leaders pulled out of their hats to confront these deep-seated problems?
The answer is: precious little. And when Germans scan the horizon for a Teutonic Bill Clinton, say, or a German Tony Blair to invigorate a moribund political establishment, they find little inspiration.
 
Paralysis
An effort last year to spur entrepreneurial initiative by overhauling the tax system foundered in a political deadlock in Bonn. When 155 economics professors, echoing widespread misgivings among Germans, called this month for the postponement of the euro's introduction beyond the scheduled starting date 11 months from now, Chancellor Helmut Kohl stifled all further public debate by saying the new currency would proceed, on schedule, as per contractual obligations with the rest of Europe. End of discussion: not once have Germans -- or most other Europeans -- been told by their leaders what the euro will mean for salaries and benefits, pensions or mortgages or purchasing power.
Successive attempts to remodel Germany's expensive state pension and health care systems, moreover, have been diluted in political compromise, as is typical in a land that prizes consensus and fears confrontation that might awaken the ghosts of the past. Indeed, the political system devised for West Germany by the Western allies after World War II provides for so many checks and balances that political paralysis is nearly inevitable.
The result for employers is that the cost of hiring has become too high: just to insure that an employee has net pay of $2,000 per month, employers must pay more than twice that amount in gross salary to cover mandatory withholdings for state pensions, taxes, health care and social security. Some economists estimate that four out of five of Germany's 4.8 million unemployed are without jobs because of these costs.
Big business in Germany has already drawn its own conclusions, exporting manufacturing jobs to countries with cheaper labor, creating the paradox of solid economic growth that does not shorten unemployment lines.
For decades, of course, Germany has been regarded as an economic model, the land that gave its people the longest vacations, highest pay, shortest work week, earliest retirement, highest pensions and deepest social security net. So it is not surprising that the Darwinian ethic underlying economic growth in the United States -- not to mention the legacy of Thatcherite Britain -- should collide with German insistence that more than just the fittest should survive: the weak need their pensions and health care and unemployment benefits, too.
The government paralysis stems from various factors. National elections next September have already transfixed politicians as they jostle for position rather than tackle issues or contemplate risks. Chancellor Kohl and his coalition have been in office since 1982, so the twin genies of fatigue and arrogance that beset Britain's Tories in the late 80's and early 90's and marked the tired final days of the Bush Administration have become increasingly visible in recent years.
With the fanfare of reunification reduced to a long, expensive, bumpy diminuendo, the nation's political life seems to be on hold, awaiting the planned move of the government to Berlin next year, the coming of the euro, the advent of the millennium, the elections.
The only problem is that the rest of the world is moving on. Where the United States and Britain have performed the same conjuring act -- ousting longtime conservative governments with a combination of youthful, charismatic leadership and the embrace of centrist policies that replace ideology with pragmatism -- Mr. Kohl, Europe's longest-serving leader and most powerful conservative figure, is unchanging and unchanged.
"His whole political thinking has been rooted in history," said Patricia Clough, the British author of a newly published study in German of Mr. Kohl. "His two missions have been the reunification of Germany and to unite Europe so that there can never be war again. And he's never really grasped that the world is changing on other fronts, like globalization."
 
Fear of Change
Yet Mr. Kohl, whose principle currency is his own immutability, may still be in power after the September vote: not only is there no German Clinton or Blair on the horizon, but it is far from certain that German voters would risk embracing one at precisely the moment they sense so many other uncertainties.
"The loss of the German mark will be so traumatic for many Germans that they will not want to risk anything else," Ms. Clough said. So while Mr. Kohl may be postponing hard choices for a successor well down the road, she said, part of his strategy now is "to reassure Germans that they will be safe, that nothing will change."
Neither is it clear who will challenge that strategy. The single most popular politician in the country, according to opinion surveys, is Gerhard Schroder, the state premier of Lower Saxony. But he has yet to win the endorsement of the opposition Social Democrats as a candidate for Chancellor, and only last month he established strictly non-Darwinian economic credentials by nationalizing a steel mill to preserve jobs before key state elections on March 1.
For some, though, there is a different, less tangible malaise. The Thatcherite Britain of the 80's brought real pain to entire sectors of the population as much as it revolutionized the economy. America's middle-class in the early 90's endured the trauma of downsizing as the price for low employment and world-beating growth.
As if anesthetized by decades of well-being, by contrast, many Germans sense change is inevitable, but by and large they have not felt that kind of radical pain. Indeed, many would ask: Why should we? In a land whose voters have grown accustomed to comfort and security, that is a question the politicians would prefer to postpone for another day.

HEADLINE: Going in Style: The Loved One Gets a New Age Send-off

BYLINE: By JEFF STRYKER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
A Taurus rocket launched earlier this month from Vandenberg Air Force Base in Lompoc, Calif., carried a standard payload of three communications satellites. But also along for the ride were the cremated remains of 30 individuals who had paid $4,800 each to become one with the universe.
They were packed by Celestis, a Houston-based commercial venture, in a canister with lipstick-sized vials containing about seven grams each of human remains. The launch drew attention to the increasingly creative possibilities for disposing of cremated remains -- or "cremains" as they are known in industry -- and to the growing popularity of cremation itself. 
 Today, about one in five Americans is cremated; the number is expected to grow to one in three by 2010, according to Jack Springer, executive director of the Cremation Society of North America. In California, the departed are cremated at nearly twice the national rate. And cremation is even more popular in Hawaii, Alaska, Nevada and Washington, where more than half of those who died in 1995 were cremated. The preference for cremation is clearly regional: the rate in Alabama and Mississippi was only 4 percent.
A survey conducted for the Funeral and Memorial Information Council in 1995 showed that the most common reasons for choosing cremation are convenience, simplicity and economy.
Thomas Lynch, a Michigan funeral director and poet, offered another explanation in his book, "The Undertaking: Life Studies From the Dismal Trade" (W. W. Norton & Company, 1997). Cremation, he wrote, "renders our dead somehow more portable, less 'stuck in their ways,' more like us -- you know, scattered."
The human body yields about 5 to 12 pounds of ashes, coarsechunks of brownish-gray bone fragments, which are sometimes used for a kind of reincarnation. Mark Gruenwald, the Marvel comic book editor who died of a heart attack in 1996 left orders that some of his ashes be mixed into ink used to print "Squadron Supreme" (Marvel Books, 1997), a book-length compilation of 12 original issues of the utopian comic series he had created a decade earlier.
Among those who do not want to sit out eternity in a fancy urn is Pat Schroeder, the former Democratic Representative from Colorado. "I always wanted to be cremated and made into a doorstop because, basically, what I want to do is hold doors open for people," she said last month in an interview on National Public Radio.
 
Wide-eyed Students
Gerald Larue, who teaches a course on death and dying at the University of Southern California, likes to confront his students with the reality of death with an assist from Herman Harvey, a departed U.S.C. psychology professor whose cremains he inherited. Professor Larue circulates a portion of his late friend's cremains ("about a quarter cup in a little jar") to his wide-eyed students. "He is still teaching," Professor Larue says.
With the funeral industry slow to acknowledge cremation's burgeoning popularity, independent entrepreneurs have seized the opportunity, offering a wide range of cremation accessories. On the World Wide Web, the "Online Urn Mall" has a company selling cremation jewelry -- gold and silver pendants with space to store a small amount of ashes. Another company offers "personality urns," 400 varieties of theme urns for loved ones with a particular interest, like golf, hunting, or religion.
But the most grandiose use of ashes belongs to Celestis. This month's shipment was its second.
The first, last April, included the remains of counterculture icon Timothy Leary, "Star Trek" creator Gene Roddenberry, and 22 other men. The second launch had the ashes of 24 men and 6 women, including a married couple, Anthony F. Santore and Catherine Telesco-Santore of Brooklyn, commingled in a vial inscribed "Together Forever."
Perhaps the most heartbreaking traveler is Danny van der Hoek, a 15-year-old Dutch "Star Trek" fan who committed suicide last Sept. His family solicited money through an Internet site to fulfill his wishes to end "in a final blaze of glory just like Gene Roddenberry did."
Celestis plans more launches, having recently signed up with a partner in Japan, where cremation rates approach 99 percent and "Star Trek"-mania is rampant.
Meanwhile, for a display of pyrotechnics closer to earth, Pacific Memorial of Los Angeles will incorporate cremains into a fireworks display.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
War in The Gulf? Peace in The Pits

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
War is . . . swell. That was the stock market's rather unseemly message when the United States bombed Iraq seven years ago. The Dow Jones industrial average shot up more than 100 points the day the bombardment began, and in the following month it soared 17 percent. Indeed, the current leg of the bull market began when Desert Storm did, in January 1991.
And a war dividend seems unlikely this time around. Back in 1990, investors were worried about the coming hostilities, and stocks slid sharply in autumn, ending the year down 12.5 percent from their July highs. Oil prices soared, as did fears of inflation. And many citizens, haunted by memories of Vietnam, ached at the thought of Americans coming home in body bags. 
 When Desert Storm finally swept Iraq, patriotic fervor swept the states, and the stock market quickly recovered all it had given up before the bombing began.
Such anxiety is absent this time. Investors continue pouring money into mutual funds and borrowing money to buy stocks. And stocks have continued to soar: the Dow, which closed at another record high on Wednesday, ended the week up almost 44 points.
This may be yet another sign of the irrational exuberance that has professional worrywarts wringing their hands. And there is a danger, if the market has truly discounted the effects of war, that any disappointing development will send stocks into a swoon. In the short term, securities markets move based on expectations about the future. If those expectations are met, investors shrug; if not, they can panic.
Investors may be behaving quite rationally indeed.
The price of oil is not a worry. Traders, faced with a glut of the stuff and falling demand from Asia, wouldn't mind if some barrels went up in sooty smoke. Oil futures are at their lowest since the spring of 1994.
The bombing may, of course, be averted. President Clinton, though looking increasingly boxed in, may be more willing to find a face-saving compromise after last week's failed pep rally in Ohio. The White House, after all, is not famous for taking unpopular stands, and it may be swayed by public criticism of its policies and cynicism about its motives.
If not, well, Saddam and his toxic bugs are plenty scary, but compared with his military might in 1990, "he's a nothingburger," says Charles A. Gabriel Jr., a political analyst for Prudential Securities.
As for the other "major" problems on the country's horizon, they, too, seem less serious than people feared just a few weeks ago. The stock market is probably far too optimistic about the fallout from troubled Asian economies, but the clouds come with a silver lining -- the Federal Reserve has stopped threatening to raise interest rates. And l'affaire Lewinsky is low-rent Watergate -- more spicy but less filling than the Nixonian original.
The economy, meanwhile, is just right -- and somehow keeps getting better. Jobs are plentiful, interest rates low, inflation only a memory. And more people than ever are sharing in the stock market's bounty.
Of course, eventually, something will go wrong. Corporate profits will plunge, the trade deficit will soar, Tokyo will topple or, most likely, something utterly unforeseen will stop the parade.
But no one knows when. So even in the shadow of war, American investors cannot be faulted for counting their mutual fund balances -- and their blessings.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Retirement Foresight From the Younger Set

BYLINE: By INGRID EISENSTADTER

 BODY:
JUSTIN BIER is about to make the third annual contribution to his I.R.A. He has kept the money in Treasuries so far, but now that he has a tidy sum accumulated, he is scouting out equity investments.
But unlike most owners of individual retirement accounts, Justin is not a grown-up. He is 16 years old -- today is his birthday -- and his I.R.A. contributions come from the money he earns doing filing and computer work for about two hours a day at the office of his father, Robert Bier, a podiatrist in Edison, N.J. 
 Dr. Bier's accountant suggested the I.R.A. when Justin started working for his father -- you need earned income to have an I.R.A. -- and the boy is now enthusiastic about it.
"I know I have a secure future," said Justin, who earned $5,900 last year from his office job and the tennis lessons he gives on weekends.
He should feel secure. Starting an I.R.A. as a child can mean a huge kitty at retirement. These early-bird accounts may become even more attractive given recent tax-law changes, like the creation of the Roth I.R.A. and the loosening of rules for using I.R.A.'s to pay for education.
The accumulations in these accounts can greatly exceed even those of the most assiduous of grown-up investors. Consider an enterprising 25-year-old who faithfully salts away $2,000 a year and earns an 8 percent annual return until he retires. At age 65, that person will have amassed $608,000. But if he started at age 10, he would have $1.98 million -- more than three times as much.
Indeed, a 10-year-old who makes just one $2,000 deposit at 8 percent will see the account grow to $138,000 by age 65. The compounding benefits of a 55-year investment horizon are so great, in fact, that putting small sums, even $50 or $100, into such an I.R.A. is worth it. (The law sets no rules on minimum deposits, although mutual funds or brokerages may.)
Because there is no age requirement for I.R.A.'s, many children who have earnings can play the game: a 4-year-old who earns money from a television commercial, a 12-year-old with baby-sitting or paper-route income, a teen-ager who flips burgers or a boy like Justin who works in a parent's business.
"Tax court has allowed parents to pay wages to children as young as 7," said Henry Fellman, author of "Keep Your Hard-Earned Money" (Simon & Schuster, 1998). The only requirements are that parents "pay a reasonable salary for work actually performed" and "treat employed children as any other employee, such as by using time cards," he said.
If an I.R.A. is set up for a child, a parent or other adult must serve as custodian, making investment decisions and otherwise controlling the account until the child comes of age.
No one knows the exact number of these minors' I.R.A.'s because the Internal Revenue Service does not track the age of owners. Nonetheless, such youngsters are clearly a rarity.
"Out of our 1.9 million I.R.A.'s, only about 10,000 are custodial I.R.A.'s," said Wendell Collins, a spokeswoman for Merrill Lynch. And those custodial accounts include not only those of minors but also those of elderly investors who need assistance in managing their affairs.
Setting up a child's I.R.A. is often not easy. Many institutions accept the accounts only if they are established under the Uniform Gifts to Minors Act or the Uniform Transfer to Minors Act.
"I called 8 or 10 mutual fund companies, but couldn't find one that would accept my son's I.R.A.," Dr. Bier said. Justin's account is now at a local bank.
There are institutions, like Vanguard, Charles Schwab and Quick & Reilly, that do accept minors' I.R.A.'s. "Inquiries about children's I.R.A.'s come with increasing frequency," Brian Mattes, a Vanguard spokesman, said.
But sometimes there are restrictions. "We open these accounts only for existing customers," said Charles Salmans, a spokesman for Quick & Reilly, adding that the firm also requires proof of the child's income and of the custodian's identity.
The Taxpayer Relief Act, which took effect on Jan. 1, may make minors' accounts more popular.
The Roth I.R.A. is one big reason. Money is deposited in these accounts on an after-tax basis, but the earnings are never taxed. In a traditional I.R.A., by contrast, contributions and earnings are both taxed upon withdrawal. Deciding which type a person should have depends on many factors, but the Roth version has a clear draw for children's I.R.A.'s: its forever-tax-free earnings can make the accounts' very long time horizons extremely lucrative.
Under certain conditions, the new tax law also permits penalty-free withdrawals from I.R.A.'s to pay for higher education. In this respect, as in some others, children's I.R.A.'s are treated no differently than their parents'. And given that the growth in education costs continues to outstrip inflation, such tax-advantaged accounts may become a major source of school financing.
Investors should be aware that the new rules on education withdrawals hide one potential disadvantage: They could lead to diminished financial aid.
True, the Federal Government does not include I.R.A. savings in calculating aid under its education programs, like Pell grants. Nor do most private schools factor in I.R.A. assets, according to Kathleen Payea, manager of need analysis requirements for the College Board, which provides schools with financial aid guidelines.
And some administrators say the new tax law is unlikely to prompt them to change this policy.
"It would be myopic for us to look at this as an opportunity, because in the long term we'd lose," said Don Saleh, dean of admissions and financial aid at Cornell University. If I.R.A.'s were factored into financial-aid rules, Mr. Saleh said, the school would suffer the loss of many middle-class students.
Nevertheless, some schools do at least ask the families of applicants for I.R.A. information, Ms. Payea said. And the College Board has already begun polling schools about how to handle the new education-withdrawal rules.
If schools do factor I.R.A.'s into their aid formulas, children's I.R.A.'s may be particularly hard-hit. Currently, schools expect students to contribute 35 percent of their assets to their yearly educational costs, while for parents the annual expected contribution is 5 percent of assets.
But even if school policies change, said David Charlow, an official at Columbia University, they would probably exempt I.R.A. accumulations below a certain sum.
And beyond the advantage conferred by their long time horizons, early-bird accounts can be a good teaching opportunity. That can be important when the child grows up and assumes control of the account.
Dr. Bier recently bought Justin two books on investing, and has arranged for the boy to spend a day looking around on Wall Street. Using the Internet, Justin has already started following stocks that interest him.
"I want my child to understand about working hard and saving," Dr. Bier said. "In my practice, I see lots of senior citizens, and many are having a hard time getting by."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Justin Bier, 16, is proud of his individual retirement account. "If I spent it, it would ruin my future," he says. He shares a seat and some smiles with his father, Robert, and mother, Anne, at their home in Edison, N.J. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "The Earlier Bird"
Financial planners push clients to start an I.R.A. early -- say, in their mid-20's -- in order to have a large sum at retirement. But it they start even earlier, the pot will be far bigger.

Starting at age 10: $1,980,000
Starting at age 25: $608,000

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Robert E. Torray;
Torray Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
THOUGH hardly given to spontaneous outbursts of merriment, Robert E. Torray, the portfolio manager of the Torray fund, could not help but crib a quote from Groucho Marx to close his latest shareholder letter: "Are you going to believe what I tell you, or are you going to believe your own eyes?"
Not a bad line, given that investors may have trouble believing some of the fund's sizzling returns. Over the 12 months ended Feb. 13, Torray returned 34.7 percent, compared with 28.5 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and 24.8 percent for the average fund in the large blend category -- a label for funds that hold big capitalization stocks but are not particularly growth- or value-oriented in their investing style, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund-tracking firm in Chicago. For the three-year period, the Torray fund returned 38.9 percent a year, on average, compared with 31.3 percent for the S.& P. and 26.8 percent for its peer group. 
 Investors who ask Mr. Torray how he generates such returns are likely to get treated to a long monologue from the manager, a tendency he readily acknowledges. "I get people on an airplane, and they are begging for a parachute," he said.
Part of the trick, Mr. Torray said, is the fund's concentrated portfolio: 20 stocks represent more than 70 percent of the fund's assets.
Mr. Torray, 60, who runs the fund out of Bethesda, Md., also thinks long term. After he finds a good company, he is willing to hold on to it -- virtually indefinitely. The fund's 1997 turnover was a skimpy 11.7 percent, compared with 84 percent for the average domestic diversified stock fund, according to Morningstar.
Two key considerations for Mr. Torray in evaluating a company are its management and its market position in its industry. These days, the fund holds mostly large-capitalization stocks because that is where Mr. Torray is finding the best values.
Most important, he says, is his philosophy that value derives from a company's underlying business, not from a stock's valuation characteristics. So he focuses on fundamentals..
For example, while many money managers use a company's price-to-earnings ratio as a benchmark for trading, Mr. Torray pays it scant attention.
"Some cable companies have no earnings, so their P/E is infinity," he said. "Other companies have recurring charges that reduce earnings and increase the P/E."
One of Mr. Torray's tactics is to buy shares others are dumping. "Usually, we buy into a falling stock price," he said. When he pounces, a company's stock price typically has fallen 25 percent to 50 percent over the preceding six months to one year.
Yet Mr. Torray is not put off by stocks that others call expensive. "We'll pay more for a first-rate business," he said, adding that top-notch companies "seldom sell for bargains."
Mr. Torray's "sell" discipline can be offbeat, too. While rivals will dump a stock at the first whiff of an earnings disappointment, Mr. Torray often sells only after a company fails to meet expectations over two to three years -- an eternity to many fund managers.
Furthermore, when a stock reaches his price target, Mr. Torray does not necessarily unload it. Because cash has flooded the fund -- it has swelled from $116 million in assets at the start of 1997 to almost $900 million now -- he merely stops buying shares and the company soon accounts for a smaller percentage of assets. He is not shy about comparing himself to the best, and, indeed, his investment style bears some resemblance to that of the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett.
"I do exactly the same thing as Buffett does," Mr. Torray said, buying and holding a limited number of key stocks.
 
Saying Yes to Student Loans
Mr. Torray began buying the SLM Holding Corporation, formerly the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, in February 1993, after share prices fell by more than a third from their peak in 1992.
"Shareholders got hysterical after President Clinton made student lending a cornerstone issue of his campaign and said the Government should lend directly to students and save the interest paid to Sallie Mae," Mr. Torray said. But, he says, Sallie Mae has managed to maintain its franchise.
Today, he is still adding to his position. "It's a solid company, well positioned going forward as the number of students increases and the cost of education increases, forcing more people to borrow," he said.
And shares are still reasonably priced, he said.
"The market hasn't fully embraced the company," Mr. Torray said. "Maybe student lending isn't exciting to people."
Its shares closed at $46.625 on Friday.
SLM has never had a big Wall Street following, he said, because it is not easy to categorize. As Mr. Torray sees it, SLM is a "simple business, easy to understand, and has a triple-A balance sheet."
He expects earnings growth of 13 percent to 15 percent a year over the next five years and said shares could trade as high as $60.
 
Loading Up on Morgan
Although Mr. Torray began buying J. P. Morgan only on Jan. 21, the company already accounts for more than 4 percent of the fund's holdings "and probably will get bigger," he said.
"It's probably one of the most unique franchises in the world financial business," he added.
Mr. Torray said Morgan was well capitalized and had made a "remarkable transformation from a blue-chip bank to a worldwide financial adviser, underwriter, trader and money manager that is perfectly positioned to deal with the world economy." He figures that the stock could run up 40 percent to 50 percent from current levels in the next five years. Recent rumors that Morgan might be acquired played no role in his decision to buy the stock, he said.
The company's expansion, however, has led to underperformance, which is why shares are priced conservatively, Mr. Torray said. The stock closed at $111.375 on Friday. He said the stock could hit $200 in five years.
Morgan's management has said its target is 15 percent to 20 percent return on equity compared with 14.2 percent now. "That's not unreasonable," said Mr. Torray, who figures shares could rise apace. "I could be comfortable holding shares indefinitely."
 
Sensing a Bargain in E.D.S.
Electronic Data Systems, the computer services company that was spun off by General Motors, has had some earnings disappointments. After the spinoff, shares traded at more than $64 a share, then fell into the $40's and have sunk several times into the mid-$30's. The stock closed at $44.313 on Friday.
Mr. Torray began buying shares in October 1996, five months after the spinoff.
So far, the company has "impressive top-line sales growth," and has signed new contracts, but that has not yet translated into higher earnings, Mr. Torray said.
He thinks E.D.S. can generate double-digit earnings growth. "At this price, we consider it attractive," Mr. Torray said.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Team Work;
All for One, One for All and Every Man for Himself

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
THESE days, it seems everyone is a team player, willingly or not.
Chairmen and their managers form executive teams. Factory-floor workers are lumped into quality teams. Students in grade school push desks together for "cooperative learning." Many colleges encourage, even require, students to work together. 
 And why not? Studies say that students learn better working in small groups, and they also build teamwork skills that will help them in their careers. Teams have made corporate America more nimble and innovative by tapping into ideas from all employees. Teamwork has helped Americans settle frontiers and win wars. Even Benjamin Franklin preached team ball: "We must all hang together, or assuredly we shall all hang separately," he declaimed.
 
Mixed Feelings
Time out, though. Not everyone is on the teamwork team. Often the concept is hardly more than a slogan. In other cases, the approach is misapplied. And many people simply have trouble overcoming the sense that individualism trumps teamwork for getting ahead.
Consider cooperative learning, a movement that gained popularity in the 1980's and has become a fixture in most schools. Educators are convinced of the advantages of putting classmates into small groups and assigning them a project -- students learn the material better, they say, and also learn to listen to, and respect, others' opinions. Done right, cooperative learning can turbocharge education and approach John Dewey's ideal of the school as "a genuine form of active community life, instead of a place apart in which to learn lessons."
But many parents worry that their child might be stuck carrying the load for the group, even though each student in the group is supposed to be held accountable for his or her contribution. Other parents object to the very idea of cooperative learning, in part because they see little evidence that it holds much useful value in a society that places such a premium on being the best.
Sure, it's important to be able to get along with people, their argument goes. But schools typically don't measure or evaluate teamwork. Colleges sort applicants largely by grades and test scores. When it's time to join the work force, people are hired and promoted as individuals. So many parents fear that if young Johnny helps his fellow students too much now, he might grow up to be the nice guy who finishes last.
"Cooperative learning is bunk," Marianne Moody Jennings, a professor of legal and ethical studies at Arizona State University and a columnist for The Arizona Republic, wrote a few years ago. "Learning takes work, and cooperative learning takes the work right out of learning."
In an interview, Ms. Jennings said she often heard complaints from university students about being required to study in groups. "They came for the sage on the stage, and not the guide on the side," she said. "It really does bring everybody down to a lower level."
 
Reflex Action
The business world has its own teamwork problems. Of course, there are many examples of effective teams: American car companies realized late in the game the wisdom of bringing together experts from design, engineering, production and marketing before they start to build cars.
But corporate America has a habit of taking a good idea too far. Many companies, for example, have draped themselves in the banner of teamwork without much thought. While researching a book about the skills students need to prosper in a changing economy, Richard J. Murnane, a professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, found one company that had a team of customer service representatives who worked by themselves on phones in cubicles.
"A great many more firms talk about teamwork than do it in any meaningful way," Professor Murnane said. "It's become in vogue."
In a recent article in The Harvard Business Review titled "The Myth of the Top Management Team," Jon R. Katzenbach, a consultant with McKinsey & Company, argued that groups of top managers that called themselves teams seldom actually worked together in pursuit of a particular goal.
 
Good Vibes
Instead, Mr. Katzenbach said in an interview, many companies simply put people together in a room and call them a team, leaving teamwork entirely to chance -- "real teams at random," he called them. Too often, he said, teamwork becomes a feel-good mechanism that can get in the way of actually accomplishing something. Sometimes decisions need to be made quickly, and deferring to the team in a kind of "I'm O.K., you're O.K." spirit may promote good will but little else.
"The notion of the team-based organization is dangerous because you will try to do everything as a team," he said. "It's a crazy idea."
Some executives, of course, know how to be both team players and bosses. In "Executive Teams" (Jossey-Bass; 1998), David A. Nadler, chairman of the Delta Consulting Group in New York, wrote of how the former chairman of Corning Inc. talked figuratively about wearing his "cowboy hat" when he wanted the give-and-take of a team meeting, and his "bowler" when it was time to be boss.
One can forgive many employees if they don't buy the teamwork pitch. Paul Osterman, a management professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, surveyed 500 companies in 1992 and 1997, and found that those that used work groups like teams to lift quality and productivity did not share whatever gains they realized with workers, unless those workers were unionized. He also found that those same companies tended to have more layoffs than traditional companies. It can be hard to square the fact that at the same time managers are ruthlessly pursuing bottom-line profits and their bonuses, they are also urging workers to consider themselves part of the company team.
And for all the talk of the need for team players, the star system remains alive and well in business. Many companies would like to suggest otherwise, noting that they have restructured compensation packages so that bonuses are tied as much to team goals as individual performance. But this is the age of the celebrity C.E.O. -- the lone ranger who can ride into any troubled company and turn things around, reaping outsized rewards compared with the "team" that helps him.
Business people love to use sports metaphors to talk about teamwork. But the analogy is breaking down there, too. The level of teamwork is faltering quickly in the National Basketball Association, for example, as the stars take over games and team payrolls.
The fact that workers feel less loyalty to their employers is well documented, and putting employees on teams is unlikely to change that. Fast Company magazine ran a cover article last month about the "Free Agent Nation" of some 25 million independent contractors, self-employed and temps in the United States. And Scott Adams, the creator of the Dilbert cartoon strip, has predicted in a rare moment of seriousness a future in which most professionals work for several companies and feel more secure because their livelihood is no longer in the hands of one dreaded boss.
 
'Rugged Individualism'
So should Americans be team players or free agents? Should they hang together, as Ben Franklin urged, or follow the "American system of rugged individualism" that Herbert Hoover hailed in a 1928 campaign speech?
In this country, the answer is, inevitably, both. "There is a central tension, of hardy individualism and the sense that we're all in it together," said James T. Kloppenberg, a professor of American history at Brandeis University. "And it can't be resolved."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: BY BILL WELLMAN

 BODY:

TRADE DEFICIT
Give Us Your Tired,
Your Poor, Your Exports
The nation's 1997 trade deficit reached its highest level in nine years, and a jump in December suggested that the deficit would surge again in 1998 because Asia's financial crisis makes Asian products cheaper in the United States. Imports of goods and services exceeded exports by $10.8 billion in December, a deficit increase of $2.1 billion from November. Economists had expected the December deficit to be about $9 billion. The monthly figures showed the first tentative signs of Asia's effect on trade patterns. The trade deficit with economically ravaged South Korea, for example, expanded by $300 million in December, to $343 million. 

CONSUMER DEBT
Just Say No, Occasionally
American consumers, often portrayed as fecklessly mired in high-cost debt, appear to be saying enough is enough. Their automobile, credit card and other installment debt, which excludes mortgages, rose just 4.7 percent last year, compared with 6.9 percent in 1996 and 14.2 percent in 1995. Because consumer spending has helped to fuel the economic boom, and much of that spending has been through borrowing, a drastic slowdown could be worrisome. The flip side of spending is savings, and the national savings rate fell to 3.8 percent last year, the lowest in 58 years.
 
THE ECONOMY
Pick Your Numbers
Reinforcing evidence of a robust economy and nearly nonexistent inflation, the Government reported that prices paid by manufacturers posted the biggest decline in nearly four years last month. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index, which measures the cost of raw materials and semifinished goods before they reach the consumer, fell seven-tenths of 1 percent. . . . A second report, by the Commerce Department, showed construction of homes and apartments fell slightly in January from December, but the annual rate of construction was still healthy at 1.53 million units. . . . Industrial production stalled unexpectedly in January as the output of utilities fell 4 percent, the Federal Reserve said. Manufacturing production rose, but at a slower pace than in previous months. The Fed said output at factories, mines and utilities was unchanged in January -- the first month without an increase since October 1996.
 
RIGHTS
Inequity on Maternity?
A United Nations survey of 152 countries has found that the United States is one of only six that does not have a national policy requiring paid maternity leave. Such disparate countries as the Sudan, Cameroon and Nepal, for example, mandate that a woman receive her salary while she is caring for her newborn. The majority of the countries surveyed provide benefits through social welfare systems, although some require the employer to pay and others combine both financing sources. Only the United States, Australia, New Zealand, Lesotho, Swaziland and Papua New Guinea do not require paid leave, according to the review of International Labor Organization member countries.
 
THEY'RE BA-A-A-ACK
German Re-engineering
Of all the failures under Communist rule in East Germany, none received as much ridicule as the smoke-belching little box of a car known as the Trabant. Even today, seven years after the last "Trabi" rolled off the assembly line, the jokes are still legion. Why didn't the Trabi move when the light turned green? Because its tire got stuck on a piece of gum. Why do deluxe Trabis have heated rear windows? To keep your hands warm as you push. How do you double a Trabi's value? Fill up the gas tank. But now the jokes have a new twist. The company that made the Trabant, now called Sachsenring Automobiltechnik A.G., has been reborn and is booming. Instead of cars, it makes car parts -- and not for old Trabis. Far from being an East German laughingstock, it has become a model for entrepreneurial pluck, a rare trait in the smug business world of of western Germany.
 
DOWNSIZING
Layoffs and More Layoffs
Promise Keepers, the Christian movement for men that is based in Denver, has given six weeks' notice to its entire staff of 345. . . . Springs Industries, a textile maker in Rock Hill, S.C., said it would dismiss 480 workers and close the plant, which once employed 5,000, by midyear. . . . Medtronic Inc., a maker of medical devices, said it would close eight plants -- in Austin, Tex.; Eden Prairie, Minn., and San Jose, Calif., as well as in the Netherlands, Japan and Sweden -- and cut about 600 jobs. . . . Renault plans to cut 1,500 jobs in France this year after giving pink slips to 2,800 last year.
 
VIETNAM
Dominoes, Anyone?
Vietnam became the latest Southeast Asian country to devalue its currency, as Asia's financial turmoil showed signs of pummeling even the most protected regional markets. The Vietnamese central bank allowed the country's currency, the dong, to slip to a new controlled rate of 11,800 to the dollar, a 5 percent devaluation. The move underscores the danger facing Vietnam, whose 74 million people make it the second-most populous Southeast Asian country, after Indonesia. Relatively late to open to the outside world, Communist-run Vietnam never fully benefited from the region's economic boom. But that has hardly isolated it from Asia's crash.
 
RETAILING
A More Limited Limited
The Limited Inc. said last week that it would shut down unprofitable stores in its women's apparel businesses, close all but one of its Henri Bendel specialty shops and spin off another subsidiary, Abercrombie & Fitch, to Limited shareholders. The plan is the biggest revamping since the Limited went public in 1969. Further, the company plans to close roughly 200 of its underperforming stores that carry the names Limited, Express, Lerner New York or Lane Bryant. This is in addition to the 200 stores the company began closing in December. The company will continue to open new Victoria's Secret and Bath and Body Works stores through a majority-owned subsidiary, Intimate Brands. All told, the store closings represent about 10 percent of the company's clothing businesses.
COMPUTERS
A Less Limited Dell
The Dell Computer Corporation reported quarterly earnings that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates, as the company's strategy of selling computers directly to consumers continued to fuel torrid growth. Revenue rose for a 16th consecutive quarter. By selling its machines direct to customers, with no middlemen, Dell can minimize inventory and maximize return on capital. The company also announced a 2-for-1 stock split and said it saw strong revenue gains in the United States, Latin America and Europe. Despite the economic crisis in Asia, Dell said it achieved profitable fourth-quarter results in the Asia-Pacific region, which includes Japan. Revenues in that region exceeded $240 million, a 79 percent increase from a year earlier, the company said.

HEADLINE: The Complaint Department;
Brooklyn Tenants, Too, Suffer in Court

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your article "Music Teacher Loses an Ansonia Battle" (Jan. 25), concerning Fausto Bozza's loss of a suit in Housing Court when the contract is on his side is more evidence, if not absolute proof, of how corrupt the housing court judiciary in New York City is. 
 In Brooklyn Housing Court, landlords and their lawyers routinely ignore even the required three-day notice. Most of the judges seem to be extremely biased, usually toward landlords. Landlords usually are represented by lawyers, while tenants routinely cannot afford representation.
What makes any city great is variety. If government and the courts keep pushing rent to the stratosphere, eventually there will be luxury housing and subsidized housing for the very poor. This will leave a city without a serious economic middle class and no one to do the low- and medium-income jobs, including shopkeepers and clerks. A rather desolate prospect.
 
RAYNER COLTON
Brooklyn Heights

HEADLINE: How Best to Oust Hussein?

BYLINE: By John Deutch; John Deutch, a professor of chemistry at M.I.T., was Director of Central Intelligence and Deputy Secretary of Defense in the first Clinton Administration.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Many people are calling for the United States to overthrow Saddam Hussein. But how would we actually do it?
The most obvious way would be to attack Iraq with a combination of air and ground forces. But almost no one wants to risk young American lives in Iraq, and everyone agrees that air strikes alone cannot do the job. 
 Instead, some suggest, the United States should mastermind a quiet assassination of the Iraqi leader.
For the moment, disregard that it is illegal under current law to sponsor assassination for political reasons. Also disregard past history -- for example, abortive American efforts to kill Fidel Castro in the 1960's.
But ask yourself two questions. Is it likely that we could carry out such an assassination successfully? (Perhaps, though it stretches credulity.) And could we do so quietly? (Impossible.)
There certainly are circumstances where assassination might be justified -- for example, an attempt on Hitler's life. But the conditions for reversing our policy against assassination should be pretty stringent: unanimous support from allies; a preponderance of world opinion, especially in the region, about the desirability of getting rid of the despot, and some confidence that the successor would be less evil than the target.
There would also need to be a judgment that American influence and interests in the Middle East would not be impaired for long if we were revealed to have been even partly responsible for the assassination. No, assassination is not a viable way to handle Mr. Hussein.
What about the idea of overthrowing the Iraqi Government through "covert action"? Covert action has long been an important instrument of the United States Government. It lies between open warfare and diplomacy -- the United States tries to influence political events in another country, but anonymously.
In my judgment, covert action has growing importance today, primarily in the war against drugs, terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. But could the much reviled Central Intelligence Agency organize an overthrow of Saddam Hussein with the hand of the United States concealed?
Of course, this is not the first time that some political leaders and the public have longed for a simple way to get rid of a troublesome foreign leader. Dwight Eisenhower took the covert-action approach with Sukarno in Indonesia in the late 1950's, and John Kennedy tried it with the Bay of Pigs. In 1954, Jacobo Arbenz was overthrown in Guatemala, and Col. Edward G. Lansdale, in a legendary C.I.A. operation, showed that covert action could successfully defend a legitimate regime from Communist insurgency in the Philippines.
But the record of covert action is, at best, mixed, as our experience in Iraq shows. Since 1991, the C.I.A. has supported several dissident groups -- the Kurds in the north, dissidents in London, and most recently an opposition in the Iraqi military. But, of course, Saddam Hussein is still there.
The problem is that policy makers frequently adopt covert action to avoid harder choices -- either direct military action or the difficult aboveboard diplomatic work necessary to replace a foreign leader.
Since the end of the Persian Gulf war, there has been a reluctance to undertake the policy of working publicly to replace Mr. Hussein. There is no obvious leader to back, Mr. Hussein is popular with the Arab public, and there is a risk of provoking terrorist acts against the United States.
In the presence of ambiguity like this -- remember Nicaragua? -- covert action becomes almost impossible. Consider the difficulty a C.I.A. case officer would face in talking to a prospective leader of a coup attempt against Mr. Hussein. This coup leader would be unlikely to resemble Thomas Jefferson. He or she would ask: Will the United States provide military assistance in the first few hours of an attempted takeover? Whom will the United States support after the fall of Mr. Hussein? Is there any evidence of regional support (neighbors are important) for a regime after Mr. Hussein? How much money will the United States commit if the coup is successful, and how much is available in advance (in small bills)? How will the Sunni, Shia and Kurds share power in post-Hussein Iraq?
Even if the case officer could answer those questions, that would be only the first hurdle. Once such a movement is begun, the C.I.A. would like to be able to control the insurgency, and the agency knows that is not possible. Because of their fervor, dissident groups are notoriously optimistic about what they can accomplish. They often want to blow up the radio station in town rather than the radio tower, or the railroad station rather than the railroad tracks. These actions can be bloody and are hard to control.
Covert action can be helpful if it is not considered a "hail Mary" pass at the end of a football game, but is instead part of the blocking and tackling of a concerted team effort.
If we are prepared to make a public commitment to overthrow Mr. Hussein, then we should announce our intention to form and financially support a new Iraqi dissident group. We should work with other governments in the region to describe the political and economic benefits that would come to Iraq and the Iraqi people with a new regime, one that does not seek weapons of mass destruction or threaten the security of the region. And we should authorize covert action that would be appropriate to support those public efforts.
Such an approach is more likely to catalyze change than an assassin's bullet. Covert action is not an alternative to air strikes -- those strikes, despite their limits in directly bringing about Mr. Hussein's fall, are necessary to tell the world that the United States continues to oppose Mr. Hussein's reckless conduct. But independent of any military action, we should also be working strenuously, both publicly and covertly, to nudge Iraq toward a stable life after Saddam Hussein.

HEADLINE: Education Aid To Localities Gets 2d Look From Trenton

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 21

 BODY:
Widespread grumbling about New Jersey's allocation of school aid for the 1998-99 academic year has prompted the state to start an immediate and broad search for mistakes in its grants to local districts.
A team of accountants and computer analysts from the State Treasury Department is spending the weekend poring over nearly 3.8 million state income tax returns for 1995 to insure that all districts receive the state money they are entitled to under an aid formula enacted in 1996. 
 The Whitman administration ordered the broad analysis after a study of about 1 million other tax returns earlier this week discovered errors in calculations for a handful of the state's 600 school districts, said Mary Lou Murphy, a spokeswoman for the Treasury Department.
"There's anomalies in about a dozen of the communities and we thought they had justified complaints," Ms. Murphy said. "Other towns will probably ask us to check our numbers, so we decided to do it all at once instead of piecemeal."
The complaints coincide with the state's using, for the first time, state income tax returns in calculating the amount of education aid for each school district. Under the 1996 aid formula, each district's state grant for educational programs depends on the taxable value of its property and the income levels of its residents. Previously, the state relied on income data from the 1990 United States Census to determine a district's personal-income figures.
Ms. Murphy said officials had no way of knowing how many districts received incorrect state aid figures for their new budgets until the analysis was complete. She said officials hoped to finish it by early next week.
Local school officials across the state have been complaining about the figures since the state's Education Commissioner, Leo F. Klagholz, released his $6 billion education budget on Feb. 11. The New Jersey School Boards Association says that 228 of the districts received cuts in their aid and an additional 177 received increases less than New Jersey's average rate of inflation of 1.7 percent. The local officials argue that the cutbacks or the minimal increases will force a sharp increase in school taxes or a cut in educational programs for students.
The few errors found thus far, and the weekend analysis, deal with a $2.5 billion package of aid for the Whitman administration's core-curriculum standards, a set of statewide instructional guidelines. Another $2.5 billion in state aid for transportation, special-education programs, bilingual education and computer programs is not affected, because each district's share of that money is determined by student enrollment in the programs, not a district's property values and income levels.
The few mistakes the Treasury Department uncovered in its earlier review of the one million tax returns involved discrepancies between a taxpayer's mailing address and residence. In some communities, particularly those that were once rural but have undergone major housing development in recent years, people receive their mail in post offices in adjacent, older towns. The problem in education aid calculations arises because some residents list on their state tax return the town where they receive their mail instead of the town where they live.
Consequently, the state's aid calculations have incorrectly inflated the income levels in some towns with many low- and moderate-income residents and, correspondingly, reduced their education aid grants, officials said. The focus of the weekend review is ferreting out such mistakes across the state and correcting them, said Ms. Murphy of the Treasury Department.
Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the state's school boards association, said Randolph, an older town in Morris County, lost $2 million in education aid. Its officials, he said, believe the state has overstated its income levels.

HEADLINE: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: ICE HOCKEY;
Enterprising Russian Team Hasn't Forgotten World-Beater Roots

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: NAGANO, Japan, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Look at that middle-aged man with the dark hair and the famous face, walking in and out of the Russian dressing room at the Olympic Games. Is that Vladislav Tretiak, one of the greatest goalies in world hockey history? Yes, it is. Now he is coaching the goalies for the Russian national team.
See the older man, sitting in a prime seat in the stands, looking dignified in a business suit? He is Viktor Tikhonov, the Vince Lombardi of hockey in the former Soviet Union. He was supposed to be out of favor after the U.S.S.R. ceased to exist. What in the name of Aleksandr Yakushev is Tikhonov doing here? 
 "He is an honored guest of the hockey federation," said Aleksei Kasatonov, the general manager of the Russian team.
And there is Kasatonov, everywhere, a big, burly man with a stern visage and dark hair slicked back on his head. He was a world-class defenseman for Central Army in the 1980's and he played in the National Hockey League in the early 1990's. He speaks English slowly and deliberately, with a thick accent, in a deep voice. If he were an actor, Hollywood would cast Kasatonov with a chest full of ribbons and medals, standing on a balcony, reviewing the troops and the tanks in Red Square on May Day. Now he has his team playing the Czech Republic for the gold medal in the Olympics.
With Russia making an uneven transition from a planned economy to free enterprise in the 1990's, the stories about its hockey culture have been discouraging. The great teams are disintegrating, according to visiting North American scouts and journalists. So torn by politics is the Russian hockey culture that many star players refused to play in these Olympics. Vladimir Malakhov stayed away, and so did Sergei Zubov and Nikolai Khabibulin. Slava Kozlov stayed home and so did Slava Fetisov, who used to be Kasatonov's defense partner but is not among his friends. Igor Larionov, Russia's version of Wayne Gretzky, refused to come, but later expressed regret and tried unsuccessfully to join the team.
And what did he and the others miss? An impressive charge to the championship game. The Russian team won all five of its games on the way to the final. The players who agreed to represent their country cannot stop talking about the team spirit inside the dressing room and around their living quarters.
They praise Pavel Bure, the Russian Rocket, who is the captain. He scored five goals in the semifinal game, a 7-4 victory Finland, and had a tournament-leading nine goals in all. They also speak highly of Sergei Fedorov, who joined the team at the last minute, even though he had no contract in the National Hockey League. Fedorov had 6 points on one goal and five assists in the five games leading up to the final. Aleksei Yashin also had 6 points, on three goals and three assists. On defense, Boris Mironov clobbered opposing forwards with hard, clean body checks and a few of the other kind, too. In goal, Mikhail Shtalenkov had a goals-against average of 1.82.
And what about those who stayed away and must watch their countrymen on television?
"Maybe they think, 'Maybe I should have gone to the Olympic Games,' " said Aleksei Zhamnov, one of the stars of the team. "Maybe some guys are upset."
The startling rise of Russia in this tournament has been one of the revelations of the Olympics. Coming in, Russia seemed to have the fourth- or fifth-best team in a Winter Games that allowed full participation of N.H.L. players. Canada and the United States would be challenged by Sweden for the gold and silver medals, everyone seemed to think.
After a fourth-place finish in the 1994 Olympics and a poor showing in the 1996 World Cup, Russian hockey dominance seemed to be swept into the dustbin of history. The nation had won 8 hockey gold medals in 10 Olympic Games from 1956 through 1992, but it would now go through a long, difficult rebuilding stage.
The experts ignored one element.
"We have excellent, world-level players," said Vladimir Yurzinov, coach of the Russian team.
The best of all has been Bure, whose career seemed to have plateaued with the Vancouver Canucks. Given a leadership role with his national squad, Bure accelerated his game to a new level.
"It's such a big honor to be named the captain of the team," said Bure, who added his recollections of those before him who wore the captain's "K" above the "C.C.C.P." on their red sweaters. "I've been watching hockey since I was 6 years old. I've seen those guys like Boris Mikhailov and Slava Fetisov. I've tried to learn something from them."
Zhamnov said Bure controls the atmosphere in the dressing room. "He talks to guys all the time," Zhamnov said. "He is a good captain for me and for everybody. In the final game, I hope he scores six goals."
Darius Kasparaitis, a Lithuanian defenseman who was trained in Russia and plays for the Russian team, said Bure was missed by Russia in the World Cup when he was injured. Kasparaitis said criticism of Russian hockey since then has been used by the players for motivation.
"We are here to prove we are still among the best hockey nations in the world," Kasparaitis said. "In the United States, we read all that stuff about how the Russian team is bad, not even in the first four. That made us mad."
One of the intriguing subplots has been the appearance of Fedorov, a restricted free agent who has played seven seasons with the Detroit Red Wings. When Aleksei Kovalev of the Rangers withdrew from the team because of knee surgery, Fedorov was quick to replace him. During this tournament, Fedorov has received an offer from the Carolina Hurricanes of $38 million for six years. Detroit has a week to match. The Red Wings' other options are to accept five first-round draft choices as compensation or to arrange a trade with Carolina.
Many of his teammates were curious about what frame of mind Fedorov would bring to the tournament. Some of his Russian teammates in Detroit had said in public that Fedorov had become self-centered even as he led Detroit in playoff scoring as the Red Wings won the Stanley Cup last June. The members of the national team say they have been pleasantly surprised.
Andrei Trefilov, the backup goalie, said: "He's fine. He's a leader on the team, him and Pavel." Kasatonov said Fedorov "has a high motivation because of the situation with his contract. He works unbelievable."
Fedorov expressed hope for a gold medal with a touch of patriotism.
"It helps a lot back home," he said of Russian hockey success in the Olympics. "Lots of people are looking forward to seeing us win."

HEADLINE: Greenwich Fights Beach Lawsuit With Army of Experts

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 21

 BODY:
For this wealthy community on Long Island Sound, few issues are as important as keeping nonresidents off its beaches. For years, town officials have rejected Federal and state money for park improvements, fearing it might obligate them to admit outsiders.
So it was no surprise that when a law student filed suit to open the beaches, Greenwich prepared for war. It hired some of the best legal talent in Connecticut, brought back the former town attorney who had defended the policy since the 1970's and engaged a battery of expert witnesses. 
 As testimony in the trial came to a close on Friday in State Superior Court in Stamford, the fight seemed quite lopsided.
On one side sat the five lawyers for the town and a neighborhood association. They were packed into two tables, the floor around them cluttered with cardboard boxes and file folders, their briefcases almost piled on top of each other. Against a wall were stacks of aerial photos and maps of the area.
On the other side of the room, Brenden P. Leydon, 29, sat alone, his briefcase on the floor, a few papers and books spread before him. Mr. Leydon had filed the suit when he was still a law student at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. Now a lawyer at a firm in Stamford, he said this was one of the first cases he had ever argued in court.
Still, Mr. Leydon said, the wall of defense lawyers did not intimidate him.
"O.J. didn't hire the dream team because he had a great case," Mr. Leydon said in an interview. "I knew my case, I knew what the law is. They needed all those lawyers."
Mr. Leydon, a Stamford resident, decided to challenge Greenwich's policy after he was turned away when he tried to go jogging at Greenwich Point Park, often called Tod's Point, a 147-acre site with a beach, walking trails and a view of Manhattan. The park is open only to Greenwich residents, who must buy an annual beach pass to get in, and their guests.
Greenwich residents and officials contend that if the park is opened to everyone, it will be overrun, neighboring streets will be clogged and the ecology of the area will be destroyed.
Critics say Greenwich, a town with some of the most expensive property in the nation and some of its wealthiest people, has no right to restrict access to a natural resource. The critics are also opposed to other towns' restrictions. Of Connecticut's 78 miles of beach, only 30 miles are public. In New Jersey, by contrast, all 127 miles of beach are open to the public.
Mr. Leydon maintains that "reasonable access" to the beach is guaranteed by the state's public trust doctrine, which says, among other things, that municipal parks should be open to all residents of the state. He also said that by denying access, Greenwich violates the First Amendment because it prevents people from gathering in a public place to exercise their right of free speech.
One of the town's lawyers, Ralph G. Elliot, dismissed that contention. "It doesn't have anything to do with free speech," he said in an interview. "They can say anything they want if they can get in."
Despite their formidable legal team, Greenwich residents have been worried about the suit since it was filed in 1995. Many have been steadfast in their determination to keep access to the park limited, and they firmly reject some critics' allegations that the policy is racist.
"No one here sits around thinking about the color of someone's skin," said Mary Staples-Webber, who lives just outside the entrance to the park. "The point is that Tod's was not meant to handle that many cars."
That was the core of the town's case last week. The defense called town officials, consultants and an economist as witnesses to show how the park and surrounding roads would be damaged by increased use. Jonathan S. Falk, a vice president with National Economic Research Associates, an economic consulting firm in White Plains, testified on Friday that an open park could attract about 1.4 million cars a year, up from 276,000 in 1996.
"The quality of the park would be so diminished that people would stop coming," he said.
Mr. Leydon's witnesses included a former town official, a vice president of the neighborhood association, a graduate student from the University of Rhode Island, a longtime Connecticut social advocate and a White Plains woman also active in social causes. Mr. Leydon asked her to come to court on Wednesday only after she had called him on Tuesday night to express support.
And then Mark Tedesco of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, whom Mr. Leydon had been counting on for months to provide key testimony, arrived in court on Thursday to inform the judge that agency policy forbade him to act as an expert witness in a civil case.
"I was absolutely shocked," said Mr. Leydon, who was told of the change the night before. "I had spoken to the guy for a year and a half. I wish I had been informed of the policy a little earlier in the case."
Ned Coll, the activist who testified for Mr. Leydon, said Mr. Leydon did the right thing when he filed the suit but acknowledged that he was up against strong opposition.
"That Leydon is a good guy, it seems to me," Mr. Coll said. "It was David taking on Goliath. Those other guys looked like undertakers."
While some lawyers involved in the case said privately that Mr. Leydon's inexperience often showed, they said he knew the law on the issues and they did not underestimate his arguments. As a law student, Mr. Leydon had worked on the winning side of a similar case over park access in New Jersey.
Still, Mr. Elliot said, he felt confident about the judge's ruling, which could be months away. "All the evidence that we wanted to get in is getting heard by the court," he said.
Mr. Leydon was not as successful.
On Thursday, he tried to submit a videotape of an episode of the television show, "TV Nation," that showed several nonresidents getting onto the Greenwich beach by swimming to shore. Mr. Leydon had rented a 27-inch television set and video cassette recorder to show the tape. When the judge noticed the late hour, he suggested that they watch the tape the next day. Mr. Leydon, who was taking time off from his job to fight the case, protested.
"Judge, I paid $170 to have this today and it's a daily rental," he said. "I'd rather not pay it again tomorrow."
The judge agreed to watch the tape that day. But then he rejected it as evidence.
