HEADLINE: U.S. Sees New Villain in Asia Crisis: Tokyo's Leadership

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
As finance ministers from the world's leading industrialized countries gathered here today, the United States and its European allies identified a new villain in the Asian financial crisis: not currency market speculators, not the crony capitalists of Indonesia and Korea, but the paralyzed Japanese Government.
With language not seen since the trade battles that marked the early years of the Clinton Administration, the President's top economic advisers have in recent days stopped just short of accusing Japan of gross economic negligence. By failing to stimulate its own economy and by hesitating to clean up its reeling banks, Japan, with the world's second-biggest economy, is undermining the international effort to restore stability to the rest of Asia, these advisers argue. 
 Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, has told Congress that Japan was engaging in "virtual policy" -- a derisive reference to its repeated promises to take strong measures to spur its economy and failure to take sufficient action. Charlene Barshefsky, the United States Trade Representative, declared recently that Japan's efforts to end the Asian crisis were "woefully inadequate." President Clinton has repeated the message several times in letters and phone calls to Japan's Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, who in the words of a senior Administration official, "agrees wholeheartedly and then sits on his hands."
At the opening session of the finance ministers' meeting today, the dispute with Japan broke into the open. A confidential study of the Japanese economy presented to the ministers by the International Monetary Fund concluded that Tokyo's financial initiatives have come far too late and amount to far too little. It urged immediate tax cuts and other strong action this year, and Gordon Brown, Britain's Finance Minister, said that "there was a good deal of support for that statement."
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who is normally cautious about public confrontations with Tokyo, said today that Japan needed to "very quickly get on track." He warned that as America's trade deficit increases this year because of a flood of newly inexpensive Asian imports, Japan faced the danger of "fomenting protectionist pressure" in Congress.
The criticisms met a strong rebuttal today from Japan's new Finance Minister, Hikaru Matsunaga. "I feel the economic measures Japan has taken so far have not been appropriately evaluated," he said, telling Japanese reporters that in a meeting with Mr. Rubin this morning he had not committed himself to any further actions.
There is nothing new in Japan's and the United States' meddling in the inner workings of each other's economic decision-making. A decade ago, Japan insisted that Congress eliminate the Federal budget deficit and even had a vague commitment written into an agreement between the countries, with little expectation that it would actually happen.
But the increasingly public nature of the attacks on Japan's economic management, as opposed to its trade policy, have stunned the Japanese. Some officials say they are unfairly being turned into a scapegoat for a regional crisis they did not start and are in no shape to end.
Nevertheless, in private, even senior Japanese officials concede that the basic charge leveled by the United States -- that political paralysis and indecision have prolonged Japan's troubles and thus Asia's -- carries seeds of truth.
"We made a series of bad economic mistakes, and now it is politically difficult to reverse them," an adviser to Prime Minister Hashimoto said recently, referring to Japan's decision in April to go ahead with a large sales tax increase that stalled the economy's nascent recovery. "Now the strategy is to muddle along, and hope that a giant collapse isn't in the offing that would wipe out everyone."
That is exactly the fear of the finance ministers who are here this weekend to devise a strategy to contain Asia's troubles. At the closed session today, the European nations were the first to criticize Japan and a critical review of Japan's actions dominated much of the session.
For the Japanese, the criticisms sting. After years at the fiscal pinnacle, Tokyo's bureaucrats are unaccustomed to being portrayed around the world as economic incompetents. In a half-hearted effort to defuse the mounting criticism, the governing Liberal Democratic Party on Friday announced new measures to spur the economy and to extend $2 billion in new loans to Indonesia and other hard-hit countries.
But in doing so, it gave its critics ammunition. The measures included none of the steps that President Clinton and his aides have called for -- tax cuts to encourage Japanese consumers to buy more, and a detailed, tough plan to close failing banks and restore confidence in Japan's financial system.
So far, Japan has promised to pump money into the failing banking system, which is buried under at least $600 billion of what the Japanese delicately call "problem" loans. Mr. Rubin has told his Japanese counterparts that simply pumping cash into dying banks, without closing weak institutions and tightening oversight of the banking system, would only prolong the problems.
To drive the point home, some of the former American regulators who shut banks throughout Texas and California during the savings and loan crisis in the 1980's have visited Tokyo in recent months, in case anyone wanted their advice. They were given a polite reception, one of them reported later, fed some good meals, and offered limousines to whisk them back to the airport.
"I got the impression they didn't want to hear about it," a former regulator said.
Washington's main goal these days is to get Japan to agree to buy a large share of exports from South Korea and Southeast Asia, products which are vastly cheaper now that Asian currencies have dropped in value by 50 percent to 80 percent. So far that is not happening; in fact, it is scarcely being discussed in Japan, where the domestic economy's troubles overshadow those of the rest of Asia.
"The American-led rescue of Mexico worked because the United States was growing fast enough to buy up whatever Mexico made," Robert D. Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, said this week. "In Asia, that should be Japan's role as the region's leader, and its richest economy. But the Japanese seem oblivious to it. And if Asia comes unglued again, that will likely be the reason why."
But American officials say they have little expectation that their complaints will yield many real results. Finance Minister Matsunaga was appointed to clean up the scandal-ridden ministry; he has little experience in global economic issues. Prime Minister Hashimoto is fending off scandals that have rocked his party and the country's banks, which makes public financing to bail them out politically unpopular. Moreover, Mr. Hashimoto has promised to end deficit spending, and his aides make it clear that Japan has little intention of spending the kind of money that would be required to spur the economy.
"The stagnation of the past two years was the fault of the Government," said Edward J. Lincoln, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who also was the special economic adviser to Walter F. Mondale when he was American Ambassador to Japan. "For a long time, the Japanese were in denial, saying things weren't as bad as everyone thought. Now it is clear that they are that bad, and they are making Asia's problems worse."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Japan's Finance Minister, Hikaru Matsunaga, with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin at the opening of a meeting yesterday of officials of the world's leading industrialized countries at Lancaster House in London. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Laughing With the Bourgeoisie;
A New Television Show for a New China, Shot in Manhattan, Skips the Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
New York City: A grimy city of danger and despair. America: A confusing land of ruthless capitalists and thwarted dreams.
For years, this was the America that people in China experienced on state-run television. In the early 1990's, for instance, a popular series called "A Native of Beijing in New York" recounted the travails of a married couple who came to New York with buoyant hopes but ended up divorced and disillusioned. In the final scene of the series, the protagonist, a beleaguered businessman named Wang Qiming, makes an obscene gesture at a group of New Yorkers -- and, metaphorically, at the entire city and country. 
 How quickly scripts can become dated.
In "New York Adventures," a romantic comedy series being taped in the city for Chinese television, the main characters, a young couple named Dashan and Jenny, do not toil at a sweatshop or a restaurant. They are managers at a Manhattan consulting firm. They do not live in a filthy hovel; they roam around a swank high-rise apartment with a kitchen that Martha Stewart would envy. And their boss is not a boorish Chinese patriarch; she is a sweet, intelligent Caucasian woman who speaks fluent Mandarin and develops a crush on Dashan -- without knowing that he is Jenny's husband.
On its surface, "New York Adventures" is high camp and melodrama, milking the most out of cultural misunderstandings and a would-be romantic triangle in which everyone but the American is in on the joke.
On another level, the show is about Chinese immigrants yearning for, and lassoing, the American dream of money, success and family -- a dream that only a few years ago would have been dismissed as foolhardy, even un-Chinese. But now, because the Chinese are making more money and traveling more widely thanks to recent economic reforms, the aspirations trumpeted in "New York Adventures" are considered within reach.
"People like to see something close to their lives, so they will probably be able to relate to the young couple in the story," said Junhao Hong, author of the forthcoming book "The Internationalization of Television in China" and an assistant professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo.
There are political undercurrents, as well. As it incorporates market-style economics into its own brand of socialism, the Communist Government has become more amenable to giving the masses what they want: more entertainment, less politics.
"It's no longer 'Beat up the liberal bourgeoisie' on television these days," said William Brent, president of China Entertainment Network, an entertainment consulting and production company in Shanghai. "It's: 'Have fun watching how the other half lives.' "
New York is one place, presumably, where the other half lives. But unlike the cruel maw of a city depicted in "A Native of Beijing in New York," New York is almost glorified in the new series, with backdrops that could double as a tourist's home video: Times Square, Wall Street, Central Park, Lincoln Center, the Plaza Hotel.
As with most series in Asia, "New York Adventures" is expected to run every weekday evening, at the same hour, for four straight weeks for a total of 20 episodes. The series, which should conclude its three-month shooting by month's end, is scheduled to be broadcast in Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and other cities in the spring, then find its way to Hong Kong, Taiwan, Southeast Asia and Chinese-language stations in the United States, said Richard Ting, the show's producer.
That the Chinese people would be receptive to a series taped in New York that praises the good life and co-stars a Mandarin-speaking Westerner is a far cry from 1958, when China introduced its first television station. Through the 1960's and 1970's, Chinese audiences saw programs that, as per the Government's directives, only ladled out political propaganda. There were programs on model workers. On the gospel of Mao Zedong. On the exiled Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia.
"When I was growing up, we always thought that the biggest movie star in China was Sihanouk," said Mr. Ting, who immigrated in the 1980's and is now president of the Eagle and Dragon Trading Company, a Manhattan garment company.
After 1979, television began to change as China lurched toward a market economy that leaders described euphemistically as "socialism with Chinese characteristics." The number of television stations exploded, from 52 in 1983 to 837 in 1996. People started buying their own TV sets, instead of crowding a neighbor's living room. In 1983, there were 36 million sets and by 1996 that number had grown to 286 million.
Moreover, the Government allowed commercials on television for the first time in 1979, Mr. Hong said. Now, television programs are typically financed in one of two ways: either by a flat fee from a television station and allowing the station to collect fees from commercials, or by giving a program to a station free and earning the proceeds from a 30-second or 1-minute commercial. "New York Adventures" will take the latter route, Mr. Ting said.
"Television is a mirror of social change, and people in China want to see more realistic programming now," Mr. Hong said.
Of course, certain stereotypes about Americans still endure. In "New York Adventures," every character drives an expensive car -- a Lexus here, a Celica there -- to get around town. The show's producers also wanted Rachel Meyer, the non-Chinese star, to dye her brown hair blond (which she did) and to mask her hazel eyes with blue contact lenses (which she did not).
Usually, though, the humor is very Chinese. In one episode, Jenny's father -- who speaks no English and whiles his time pining for a grandchild -- dispenses Chinese herbs to some friends. This is common in China. But in New York, he is arrested for practicing without a medical license.
Linguistic follies abound. "Tomorrow," for instance, is misconstrued as "chi mao rou," which means "to eat cat meat."
There is no shortage of the exaggerated physical comedy that tickles Asian audiences. In one scene Ms. Meyer's character, Nancy McCoy, visits Jenny and Dashan's apartment unannounced. So Jenny hides in the kitchen. Dashan -- by now a sweating and bumbling wreck -- concocts an excuse to prevent Nancy from entering the kitchen: there is a vicious dog inside. Jenny, of course, pretends to be that dog. She barks. She even bites Dashan's finger.
Mr. Ting based much of the story on his own experiences. To finance the project, he solicited $1 million from Zhejiang Furun, a textile conglomerate in his home province of Zhejiang. He traveled to China to secure the approval of the Ministry of Radio, Film and Television. He hired the cast, consisting mainly of recent Chinese immigrants.
But how he discovered Ms. Meyer -- who had never acted before -- is a tale of Hollywood-like serendipity.
On a crisp autumn day, Ms. Meyer was on a street corner in Flushing, distributing leaflets for a language school. She was speaking Mandarin -- a language that she had studied at Smith College and in Taiwan, where she had lived for three years. A crowd of Chinese onlookers stared. Finally, one of them said: "Hey, I know a producer, and he wants you to star in his show."
"At first, I was a little bit skeptical," said Ms. Meyer, 30. "Like, 'Yeah, right, you know a producer.' " But after she met Mr. Ting, read the Chinese-language script and realized that this was no joke, she took the plunge.
She described the show as a cross between "The Dick Van Dyke Show" (goofy, genial comedy) and "Melrose Place" (sudsy corporate intrigue). "I want to ride this wave, because it's a great opportunity."
For the indoor scenes, Mr. Ting rented a mansion in tony Alpine, N.J. Then he invited the crew of 20 people or so to live there in a communal arrangement to cut costs and nurture camaraderie.
On a recent day, the crew planted itself in front of the Plaza Hotel on Fifth Avenue. As usual, the characters were dressed nattily: Nancy in an indigo power suit, Dashan (played by Guo Fu Wang) in a charcoal double-breasted suit, Jenny (Xiao Hong Zhang) in a verdant faux-fur overcoat. Spectators circled the director, Zong Si Min, as he prepared to tape a crucial scene: Nancy's discovery that Jenny and Dashan are married.
Tense stuff. But in the scene, there was no vengeance exacted, no sour grapes. Instead, Nancy, gracious and understanding, offered Dashan an even better job in Asia. Smiling in disbelief, he whispered to his wife: "Ah, America!"
It was a wrap. But one group of spectators remained, mesmerized by the sight. They were tourists from China.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;
League's Top Rookies Count to Three, and Then Leave for Greener Pastures

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
It was an idea that seemed well-founded. Instead of paying enormous salaries to unproven players like Shawn Bradley and Glenn Robinson, install a rookie salary scale that would not reward the league's young players until they had three years under their belt.
But less than three years after the owners and the players agreed to the plan, it has gone bust in a number of ways. It has not helped teams keep franchise players or necessarily helped the league's out-of-whack economics. 
 Of the 13 lottery picks in 1995, only 3 have remained with the team that drafted them. And two of those three players -- Kevin Garnett in Minnesota and Bryant Reeves in Vancouver -- signed such extraordinary deals that their franchises must find creative ways to keep competitive rosters intact.
Last week, the No. 1 pick from that draft, Joe Smith, and the No. 7 pick, Damon Stoudamire, were dealt for the sole reason that the teams that drafted them felt they were not prepared to pay $100 million to keep them, or that no matter what amount of money they offered in the off season, the players would bolt.
"It's really a sad state of affairs," Golden State General Manager Garry St. Jean said recently. "You have a guy for three years and you barely have a chance to evaluate him and he's gone."
In the Warriors case, they simply did not feel Smith was worth the financial commitment.
The former players association executive directors Charles Grantham and Simon Guordine helped put together the current deal.
But the owners actually created the problem by giving up the right of first refusal during labor negotiations in the summer of 1995.
Instead of a team having the right to match another team's offer to their free agents, a player can now simply bolt.
"The flip side to the deal is that players can feel like they are sort of serving just an apprenticeship and the dynamics about how players feel about their teams change," said Russ Granik, the league's deputy commissioner. "I felt at the time that the owners gave up a lot by giving up a right of first refusal."
While some players have benefited greatly -- Garnett's $126 million deal is the sterling example -- the structure has created a league of disparate salaries, a National Basketball Association of haves and have-nots.
There is a good chance the collective bargaining agreement will be reopened in April by the owners, who have the unilateral right to do so.
There is an even better chance that the current rookie scale will be up for intense debate and, possibly, change.
"The way things are now, something has got to give," Kevin McHale, Minnesota's vice president of basketball operations, said recently.
"There's no stability and it's near impossible to keep a playoff team together in a small market. And often times, three years after you're done putting all the effort into teaching and nurturing, your player is gone to someone else."
 
The Balk Move
Eric Montross, Sam Cassell and Jim Jackson might have substantial arguments to make about not reporting to the next team they are traded to. Playing for four different teams apiece over the past year, they have been at the system's mercy.
If Montross (Boston, Dallas, Nets, Philadelphia), Cassell (Houston, Phoenix, Dallas and the Nets) and Jackson (Dallas, Nets, Philadelphia, Golden State) held out for a clothing stipend to accommodate each climate change, people would understand.
But what happened prior to Thursday's deadline -- Kenny Anderson refusing to report to Toronto and Rony Seikaly failing to show in Utah -- has the league worried and perhaps thinking about amendments to its current trade-and-report rules.
"If it becomes more and more prevalent, that's a definite concern," said Russ Granik, the N.B.A's deputy commissioner. "When our players don't report on trades, it's a little disturbing."
Section 10 of the uniform player contract states that if players fail to report in the 48-hour window after a trade, they can be suspended without pay. Orlando was apparently prepared to exercise that clause with Seikaly before the Jazz voided the deal.
Anderson's situation was even more troubling. Soon after he was traded for Damon Stoudamire, he steadfastly refused to play for Toronto. Rather than deal with the ramifications of a disgruntled player, the Raptors settled for the Celtics rookie Chauncey Billups instead.
Though the Raptors gained an improving forward in Gary Trent and another promising rookie in Alvin Williams from the Portland deal, Toronto General Manager Glen Grunwald essentially found himself taking Boston's unwanted baggage off his hands and giving up much more than the franchise could have had for Stoudamire, one of the most coveted players of the last two months.
Several well-documented tales of agents and players going into conniptions after they were informed of a potential trade led to the demise of several deals, including one in which Stoudamire was supposed to go to Orlando in a three-way deal that would have brought Anfernee Hardaway to the Nets.
"There were a lot of rumors out there, so we don't know what all was true," Granik said. "We'll take some time to digest what's happened before we make any recommendations."
 
Trade Talk
 Several of the key trades over the last 10 days invite additional comment:
*Rony Seikaly and Brian Evans to the Nets, and David Benoit, Kevin Edwards and Yinka Dare to the Magic. Comment: Nets add a bona-fide, if quirky, center to bolster playoff hopes, and rid themselves of two players who may not be in the league next year along with a small-time role player (Benoit).
*Jim Jackson and Clarence Weatherspoon to the Warriors, and Joe Smith and Brian Shaw to the 76ers. Comment: The Warriors freed more salary cap room by dealing for the free-agents-to-be Jackson and Weatherspoon, and they also got rid of two Latrell Sprewell loyalists. The 76ers didn't do too badly, either. They can find out if Smith is worth the commitment while dumping two players they were not going to invest in over the summer.
*Brent Barry to the Heat, and Isaac Austin, Charles Smith and a No. 1 draft pick to the Clippers. Comment: This is what the league's salary structure has come to: Pat Riley traded away Austin, a hard-as-nails player whom he helped mold into one of the league's top big men, for a pillowy-soft West Coast guy who can pass and shoot but does not do defense. The Clippers get a rebounding presence for at least three months, but not much more. With neither club wanting to lose solid role players for nothing, this was akin to two used-car salesmen trying to get rid of vehicles they knew were going to be repossessed by the bank. Welcome to the N.B.A., 1998.

HEADLINE: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL;
A Lot of Room to Grow

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: WORCESTER, Mass.

 BODY:
He drifts to sleep in a specially designed eight-foot bed, where his size 15 feet barely fit. To accommodate his 42-inch inseam, the material for his dress pants had to be purchased in France. Neal Fingleton is 7 feet 5 inches, weighs 270 pounds and is still growing. He is taller than all but two players in the National Basketball Association. He is only 17 years old.
The basketball players at Holy Name High School breezed through the six-and-a-half-foot doorway on the right side of the court here, dribbling and jabbering and doing what high school kids do before practice. The scene was routine, until Fingleton, the gigantic import from Durham, England, emerged. 
 A head of closely cropped light brown hair first appeared. Then the head lifted and the rest of Fingleton's 89-inch body followed; a sophomore in red shorts who is already being courted by colleges like Kentucky and North Carolina and being watched by the N.B.A. Initially, it is impossible not to gawk.
"It doesn't bother me to be this tall," Fingleton said. "I like to be different. "Like if everybody wears some kind of sportswear, I wouldn't wear it. Like this Tommy Hilfiger? Everyone wears it, so I never would. I like being different."
Besides, the XXXL Hilfiger long-sleeved shirt Fingleton tried on recently did not even stretch beyond his forearms.
Fingleton is a basketball Gulliver, as most opponents do not have a player within a foot of his size. Not surprisingly, there is already speculation about whether this still-developing giant will eventually bolt directly from high school to the N.B.A. He would get bounced around by a good Division I center right now, but he has two and a half years to get meaner, savvier and maybe even taller.
"I think Neal will play major college basketball," said J. P. Ricciardi, his coach.
"I think it's too early to say about the N.B.A. because he has so much room to get better. In the same sense, it wouldn't surprise me if a team said, 'We have the 28th pick in the draft, here's a 7-5 guy who's still getting better. Instead of taking Joe Blow from Wichita State, let's take a big kid we can work with.' "
The speculation confuses Fingleton, an innocent sort who averages 16 points, 12 rebounds and 8 blocked shots. Holy Name, which has an enrollment of only 200 boys, plays in the top division in Massachusetts and is rated as the third-best team in the central part of the state with a 15-5 record.
Fingleton knows he would have to make phenomenal progress to even dream of opposing David Robinson, one of his favorite players, by 2000.
"It would depend on how good I was," Fingleton said about turning pro. "I don't want to embarrass myself. I might want to go to college and get more experience. It would be an easier transition."
The transition to the United States has been smooth for Fingleton, who left behind his parents, an older brother, an older sister and a country that has sent only two players to the N.B.A., Steve Bucknall of the Lakers and John Amechi of the Cavaliers.
Fingleton became intrigued by the United States after Tony Hanson, a coach in England who was the second-highest career scorer at the University of Connecticut, helped send him to a summer camp at UConn. Steve Harrison, the father of one of Fingleton's teammates from England, persuaded his son, Neal, and Fingleton to leave home. Since both boys had attended the camp at UConn, they looked at schools in New England, and Holy Name stood out because it showed the most interest. But Neal Harrison changed his mind a week before the voyage was to begin. Neal Fingleton did not.
"Neal said that he wanted to go to America," Mike Fingleton, his father, said by telephone from England. "I've never gone against what my kids want to do. He loves basketball."
Fingleton talked about his move to a new country as casually as he ordered a meal of spare ribs and beef chow mein. This is a rare chance for him to improve his family's blue-collar life. His father, who is 6 feet, fixes conveyor belts for an electric company, and his mother, Christine, who is also 6 feet, is a nurse and a cook.
"I thought this would be better because in England the unemployment rate is very high," Fingleton said. "With my size, going for a job wouldn't work out."
Although Fingleton has played basketball for only three years, he is not clumsy. Fingleton, who is left-handed, was a talented soccer player until he grew from 6-3 to 7-1 between his 13th and 14th birthdays, so sprinting back and forth is not foreign to him. He runs. He does not lumber.
As would be expected, what Fingleton does best is dunk. If he gets the ball in the paint, he should score every time. But he makes Ricciardi cringe because he sometimes forgoes a shot from six feet to pass to a teammate.
Defensively, Fingleton rarely keeps his hands up throughout an entire possession. And he needs to be more adroit at positioning because his mere presence could force opponents to alter their shots.
"All the things he needs work on are correctable," Ricciardi noted. "He just hasn't played enough basketball."
Fingleton lives with a sports-crazed couple, who asked to remain anonymous, in an Italian section on the east side of Worcester. They attend his games, prepare his meals and participate in parent-teacher conferences.
When he first arrived in August, Fingleton got so many stares, he felt like a circus act. "You get some idiots," he said. "You get them everywhere."
Now the neighbors know Fingleton and offer him plates of lasagna. Soon, anyone with a fleeting knowledge of basketball will know about him. He plans to play every day until he graduates at 19, letting the college and pro teams drool over him. His basketball journey is just beginning.
"If he gets through the education, then maybe he can get accepted to the N.B.A., or whatever it is," said Mike Fingleton, Neal's father.
"There are thousands of kids in the States who want that, too. It's the best place for basketball. That's why he's over there."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: IN BAGHDAD;
CHIEF OF U.N. SEES GLIMMER OF HOPE IN BAGHDAD TALKS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Emerging from his first round of talks with Iraqi leaders in his last-ditch effort to find a solution to the standoff over United Nations weapons inspections, Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that he hoped to be able to return to New York next week with a written agreement.
"It's not easy," Mr. Annan said in an interview before a second round of talks between Iraqi and United Nations delegations this evening. "We still have a lot of work to do. But we had a good meeting." 
 He said that an appointment with President Saddam Hussein had not yet been arranged, but that he expected to see the Iraqi on Sunday.
Mr. Annan, interviewed at an opulent Government guest house on the banks of the Tigris River that President Hussein put at his disposal, seemed confident that he would get a substantive agreement that could avoid an attack on Iraq by the United States and its allies.
He said that any agreement would be taken back to the Security Council, but that the Council would not be able to rewrite it. He has said repeatedly in recent days that he has the Council's backing for this trip, and that this gives him enough flexibility to conclude an accord.
But United Nations officials said Mr. Annan was fully aware that he could run into strong criticism from the United States and Britain if he presents an agreement that seems to circumvent the authority of the United Nations or the Special Commission charged with eliminating Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.
 In Washington, President Clinton met for the second day in a row with his foreign policy aides to discuss diplomatic and military options, once Mr. Annan completes his trip. And the United States advised American citizens to leave Iraq as soon as possible. Page 10.
Mr. Annan said the Iraqis had been cooperative, especially with the team he sent here last week to map eight "presidential sites" as a basis for talks on how they could be inspected. Iraq has banned weapons inspectors from those sites. "We started well," he said. "That's why I say I'm rather optimistic."
Mr. Annan expects to remain in Baghdad until Monday for a day of talks on the program under which Iraq is allowed to sell oil to buy food, medicine and other essential items. On Friday the Security Council doubled the amount of oil Iraq can sell.
In his meetings today and in the official press, Mr. Annan was greeted with a barrage of complaints against the weapons commission.
An editorial in a Government-owned newspaper -- there is no free press in Iraq -- said Baghdad did not have a problem with inspections but only with the attitude of the Special Commission teams, which it said did not have an adequate regard for Iraqi sovereignty and dignity.
A number of United Nations officials based here who are not part of the inspection process say the inspectors, who are neither diplomats nor United Nations employees, have been abrasive in their dealings with Iraqis -- and sometimes in their relations with relief agency officials. The Iraqis are more broadly critical of the inspectors, accusing them of trying to intrude into Government areas where they have no right to be and of spying for the United States.
Officials of the weapons commission say the complaints have become more strident as the inspectors close in on suspect sites under the control of the President, his Special Republican Guard or other services.
Apart from his talks today with an Iraqi team led by Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz, the Secretary General also met with the Russian Ambassador to Iraq, Nikolai Kartouzov; a special envoy from Russia, Deputy Foreign Minister Viktor Posuvalyuk, and diplomats based in Iraq from more than a dozen countries.
He also met with Ambassador Yves Aubin of France. France and Russia have been most active in trying to help Iraq settle its problems with the Security Council. Both countries have substantial current or potential economic interests in Iraq.
Mr. Annan said he sensed that Iraq, which has opened the country to foreign news organizations in large numbers for the first time since the war in 1991, seemed to be eager to escape from its years of pariah status, which began with its invasion of Kuwait in August 1990.
"In a way, they have used this crisis to open up to the other Arab leaders," he said, adding that there were also contacts now between Iraq and even Iran. "Both Iraq and Iran are trying to break out of isolation," he said.
Iraq also needs the oil money that it has been denied since 1990. President Hussein has many large and expensive projects under construction in Iraq -- many of them opulent palaces -- and diplomats here are puzzled about how he can pay for them.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, left, met yesterday with Secretary General Kofi Annan, right, to discuss resuming arms inspections. (Reuters)(pg. 10)

HEADLINE: Julian Bond Elected to Lead A Reorganizing N.A.A.C.P.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Julian Bond, a long-time fighter for civil rights, was narrowly elected chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday evening. In the second round of balloting, Mr. Bond defeated Joe Madison, a Maryland radio host, by a vote of 29 to 24, with one abstention.
"I thought I could serve and offered myself," Mr. Bond told the organization's annual meeting at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan. "It's kind of crazy to say I earned it, but in this business you have to earn your credibility every day." 
 Mr. Bond, who served for 21 years in the Georgia legislature and now teaches history at American University in Washington and the University of Virginia, vowed to continue the campaign of his predecessor, Myrlie Evers-Williams, to rebuild an organization that three years ago was torn by scandal and financial chaos.
"We're on our way to financial health and integrity," he said. "The challenge is continuing that. It is a daunting challenge."
Mr. Bond said that there is "a very rigid division" between his role of chairman, a voluntary position, and that of the president and chief executive officer, Kweisi Mfume. He said that the chairman, who must be re-elected each year, "establishes policy in a fairly general way," while the president carries it out on a sustained basis.
The nation's oldest civil rights group is aware that it must keep up with an ever-changing American society and wants to be much more inclusive in discussions involving civil rights. "Colored people come in all colors and we want very much to reach out to all of these emerging minorities in America," Mr. Bond said.
At the organization's nadir three years ago, the two men in the organization's top posts were discredited. Benjamin L. Chavis Jr. was dismissed as executive director in 1994 for using the organization's money to pay an out-of-court settlement to forestall a sexual harassment suit. William L. Gibson Jr. was ousted as board chairman in the wake of charges of financial improprieties in 1995.
Ms. Evers-Williams, widow of Medgar Evers, the assassinated civil rights leader, led the climb back. "When I greeted you as chairman in 1995, the future of the then 85-year-old N.A.A.C.P. was almost nonexistent," she said in a speech. "The once pristine reputation was tarnished by scandal, burdened and weakened by disengaged leadership."
Since then, the organization has gone from a $5 million deficit to a surplus of more than $2 million. Mr. Mfume, a former Baltimore congressman, was named president and chief executive officer in 1996, a new and expanded title, and given greater responsibilities. The organization strived to become a more active voice in issues ranging from defending affirmative action to battling police brutality to expanding economic opportunities for minorities.
Mr. Mfume cited the efforts that have been made to increase management employment and contracting opportunities for minorities in the hotel industry last year. This year, he said, the same approach will be used on the telecommunications industry. "This is the next frontier of a larger civil rights movement," he said.
Ms. Evers-Williams said she decided not to seek re-election to set up the Medgar Evers Institute to fight for civil rights and write a book, among other things.
Mr. Bond's succeeds Ms. Evers-Williams after a lifetime of fighting for civil rights. As a student at Morehouse College in Atlanta, he was a founder of a student organization that helped win integration of theaters, lunch counters and parks. He was arrested for sitting in at the then-segregated cafeteria in Atlanta's City Hall.
In 1960, he helped found the Student Non-violent Coordinating Committee, and became the group's communications director.
In 1986, he lost a bitterly fought Georgia Congressional primary to John Lewis, himself a legendary civil rights leader.
Although the organization's leaders spoke of goals in fairly broad terms, some delegates voiced a desire to get back to more active programs and to restore positions cut during the climb back to financial health. The staff that makes and carries out policy was cut from 120 at the end of 1994 to 47, and has now climbed back to 65, said Leon W. Russell, one of the four losers to Mr. Bond. "We need to get programming back in line," he said.

HEADLINE: Lost Hopes of the Arabs

BYLINE: By Ira M. Lapidus; Ira M. Lapidus's most recent book is "A History of Islamic Societies."

 BODY:

THE DREAM PALACE OF THE ARABS
 A Generation's Odyssey.
 By Fouad Ajami.
 344 pp. New York:
 Pantheon Books. $26. 
 In this bold, imaginative and sure-to-be-controversial book, Fouad Ajami tells how Arab writers and intellectuals have neither accommodated to reality nor created the world they need. Ajami himself comes from a Shiite village in southern Lebanon, which he left for Beirut and a new life combining Arab nationalism and American pop culture. In 1963 he arrived in the United States, where he has become a noted scholar and a voice for secular, liberal and cosmopolitan values.
From this vantage point, he gives a vivid and often moving account of Arab thought today against the background of the lost era of progressive pan-Arab nationalism and high hopes. Since the defeat of the Arab states by Israel in 1967, that dream has collapsed into dictatorships, wars, communal hatreds, sectarian religious violence and a fixation upon the futile conflict with Israel. Hope has turned into disillusionment and despair. In "The Dream Palace of the Arabs" Ajami speaks openly of painful truths that many Arab intellectuals would rather keep within the family.
The first chapter of the book is a long elegy on the fate of Lebanon, memorialized through the lives of important, but defeated, intellectuals. Ajami does not go into the events of the civil war, but devotes much of the chapter to the suicide of Khalil Hawi, a renowned Lebanese poet, at the moment of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982. Hawi was born into a poor Eastern Orthodox village family. He moved to Beirut as a boy to do construction work, saved enough money to enter the American University of Beirut and eventually became a professor there, as well as a greatly esteemed Arab poet. Like many other upwardly mobile Lebanese youngsters, he was a follower of Anton Saadah's fascistic Greater Syria movement, and then of the pan-Arab movement led by Gamal Abdel Nasser. Hawi and other Arab intellectuals were fascinated with the great men -- Saadah, Nasser and, later, Saddam Hussein -- who promised the fulfillment of the Arab political dream though violence. They put collective political redemption before civic and liberal values.
Parochial young men like Hawi, Ajami says, needed larger identities to transcend their local origins. But there would be no Greater Syria, no Arabdom, not even a Lebanon to receive Hawi. Never married, never comfortable as a village man in his upper-class American University environment, he became embittered by a sense of guilt and inadequacy after the defeat of the movements he had supported. The Israeli invasion was the last measure of his personal and public shame. He had left home, it had turned out, for nowhere.
Shifting to the Arab states of the Fertile Crescent, Ajami reviews the events of the recent decades, combining political commentary with discussion of Arab thought. He emphasizes a much neglected motif of the 1970's and 80's -- the rise of Shiism in opposition to the Arab nationalist ideologies. For many Shiites, pan-Arabism was identified with inequality, the propertied classes and Sunni dominance. The revolution in Iran encouraged the Shiite underclasses throughout the Arab world to rise against their overlords. Ajami sees the Iran-Iraq war essentially as a struggle to counter the rise of Shiite influence in Iraq, Lebanon, the Persian Gulf and the Arabian peninsula. But Shiite messianism also failed to change regional politics. Family regimes in Arabia and military dictatorships in the Fertile Crescent remain in power. Opposition is fragmented, and the aspirations of ordinary people have been defeated by the oligarchs. The intellectuals have strong words but no vision of a better future.
Ajami looks at this lost opportunity through the eyes of the famous poet Adonis. Born Ali Ahmad Said to a Syrian Shiite family, he came to Beirut in 1956 and adopted the name Adonis to suggest the pagan cult of fertility and resurrection. Sympathetic to the lower-class Shiite movements and prepared to make gestures of reconciliation to Israel, Adonis earned the suspicions of pan-Arab and Palestinian intellectuals. In 1986 he left Beirut for Paris and died in exile.
Ajami's deepest disappointment is with Egypt, and his chapter on that country, replete with recent interviews with Egyptian intellectuals, is among the most interesting in the book. Egypt had the most sophisticated literary and cultural resources in the region, and was for decades the pathbreaker for Arabs everywhere. Now it seems to be embarked on what Ajami calls a "Sisyphean quest for modernity and national power." Constitutionalism, liberalism and dictatorship; capitalism, socialism and capitalism again; pan-Arabism and Islamist movements -- everything has been tried. Nothing has worked.
Egypt is now riven between a Western and an Islamic orientation. The Government is at war with the militant Islamists, the Gamaat Islamiyya, and in its defense of order it has centralized power, warding off both the demands of the middle classes for political participation and the emergence of a broadly based, popular regime. The violent Islamist groups, despite their assaults on the Government, on foreigners and on the Copts, have not been able to mobilize the Egyptian masses. However dangerous, they remain sectarian and marginalized.
At the same time, to retain its legitimacy the Government permits and promotes an Islamic cultural revival through the media and in the schools: Egyptian culture is being Islamized from within. Ajami celebrates the few voices who defend secularism, the rights of the Coptic population against Muslim extremists and the pluralistic, many-layered cultural identity of Egypt. Among them is Nasr Hamid Abu Zeid, a theologian dedicated to the rational and philosophic interpretation of religion. But he too has been forced into exile.
The struggle between the state and the Islamists in Egypt is vividly described, but in this case Ajami does not let the opposing point of view speak for itself. This is unfortunate. Even though some Islamist groups represent little more than brutal terrorism, there are also thoughtful and humane people trying to reconstruct their societies on a religious and traditional basis rather than a modern one. Their claims to represent a moral and communal alternative to the barren, materialistic individualism of the West are winning a substantial following, especially among students and the middle classes. Any serious reconstruction of Arab identity and of Middle Eastern states now has to take Islam into account, even if the failure of many religious leaders to condemn terrorism remains a barrier to serious dialogue.
The Palestinian case, which is the subject of the final chapter, carries much of the book's burden. While Yasir Arafat, Hosni Mubarak and King Hussein of Jordan, the politicians, have backed peace with Israel, the intellectuals, with some noteworthy exceptions, have opposed it. For example, in Egypt the confident, cosmopolitan intellects of the older generation -- Tawfic al-Hakim and Naguib Mahfouz among others -- saw that reconciliation with Israel was essential to free the Arabs for their own development. But the younger generation, powerless and resentful, fears a peace in which Israel may become a dominant economic and cultural power.
Among the Palestinians themselves, invented memory is the enemy of the real world. The story of dispossession from the land is, after all, the basis of Palestinian identity, and around that story a vast edifice of memory -- the charm of the houses, the villages and the olive groves of yesteryear, all now lost, all now unbearably inhabited by the enemy -- is being cultivated. Nothing in the real world can match this nostalgia for the return to home and the bitterness against enemies that it engenders. With sad detachment Ajami notes that Arab writers, with few exceptions, do not explore the possibilities of peace.
We should be wary, though, of looking upon all this as simply an Arab problem. In Israel too there is a rising tide of nationalist fervor, religious messianism and political intransigence. In many other nations and regions, racism, ethnic self-centeredness and religious sectarianism are leading to violence and preventing the formation of more inclusive societies. Everywhere in our interconnected world we are suffering from unreal hopes and parochial loyalties. Dream palaces are not just a danger for the Arabs. More and more, they seem to be a danger for all of us.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 22, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A review on page 8 of The Times Book Review today about "The Dream Palace of the Arabs," by Fouad Ajami, includes an erroneous reference to the death of an Arab poet, taken from the reviewer's advance proofs. The writer who died after the exile of Adonis (Ali Ahmad Said) to Paris was Saadallah Wannous; Adonis remains alive.

SECTION: Section 2;Page 1;Column 2;Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2343 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
A TV Generation Is Seeing Beyond Color

BYLINE: By NANCY HASS

 BODY:
IT'S NOT HARD to figure out why, come Mondays at 9 P.M., Anna-Lucille Calabrese can be found parked in front of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer." Like Buffy, the heroine of the hip hourlong drama on WB about a girl who reluctantly takes on the task of ridding her high school of an infestation of the undead, Anna-Lucille, 13, is bright, popular and tinged with teen-age irony.
Also like Buffy, whose milieu is the lush environs of Southern California, Anna-Lucille lives in a wealthy suburb -- in her case, Montclair, N.J. Her father, a publishing executive, drives a fast black Porsche sports coupe. 
 "She's smart and in control," says Anna-Lucille of Buffy, whose blond hair and Ivory Girl looks are part of the joke.
But Anna-Lucille is hardly the neat little demographic package that television executives wish for. In fact, during the hour before "Buffy," she does something that not only skews the precarious economics of the multibillion-dollar entertainment industry but also adds a wrinkle to the national debate on race: she flips the channel to watch "Martin" reruns and "In the House," shows with entirely black casts, on UPN.
Like a growing number of young white television viewers across the country, Anna-Lucille crosses the color line daily and barely notices. She and her peers seem not to care much about race, at least when it comes to the small screen. "They're funny, too," she says of the shows she watches. "They're crazy, but they're funny."
The crossover trend among young television viewers is remarkable because it directly contradicts the habits of older Americans. In fact, over all, there is astonishingly little overlap between the most-watched shows among blacks and those among whites.
"E.R." is No. 1 among whites but 18th with blacks. "Seinfeld," a close No. 2 with whites, is an astonishing 54th among black viewers. "Between Brothers" is the most popular show among blacks, but it ranks 107th among whites. In fact, not a single show is in both the top 10 for blacks and the top 10 for whites. Only 4 shows appear on both racial groups' top 20 lists; the one with the highest ratings is "Monday Night Football." Not one is a comedy.
"Blacks generally watch black shows, and whites generally watch white shows," says Dean Valentine, a former Disney executive who became president of UPN last November. "It's a reflection of how fragmented our society has become."
Children, however, increasingly seem to be bucking the trend. "Kids are much more color-blind than adults in their television viewing," says Douglas Alligood, who has for the last decade tracked such trends for BBDO, the advertising agency. "And they're becoming more so. They make decisions based on the context of the show, not simply the racial content."
Laura Herrold, a white 11-year-old from Ridgewood, N.J., who watches "Sister, Sister" and "The Smart Guy," as well as "Sabrina the Teen-Age Witch," agrees. "My friends and I don't even talk about whether the people on the shows are black or white," she says. "We watch those shows because they're about people our age."
It's easy to see this news as the harbinger of a new age of racial harmony, led by the youth of America. On one level, the trends mean that young people are more accepting of diversity than their parents. But while some questions that the crossover brings to mind are sanguine, others may not be.
When today's teen-agers grow into adults, will they continue this tolerance of diversity and pass it along to their children? Or will they, as their parents did, switch to "segregated" television. Are the series watched by white teen-agers the best possible reflections of black culture they can find? And will the young networks that present most of the black series continue to do so, once they've established themselves?
The racial chasm in television viewing is relatively new. That's because until the last several years there weren't enough shows with black casts to fragment the audience. "Growing up, television was a white medium entirely," says Samm-Art Williams, a black playwright who has written for series like "Martin" and "Good News." "We came of age watching 'Father Knows Best' and 'The Donna Reed Show.' Everyone did." But Fox, WB and UPN have changed that. With NBC, CBS and ABC programming shows with largely all-white casts aimed at a wide swath of middle America, the three upstart networks, each of which has its biggest affiliates in major urban areas, have in the last few years developed more than a dozen sitcoms with all-black core casts.
The result is a slew of new black media images, ranging from warm and fuzzy dads like Robert Townsend on "The Parent Hood" to the feisty 20-something roommates on "Living Single" (which was recently canceled after four and a half seasons).
But such shows have also polarized America's viewing habits, underscoring the depth of the nation's ambivalence about race and identity. Television dramas like "E.R.," "N.Y.P.D. Blue" and "Chicago Hope" have gracefully integrated their casts (if not, by and large, their audiences). But the races rarely mix on sitcoms. While a few black shows have white minor characters and some of the white shows trot out an occasional black person, prime-time comedy is one of the last bastions of public segregation.
The major networks insist that that's how people, especially older white people, like it. As white viewers get older, the number of them watching sitcoms about black people dwindles to a virtual handful, according to the ratings. Oddly enough, older black people start watching shows that are predominantly white.
"The figures are very stark," says Karen Kratz of A. C. Nielsen, the rating service.
The sole exception to this racial parting has been Bill Cosby, whose audience throughout the years has attracted both blacks and whites. "The Cosby Show," which ran from 1984 till 1992, on NBC was No. 1 in both black and white households. "He is an aberration," says Mr. Alligood. "Cosby," Mr. Cosby's current show on CBS, is 15th in black households and 27th in white households.
Even the immensely appealing Will Smith, who starred for five seasons on NBC's "Fresh Prince of Bel Air," was not truly a crossover success. His show, at its height in 1993, was No. 1 among black viewers but never rose above No. 36 with whites.
But if the viewing habits of the current crop of young people are any indication, America is slowly becoming less race-conscious. This season, the white teen-age viewership of several youth-oriented black-skewed shows rose significantly. "Sister, Sister" had a 42 percent increase in white viewers last year. "The Wayans Brothers" showed a 27 percent rise in its white audience. "Moesha" (starring the pop star Brandy as the girl next door), "Hanging With Mr. Cooper" and "The Smart Guy" saw smaller percentage gains in white viewership.
Although the numbers are still relatively small, industry insiders who have experienced firsthand Hollywood's uncomfortable and often clumsy relationship with race are encouraged.
"This is an extraordinary phenomenon," says Stan Latham, a black director who has worked on virtually every black sitcom from "Cosby" to "The Steve Harvey Show." "I know it sounds excessive, but I really think this could be the salvation of American culture."
Sociologists say there are several reasons that more white teen-agers are watching black sitcoms. To begin with, the shows are there; nearly half of the youth-oriented sitcoms are now made up of largely black casts. In addition, they say, young people of both races are less conscious of color overall and more accepting of diversity. (Indeed, some white teen-age shows -- "Sabrina the Teen-Age Witch," "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" and "Clueless" -- have attracted big followings among black teen-agers.)
Finally, elements of black street culture have become popular among young whites. For nearly a decade, hip-hop music has outsold rock among white teen-agers, and the clothing esthetic that accompanied it -- baggy pants, oversize polos with huge logos, expensive sneakers -- long ago infiltrated even small-town America.
Notably, it was white viewers who made "Yo! MTV Raps," now the channel's most popular show, a hit in the early 1990's. Before then, MTV had largely ignored rap videos.
"The inner cities weren't even wired for cable when the show took off," says J. Fred McDonald, a University of Northeastern Illinois sociologist and author of "One Nation Under Television: The Rise and Decline of Network TV." "It was white kids who showed the music executives that they would buy that sound."
These days, rappers are far from the only black entertainers on television. "There is an amazing number of diverse black images available on television these days, from Janet Jackson to Samuel Jackson to Coolio to the dramatizations of the Tuskegee experiment," says Todd Boyd, a professor of critical studies at the University of Southern California's school of cinema studies and author of "Am I Black Enough for You? Pop Culture From the Hood and Beyond." "That's the sort of environment that kids -- black and white -- grow up with now. It's no wonder white kids have no problem enjoying black sitcoms."
But the negative side to such a crossover is that it further institutionalizes mediocre programming.
"The problem is that most of these sitcoms with all-black casts are less than spectacular," says Mr. Boyd, echoing a comment often heard in program development circles in Hollywood. Even the network executives who present them agree that virtually none of these shows are in the league of sophisticated, and all-white, sitcoms like "Seinfeld," "Frasier" or "Friends." Most episodes of "The Wayans Brothers," on the WB, for example, are little more than 22-minute showdowns to prove which of the lead characters is the bigger muttonhead. "We know the overall quality of these shows is pretty bad, and we aren't happy with many of them," says Mr. Valentine of UPN.
There is widespread ambivalence about such shows among leaders of black organizations. In February 1997, the Hollywood and Beverly Hills chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. issued a statement condemning shows like "Martin" for promoting derogatory stereotypes. And yet just months before, the organization's national board had awarded the show's star, Martin Lawrence, its coveted Image Award. "Martin," canceled last spring after five seasons, was among the most popular series with young white viewers.
Mr. Boyd and others worry that white teen-agers who live in all-white neighborhoods may use the shows as their only reference point in their perceptions of blacks. "These shows could actually impair their understanding of the depth and breadth of black culture," he says.
BUT SOME writers, including Mr. Williams, take issue with those who believe it is a comedy writer's responsibility to "uplift the race."
"I think black folks need to stop taking themselves so seriously," says Mr. Williams. "It's my job as a sitcom writer to tell jokes, to have fun. If you're going to cure ills, go to the theater."
Ed. Weinberger, who wrote for "Cheers" and "Taxi" and more recently created "Sparks," a sitcom about a black law firm, for UPN, says his two sons, ages 10 and 13, love some of the black comedies because the humor is broader and faster moving. But not all pass muster.
"My kids like 'Jamie Foxx' and 'Martin,' " Mr. Weinberger says. "They don't like the quiet comedy of 'The Parent Hood' or 'The Gregory Hines Show.' The thing that sells them isn't race; it's the nature of the comedy. They like it fast and stupid."
Quiet, fast or in-between, the era of black sitcoms is ebbing. Despite the influx of new young white viewers, the tenuous economics of running a network are leading some executives to rethink the strategy of catering to urban audiences. "Our advertisers are totally conscious that we be very crossover," says Mr. Ancier. "The message is, if you don't make shows that appeal to white audiences, you fail."
That message was borne out last year. Fox, once a bastion of bawdy black comedy, has nearly completed its transformation to a whiter shade of pale. Added to its successes with "The Simpsons" and "The X-Files," its current home run is "Ally McBeal," a quirky hourlong drama about a white female lawyer in her 20's. The WB's ratings gains this year outstripped any of the six networks, but it wasn't the channel's black sitcoms that made the difference; the gains were made largely on the strength of "Buffy" and "Seventh Heaven," a pious drama about a white minister and his large family. And late in the season Mr. Ancier persuaded the creators of "Moesha" to transfer the main character to a nearly all-white private school. The move was intended to increase the number of white viewers who tune in.
One popular strategy is to concentrate on multi-ethnic shows, integrating the casts in order to hold onto the core black audience while attracting new white viewers. Winifred Hervey, a black sitcom writer who is a veteran of "The Golden Girls" and the creator of "The Steve Harvey Show," says she is frustrated by the new emphasis on the multiracial. "A good show doesn't come from someone saying, 'O.K., we want you to write a crossover drama.' The really worthwhile shows spring from a story you want to tell, not from demographics."
But Mr. Valentine says he is determined to satisfy both his advertisers and his audience by "breaking down the ghetto."
"People get really upset about segregation in society, so what I'm unclear about is why they think it's all right on TV," he explains. "We have to bring in a lot of people of all ages and races."
To Edwin Kaplan, a precocious 11-year-old from Montclair, that sounds just fine. "I like shows because they make me laugh," he says. "I don't care if they're about black people like 'Family Matters,' white people like 'Full House' or a family with black and white kids together. After all, the problems always get resolved in 30 minutes. What's the difference?"

SECTION: Section 3;Page 7;Column 1;Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Has Vanguard Windsor's Shine Begun to Fade?

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
TWO years after he took the helm of the mighty Vanguard Windsor fund, Charles Freeman has hit some choppy waters.
The fund, whose $21 billion in assets makes it the second-largest of Vanguard's non-index funds, lost 3.4 percent in the fourth quarter -- the first quarterly loss since Mr. Freeman took over as manager at the end of 1995. In 1998, the fund has gained about 4 percent, through Thursday, a better performance but still behind the average for its peer group. 
 Like so many other funds that lost money in the fourth quarter of last year, Windsor had trouble navigating the shoals of Asia, whose economic turbulence swamped the share prices of many American companies that do business there.
Hit particularly hard were the stocks of large, cyclical companies that the Windsor fund has long favored, including makers of basic materials like aluminum, paper and chemicals.
For now, investors in the fund, which has been closed to new investors since 1989, have little cause to fret. But they would be wise to watch carefully to see which direction Mr. Freeman aims to take the fund from here.
The investment style favored by Windsor was honed by John Neff, the famed manager who piloted Windsor for 34 years. Both Mr. Neff and Mr. Freeman work for the Wellington Management Company, a Boston-based asset manager hired by Vanguard to oversee some of its funds.
Wellington's managers like to buy big stakes in companies whose share prices have been beaten down but whose fundamental outlooks remain good, and then hold onto them for a very long time.
Mr. Freeman has largely stuck to that style, but in the most recent quarter he has slashed some of the fund's larger and more longstanding positions in stocks of cyclical companies. In fact, those positions were largely responsible for the downturn in performance last quarter, said Jeff Molitor, director of portfolio oversight at Vanguard. (Mr. Freeman declined to be interviewed last week.) Mr. Molitor said that about one-quarter of the fund's assets were invested in cyclical companies in October, when the Asian weakness hit.
"The portfolio really got hit the hardest near the end of October, and the cyclical stocks did not bounce back to the same extent that the market did," Mr. Molitor said. "The cyclical stocks were down 10 percent to 12 percent on average. In a market that is up 3 percent, that's a big gap in performance."
But not all of the fund's weakness came from Asia, said Daniel P. Wiener, editor of the Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors, a newsletter based in Potomac, Md. Shares of Seagate Technology, the maker of data storage systems, fell 44 percent in the fourth quarter after the company warned of slowing sales.
As the owner of 16.7 million shares of Seagate, the Windsor fund was one of the company's largest shareholders. The fund still owns most of those shares, but it sold its holdings of several other companies, many of them cyclicals, in the fourth quarter of last year.
For example, Mr. Freeman sold all of the fund's 12.6 million shares of USX-Marathon Group, the oil and natural gas company, and all of its 1.3 million class B shares of Continental Airlines.
He has not abandoned the cyclical stocks altogether. In place of the recently sold holdings, Mr. Freeman established large positions in Lafarge, a maker of cement and building materials, and EEX, an oil and gas producer.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 1, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the recent performance of the Vanguard Windsor fund referred incorrectly to the fund's holdings of cyclical stocks, reflecting filings by the Vanguard Group with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The fund still owns 12.7 million shares of USX-Marathon Group, about even with its holdings at the end of October, and 261,000 shares of Continental Airlines class B, down from 1.3 million shares at the end of October; it did not sell all of its shares of either stock in the fourth quarter. Charles Freeman, the fund's manager, said last week that the fund has maintained its weightings in cyclical stocks since the end of October at about 45 percent of its assets.

HEADLINE: Calling Infertility a Disease, Couples Battle With Insurers

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN

 BODY:
Roberta Kraft is $38,700 in debt. She owes money on her Visa card. She owes money on her American Express card. She owes money to her parents and to her best friend from college. She and her husband have not bought new clothes in two years and live in a cramped one-bedroom apartment because they have spent all their discretionary income -- and a good chunk of their future earnings -- in a single pursuit: trying to have a baby.
In her still unsuccessful quest, Ms. Kraft has economized in ways she never imagined. She bought fertility drugs from a pharmacy in Mexico because they were cheaper than those sold in her Upper East Side neighborhood. She withdrew money from a retirement account, paying steep penalties. She sold a pair of diamond earrings she had inherited from her grandmother, tearfully rationalizing that her grandmother would have given her blessing. 
 Ms. Kraft has gone to such lengths because her insurance company will finance few of the procedures she needs to become pregnant. And so, in addition to the emotional ordeal that they face, she and her husband are also struggling with a severe financial crisis.
This crisis is striking a growing number of couples as scientists develop new treatments to combat physical problems that prevent pregnancy -- treatments that few insurers are willing to cover and that few couples can easily afford.
To patients like Ms. Kraft -- who would speak only if her maiden name was used and her husband was not identified -- and the doctors who treat them, such refusals by insurance companies amount to discrimination. Infertility, they say, is a disease, like diabetes or emphysema, whose treatment should be covered by any basic insurance policy. When it is not, they argue, patients go without crucial medical care that could lead to pregnancy, or they pay enormous expenses on their own or get inappropriate care simply because it is treatment their insurance companies will pay for.
But others question whether the inability to become a biological parent is a medical condition or a social problem. And they ask whether society can, or should, pay for costly treatments that benefit a narrow group of people when growing numbers of others lack insurance for even basic health care.
"The debate comes down to this," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health-care economist at Princeton University, "Is having your own offspring with your own genes a matter of human right? And if you can't accomplish that on your own, do you have the right to have your efforts to achieve it financed?"
The issue came to the fore last month, when Aetna, one of the nation's biggest health insurers, announced that its U.S. Healthcare health plans would no longer offer coverage for advanced infertility treatments. Company officials said that because few other health plans offered such benefits in their basic packages, women with fertility problems had been disproportionately joining U.S. Healthcare plans, saddling the company with an unfair share of costs for infertility treatments.
 
Some States Require A Degree of Coverage
Thirteen states, including New York and Connecticut, require health plans to offer some coverage of infertility treatments. Two states, Massachusetts and Illinois, mandate that in vitro fertilizations be included.
But these regulations do not cover many workers because many businesses -- those that insure themselves under provisions of a 1978 Federal law -- are exempt from state jurisdiction. This applies to many more people than one might imagine, since many large companies self-insure and use a commercial carrier to administer the plan.
Several recent studies have found that it would cost less than $3 per member per year if coverage was mandated for advanced reproductive technology -- procedures that manipulate the union of sperm and egg.
In vitro fertilization, in which eggs are combined with sperm in a laboratory dish and the fertilized embryo is implanted in the woman's uterus, is the most common of these procedures. The procedure costs about $8,000 for each attempt, and most couples try several times before they succeed.
About 6.1 million women in the United States, or 10 percent of the women of reproductive age, are infertile, according to the most recent figures from the Federal Government's National Center for Health Statistics. Of these, about 600,000 have tried assisted reproductive technology in their attempt to bear children.
"I hate talking about money in relation to my kids," said Pamela Madsen, whose two sons were conceived through in vitro fertilization, "but by mother always jokes that she holds the mortgage on them."
 Ms. Madsen's experiences in what she calls the "ovarian Olympics" led her to become president of the New York chapter of Resolve, a support group for people with infertility problems.
 Lacking comprehensive insurance to finance many of these procedures, couples with fertility problems describe a web of efforts to pay for the medications and therapies they need to try to have a child.
The first step usually involves exhausting their savings. The next step is signing up for a host of credit cards and charging up to their credit limit. If they can, they usually then borrow from relatives or friends.
"We don't go to the movies, haven't taken a vacation in so long, and I can't remember the last time I bought new clothes," said Elizabeth Prike, a high school teacher from Woodside, Queens. Her 4-month-old son, Thomas, was born after she took fertility drugs and was artificially inseminated with sperm from her husband, Stephen, a production manager at a box-making plant.
Mrs. Prike's insurance company paid for her drugs, but did not cover any office visits, blood tests, sperm treatments or the insemination itself, leaving the couple more than $10,000 in debt to Brooklyn I.V.F., an infertility clinic. To help pay the collection agency handling their account, Mrs. Prike said, she went back to work sooner than she had hoped.
"I just felt cheated by my insurance company," said Mrs. Prike, who tried to get pregnant for seven years. "I paid into the plan and then my disease isn't covered. That's just not fair."
George J. Annas, chairman of the health law department at Boston University's School of Public Health, disagrees. "Not having these treatments covered is unfortunate, but it is not unfair," said Mr. Annas, arguing that assisted reproductive technology is an elective procedure, not a necessity.
"In fact, people don't have the right to any health care in this country except emergency care," he noted, adding that if the country had national health insurance, "then we should think about adding this as a benefit."
"Not that people shouldn't have access to these procedures," he added. "If you want them, though, you have to figure out how to pay for them. If an insurance company offers it, also fine. But to mandate it, given the growing numbers of uninsured people, makes no legal, economic or health care sense."
 
Medical Decisions Based on the Program
Doctors across the country say the way the system tends to work now, many women end up pursuing inappropriate, often expensive, treatments that are unlikely to solve their fertility problems because certain procedures are covered by insurance on the theory that they are designed to correct a physical problem rather than to address infertility -- a point that several insurance officials conceded privately was economically irrational.
The most common example cited is surgery to clear blockages in the fallopian tubes. Such surgery, which is highly invasive and requires anesthesia, usually costs about $12,000. Sometimes, it is enough to allow once-infertile women to conceive on their own. Often, women undergo the procedure several times, to no avail, each vain attempt covered by insurance.
Many reproductive specialists argue that given the option, they would often forgo the surgery and perform in vitro fertilization, which they believe in many circumstances has a greater chance of producing a pregnancy. But since most insurance plans don't cover such assisted technology, many patients who cannot afford to pay out of pocket undergo repeated tubal surgeries, hoping they will beat the odds.
"People make terrible medical decisions because of their insurance coverage," said Dr. Kenneth J. Ryan, professor emeritus of obstetrics, gynecology and reproductive biology at Harvard Medical School and chairman of the ethics committee of the American Society of Reproductive Medicine. "The system as it exists makes no sense."
 After two surgeries to clear blocked tubes failed to help Anette D'Orlando become pregnant, her doctor urged her to try in vitro fertilization. Mrs. D'Orlando and her husband, pat, were relieved when the nurse told them that their insurance company had verified that the procedure would be covered.
 Mrs. D'Orlando began a painful drug regimen to stimulate her ovaries to produce extra eggs. But a day before the doctor was set to harvest the eggs, the insurance company rejected the claim for payment. Franctic, the D'Orlandos paid for the procedure partly in cash and charged $5,000 on their Visa card.
 Mrs. D'Orlando is now pregnant and the couple is fighting with the insurer.
 "They paid for these operations that didn't work and not for the one that did," said Mr. D'Orlando, "and now I'm starting a family with a big debt handing over me."

Crossing the Border For Bargain Drugs
To save money, some people resort to measures that can be dangerous. Many women buy drugs from overseas pharmacies. Others, alerted through word of mouth or postings on the Internet, buy or get drugs from other women who have leftovers from their own prescriptions -- a prevalent practice that is illegal and, doctors warn, potentially dangerous since there is no guarantee that the medications are not expired or that they actually are what they purport to be.
Theresa Grant drove 50 miles from her home in Tucson, Ariz., to the Mexican town of Nogales, where she bought the drugs she needed for her treatments for one quarter to one sixth the price at her local pharmacy.
"I saved thousands of dollars," said Ms. Grant, who runs a family restaurant and is a co-founder of the International Council on Infertility Information Dissemination, an information and advocacy group for people with fertility problems.
But Ms. Grant said that she would not have taken the risk had her doctor not recommended the specific pharmacy that she went to.
From her home in Monsey, N.Y., Chedva, who spoke on the condition that her last name not be used, runs a kind of drug cooperative for needy, infertile women from the local Orthodox Jewish community.
"People call in saying, 'I have extra Pergonal that maybe someone else can use,' and other people call saying, 'Maybe you have some Pergonal because I can't afford my prescription,' " said Chedva, who spoke as she worked on an art project with her 5-year-old son, conceived after 13 years of infertility treatments. "We bring them together."
She acknowledged the illegality and dangers, but said women in this situation really have no choice, and she said she is very cautious about the donated drugs she accepts.
For her own drugs, she said, she sent her prescription to relatives in Israel, who filled it for a third of the cost locally. To defray other treatment costs not covered by insurance, she took an interest-free loan from a local charitable organization, one of many set up by Jewish communities around the country to help childless Jewish couples pay for infertility procedures.
"We are drowning in more and more debt, every month more," said Chedva, who estimated that she and her husband, a Talmudic scholar, owe about $40,000 to friends, relatives and the community fund. She said they are trying to put together enough money to try to conceive another child.
Dr. Richard Grazzi, a fertility specialist who runs Brooklyn I.V.F., said it was painful to him, as a practitioner, to see how often money issues intrude between him and what he thinks is the best treatment for his patients.
At first, he was lax in making sure that uninsured patients had the means to pay the clinic for treatment. But mounting debt forced them to be stricter with payments.
To help patients who cannot afford care, his office has worked with a local branch of Citibank to arrange for "infertility loans." The program was started by a bank officer who was a patient in the clinic.
"Nobody who hasn't experienced infertility can understand what these couples go through," Dr. Grazzi said. "It's a medical crisis, a personal crisis, a sexual crisis, religious, existential and marital crisis," he said. "When you throw financial stress on top of that, it's just a setup for disaster."
