HEADLINE: In the Shadow of Silicon Valley, 'Digital Coast' Emerges

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
No true booster of Silicon Valley or its New York wannabe, Silicon Alley, would dispute the benefits of a catchy moniker for raising a region's high-technology profile and attracting coveted talent and venture capital.
But Los Angeles Mayor Richard J. Riordan's announcement last week that this city would henceforth be known as "Digital Coast" elicited little more than snickers and derision from its geographic rivals. 
 "Already people are talking about 'Digital Toast,' " sniffed Mark Stahlman, a co-founder of the New York New Media Association and the man who coined the derivative Silicon Alley label to describe the cluster of Internet companies in lower Manhattan.
A spokesman for Joint Venture Silicon Valley, an economic development group in San Jose, Calif., was more magnanimous, noting, "At least they stayed away from 'silicon,' since there is only one Silicon Valley, and everyone has already tried to do a takeoff."
It was precisely such dismissals of Los Angeles as a cyberlightweight that compelled a group of entrepreneurs to throw themselves a naming ceremony last week. The considerable talent pools of aerospace and entertainment industry workers here have spawned many new-media companies in recent years, but free association probably still conjures O. J. Simpson and star maps in the minds of most people more quickly than it evokes, say, cutting-edge Web site design.
So, with the Mayor's support, members of the high-technology industry here formed a committee to put itself on the map, as it were. The Digital Coast designation was selected from a list of hundreds of suggestions over the last several months. A first choice, "Tech Coast," was abandoned because of a trademark dispute.
"I'm glad we didn't go with 'Silicon Sandbox,' " confided Nick Rothenberg, chief executive of US Web/ W3-designs, "because I'm not sure business people could have carried it around and used it in quite the same way."
Kevin Wall, chief executive of a software company, Box Top Interactive, and chairman of the naming committee, said: "We're living in the shadow of Hollywood. We want to be recognized, and for that we need a collective identity."
Or as another executive attending the festivities put it, "We're not going to let ourselves be defined by the outside anymore."
Indeed, this being a town proficient in image making, Digital Coast is not meant to be merely a name but a "brand," complete with a marketing plan for "signage and banners," according to the Mayor's news release.
If this self-baptism seems a bit forced, it is far from the first time a locale has draped itself in techno-chic associations. One Web site (http://www.tbtf.com/siliconia.html) lists 45 instances of "siliconia" associated with 55 locations, including North Carolina's Silicon Triangle, the Silicon Fen in Cambridge, England, and even the Silicon Swamp of Perry, Fla., on the Gulf of Mexico.
But the big rivals remain New York, Southern California and Silicon Valley. And while much of the rivalry appears to be tongue in cheek, thousands of jobs are at stake in any economic engine created by companies converging and multiplying to create a new industry.
So far, the original Valley has far outstripped its rivals. But Los Angeles reasons that as bandwidth expands and on-line entertainment becomes more feasible, it will come into its own -- though only time will tell whether its bid to become "the new-media capital of the world" is simply California dreaming.
"Multimedia is our ticket for success into the next century," Mayor Riordan said at the ceremony last Wednesday as slides of the Southern California coast at sunset, night and midday flashed on a screen behind him. "The future is in our hands, and we're going to win."

HEADLINE: U.S. Treasury to Hold Its Regular Auction of Bills During the Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. It also includes two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday and a 52-week bill being auctioned on Thursday.
At the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.06 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.08 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 5.02 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.38 percent, and the five-year note at 5.47 percent.

HEADLINE: Who's Lining Up At Box Office? Lots and Lots Of Girls;
Studios Aim at Teen-Agers, A Vast, Growing Audience

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Girl Power has seized the entertainment business.
The teen-age girl audience is emerging as the most powerful demographic factor driving the success of movies like "Titanic," the James Cameron epic heading toward a worldwide box office record, as well as television shows like "Party of Five," "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," "Ally McBeal" and "Dawson's Creek" and recording stars like LeAnn Rimes, the Spice Girls, Fiona Apple, Jewel and the Backstreet Boys. 
 This vast audience of girls is not only growing but also getting younger. "In the music business, teen-age girls have always been one of the central heartbeats, from the bobby-soxers who loved Sinatra to the girls who screamed for Elvis and the Beatles to the current phenomenon of Spice Girls and Hanson," said Danny Goldberg, chief executive officer of Mercury Records, which has earned millions of dollars from Hanson and others.
"But now the teen-age years seem to start at 8 or 9, in terms of entertainment tastes," he said. "The emotions are kicking in earlier. It's a huge audience."
Jamie Kellner, chief executive officer at the WB television network and former president of the Fox Broadcasting Company, said WB had largely been created to appeal to teen-agers and young adults.
"From Day One, our network has been rather female-skewing," Mr. Kellner said. WB's highly rated new drama series, "Dawson's Creek," which leans heavily on teen-age relationships and sexual issues, is written by Kevin Williamson, who wrote the movies "Scream," "Scream 2" and the film adaptation of "I Know What You Did Last Summer," all wildly popular with teen-agers, especially girls.
"What the female teens want is empowered female teen characters, which is something that has been missed for a long time on television," said Mr. Kellner, who is now casting a series pilot, called "Felicity," about a college student.
What is evident about the startling box office for "Titanic," which has already grossed more than $402 million in the United States, is that a hefty portion of the repeat business is coming from teen-age girls and younger women, who are seeing the film four or five times. Unlike teen-age boys, who attend movies with a friend or two, girls prefer going to theaters in packs.
Even before the release of "Titanic," Paramount, the film's distributor in the United States, had tested audience reactions and was fully aware that teen-age girls were the commanding demographic factor for the movie. (The film is distributed abroad by 20th Century Fox.)
"In our original concept testing -- when we read the concept of the movie over the phone and who was in it -- we mentioned Leonardo DiCaprio, and there was a lot of interest in him among girls," said Robert G. Friedman, vice chairman of the Paramount Motion Picture Group. "When we tested the first trailers, the young girls were the highest quadrant in their interest in seeing the film. And when we screened, the girls were one of the highest-testing groups who enjoyed the movie."
Accordingly, the studio marketed the film as a story of young lovers, with a heavy emphasis on Leonardo DiCaprio, whose 1996 film, "William Shakespeare's 'Romeo and Juliet,' " also drew throngs of girls. (Mr. DiCaprio, like Brad Pitt, is, according to Variety, also a megastar in Japan, the world's second biggest overseas market for Hollywood films, after Britain, largely because of Japan's huge audience of moviegoing teen-age girls.)
 
Saying Attention Must Be Paid
Robert Levin, president of worldwide marketing at Sony Pictures Entertainment. "A while ago everyone was really focusing on the young male audience: young male action movies, young male comedies. Now we're saying, 'Wow, there's really a young female audience out there that we must be attentive to.' "
Buffy Shutt, president of marketing at Universal Pictures, said: "By sheer bulk, the young girls are driving cultural tastes now. They're amazing consumers. And it's happening now because of demographics and more women being involved in the programming and movie-making process."
Laura Ziskin, president of Fox 2000, a division of 20th Century Fox, who is making "Never Been Kissed," a teen-age comedy with Drew Barrymore, said, "I still don't know how to make a movie for a 17-year-old boy, and I'm not doing that. But at least I have a chance of making a good movie for a teen-age girl."
(Ms. Barrymore, who is especially popular among girls, stars with Adam Sandler in "The Wedding Singer," a comedy that opened over the Presidents' Day weekend and has grossed nearly $39 million. It is in the No. 2 spot after "Titanic.")
Ms. Ziskin said, "Young women have rarely been able to see their experiences dramatized on the screen, and we're finally starting to see it now, which is a new thing historically."
Population data project that the nation's teen-age population will soar to more than 42 million by 2010 from 38.2 million last year. That is not quite as large as the postwar baby boom at its peak, but it is still a powerful cultural and economic force with vast spending power amounting to as much as $80 billion, perhaps more. It was the baby boomers, after all, who made huge hits of films like "Saturday Night Fever"(1977), "Flashdance" (1983) and "Top Gun" (1986). A study by the Motion Picture Association of America, the industry's lobbyists, showed that 48 percent of 12- to 17-year-olds say they go to a movie at least once a month, compared with 26 percent of people 18 and over.
A recent random sampling of some teen-age girls in Manhattan, waiting in line to see "Titanic" at the Olympia Twin theater, at Broadway and 107th Street, showed that the lure of the film was fairly predictable: it was a tragic love story, against the backdrop of an epochal event, that starred the baby-faced Mr. DiCaprio, whose sensitive good looks made the girls swoon.
"He's beautiful, but I love the whole movie too; it's so sad," said Eliana Cabrera, 13, who had already seen the movie three times and had shown up with about a dozen girls from Intermediate School 218 in the Inwood section of Manhattan to see it again.
Across the country, at Mann's Chinese Theater in Hollywood, Kelly Jones, a college student who was waiting in line a second time to see "Titanic," said of the film: "It has a good story, and the women in it aren't bimbos like in a lot of films where there's too much violence, too many car chases and too many stupid jokes."
"Titanic" is hardly the only film to awaken Hollywood to the teen-age girl audience. The box office for another current hit, "Good Will Hunting," is being driven heavily by girls because of the presence of two young actors, Matt Damon and Ben Affleck.
 
Taking a Clue From 'Clueless'
Of course, there has always been television and movie fare with special appeal to girls, but what may have set off the current trend was Amy Heckerling's "Clueless" (1995), a sharp comedy about some spoiled Beverly Hills girls that was based loosely on Jane Austen's "Emma." An unexpected hit, the film took in $57 million at the box office and was later turned into a television series. One year later, teen-age girls surged into theaters to see Baz Luhrmann's MTV-inspired "William Shakespeare's 'Romeo and Juliet,' " with two teen-age icons, Mr. DiCaprio and Claire Danes.
More recently, "Scream," a sly horror film last year that was scary yet spoofed the genre, emerged as a huge hit, grossing $103 million. A major reason for the film's success: among its stars were television regulars like Neve Campbell of "Party of Five," Courteney Cox of "Friends" and Sarah Michelle Gellar of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," all of them teen-age favorites.
"For the first time in the horror genre, young women drove the business on 'Scream' and then 'Scream 2,"' said Mark Gill, head of the Los Angeles office of Miramax, which released the two films. "Most of the lead characters are young, hip attractive women, and the audience identifies with them."
What seems to drive the horror genre, though, is sex. "These movies tap into those raging hormones that you don't know what to do with," said Mr. Williamson, the screenwriter. "You sit in the theater and have a therapeutic experience. These characters are smart as can be; they're savvy; they're self-aware. You haven't seen that before in too many horror films."
And virtually every studio is now making, or planning, a handful of films aimed at teen-age girls. "It's a re-emerging audience, and everyone is taking a closer look at it," said Joe Roth, chairman of Walt Disney Studios, which has put at least two such movies into production.
This crowd, he said, is lucrative. "They're easier to market to, compared to the older audience, because their tastes are very specific," Mr. Roth said. "They come to a movie over and over again if they like it. They don't work; they don't have families to raise. They're available consumers with money."
Several studio executives said the potential power of this audience has quietly resulted in a generational shift among stars: that is, Harrison Ford and Mel Gibson and a handful of other top stars are slowly being superseded by young actors like Mr. DiCaprio, Ms. Danes, Will Smith, Matt Damon and Kate Winslet.
 
Audience Waiting To Be Discovered
Meanwhile, the movie industry's rediscovery of the young female audience is greeted with cynicism in some quarters. The consensus is that this audience was always there, but never fully acknowledged until lately.
"The success of a film like 'Lethal Weapon' was not just because young males showed; half of the people sitting in that room were women who wanted to see Mel Gibson," said Robin Swicord, a screenwriter of films like "Little Women," who has written and plans to direct a film for Paramount about young models, aimed at the female audience.
" 'Last of the Mohicans' was a surprise hit to a lot of people," she said, "but the reason it was a hit was because women and younger girls went again and again to see this romantic story and Daniel Day-Lewis running through the forest with his shirt off."
Laughing, she said, "Actually, we called 'Last of the Mohicans' by another name: 'Lust of the Mohicans.' "

HEADLINE: The Misguided Max Tax

BYLINE: By William G. Gale and Robert D. Reischauer; William G. Gale is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. Robert D. Reischauer, a fellow at the Brookings Institution, was director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1989 to 1995.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The latest fad in the seemingly endless stream of budget proposals involves limiting total tax payments. Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, wants to cap Federal revenue at 19 percent of gross domestic product. Some have gone even further, pushing for a constitutional amendment that would limit Federal taxes to 25 percent of income. The "Max Tax," a variation on this theme, would let each taxpayer choose between filing under the current system and simply paying 25 percent of gross income.
These proposals may seem simple and fair. But they would constrain public policy in unwise and dangerous ways, give away needed Federal money and provide a huge tax break for the wealthiest households. 
 It's true, as advocates for tax limits like to point out, that the Federal Government has more revenue today relative to the size of the economy than at any time since the end of World War II. But there are good reasons that this is the case.
First, lawmakers increased tax rates in 1990 and 1993 to reduce the deficit. And guess what? For the first time since 1969, we will have a budget surplus. A tax limit like the Max Tax, which would reduce revenue by more than $100 billion, would throw this accomplishment away.
Second, since the 1960's payroll taxes have risen to match the rising costs of Social Security and Medicare. This largely explains the higher overall tax burdens facing individuals. Yet even these higher taxes will not meet the challenge that these two programs face when the baby boomers begin to retire in a decade.
Third, both the economy and stock market are booming. When incomes, corporate profits and capital gains soar, Government revenue rises more than proportionately, because the tax system is progressive.
But tax limits would be a windfall for the wealthy. If the Max Tax had been the law in 1994, those individuals with adjusted gross income below $50,000 a year -- that's 90 percent of all taxpayers -- would have received cuts averaging only $150. Those with incomes exceeding $200,000 -- the top 1 percent of taxpayers -- would have received cuts averaging $40,000. Should we reduce progressivity in the tax system when the richest among us are receiving a disproportionate share of the wealth?
It would be unwise and risky to limit taxes through a constitutional amendment or some arbitrary statutory cap. If the nation needed to expand the defense budget significantly, we would want to consider raising taxes; otherwise, we may find ourselves recklessly financing any buildup through soaring deficits, as we did in the 1980's.
Moreover, a cap on taxes would be difficult to design and implement. Clear and accepted definitions of "taxes" and "income" would be needed, but none exist. For example, would it make sense when calculating a tax limit to equate income and payroll tax payments even though some portion of the latter will be returned to the taxpayer in the future as Social Security benefits?
Tax lawyers and financial planners would have a field day designing ways to game the new system. Under a tax limit, they would create mechanisms to shift corporate income, which would still be taxed at a 35 percent rate, to upper income households that would face a 25 percent rate on unlimited amounts of gross income.
The next step in tax reform should be to simplify the tax code. This does not require a constitutional amendment, a depletion of Federal revenue or a huge tax cut for the wealthy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Merrymaking Is Clashing With Tradition in Mardi Gras Tableaux

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The parades, the lifeblood of the pre-Lent Carnival season for many people here, still course through St. Charles Avenue to cries of "Throw me something, mister!"
The famous beads, plastic junk endowed with some almost mystical importance for a moment in time, still fly from the floats. Shriners, fezzes in the wind, still rumble along on their matching Harleys between high-stepping marching bands and woodenly waving beauty queens. 
 At the tableau balls of the super-secret societies known as krewes, the rustle of this season's silk still mixes with the reek of old bourbon and older money, while in the French Quarter, tourists who still think Mardi Gras is license to get blind and staggering drunk, still do.
It is the season of merriment in New Orleans leading up to Lent, which started with the Feast of the Epiphany on Jan. 6 and ends at midnight on Fat Tuesday, Feb. 24.
To most outsiders, the "Greatest Free Show on Earth," is just as loud, grand and weird as ever. But to people who know its past, Carnival -- most people call it Mardi Gras -- is shrinking, both in history and scope, becoming more tawdry and tourist-oriented at the expense of tradition, even as studies on its economic impact show that that, too, is dwindling.
Traditionalists say it is not just the old battle over the exclusivity of some historic krewes, which for years admitted only whites, but also a creeping shoddiness in how it is all played out.
"What we've known and loved has been turned into a theme park to amuse visitors," said Henri Schindler, a Carnival historian and float designer whose creations built from papier-mache -- on themes of literature, mythology and history -- have been called rolling pieces of art.
"Now," Mr. Schindler said, "we have double-decker buses carrying Wayne Newton and Steven Seagal."
But it is more than a matter of taste, of style. It is a feeling that Carnival, long considered a party for locals that the outside world could see and hear and taste but never really become part of, is fighting for its very identity.
It is now possible simply to purchase one of those coveted places on a parade float, even if those floats are less imaginative, less grand.
As cameras for MTV, true-life crime shows and tabloid news programs roll in the French Quarter, the drunken partying has grown so extreme -- flashes of nudity have given way to the actual performance of oral sex acts on Bourbon Street -- that it is the drunkenness and obscenity itself that threatens to become Carnival's theme.
"We've lost quite a bit," Mr. Schindler said. "What is happening is the modernization, Americanization and homogenization of Carnival."
The latest addition to Carnival is the Krewe of America, and members need have no connection to New Orleans or its history. Instead, members from around the country can purchase a $2,500 package for two that includes hotel room, plane tickets, a brunch, a ball, and a place on one of the krewe's parade floats.
The krewes, the New Orleans variation of crews, are nonprofit clubs financed by dues and fund-raising projects, and most of them are involved in charities. Memberships have been traditionally limited to people who live in or around the city.
To traditionalists, the Krewe of America turns history on its head. It is supposed to be local residents tossing beads to tourists, not the other way around, said Arthur Hardy, a Carnival historian and publisher of the "Mardi Gras Guide."
"It's still a party we throw ourselves," Mr. Hardy said. What the Krewe of America is doing, he said, "is like having the audience join in a Broadway play."
But the Krewe of America's captain, Jack Blossman, said the whole idea of the krewe was to let people see behind the mask.
"Most people only see Mardi Gras from the curb," said Mr. Blossman, a banker who lives outside New Orleans. "We give them a chance to get on the inside."
It is open to people of both sexes and of all colors. That is in stark contrast to organizations like Comus, the oldest parading krewe, which stopped parading after a 1991 city ordinance banned membership discrimination. Other krewes followed the lead of Comus, but those organizations -- made up of white men -- still celebrate Carnival with fancy-dress balls. Other organizations with long traditions, like Rex, opened their membership and still parade.
In a move that rankles many traditionalists, the City Council granted the prime parade slot once held by Comus -- at 5 P.M. on Fat Tuesday -- to the Krewe of America.
"I hate to see it become a corporate perk, a junket," Mr. Schindler said.
Mr. Blossman said that "every parade has people from out of town" who ride along, but the krewes do not advertise that fact. In time, he said, his krewe hopes to have 20 people from each state. While he says that his krewe is trying to get along with the Carnival establishment and carving out its own place in the culture, Mr. Blossman contends that snobbery is behind much of the hostility.
There is a middle ground between the new krewe and traditionalists. Krewes like Bacchus, founded in 1968, and Orpheus, founded in 1994 by the singer Harry Connick Jr., include celebrities, popular floats and generous "throws," the beads, aluminum doubloons and plastic cups that the crowds clamor for.
Beyond the cultural impact of Carnival is its immense economic one, from tourism dollars, but after years of increases, that is also changing. According to a study by the University of New Orleans, the economic impact fell to about $801 million in 1997 and to $810 million in 1996 from a high of $929 million in 1995.
The number of parades are also falling, to 45 last year from a high of 55 in 1986. And as the parade culture dwindles, the culture of rampant drunkenness grows.
Last year, people had sex on Bourbon Street. Videos of the street scenes from Fat Tuesday are on sale in X-rated video stores.
"I'm not a prude," Mr. Hardy said, but in the past few years he said he had seen the ribaldry go from the traditional naughtiness -- it is common for a young man to ask a young woman to show him her breasts in exchange for beads -- to acts that are far lewder.
That increasingly dangerous reputation of anything goes is scaring away more middle-class adult visitors, the kind of people who actually spend money, and attracting young people who only want to frolic in a drunken haze, traditionalists say.
What many people see on television, particularly from Bourbon Street, "is a drunken orgy," Mr. Hardy said, adding, "They feel they have a license to behave this way."
But historians also say that Carnival in New Orleans is always in flux, in agitation, in transformation, and that in other ways it never seems to change at all.
Just saying, for instance, that an old-line krewe has opened its membership does not mean that the membership is actually any more integrated -- and memberships are still largely secret. The majority white krewes are still, say historians, almost exclusively white, and the black krewes, like the famous Zulu Social Aid and Please Club, are almost exclusively black.
The parades, much more than elitist balls, are the twine that holds the whole thing together, residents say. Anyone can come to a parade.
Earlier this week, as the Krewe of Pegasus paraded down St. Charles, there were no grand floats. But marching bands from inner-city high schools had people dancing on the trolley tracks that run between the four-lane street. There was no real sense of mystery, of intrigue. But a horse did go a little crazy and almost trample a group of drunk college boys in bad Hawaiian shirts.

HEADLINE: Report Finds Bias in Lending Hinders Home Buying in Cities

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
While the number of Americans who own their homes has reached a record level, a new report by the United States Conference of Mayors contends that discriminatory lending practices in urban areas have kept many city dwellers from participating in the boom.
Last year, the overall national rate of home ownership reached a record high of 65.7 percent. But the report, "America's Home Ownership Gap," found a sharp difference in likelihood of owning a home in different places. 
 Citing evidence compiled by the Federal Reserve Board and the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University, the report said 71.5 percent of people who live in the suburbs own their homes, compared with 49 percent who live in cities.
The disparity, the report said, stemmed largely from redlining by banks, a practice that makes mortgage loans unavailable to low-income buyers. It found that those same people are also affected by real estate agents who steer them away from certain neighborhoods and by the current limits on Federal Housing Administration loans.
Typically, the people who have been hurt are members of minorities, who disproportionately live in cities. The report said 71.3 percent of whites are homeowners, compared with 43.6 percent of blacks and 41.7 percent of Hispanic Americans. The Federal Reserve concluded that minority households applying for mortgage credit were "much more likely" to be rejected than white households with similar incomes.
"Redlining and all other forms of housing discrimination are ugly stains from America's past that have no place in America today," said Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo, in response to the report's findings. "This report proves that home ownership in America is still too often separate and unequal."
Home ownership is viewed by many sociologists and politicians as vital to neighborhood stability, a key to promoting safer streets, better schools and economic development.
That pattern has worked successfully in suburban areas for decades as thousands of bedroom communities have sprung up around urban centers. But in many cases, the outward flow has led to the decline of inner-city neighborhoods, with renters and, often, wrecking balls claiming homes once owned and occupied.
Some cities, like Philadelphia, Cleveland and Detroit, are fighting back with ambitious redevelopment plans, making use of local and Federal programs that emphasize home ownership as the best way to rehabilitate eroding neighborhoods.
But as the report found, discriminatory practices continue to impede the development, even as incomes are rising and many banks have lowered their mortgage rates.
The report quotes Willie Brown, the Mayor of San Francisco and chairman of the mayors' conference on community development and housing, as saying: "We've got more people in more jobs making more money and buying more homes. But these home buyers aren't minorities, and that raises the question: Shouldn't all boats be rising on this strong economic tide?"
The report offers few concrete solutions, other than to urge the private mortgage industry to make more loans available to lower-income buyers. Mr. Cuomo said that the Administration is proposing to raise Federal housing loan limits, which have been in effect for 21 years.
Passage by Congress, he said, would enable three million more families to buy their homes.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: IN BAGHDAD;
Despite Threat of Missiles, the Iraqi Capital's People Take a Crisis in Stride

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 22

 BODY:
In a city where crucial negotiations about the fate of Iraq's 22 million people might be headed toward an optimistic resolution, the people of Baghdad seemed cool and placid today -- almost nonchalant.
In stores and coffee shops, people glanced at television screens showing other Arabs supporting them and international diplomacy working full blast -- taking it all in stride. 
 Even during the last four weeks, when it has appeared that a formidable American armada was getting read to send a shower of missiles over Iraq, hardly anyone here rushed to hoard food. And the value of the dollar, which usually soars in times of danger, has actually fallen.
True, Maher Yaacoub knew today that things were looking up. He could see it by glancing at the reports taken from CNN flashing on the Yasir Almeheidi electric shop's television just behind the rickety table where Mr. Yaacoub peddles single cigarettes from open packs.
The CNN reports, complete with Arabic translation, gave hourly details of talks in Baghdad with the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, asserting that they were going well. And everyone in Iraq knows that when the tightly controlled Iraqi media starts showing uncensored reports from a major "imperialistic American" network, it is a clear sign things are swinging Iraq's way.
Still, Mr. Yaacoub said philosophically: "What will happen will happen. We have been there before."
But overall some 60 people interviewed over the weekend appeared fatalistic, skeptical and even defiant despite assurances from their Government that there was some light at the end of the tunnel after seven years of severe economic sanctions.
"My dear friend," said Kazem Hani, 24, a pharmacist, "we are at the mercy of America, whose President is surrounded by people who hate Muslims and Arabs, who has a sexual scandal on his hands that he wants to resolve at our expense, and who is pressured by generals to try their new toy missiles on somebody. With odds like that our only refuge is God, not, excuse me, Kofi Annan."
The pharmacist was sipping tea this afternoon with a colleague in Soraya's Pharmacy, off the main shopping artery, Saadoun Avenue. The largely empty shelves contained only two kinds of medications: a pain killer and an antidepressant that can only be dispensed with a doctor's prescription.
As 13 clients came in over a two-hour period, the two pharmacists were able to respond only to three requests for pain killers. To the rest the answer was the same: "Sorry, brother. I don't have it." The customers shuffled out in the same resigned way they shuffled in.
Does anybody around here ask for gas masks?
Mr. Hani laughed bitterly. "You are talking to someone who has not eaten a banana in seven years," he said. "I last had meat a month ago. When I come to work every morning here, I say good morning to six engineers who are peddling cigarettes on this street to supplement their incomes. Do you believe anyone here is worried about gas?"
"They say your school years are your happiest years. They have been my most miserable years. I went into pharmacology school under the embargo and graduated under the embargo. Dreams, hopes of marrying, traveling, opening a business, are all evaporated.
"We have no army. Anyone can see we cannot defend ourselves. But they are going to attack us because, after searching our country for seven years, they suddenly discover we have biological weapons?"
Mr. Hani leaned forward and added, "I think this may be the first time a lot of people may die because your President has turned the White House into a brothel."
This gloom did not lighten yesterday when it was announced that the Security Council authorized a doubling of the amount of oil Iraq can sell for food. If anything, the move was seen as a cynical ploy because the embargo has not allowed Iraq to maintain its oil infrastructure so it is doubtful whether it can pump the additional oil. At the moment, Iraq is pumping 1.5 million barrels of oil a day compared with a capacity of 4 million before the embargo was imposed in 1990.
Asked about prospect of getting more food and medicine, Issa Khalid, owner of a leather shop, side-stepped the question, asking, "Tell me first, is it true American citizens were advised to leave Iraq and the whole Middle East as soon as possible?"
It was, the answer came back. "Well, is there need to say more?"
These assertive comments seem to longtime travelers here to indicate a change in the way Iraqis view the rest of the world. Many expressed defiance toward other countries.
Perhaps as a result of the shift in mood, Baghdad appears more open to foreigners than at any time since the crisis began. Foreign reporters have flooded the country in the last four weeks and have found few obstacles to their movement or their ability to talk to people.
What is even more remarkable is that Iraqis are talking. In a clear break with almost predictable behavior in the past, hardly anyone interviewed in the last few days asked that their names be withheld.
In the once peaceful, almost idyllic, setting of the School of Fine Arts -- dotted with sculptures of goddesses and nymphs -- scores of the 600 male and female students were receiving their daily military training today under the gaze of 43-year-old Youssef Rashid, chairman of the Theatrical Arts Department.
Mr. Rashid, a pensive intellectual, seemed almost perturbed at the sight of his young artists being forced into such rough activity. But when asked if this is not perhaps the fault of Iraq's leaders, he bristled.
"Why?" he said. "Is it Saddam who has imposed the embargo? Besides, what is America to tell any country what leadership it should have. This is a country with thousands of years of culture that is now watching its babies dying of malnutrition."
Beyond the defiance, there is a far more widespread sentiment that anything Iraqis do, or refuse to do, does not matter anymore.
"We are used to this -- it has been eight years, you know," said Ohoud Ibrahim, a 36-year-old actress with a riveting stare who teaches here. She is star of a popular play in Baghdad called "A Screwed Up World."
Watching students learning how to use machine guns, she said: "You know, sometimes I go out of the theater at night wondering if what is happening between us and America is weirder than the play. I think most people in Iraq are at the point where they just don't care."
The main beneficiary of this mood is President Saddam Hussein. "If you think anybody is going to rise to overthrow him, forget it," said a woman named Nadia, who was virtually the only person interviewed who insisted on a measure of anonymity. "He is our devil and the devil you know is better than the devil you don't know, especially Clinton."

HEADLINE: Higher Quota Urged for Immigrant Technology Workers

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Under pressure from Congress and the computer industry, the White House is seriously considering proposals to increase the immigration quota for computer scientists and other information technology workers, so that foreigners can fill thousands of job openings in this country.
The issue is extremely divisive. President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore want to placate friends in Silicon Valley, who say there is a critical shortage of technology workers, but they risk offending organized labor. 
 Under current law, employers can bring in up to 65,000 skilled foreign workers each year. The workers receive visas, known as H-1B visas, that last up to six years.
In 1997, for the first time, the Government issued the maximum number of such visas, and it expects to reach the limit again in May or June, several months before the end of the current fiscal year.
High-tech companies, which depend on foreign workers for essential services, have been lobbying the Administration to support an increase in the annual limits. They say there is an urgent need for Congress to act this year, and some lawmakers are eager to do so.
The initial, public response from the Administration was negative. In January, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said, "This Administration does not support an increase in the caps on visas."
But confidential White House documents show that the Administration is seriously considering proposals that would increase the quota by 50 percent or more. The Administration contends that any increase should be linked to education and training and new protections for American workers.
One industry group, the Information Technology Association of America, sees "a severe shortage of competent and skilled information technology workers." It says there are 346,000 vacancies, representing 10 percent of all the jobs for computer programmers and engineers and systems analysts.
Harris N. Miller, president of the association, said, "The shortage threatens not only the information technology industry, but the growth of the entire U.S. economy, our global competitiveness and the wage stability that is the bedrock of this country's low inflation."
Senator Spencer Abraham, the Michigan Republican who heads the Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, shares this concern.
"If American companies cannot find home-grown talent and if they cannot bring talent to this country," Mr. Abraham said, "some of them will move their operations overseas, taking American jobs with them. That is why I am going to use my position to propose that we increase the number of more highly skilled temporary workers we allow into the United States."
Speaker Newt Gingrich said he too supported an increase in the quota for "people of high talent."
The Commerce Department predicts that the United States will need more than 1.3 million new information technology workers -- an average of 138,000 a year -- in the coming decade.
The openings come in the context of a tight labor market. Over all, the national unemployment rate last year, averaging 4.9 percent, was the lowest since 1973.
The options for increasing the immigration quota are described in a memorandum requested by Elena Kagan, deputy director of the Domestic Policy Council at the White House. The memorandum, prepared and approved by senior officials at the Departments of Commerce, Labor and State and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, begins by saying, "This is a very controversial issue."
Seth Harris, the Acting Assistant Secretary of Labor for Policy, said Ms. Kagan had "asked the Labor and Commerce Departments to draft a memorandum setting forth options with respect to the proposal to increase the cap on H-1B visas."
White House documents show that the Commerce Department, the State Department and the immigration service favor an option that would set the quota for skilled foreign workers at 80,000 to 100,000 a year. Information technology and other industries with shortages of skilled workers would have priority in getting the extra visas, above the current 65,000.
At present, employers seeking H-1B visas do not have to show a shortage of American workers, nor do they have to show that they tried to recruit Americans for the jobs.
The Labor Department would prefer to keep the cap at its current level, but might give priority within the quota to industries that have shortages of skilled workers, the documents say. Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the ranking Democrat on the immigration subcommittee, favors this approach.
Technology companies say that, while they support more education and training for Americans, they need skilled labor immediately and therefore want to bring in additional foreign workers.
Administration officials said they would prod Congress to adopt new protections for American workers as lawmakers consider raising the quota for foreign workers. The President's proposals would require employers to recruit Americans before importing foreign labor, would ban the use of foreign workers to replace laid-off Americans and would reduce the maximum stay for H-1B workers to three years, from six.
The memorandum to Ms. Kagan notes that "critics of raising the H-1B cap, such as the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Institute for Electrical and Electronic Engineers and the American Engineering Association, say industry drastically overstates any problem."
Hal Ponder, a lawyer with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s department for professional employees, said organized labor opposed increasing the quota until there was more careful study of the problem.
"We question whether there is a shortage of information technology workers," Mr. Ponder said in an interview. "If there is a shortage, there are skilled workers in the United States who could meet that need."
Norman S. Matloff, a professor of computer science at the University of California at Davis, said that many technology companies were seeking cheap labor. As a result, he said, they prefer to hire recent graduates and foreign workers and often discriminate against American computer programmers over the age of 40, who are perceived as requiring higher salaries.
"Foreign nationals are willing to take lower salaries in exchange for the prospect of becoming permanent residents of the United States," Mr. Matloff said. "Even though they often earn less than U.S. citizens with comparable jobs, they still receive more than they would be paid back home in India or Russia."
The memorandum to the White House from the Departments of Labor, Commerce and State says: "The H-1B program seldom operates as a temporary worker program with workers coming to this country for a short duration and then returning to their homes. Instead, it operates often as a probationary employment program. Employers bring workers to the United States and, if they perform well, sponsor them for permanent admission to this country. This linkage permits employers to hire foreign workers without first recruiting U.S. workers."
Under this arrangement, the memorandum says, "U.S. workers are never provided a genuine opportunity to compete for these jobs."
Stephen H. Leven, director of human resources at Texas Instruments, said that most of the people hired by his company on H-1B visas were foreign citizens who graduated from American universities with degrees in electrical engineering.
"Employers expect to hit the H-1B ceiling as early as May this year," Mr. Leven said. "Once the cap is reached, companies will be unable to hire additional foreign workers until the new fiscal year begins in October. That will be devastating to U.S. companies seeking to bring new products to market."
In their memorandum to the White House, Administration officials said the industry's conclusion about a dire shortage of skilled technology workers was "not entirely accurate." While there seem to be shortages of technology workers in selected occupations and some local areas, the memorandum says, "wage data do not suggest acute skill shortages nationwide."
By contrast, the Information Technology Association of America says, "Our industry is facing a national labor shortage of historic proportions."

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
United Nations Chief Reaches Deal With Iraq
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq met with Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General, and agreed to lift his ban on arms inspections at so-called presidential properties, a spokesman for Mr. Annan said. The agreement could avert another American attack on Iraq and recharge the arms inspection process that was put in place after the Persian Gulf War. A1
 
Senior Clinton Administration officials warned that deeds, not words, were required to resolve the crisis with Iraq. They said they would withhold judgment on the import of Mr. Annan's visit to Baghdad until he returned on Tuesday with details. A1 

Iraq was said to have agreed to inspections of eight "presidential sites" that it had declared off-limits to United Nations weapons inspectors and dropped its demands for a time limit on inspections. The agreement apparently does not address the issue of all the sites that the commission in charge of Iraq's disarmament has identified as suspect. A8
 
The people of Baghdad seemed almost nonchalant at the news about the negotiations. Some said the penury imposed by seven years of sanctions made theirs a life not worth living and shrugged off the threat of an American strike. One Iraqi quoted a saying, "A wet man does not fear rain." A9
 
A New Kind of Leader in Korea
Kim Dae Jung, who on Wednesday will become the President of South Korea, insists that the solution to Asia's economic crisis is more democracy, greater openness and freer markets. Mr. Kim, a renowned dissident who opposed South Korea's military dictatorship, has said he is willing to speak out against human rights abuses in the region. A1
 
Shake-Up in Key Indian State
As another 200 million voters cast ballots in the second of three key days in India's general elections, the state government of Uttar Pradesh was ousted after defectors from a coalition led by a Hindu nationalist party switched sides and pledged their support to a new coalition. A3
 
Fires Flare Again in Indonesia
Small farmers and large plantation owners in eastern Borneo have apparently resumed their slash-and-burn land clearing, unleashing fires that threaten to blanket Southeast Asia with smoke and haze the way they did last fall. The Government of Indonesia has banned burning, but the farmers are desperate to survive as food shortages and bankruptcies spread throughout the country. A3
 
Belfast Talks to Go On
The British and Irish Governments have decided that terrorist attacks by splinter groups who object to the Northern Ireland peace talks should not be allowed to derail the talks, officials close to the negotiations said. Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said that his party would not be deterred by "Republican militants." A4
 
NATIONAL A10-15
 
Tobacco Papers Suggest Altered Nicotine Levels
Tobacco industry documents, some released recently, strongly suggest that the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company altered nicotine delivery to smokers, apparently believing that doing so would increase the "kick" of its Winston brand and make it more competitive. A1
 
A Shrinking Mardi Gras?
It is the season of merriment in New Orleans, and to most outsiders, the "Greatest Free Show on Earth" is just as loud and weird as ever. But to people who know its past, Mardi Gras is shrinking, both in history and scope. They say it is becoming more tawdry and tourist-oriented at the expense of tradition, even as studies on its economic impact show that that is dwindling as well. A10
 
'No' on Caterpillar Contract
The United Auto Workers voted to reject a new contract with Caterpillar Inc., continuing its six-year dispute with the nation's larger maker of earth-moving equipment. The nationwide vote on the proposal was 58 percent against and 42 percent in favor. Although the contract proposal, supported by union leadership, would have ended the uncertainty for about 13,000 workers in four states, it also required them to give way on some issues that twice led to long, bitter strikes. A10
 
Homeownership Up, for Some
The number of Americans who own their own home has reached a record level, but a new report by the United States Conference of Mayors says that discriminatory lending practices in urban areas have kept more city dwellers from participating in the boom. The report says the people who have been hurt by those practices are minorities, who disproportionately live in cities. A13
 
On the Campaign (Finance) Trail
Among voters these days, campaign finance is second fiddle at best to topics like Iraq, Senator Russell D. Feingold learned last week as he made his rounds in Wisconsin to talk to constituents. But despite some stinging put-downs -- one person suggested hanging a banner outside the White House saying, 'The Best Government That Money Can Buy' -- Senator Feingold professes to be optimistic about the campaign finance debate that begins in the Senate today. A14
 
A Fine Line on Immigration
The White House is considering proposals to increase the immigration quota for computer scientists and other information technology workers, so foreigners can fill thousands of job openings in the United States. The computer industry supports such plans, but the Administration risks offending organized labor. A13
 
New Search in Anthrax Case
More than a dozen F.B.I. agents searched the Logandale, Nev., home of William Job Leavitt Jr. again, even though Mr. Leavitt has been released from jail after tests showed that a substance he possessed was a harmless anthrax vaccine and not a biological weapon. A14
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Prostitution Gets A Little More Discreet
The number of prostitutes on New York City streets has thinned, in large part because of the surge of Disney-style family entertainment in Times Square and the city's assault on "quality of life" crimes. But prostitution, though less visible, is no less prevalent. More discreet forms have been able to flourish, thanks to the Internet, cellular phones and escort services. A1
 
Ferraro on the Attack
Geraldine A. Ferraro denounced Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for repeatedly blocking measures to restrict campaign contributions, and urged him to support a bill to overhaul campaign finance coming to the Senate floor this week. Ms. Ferraro took a break from her own schedule of fund-raising to seize on an issue that she and the two other Democrats seeking the nomination to run against Mr. D'Amato said was one of his biggest political vulnerabilities: his aggressive fund-raising practices. Mr. D'Amato reiterated his opposition to the measure through a spokesman. B3
 
Changes at Oxford Expected
Oxford Health Plans is close to announcing that its founder and chairman is stepping down and that it has raised more than $600 million in badly needed capital, according to people who have been briefed on the negotiations. The deal could be announced as early as today. B1
 
No Money for an Aging City
With New York City expecting a huge budget surplus for the second straight year, the suggestion naturally arises that the city spend some of its extra $1.2 billion to fix its crumbling infrastructure. But city officials are holding on tight to their extra money, saying they need it for those difficult years that are sure to come. And many lawmakers agree, despite the seemingly unending need to mend an aging city. B1

Abraham A. Ribicoff
The popular Governor of Connecticut, Congressman and United States Senator who served as America's first Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, under President John F. Kennedy, was 87. BUSINESS DAY D1-9
 
A Disk Drive Renaissance
An I.B.M. laboratory has developed a disk drive the size of a poker chip that can hold the equivalent of more than 500 large novels, offering striking evidence that one of the computer industry's oldest technologies is in the midst of a remarkable renaissance. D1
 
Allstate Fights Fraud
The Allstate Insurance Company is serving notice today on 45 doctors, lawyers and street-level workers in Los Angeles that they are being sued for $107 million for what the company contends was their part in orchestrating scores of fake crashes to defraud the company. It is the biggest suit ever filed in connection with fake auto accidents. D2

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Continuing to Give, Despite Obstacles Great and Small

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
A stolen car. Kidney stones. Unemployment. These misfortunes, which plowed into Joseph Leary's life just before Christmas, helped turn December and January into his "winter of major discontent," as he put it.
But while the hardships made Mr. Leary anxious, depressed and financially pressed, he still sent his annual $25 to The New York Times Neediest Case Fund -- with a prodigious explanation. 
 "So the dog didn't eat my check," wrote Mr. Leary, a graphic artist from the Upper West Side. "But I have an even better batch of excuses."
As the fund-raising appeal enters its final week, many donors have been asking forgiveness for acting so late. "Sorry I didn't get to this sooner," wrote Marcia Blecker of Roslyn, N.Y., "but unfortunately we've had an onslaught of family deaths and I've been down with the flu."
Others, however, had less sympathetic reasons. Daniel and Hannah Finnie, ages 6 and 4, dispatched their $10 just before Christmas. But their father, Matthew, thought he might save a few pennies by mailing their donation in a recycled business-reply envelope, which the Postal Service returned six weeks later.
"Sorry for the delay," Mr. Finnie, of Basking Ridge, N.J., wrote in a note that finally arrived last week. "I got cheap and tried to reuse an envelope so it ended up costing me an extra stamp instead."
Whatever the excuse, contributions postmarked before Feb. 28 will be added to this season's tally of $5.4 million, the largest amount ever collected by the fund. Gifts postmarked after that date will be counted toward the next appeal. The previous record, $5.08 million, had been set in 1991-92. When the campaign ends on Saturday, the money will be distributed among seven of the city's most prominent charities. And because The Times pays all administrative costs, every dollar will go to help those who have fallen on hard times.
While the success of this year's campaign may have tempered the philanthropy of some, it seems to have fueled the generosity of others. C. Stephen Heard of the Upper East Side sent $300, his second gift of the year, hoping it might inspire others and "help push the needle toward the $6 million mark," he wrote. "I will try to send one more before the end of February," he added.
Many of the 12,000 people who have contributed to the fund so far this year say they did so because they wanted to alleviate the suffering of New York's most desperate residents. Others, like Jennifer Anne Hull of the Upper East Side, were also moved by a twinge of guilt.
"It's Saturday night and my aching feet have finally recovered from a day spent shopping the designer sale racks at Saks," she wrote in a note that accompanied her $175 gift. "While mentally congratulating myself on scoring a $450 Claude Montana blouse for $160, my eyes glanced over an article in The Times headlined 'Out From Under a Threat of Eviction: No Longer a Need to Choose Between Rent and Food.' There's another check that I need to write today, and it's enclosed."
Some contributors have made a habit out of giving. Albert and Mimi Jaffe recently moved to North Carolina from Westchester County, but they continued their custom, sending in $2 for every year they have been together, a figure that represents the cost of a marriage license when they were wed 58 years ago. "We hope to continue this tradition as long as we're alive and kicking," Mr. Jaffe, a semi-retired insurance writer, said in an interview. "And I've included a much more sizable bequest in my will when we're not."

HEADLINE: Prostitutes on Wane In New York Streets But Take to Internet

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
The old prostitution haunts now crawl with nearly as many police officers as streetwalkers, part of New York City's continuing assault on "quality of life" crimes. Once-seedy areas where the sex business flourished, like Times Square, have given way to Disney-style family entertainment. And the combined forces of AIDS and drug addiction have further thinned the ranks of prostitutes on neighborhood streets.
But while prostitution may be less visible in the city, it is no less prevalent. The Internet, pagers, cellular phones and subterfuges like escort services have enabled more discreet forms of prostitution to thrive beyond the reach of the street-level crackdown, the authorities and prostitutes themselves say. 
 "You have some people who have no alternative but the street," said Capt. John Costello, commander of the Manhattan South police vice squad. "But there are a whole lot of people that we never deal with, working out of offices, apartments and the Internet. And if they are acting behind closed doors and are discreet, we will never hear about them."
As the police have forced prostitutes to change tactics, the city's resurgence as a destination for conventioneers and tourists has expanded the demand for prostitution, said Ronald Moglia, a professor of human sexuality at New York University.
And the business is adjusting. Prostitutes cruise the Internet nightly looking to arrange liaisons in New York, the computer and modem having replaced the sidewalk and street lamp as the means by which many prostitutes and customers meet, size one another up and negotiate transactions. Ads for sexual services flourish on Web sites and in mainstream publications. And the current Manhattan Yellow Pages now has 52 pages devoted to escort services -- legal businesses that the police say frequently front as prostitution rings. That is 17 more pages than two years ago.
Long-established escort services are feeling the competitive squeeze.
"This business is growing like crazy," said Nerissa Braimbridge, whose International Escort service in Manhattan has brought together young women and wealthy men for more than two decades -- for companionship only, she said, adding that her service receives many queries over the Internet. "It's grown from something small to something degenerate. Everyone is getting into the business and operating as an escort."
Prostitutes have certainly not been driven off the streets, and many still shiver nightly on the sidewalks in desolate stretches of the city. But they are an increasingly beleaguered, often desperate group.
"It's not like it used to be," said Candace, a 41-year-old prostitute who has worked in Hell's Kitchen and other Manhattan neighborhoods for more than a decade. Referring to Ninth Avenue, she said: "There used to be 15 girls working here; now it's only me. You've got to move around a lot more and work more secluded places to get by, and you can't take as much time sizing up your customer. Things are tough on the street."
But another prostitute, a 26-year-old man who gave only his professional name, Steve, has managed to do brisk business while keeping far away from the hazards of the street corner. On a recent evening he worked at his computer making dates for Valentine's Day. He said he had found steady work since he began selling sex on the Internet, through an on-line account that cost him $10 to set up.
A posted profile describes Steve as a "head-turning escort for evenings or travel" whose hobbies include "making wealthy men very happy."
On-line prostitutes say the Internet is a natural medium for selling sex: it is anonymous and connects them to a vast array of potential clients. It is safer than the streets, where vice officers and predatory strangers are constant threats.
And it is cheap. An escort company can buy an ad on a Web site for $50 a month, compared with thousands of dollars for half a page in the Yellow Pages. Prostitutes also say the Internet enables them to avoid sharing their profits with a pimp or an escort agency.
One beneficiary of the evolution of New York prostitution has been Redlightnet.com, a clearinghouse for the on-line sex trade that has been run for a year and a half out of a small apartment in Chelsea. Redlightnet's page on the World Wide Web is supported by more than 10 regular advertisers in the escort business and more than 400 personal ads.
"It doesn't take a rocket scientist to do this job, it just takes looks," said Alan M., a 26-year-old former Navy sailor who said he started selling sex out of his home in Chicago several months ago and averages $1,500 a week for about 10 hours' work. His costs are mainly for clothes and keeping his computer in good repair. Clients pick up most other expenses, including taxi and plane fares when he travels to New York and other cities.
In these and other ways, off-street sex workers are sharply different from those who walk the streets, experts say. They usually do not refer to themselves as prostitutes, sociologists say, noting that it is easier for them to escape the industry's stigma because they are unlikely to develop a criminal record and are more often in business for themselves.
"You have a more open attitude toward sexuality on the part of young people," said Ira Reiss, professor emeritus of sociology at the University of Minnesota. "Now we have a variety of new communication devices, there is a much easier moral code and a willingness to experiment and try new things by both men and women. And it's much easier to say, 'I'm just making extra money.' "
There are no authoritative figures on the prostitute population in New York City. But evidence from a variety of sources suggests that the industry is growing, even as fewer prostitutes work the street. And electronic technology appears to be central to the industry's success, both in attracting business and avoiding the authorities.
 
Discreet Operations Are Rarely Targets
The police say prostitutes who work on line or for escort services are unlikely ever to be arrested, since law enforcement agencies rarely go after discreet indoor operations. In fact, the only way such businesses get into trouble, escorts and police officials say, is by employing under-age prostitutes, annoying neighbors with too much foot traffic, or failing to pay taxes.
One New York State law enforcement official who spoke on condition of anonymity said his office had made several attempts to reel in on-line sex workers over the last year but had failed each time because the prostitutes became suspicious before a deal was brokered.
According to the city police, only 30 establishments were closed during the first eight months of last year, and only 44 were closed the year before. While the Police Department could not give complete statistics for prostitution arrests in 1997, vice squad officers arrested fewer than 2,000 prostitutes and clients in 1996, fewer than a third of whom were prostitutes working inside buildings.
From January to October 1997, the department's vice enforcement division arrested only 1,380 prostitutes and their customers, fewer than half from inside establishments.
The police say there is no evidence that a significant number of street prostitutes have gone into the booming escort business. But many have adopted more modest technological means to stay ahead of the police. They try to build client lists so that they can arrange work by phone rather than on the street. Others work out of bars or dance clubs, giving out pager numbers to clients. Pimps sometimes set women up in roving vans and limousines, beeping them whenever the police are spotted.
 
Using Technology To Evade Prosecution
Escort services, which are often fronts for prostitution, are notoriously ingenious at evading prosecution. Police officials said attempts to find and infiltrate such services required a great deal of luck. The telephone numbers they use are often in locations where no prostitutes have ever set foot, instead housing only a receptionist with a bank of phones.
Donna, a 26-year-old escort who has worked for several services in the city, including one on line, said she had never met the madam of a service that calls her regularly. Its phone number, which turned out to be a beeper, was given to her by another escort she knew. When she first called looking for a job, she left her number and was quickly called back by a woman who asked her who she was and what she wanted, then told her to go to a bar in SoHo and wait.
Donna was met there by a man who asked her questions about her background and took her phone number. He gave her a key to a hotel room in mid-Manhattan and explained the rules. She was to report when available, for periods ranging from all day to one hour. The key was for a hotel room that contained a locked closet, where the money that she and other escorts made would be left.
Now, she is paged occasionally and told to go to a certain client's hotel room. Or she is told to go to the service's hotel room and wait five minutes for a man to come calling. One always does, she said.
Undercover officers say that when they do make contact with a real bordello, its operators usually tell them to call back from a pay phone before giving out their address. Someone from the operation then looks out the window to see if the client is a recognized officer.
If he is, the receptionist just hangs up. Should an officer get in the front door, he will be questioned by a worker and asked for several forms of identification before he is allowed to pass.
"They have closed-circuit cameras, lookouts and sometimes vastly superior technology," said Captain Costello, the Manhattan South vice squad officer, adding that officers often show up at an establishment to find that their cover has already been blown.
"They say they're sorry, we're closed," he said. "Then, you're just standing there looking like a jerk."
 
After Crackdowns, A Changing Market
Although prostitutes have thrived behind closed doors, their counterparts on the street have had far less luck in evading the law. The city's police crackdown on streetwalking began in 1994, when more than 9,500 prostitutes and clients were arrested. Clients found their names being published and vehicles taken away, while judges proved less likely to allow prostitutes back on the street without jail sentences.
Experts say the crackdown has cut the number of streetwalkers in half in some parts of the city, and repeat offenders are fewer.
The number of convictions per prostitute has also declined, with 50 percent of the prostitutes now seen by the court having no more than one prior conviction, said Michele Svirdoff, research director at the Midtown Community Court's Center for Court Innovation.
"When the court first opened, it was not unusual to see defendants who had 100 prior arrests on their sheet," she said. "Now, a majority of those we are seeing are novices. What that tells is that the market is changing."
 
Upturn in Consumerism Is Increasing Prostitution
Like any service industry, prostitution is affected by the economy, and both sociologists and prostitutes can cite numerous economic reasons that it flourishes in New York City. For one, in a city where well-paying, low-skill jobs are scarce and the unemployment rate, nearly 9 percent, is well above the national average, the lure of prostitution can be high. At the same time, experts say, demand for prostitutes has been increasing sharply now that clients have more disposable income and tourism and convention business is booming.
"Prostitution is a market-related economy, so if there is a lot of consumerism, then it grows," said Professor Moglia of New York University. "And an increase in tourism obviously increases prostitution because it is an increase in consumerism."
The operator of Redlightnet, the on-line prostitution clearinghouse, who spoke on condition that his name not be given, said more ads were coming in and more prostitutes were going on line every week.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign for safer streets, he said, had unwittingly helped his businesses. "He has generally made the streets safer for all New Yorkers and tourists, and more tourists means more hookers here to take care of them."

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
8 Nations Adopt Strategy on Jobs

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Russia and the world's seven top industrialized nations, the so-called G-7, adopted a jobs strategy today that seeks to combine free-market incentives with providing jobs for low-skilled workers.
Much of the group's communique, issued by labor and finance ministers after two days of meetings, sounded similar to strategies for dealing with the effect of globalization and technology debated at three previous jobs conferences. 
 However, the eight countries -- the United States, Russia, Japan, Canada, Britain, Germany, France and Italy -- promised to submit proposals detailing how they will carry out the strategy at a meeting in Birmingham, England in May.
The seven-point plan includes fostering entrepreneurship, offering incentives to welfare recipients to work, encouraging lifelong learning and loosening up on state regulations that hamper small and medium-sized businesses.

HEADLINE: Officials Say Surplus Is for Patching Budgets, Not New York

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
For the second straight year, New York City is expecting a huge budget surplus. But at the same time, its public works often seem to be on the verge of collapse, with bricks raining down from schools, streets caving in, and students learning in bathrooms in crowded schools with coal furnaces.
The question, then, naturally arises: Why not spend the city's $1.2 billion surplus to fix the city's deteriorating infrastructure, the same way a homeowner might use a bonus from work to put on a new roof? 
 But city officials are holding on tight to their extra money, saying they need it for those difficult years that are sure to come. Many lawmakers agree, despite the seemingly unending need to mend an aging city.
"Being a parent whose children went to a school that was a coal-burner, I understand their worries," said Herbert E. Berman, the chairman of the City Council Finance Committee, whose children attended Public School 203 in Brooklyn. "But as legislators, we can't spend wildly. Someone has to make the hard choices."
Nothing legally bars Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the Council from dipping into the surplus to build a new elementary school in Jackson Heights, Queens, or to replace century-old water mains in lower Manhattan. In fact, the $1.2 billion surplus is so large that it could pay for 30 new schools, as well as for 200 others to have their coal furnaces converted to ones running on gas.
But officials who will decide the final shape of the city's $34.3 billion budget for the next fiscal year say that an intractable problem prevents them from such spending: the inevitability of budget deficits. Simply put, the city in most years spends more than it collects in revenues -- and those deficits are expected to return and grow. But this year and last have been exceptionally good for the city's coffers, leaving City Hall awash in money, most of it from soaring profits on Wall Street.
Officials note, however, that that stream of revenue could soon stop flowing, and they argue that the current surplus should be used to patch up deficits that are anticipated in future years. With that in mind, Mr. Giuliani last month proposed using 73 percent of this year's surplus to help close the expected budget gap of $2.1 billion for the next fiscal year, which begins in July.
The city is already planning to spend $4 billion to $5 billion annually over the next five years on its sewers, roads and buildings. That money is included in a separate capital budget. But many advocates and independent fiscal monitors say that the city's public works have fallen into such disrepair that drastic action is needed, like dipping into the surplus in its regular budget, and using that money for specific, urgent repairs.
"Given the fact that there is a surplus, spending more on critically needed infrastructure makes a lot of sense," said Douglas A. Criscitello, director of the city's Independent Budget Office, a city-financed watchdog agency that the Mayor wants abolished. "Infrastructure improvements are an important economic development tool. When a business is looking to locate here, they're going to look around at infrastructure very broadly. Can their employees send their kids to good schools? Are the parks up to snuff?"
Even politicians who want to save the surplus for the future quickly acknowledged that the nation's oldest city has unlimited physical needs. Sheldon S. Leffler, a Queens Democrat and a member of the Council's Finance Committee, pointed to the public schools -- with their decrepit buildings, crowded classrooms, and closets, bathrooms and trailers used for instruction -- as having the greatest need.
Officials cited other major needs across the city, like backed-up sewers that periodically flood southeastern Queens, an ancient water main leaking under Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, and the Third Water Tunnel, whose construction began in 1970 but was halted during the city's fiscal crisis in the 1970's.
The city finances capital projects by issuing long-term bonds, which are repaid over 20 to 30 years, in keeping with the view that several generations of taxpayers should share the cost of rebuilding a road or bridge. And it keeps that capital budget completely separate from its $34.3 billion operating budget.
Even if it wanted to dip into that operating budget, there would be limitations: about 90 percent of it cannot be touched, because the money is used to pay for salaries, benefits and programs mandated by Albany and Washington.
So the annual debate over the budget essentially revolves around the remaining 10 percent. And the emergence of the budget surplus has intensified the debate about tapping into the operating budget for capital needs.
But experts caution that an economic slowdown or a decline in the stock market could quickly eliminate the surplus, again forcing the city to close budget deficits through unpopular measures, like cutting services or raising taxes -- something the Republican Mayor has shunned.
"Once we fix our gaps, then I'll get engaged in a debate" over how to use the surplus, Joseph J. Lhota, the Mayor's budget director, said. "But I think it's irresponsible to use that money at this point. All they're basically saying is, 'Take that money, use it for this other project and cut some other services,' without ever telling us what to cut."
The city is anticipating a budget deficit of about $2 billion to re-emerge in the next fiscal year. The gap is expected to widen at the turn of the century, with the city expected to spend more on a new contract with its municipal workers.
The city is legally bound to balance its operating budget every year. That is why Mr. Giuliani wants to use 73 percent of this year's surplus to help close next year's projected deficit, with the rest being used to finance programs and make up for revenues lost to tax cuts.
At the same time, the city is trying to patch up its aging public structures. Like many of the city's current problems, officials say those problems are rooted in the city's fiscal crisis of a generation ago, when it fell behind in maintaining its roads, bridges and other public works.
By the mid 1980's, the Williamsburg Bridge and other spans were in serious danger because they had not been painted for years, the most visible signs of the city's deteriorating infrastructure. And so the city borrowed heavily to rebuild itself, especially in the late 1980's.
Today, the city is saddled with $30 billion in outstanding debt. This year, the city is spending about $3 billion to pay interest and principal on the debt. Those debt service costs are a big cause of the anticipated budget deficits in coming years.
In fact, some fiscal monitors suggest that this year's surplus provides an opportunity to move away from its old practice of issuing debt to finance improvements of public works. Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, said the city could use the money to retire long-term debts -- or to pay cash for capital projects.
"We would support using the surplus that way if it was a really serious infrastructure need that everybody would benefit from," he said.
Mr. Criscitello, the director of the city's Independent Budget Office, said he favored earmarking some of the surplus for physical improvements to the city, instead of cutting about $774 million in taxes over the next four years, as the Mayor has proposed.
While Mr. Giuliani has argued that cutting taxes would create jobs, Mr. Criscitello said that poorly maintained parks and crumbling school buildings could send middle-class families packing -- and the city would ultimately lose their tax receipts.
It is an argument that advocacy groups for the city's public schools take even further. Pointing to a $2.4 billion state school construction bond act that was narrowly defeated in November but garnered the support of more than 70 percent of city residents, they say New Yorkers want their elected officials to spend more on schools.
Gail B. Nayowith, executive director of the Citizens Committee for Children of New York, suggested that a third of the surplus should be spent on renovating schools and child-care centers.
As a chief financial officer, "the Mayor's plan deals responsibly, in part, with the reality of limited resources and budget deficits in the future," she said. "But for the Mayor of a city, it really does make sense to redevelop your infrastructure."
