HEADLINE: Race Discrimination Furthers Income Inequality

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Feb. 17 editorial on black-white income inequality repeats the claim that "such inequality is more a problem of poor education, weak skills and the rise in single-parent families than of race." In fact, continuing racial discrimination plays an important role in perpetuating this inequality. 
 The evidence for continuing housing discrimination is strong. A 1989 national study found that blacks were shown about 25 percent fewer housing units than were equally qualified whites, and over the last four years similar studies have found no sign of a downward trend.
Discrimination in housing restricts the access of blacks to good school districts and therefore contributes to the black-white skill differential. Housing discrimination also limits the access of blacks to neighborhoods near jobs and helps confine many black households to high-poverty neighborhoods.
Studies of hiring practices have documented continuing hiring discrimination against young black men. Racial discrimination still has a lot to do with the black-white income gap, and anti-discrimination policy has a key role to play in bringing incomes closer together.
 
JOHN YINGER
Syracuse, Feb. 17, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of economics and public administration at Syracuse University.

HEADLINE: NASA Must Reignite Research, Panel Says

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TO fulfill dreams of exploring the solar system, finding planets around distant stars or possibly traveling to other worlds, the United States needs to invest more in key space-related technologies that no one else is developing, experts say.
One secret of NASA's recent success in using small, relatively inexpensive spacecraft to explore outer space has been in adapting existing technologies and off-the-shelf components for these budget-conscious missions, such as last year's Mars Pathfinder triumph. 
 But a panel of scientists and engineers looking into what will be needed for further exploration in coming decades says there are limits to this approach of adapting general technical know-how for space applications. If the National Aeronautics and Space Administration wants to continue meaningful research beyond the Earth in a time of constrained budgets, it says, the agency needs to explore new technology unique to its goals.
"Although NASA has recently proved adept at incorporating modern technologies into its spacecraft, the agency currently supports relatively little work in long-term space technology development," said a report published this month by a committee of the National Research Council, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences.
The committee of engineers, scientists and aerospace experts said NASA should devote modest, but consistent, amounts of money to several areas of research with the potential of producing unique technology for space applications. The panel identified six areas that should get priority for additional research and development, and suggested that significant advancement could be made in each field with modest investments of $3 million to $5 million a year for up to five years.
"There have been previous reports on future space technology, but they all assumed that there would be new funding for the work," said the panel's chairman, Dr. Daniel E. Hastings, chief scientist for the Air Force. "NASA asked us to tell it what to invest in, but to assume that the budget was not increasing. The agency wanted to know where it could get the most return for the modest investment it was able to make."
NASA has a history of inconsistent support of new technology, Dr. Hastings said, too often backing research with near-term, not long-range, payoffs, and following fads and changing directions every few years. "You can't make progress with this oscillation of funding, with some research getting a lot of money for a while, then little or nothing," he said. "We recommended setting a few priorities and giving them steady support until they prove themselves or not."
These are the six technological areas in which the panel said additional research and development could produce significant advances for space exploration between the years 2000 and 2020:
*High data-rate, wideband communications covering planetary distances. Instead of conventional radio communications, new systems could use microwave or optical transmissions based on laser technologies. This would require research into pinpoint tracking and pointing methods as well as high-efficiency, low-power lasers. Such systems could transmit so much more data over greater distances than traditional approaches that robots on other planets could send live, high-resolution images to Earth as they explored.
*Microelectromechanical systems for space. Microscopic sensors, gears, switches and other devices being developed for industries such as electronics and computers could be used to create small, low-cost, low-energy sensors and devices for spacecraft. Ultimately, this technology might create a new generation of miniature spacecraft that could hitchhike into space aboard larger craft or be fired into orbit by cannons or other gun launchers.
*Radiation-resistant computer memories and electronics. Radiation in space can damage computer chips and sensitive electronics, a problem made more acute as such devices decrease in size. More research could lead to new types of low-mass shielding, radiation-resistant circuitry materials and better ways to recover data disrupted or damaged by atomic particles.
*Nuclear power systems for space. To power deep space missions too far from the Sun to run on solar energy, or to produce high peak power for bases on the Moon or Mars, requires compact, durable and reliable nuclear reactors or thermoelectric generators. Research is needed on advanced nuclear systems that use less atomic fuel, are more efficient and have greater safety margins than current ones. Environmentalists and others opposed to sending nuclear material into space mounted protests in October when NASA sent the Cassini spacecraft on a roundabout journey to Saturn.
*Precision-controlled large space structures. Large, lightweight structures, including expanding antennas, inflatable supports, extendable girders, and multiple, moving telescope mirrors, are difficult to control in weightless environments. Research is needed to make them less susceptible to temperature changes, vibration and other disrupting factors. In addition, work is needed on precisely controlling the orientation and movement of these structures so that they are stable platforms for scientific instruments that must be pointed with extreme accuracy.
*Methods for extracting and using natural resources found in space. The cost of planetary exploration and establishing bases on the Moon or other worlds might be greatly reduced by developing methods of mining and refining raw materials on the site for oxygen, rocket fuel and building materials for structures. Research is needed on robotic systems to move and prepare materials, as well as on methods to process them and store the resulting products. Proponents of mounting a manned Mars mission shortly after the turn of the century espouse using this approach as a way of making it economically feasible.
The NASA official who received the new report, Samuel Venneri, the agency's chief technologist, said the conclusions were consistent with NASA's thinking and direction. "NASA is moving toward being a more aggressive research and development agency," Mr. Venneri said. "We've already taken some of the recommendations and expanded them. This report is an independent assessment of the direction we are taking of doing more research and getting out of operational areas, such as running the space shuttle system."
Mr. Venneri said the agency is spending less than the study recommended on research into nuclear power and mining resources on the moon, asteroids and other planets. "We are supporting some efforts in these areas, but have to invest less in them for now because of the priorities of other projects, such as the space station."
In other areas, such as research into building and controlling large objects in space, support well exceeds the study's recommendations, he noted.
At NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., and other centers, work is under way toward building large orbiting astronomical observatories, including a next-generation optical instrument to replace the Hubble Space Telescope and a Space Interferometry Mission to study the motion of stars, black holes and distant galaxies.
Dr. Stephen C. Unwin, deputy project scientist for the interferometry mission, said that with sufficient money, researchers hope to launch the observatory into orbit around the Earth's poles in 2005. Designed to be flown on a small, inexpensive Delta 2 rocket, the 3,750-pound observatory would unfurl a 35-foot-long boom holding seven telescopes with 12-inch diameter mirrors.
The spacecraft, with its telescopes operated in pairs with one in reserve, would lock onto distant guide stars and stabilize its position while measuring light falling on pairs of mirrors at slightly different times and angles. Combining light from a star or galaxy that hits separate mirrors at time differences measured in billionths of a second requires precise control, scientists say.
"We've chosen an almost circular, polar orbit to keep the spacecraft in sunlight most of the time," Dr. Unwin said. "We don't want the structure creaking or moving while adjusting to temperature changes caused by moving between shadow and sun. We need a very stable spacecraft."
Dr. Keith E. Wilson, a senior engineer in the optical communications group at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, said he would welcome the added research money in laser communications recommended by the study. "The work we have done so far is very promising, but we have not ironed out all of the issues," Dr. Wilson said. "With a small, added investment, we could answer many of the remaining questions."
There was a successful demonstration of some of this capability in December 1992 when the Galileo spacecraft sped past Earth on its way to Jupiter. During the Galileo Optical Experiment, narrow laser beams were sent from the Earth for the first time to a deep-space craft. Over eight days, Galileo detected light pulses from Earth at distances between 300,000 miles and 3.5 million miles away, record distances for such transmissions, Dr. Wilson said.
And in a seven-month experiment ending in May 1996, Dr. Wilson and colleagues demonstrated the first ground-to-space, two-way optical communications when laser pulses were transmitted between a Japanese satellite and ground stations a dozen times. "You can easily see the potential for optical communications," Dr. Wilson said, "and it looks very promising."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
The Fed's relatively high interest rate hasn't cut growth.

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
WHILE market interest rates have fallen sharply over the last 10 months, one rate has not budged.
The Federal funds rate, which is the Federal Reserve's target for short-term interest rates, has been at 5.5 percent since last March. After adjusting for the decline in inflation, the real rate is actually more than half a percentage point higher than it was a year ago. 
 "One might have thought that would have slowed the economy," said N. Gregory Mankiew, a professor of economics at Harvard. "It is a little surprising that it hasn't."
The Fed funds target rate -- practically, the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans -- is the Fed's main tool for guiding the economy. Higher rates make it more costly to borrow and mean less fuel for the economy.
But the best measure of how hard the Fed is pulling on the economic reins is this rate after inflation, or the real rate. If the Fed funds rate is 6 percent but inflation is 6 percent, the real rate is zero, and the Fed is letting the economy run.
The economy's strength now in the face of a relatively high real rate highlights the potential problems for Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who begins his report on monetary policy to Congress today.
Both the stock and bond markets have rallied this year on the view that economic turmoil in Asia will keep the United States economy from overheating by cutting demand for American exports. The sharp currency devaluations in Asia are also expected to curb inflation since imports from the region will be much cheaper. The consensus is that the Fed will leave its interest rate target unchanged, even though there are no significant signs of a slowdown in the 3.9 percent pace of growth last year.
But the weak tug from the high real Fed funds rate indicates that Asian influences may not slow the economy as much as many forecasters expect. Then the Fed would feel increasing pressure to keep inflation from returning by raising its short-term interest rate target, which would upset both the stock and bond markets.
The other risk is that the economy is slowed more by Asia then expected. Then real rates, which seem benign in this strong economy, could suddenly begin to bite. With high real rates acting as a drag on the economy, the Fed would have an incentive to cut its target. "If growth slowed down to 2 percent this would be the hot debate at the Fed," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "Are these real rates too high?"
The real Federal fund rate is not dragging down the economy now because consumers are spending freely, encouraged by the "wealth effect" from the stock market run-up of the last three years. The new highs being recorded by major market indexes just reinforce the trend.
Henry Kaufman, an economist and money manager, says that high real rates can have much more impact when the economy is slowing down or in a recession. Given the robust growth now, he said, "this level of real rates is not a restrictive influence."
Another factor is that many companies want to invest in new technology, causing them to ignore the higher real rates. So business investment, another important engine of growth, has kept chugging along. "This level of real rates does not slow down the robust capital spending we have had," said Wayne D. Angell, a former Fed governor and now chief economist at Bear Stearns.
Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, takes another tack. First, he dismisses the contention that Asia is going to lead to a major slowdown in the United States.
While the real Federal funds rates has gone up, other real rates have declined, he points out. The 10-year rate, adjusted for inflation, has fallen to 3.69 percent in January from 4.05 percent last May, while the real Fed funds rate has risen to 3.89 percent from 3.27 percent. The 10-year rate is a common benchmark for setting fixed-rate mortgages.
Mr. Greenspan noted the trend when answering questions from the Senate Budget Committee last month. The rising real Federal funds rate was effectively "tightening" monetary policy last year, he said, but the impact was not "spilling over into long-term rates."
Part of the reason other real rates have fallen, Mr. Barbera said, is that Asians have stopped borrowing. "We are not competing as much for funds," he said.
This stimulus from lower real rates can be seen in the robust housing market, he says. Retail sales are also stronger then they seem, he said, because prices, not unit sales, have fallen.
In his testimony to the Senate Budget Committee late last month, Mr. Greenspan indicated that he was depending on Asia to curb growth here. And in the December policy meeting the Fed went to a neutral stance from one that assumed that the next rate move would be up. So of the two economic risks, a stronger-than-expected economy would surprise the Fed the most.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq at New Closing High as Technology Shares Soar

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Technology stocks soared yesterday as investors brushed aside concerns about the impact of Asia's economic woes on American corporate profits, catapulting the Nasdaq composite index to a new closing high.
The technology-laden index rose 23.63 points, to 1,751.76, eclipsing its old high of 1,745.85 reached on Oct. 9 by 5.9 points. Other indexes were mixed, however, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 3.74 points, to 8,410.20, but the broader Standard & Poor's 500 up 3.93 points, to 1,038.14. 
 Many analysts viewed the Nasdaq gains as a positive sign for the overall market, paving the way for the 1998 rally to continue.
"It tells you that maybe not right away, but in time, the United States economy is going to recover from this Asian-induced soft landing," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany.
Eugene Peroni Jr., director of technical research at Janney Montgomery Scott, said the Nasdaq's ability to hit a new high on the heels of a string of records by both the Dow and the S.& P. "might introduce further buying and renewed investor confidence.
"Its stronger performance helps to fortify the advance that's already taken place," he said.
Several of the stocks that led the Nasdaq higher yesterday -- like Microsoft, Intel and Dell Computer -- have recouped all of the losses sustained during the fourth quarter, when technology shares fell amid concerns that the economic turmoil in Asia would hurt their profits.
After falling 2.31 percent in the fourth quarter, Microsoft is up 24.9 percent so far this year; Intel is up 34.3 percent, after slipping 23.9 percent, and Dell has risen 54.9 percent, after a 13.3 percent fall.
However, Oracle, which fell 38.7 percent in the fourth quarter, has regained less than half of that loss, rising 18.2 percent this year. Also, Applied Materials, another of the index's worst performers at the end of 1997, falling 36.8 percent in the fourth quarter, has recouped only a portion of its loss, rising 24.1 percent this year.
Over all, the Nasdaq, which fell 7.35 percent in the fourth quarter, is up 11.6 percent this year.
Microsoft gained ground yesterday on investor enthusiasm for the company's 2-for-1 stock split. In moving higher, the company edged closer to becoming only the second company to have a market capitalization of more than $200 billion. Now, General Electric holds that distinction, with a value of $254 billion.
Even as the Nasdaq caught up with the other major indexes by reaching a record high, those market gauges were mixed. The Dow was dragged down by oil company shares such as Chevron and Exxon. Investors retreated from oil stocks on expectations that an agreement between the United Nations and Iraq over weapons inspections would ease concerns of oil supply shortages stemming from conflict in the Persian Gulf.
Countering the slide in oil shares was a 6-point gain by Merck, which rose 4.6 percent, to 130 5/8, on news that the Food and Drug Administration had approved the sale of a new product, the first once-a-day pill for the prevention and treatment of asthma.
Despite the strong gains in the Nasdaq, trading was muted, as investors limited their activity prior to Congressional testimony of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, which begins today.
Analysts were divided on whether the Nasdaq's run could continue.
The recent gains have been concentrated in the larger companies that make up the index, they point out, with smaller companies' stocks continuing to be sluggish.
If smaller-company shares were to begin performing better than large capitalization issues, Mr. Peroni said, "I would be a little bit more concerned" that investors were willing to take on more risk, raising the possibility of a selloff.
But Thomas Galvin, chief equity strategist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, said he believed that the recent gains already left technology shares poised for a slide.
"We've had this Asia relief rally because technology got the most banged up in the fourth quarter, but I would tend to believe that technology has got to take a break," Mr. Galvin said. "I think the consensus view is that Asia is behind us."
But as the economies and businesses in those countries struggle to regain their financial footing, American companies may yet feel some reverberations later in the year, he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Pitfalls in Cutting Korea's Lifetime Work Force

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
When this country's most militant labor union shelved a potentially crippling strike early this month, fears started to fade that the chances for South Korean economic recovery would be set back by debilitating labor unrest.
But the pace and scope of change in the nation's labor practices, regarded as an indispensable part of getting the Korean economy back on its feet, are of increasing concern to foreign investors and economists. 
 If they were expecting restructuring along the lines of Eastman Kodak, AT&T, I.B.M. or scores of other American and European companies, where thousands of jobs were eliminated, they are likely to be disappointed.
The greatest barrier to sweeping job cuts in South Korea is the country's business culture, with its tradition of lifetime employment. "What you'll see will be grudging, gradualist adjustments," said Richard Samuelson, head of research at SBC Warburg Dillon Read here, "along the lines of 2 percent here, 5 percent there -- which may be followed six months later by another 2 or 5 percent."
So jobs will disappear, but not overnight.
One of the strings attached to the International Monetary Fund's $58 billion bailout of the South Korean economy was a demand for greater labor flexibility -- a euphemism for scrapping laws rigidly protecting workers from layoffs. Analysts and economists figure that the I.M.F. plan means at least a million people will lose their jobs this year, which they view as the bare minimum needed to weed out the excesses of South Korea's bloated corporations.
But reaching that number quickly, and thus hastening a recovery, will not be easy, given the tactics that South Korean companies are likely to use: "honorary retirement," similar to early retirement in the United States, and the attrition and hiring freezes that companies have been using to prune their work forces since the middle of last year.
The National Assembly has provided some help, recently approving legislation that will make layoffs easier. Under the new law, mergers and acquisitions will be the easiest way to eliminate large numbers of workers, and the law scrapped requirements that forced a company to go to court for approval -- a long and difficult process.
It is a sort of enticement for South Korea's conglomerates to consolidate, but its other main purpose is to lure investments and takeovers by foreigners.
In fact, many in the labor movement and in business think the Government is hoping that the messy, unpopular task of laying off masses of workers will fall to foreigners. "That's why this law was introduced in the first place," said Yoon Young Mo, international secretary of the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions, which canceled the threatened strike -- although not before delivering a setback to the recovering stock market and spurring a drop in the value of South Korea's currency, the won.
"We believe the mergers and acquisitions by foreigners the law is encouraging will lead to mass dismissals," Mr. Yoon said.
Although he refused to rule out future strikes by confederation members, Mr. Yoon predicted that as unemployment soared, it would set off a panic among an increasingly desperate public with nowhere to turn for relief in a society where lifetime employment and ironclad familial loyalty had until now made a social safety net unnecessary.
But in the same way that the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions does not want to be blamed by the public for derailing a recovery, foreign investors are wary of being blamed for the economic pain the country and its citizens will undergo in the next year or two.
Perhaps that is why Citibank and Chase Manhattan, long rumored as respective suitors for the failed First Korea Bank and Seoul Bank, have put any discussions on hold for now. The prospect of cutting a significant number of jobs and then trying to sell retail banking services to those former employees' families and neighbors is daunting.
"Foreigners are going to be cautious about investing in businesses which need to be radically restructured, particularly when it comes to layoffs," said Michael S. Brown, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Korea.
While public unrest could show up in strikes, business and labor leaders say that President-elect Kim Dae Jung, a former political prisoner who has long been aligned with the labor movement, is well positioned to mediate.
To understand how deep Mr. Kim's ties to labor lie, consider the sentiments of Ahn Pong Sul, director of the international department of the Federation of Korean Trade Unions, the largest labor organization, with 1.5 million members. "If we had not elected him," Mr. Ahn said in an interview, "I would have left this country because there would have been no hope for me and my family."
Mr. Kim was possibly the only South Korean politician capable of coaxing labor to sit down at a table with management and Government officials and hammer out the blueprint for revamping the economy that led to the new legislation -- which also includes significant and painful changes for corporations and steep budget cuts for the Government.
Once all parties signed off on the blueprint, reneging became extremely difficult. Almost immediately after it was signed, all sides expressed dissatisfaction with it, so the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions' threat to strike because it objected to certain provisions seemed churlish.
The agreement, the first of its kind in the country's history, is expected to act as a restraint on the labor movement. "I don't expect labor to attempt to disrupt the economy because that would be the opposite of what everyone is working to accomplish," said Lee Yong Hwan, executive director of the Federation of Korean Industries, a business organization. "Times have changed; the militant labor union is not as militant as it was two or three years ago."
Mr. Ahn of the Federation of Korean Trade Unions put it a different way. "Please remember that Asia, including Korea, is rooted in Confucian values that emphasize harmony and respectful relations among different classes and peoples," he said. "In difficult situations, those values get stronger."
How to rapidly change the economy without engaging in mass layoffs remains a quandary, however. The Government, which insisted on the layoff legislation, sent a conflicting message a few days ago, when Labor Minister Lee Ki Ho warned of "harsh retaliation" against employers who abused the new law.
Given the law's stringent requirements, including a 60-day notification to union representatives, full severance pay for laid-off workers and a promise to hire them back once business improved, making use of it in the way that the I.M.F. intended may be difficult.

HEADLINE: J. P. Morgan Weighs Merger And Cuts Jobs

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company, frustrated in its efforts to become a major investment banking concern, said yesterday that it would consider a merger, a once unthinkable option for a company that has historically prided itself on determining its own fate. The company also said that it would dismiss about 5 percent of its employees, or some 700 people.
In an internal memo circulated yesterday at the New York headquarters of Morgan, the company's chairman and chief executive, Douglas A. Warner, said that a merger with another institution was "an option" that the bank was considering in an effort to vault to the top of the investment banking world. Bank advisers said that Morgan has been seriously considering a big merger in recent weeks but that no transaction was imminent. 
 The memo also said that layoffs were necessary "so that expected revenue growth exceeds expense growth" in 1998. But even with the job cuts, Morgan does not expect to reduce its overall expenses sharply, a sticking point with analysts who have long complained that the bank's operating budget is bloated.
The layoffs are expected to occur over the next two weeks and will affect employees worldwide and in every line of business. Morgan laid off about 5 percent of its employees, or about 850 people, in early 1995. At that time the bank employed about 17,000 people. Today it employs about 14,000 people.
Bank advisers see Goldman, Sachs & Company as one of the most ideal partners for Morgan, but Goldman's more aggressive company culture and the fact that Goldman executives would want to run the combined concern are considered to be likely deal breakers. Other potential merger partners include the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Credit Suisse Group. Although there was speculation recently that Deutsche Bank A.G. was considering a merger with Morgan, bank advisers said no such talks were taking place.
For his part, Mr. Warner has not found a partner that suits him. His memo said that "no strategic merger yet envisioned matches the promise of our own growth strategy if we execute it successfully."
The problem for Morgan, however, is that it has yet to execute its strategy of transforming itself from a traditional commercial bank into an investment bank as successfully as it needs to do. Investment banking's leaders -- Merrill Lynch & Company, Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Goldman -- still dominate such businesses as stock and bond underwriting and mergers and acquisitions, so it will not be easy for any company to steal market share from them.
That is not to say that Morgan has not made substantial strides reinventing itself from a legendary, blue-chip bank that once held uncontested access to the cream of America's corporate giants.
In 1980, when Morgan began pursuing investment banking opportunities, about half of its revenue came from such traditional businesses as corporate lending and advising clients on the outlook for interest rates. In recent years, about 75 percent of its revenue has come from new lines of business like trading and underwriting.
Indeed, Morgan is so proud of its accomplishments that Mr. Warner keeps a laminated newspaper article in his office commemorating the date eight years ago when regulators first gave the bank permission to underwrite stocks.
But while the bank now has a more diverse and sophisticated financial arsenal at its disposal, the company has not risen to the top of the investment banking business and its profitability has been sacrificed in the process.
Morgan recently reported fourth-quarter profits of $271 million, a 35.3 percent drop from the $419 million the bank earned in the fourth quarter of 1996. For all of 1997, Morgan earned $1.465 billion, down 6.7 percent from the $1.57 billion it earned in 1996.
Mr. Warner noted in his memo that Morgan's stock price "is lagging competitors' and some observers have questioned the viability of our strategy." He pointed to the bank's problems in Southeast Asia -- Morgan recently recognized $587 million in Asian currency swaps as nonperforming and is embroiled in a rancorous legal dispute with South Korean companies involving such swaps -- and bloated expenses as the culprits dragging down the stock. The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, another bank with heavy Asian exposure, is also considering layoffs in its Asian operations and Chase Manhattan expects some substantial layoffs this year.
"Stronger financial results must be a priority," Mr. Warner said in the memo. The bank plans to focus on derivatives trading, risk management, asset management, emerging markets, mergers and acquisitions, and stock and bond underwriting. It is not clear what will happen to such businesses as public finance.
While there has been talk within Morgan of another major reorganization of senior executives following a reshuffling that took place in December, there is no sign that a shake-up is planned. But Morgan employees say that the bank's presidency, a position currently held by Mr. Warner, is likely to be awarded to another person at the bank because Mr. Warner is believed to have too many demands on his time. Leading candidates for that job are Peter Hancock, who oversees the bank's fixed-income and credit businesses, and Ramon de Oliveira, head of Morgan's asset management business.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
TV's Olympic Ads: Straight From Dullsville

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Now it can be told. As if all the reasons viewers shunned CBS's coverage of the 18th Olympic Winter Games weren't enough to chill network executives, there was yet one more: dreadfully dull commercials.
Oh sure, the network's presentation was lackluster and few if any athletes stood out amid the parka-clad crowds. Yes, events were postponed repeatedly by bad weather and delayed because of the 14-hour time difference with Japan. And it may be true that Americans are no longer willing to devote three hours or more an evening to watching teen-agers on ice skates. 
 But the myriad shortcomings of the Games -- evident apparently even to CBS, which played "Let's Call the Whole Thing Off" during the closing credits on Sunday night -- were more than matched by the poor performance of Madison Avenue. One advertiser after another flopped, failed or fizzled, turning in showings that made Todd Eldredge and Alberto Tomba seem like champions by comparison. To put it another way, marketers treated consumers the way members of the United States men's hockey team treated their rooms.
The pedestrian and uninspired results of the Olympic competition among advertisers, coming so soon after the paucity of breakthrough spots during Super Bowl XXXII, proved again that the evil of banality may be more inimical to pitching products than all the complaints about clutter, overcommercialization or ratings shortfalls that required the running of additional "make-good" ads.
Now it's time to award imaginary medals in this column's post-Olympics advertising review. Some of the horrifying commercials received the feared lead medal for base, and debased, performance. Some of the many spots that rang falsely were presented tin medals. Not surprisingly, only a handful qualified for gold.
Here are a baker's dozen examples of how advertisers and their agencies fared:
AMERICAN AIRLINES -- A young woman working for the American Airlines unit of the AMR Corporation fawned over a corporate fat cat traveling in first class whose daughter has given birth. Her gushing over her wealthy customer was obsequious enough to turn die-hard Republicans into committed Communists. Lead. Agency: Temerlin McClain, part of True North Communications.
CBS -- Some promotional spots for the CBS network unit of the CBS Corporation were cute, particularly one that spoofed the Apple Computer "Think different" campaign by urging viewers to "Think funny." But commercials with Olympic themes fell flat, especially those replete with lame stereotypes about the French (they like cheese and Jerry Lewis, dislike bathing) and Italians (they act like cast members of "The Godfather"). Lead. Agency: in-house.
DIET COKE -- The Coca-Cola Company's second-most-popular product was reduced to an irrelevant prop in two sets of somnolent serial spots about a father's awkward dialogue with his daughter and a son being cross-examined by a pair of puzzled (and puzzling) parents. Lead. Agency: Wieden & Kennedy.
EASTMAN KODAK -- Commercials for Max film from the Eastman Kodak Company showed how conventional "problem-solution" advertising could be effectively freshened. The pitfalls of using the wrong film were dramatized on a picture-taking trip through Hollywood as Burt Reynolds came out as "Blurred Reynolds" and a photograph of Doris Day's signature at the Chinese Theater turned into "Wrong time of day." Gold. Agency: Ogilvy & Mather, a unit of WPP Group.
FORD -- An image campaign for the Ford-brand vehicles sold by the Ford Motor Company, featuring the preternaturally avuncular actor John Corbett as pitchman, offered a pastiche of "Our Town," "Northern Exposure" and "A Prairie Home Companion," seemingly set at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich. The campaign carries the theme "Built to last"; let's hope it isn't. Tin. Agency: J. Walter Thompson Detroit, part of WPP.
FRITO-LAY -- A spot for the Frito-Lay unit of Pepsico Inc. presented a curious cross-cultural clash, pitting a Jewish waiter in a delicatessen against an all-American customer who dared eat Deli Style Lay's potato chips in his restaurant. Oy vay! Lead. Agency: DDB Needham New York, part of Omnicom Group.
JOHN HANCOCK -- A moving spot for the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, shown only during the opening and closing ceremonies, eschewed selling policies for an emotional appeal to raise funds for the Sarajevo Olympic Children's Fund, which seeks to rebuild the city that played host to the 1984 Winter Games. Gold. Agency: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.
KFC -- A commercial that delightfully debunked traditional paeans to the Olympic spirit by showing how people crowded into a living room to watch "Susie's big night" of skating on television could be quickly and easily distracted by a sale on fried chicken. Gold. Agency: Young & Rubicam Advertising.
McDONALD'S -- One commercial, spoofing teary Olympic tributes, elicited laughter when a skater's parents turned out to be too busy eating you-know-where to catch her performance. (Was she named Susie?) But other spots about hockey and skiing were as much fun as a visit to a drive-through window with a malfunctioning microphone. Tin. Agency: DDB Needham Chicago, part of Omnicom.
MICHELOB LIGHT -- A commercial centered on a mystery involving the Michelob Light brand of beer sold by the Anheuser-Busch Companies was as fascinating and absorbing as Jim Nantz, the CBS Olympics host. (And speaking of mysteries, who hired him?) Tin. Agency: Leap Partnership, a unit of the Leap Group.
TYLENOL -- This commercial from Johnson & Johnson, centered on vignettes of people overcoming pain, seems to have been translated from English to German to Japanese to English. An announcer proclaims "We are Tylenol," then intones such puzzling phrases as "How we care is who we are" before concluding that Tylenol is "the most trusted strength in pain relief." Tin. Agency: Saatchi & Saatchi, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.
U.P.S. -- Several commercials for United Parcel Service that were centered on Olympic themes delivered little of interest. One spot celebrated the "snowlets," those annoying symbols of the Winter Games, by showing how popular snowlet merchandise had become in Hong Kong, Singapore and Tokyo. What, is the Asian economic crisis over already? Another spot cheered on an athlete who was a U.P.S. driver by day and a "speed-hungry, bobsledding missile" by night. Commuters along his route must pray he never confuses day for night. Lead. Agency: Ammirati Puris Lintas, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
WENDY'S -- Here were spots for consumers who like their commercials more stuffed than a Wendy's baked potato. One commercial was overcrowded with R. David Thomas, the founder of Wendy's International Inc., plus various hockey players, the former hockey star Cam Neely and a plug for an in-store game called "Go for the Goals." Lead. Agency: Bates USA, part of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C.
Will the woes of the 1998 Winter Games affect coming competitions? While advertisers and agencies are likely to try using the problems CBS confronted in Nagano as leverage to pay less for commercial time, giant global marketers -- including Coca-Cola, McDonald's, the AT&T Corporation and Visa International -- are already planning their ad ploys for future Olympics. The Summer Games in 2000 are appealing because they will be played in photogenic Sydney, Australia. And the next Winter Games, in 2002, will be played in Salt Lake City -- and American venues typically mean higher American ratings.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "Going for the Gold, and Baser Metals"

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Rally on Defused Iraqi Crisis Is Short-Lived as Dollar Falls

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
An early bond market rally on the defused Iraqi crisis faded yesterday and left prices lower for the fourth day, hurt by weakness in the dollar and apprehension about the Congressional testimony today by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
Unfounded rumors that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had resigned also contributed to the selling. 
 The 30-year bond fell 14/32, to a price of 103 5/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to a nearly two-week high of 5.90 percent, from 5.87 percent Friday.
The bond market derived some early strength from the accord that eased the threat of a United States-led attack on Iraq. Oil prices plunged to nearly four-year lows on that news, viewed by bond traders as a sign of reduced inflationary pressure.
But bond prices reversed course as the Iraqi news caused a sharp fall in the dollar's value. As the threat of an imminent conflict eased, the bond market turned attention to Mr. Greenspan's twice-yearly report to Congress on the economy.
Some traders said his remarks could pose a risk to bonds if he did not reiterate his fears about the economic crisis in Asia.
Mr. Greenspan has said that Asia's financial problems could result in a United States economic slowdown and deflation, but so far the impact from Asia has been slight.
Another uncertainty that emerged was the impact of the Labor Department's report on January consumer prices, to be reported today.
Although many traders expect the Consumer Price Index to offer further evidence of benign inflation, as the Producer Price Index report did last week, they were not confident enough to buy bonds on that assumption. Others, however, suggested bonds represented a buying opportunity.
"Even if we get a negative surprise in the C.P.I. report, many investors are sure to take comfort in the apparently favorable developments in Iraq over the weekend," said Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Accord With Iraq Pushes Oil Prices Down to 1994 Levels

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The price of crude oil fell sharply yesterday after Iraq and the United Nations Secretary General signed an agreement allowing the inspection of weapons sites, staving off for the present the prospect of United States air attacks and the risk of an interruption of oil supplies.
Yesterday's price decrease -- crude oil futures fell 87 cents, or more than 5 percent, to $15.37 a barrel -- wiped away the last of the rise in prices late in January as expectations of an attack grew. That brief surge now looks more like a blip as yesterday's drop continues a pattern of much of the last year, in which prices have fallen by more than one-third, pushing them down to levels not seen since early in 1994. 
 That has benefited drivers, with prices for 87-octane unleaded gasoline falling below $1 a gallon in some cities. But share prices of oil and oilfield-service companies fell yesterday as analysts and investors calculated that lower retail prices could squeeze earnings.
To be sure, some analysts predicted that prices could not stay at current levels, particularly as demand increases with the approach of spring and summer, when Americans drive more.
But in the short term, they said, prices could drop a bit further before rebounding, amid heavy worldwide supplies. This has been caused in part by a decision in November of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase production to 27.5 million barrels a day from 25 million. Though some members of OPEC were already producing more oil than their quotas called for, the increase in the ceiling has only added to supplies.
An unusually mild winter in the United States, which has reduced the need for heating oil, declining demand in Asia amid the economic crisis and growing production from oil regions like the North Sea have all contributed to plentiful supplies.
There is also the prospect of more oil being pumped. The United Nations Security Council approved a resolution last week that would allow Iraq, under an oil-for-food program, to export $5.2 billion worth of crude oil over a six-month period, compared with the previous limit of $2 billion.
That would enable the Iraqis to pump far more than their current level of roughly one million barrels a day. Some industry experts, however, question whether the country could increase output significantly, at least initially, because its oil equipment has badly deteriorated in the seven years of economic sanctions since the end of the Persian Gulf war.
Though there are oil-industry economists who expect prices to drop as low as $14 a barrel, there are reasons why prices at that level may be short lived.
Demand for gasoline and other oil products has remained strong, particularly in the United States, and could eat into global supplies. Also, there are signs Saudi Arabia, which is now producing about 8.6 million barrels a day, might be willing to cut back to help shore up the price.
Ali Naimi, the Saudi oil minister, suggested last week that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should start reducing their production. He said that if other OPEC countries signaled a willingness to reduce output, his nation's officials would be willing to sit down with the others to see what further cuts might be required.
"The Saudis are willing to do something, but they don't want to be first," said Adam Sieminski, an oil analyst for BT Alex. Brown. But for big producers like Venezuela and Nigeria, as well as Saudi Arabia, where so much public and private revenue is dependent on oil prices, he said, "The pain will ultimately become unbearable, and they will cut a deal to cut production."
James T. Colburn, vice president for energy options at ED&F Man International, a major oil-trading firm, said it would take relatively little -- perhaps a cut of about a million barrels in the OPEC output of 28 million barrels a day, including quota cheating -- to make an impact. "They would not have to cut too much to have this thing pick up again," Mr. Colburn said.
Still, the short-term outlook for low prices depressed oil stocks yesterday. Exxon fell $1.8125, to $62.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mobil was down $2 to $70. Amoco lost $1.25, to $83.3125, and Chevron dropped $2.1875, to $77. A service company, Schlumberger, was down $2.4375, to $72.0625.
Kenneth T. Derr, chairman and chief executive of Chevron, said he was still betting that later this year the price of crude oil will have risen to the $18-to-$20-a-barrel range.
Thus, his company and other major producers are not planning to cut back on their exploration budgets at this point. "I think this a short-term drop in prices," Mr. Derr added.
Whether drivers will continue to enjoy low gasoline prices is also uncertain.
Michael Canes, chief economist of the American Petroleum Institute, the major industry trade group, said that while further drops in crude oil could bring prices at the pump down, drivers were also burning gasoline at a fast pace.
The demand for gasoline was up about 3 percent in January, compared with that a year earlier, he estimated. If such strong demand continued, it could eat up the current high inventories of refined petroleum and retail prices could rise sharply when the seasonal increase in driving begins in March.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Want to Play In New York? Ask Politely

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
WITH the Grammy Awards being held tomorrow night at Radio City Music Hall, it's none too soon to wonder if the recording industry's big show will move to another city next year and become, as a headline writer put it, the Scrammys.
As you may know, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been singing "Hit the Road, Jack" a lot lately. He feels that Michael Greene, the in-your-face chief of the awards presentation, has done insufficient penance for supposedly screaming obscenities and threats at a mayoral assistant. 
 It does sound as if Mr. Greene's behavior was off the charts. But he tried to make nice by sending the aide roses. She threw them back. He then said, "I'm sorry if I offended anyone." Not good enough, the Mayor said yesterday, calling it a "phony apology." He wants an act of full contrition, something closer to the journey to Canossa that Emperor Henry IV made in 1077, when he appeared in penitent's garb before Pope Gregory VII. That, Mr. Greene suggested yesterday, is not about to happen.
What elevates this above a mere spat is that Mr. Giuliani has said the Grammys can go back to Los Angeles, and the heck with their estimated $40 million contribution to the local economy. Shades of last year when the Mayor said he didn't give a hoot if the United Nations left town, taking with it the $3 billion-plus a year that diplomats spend here. (Despite his fondness for "The Godfather," he has a way of standing a line from that movie on its head. Sometimes at City Hall, it isn't business; it's strictly personal.)
Should the Grammys indeed leave New York, "we'll replace that with three other things in a day," the Mayor said. Oh? Like what? So far, he hasn't elaborated.
It would be lovely if the city could wrest the National Spelling Bee from Washington, especially since the reigning champ is a Brooklyn girl, Rebecca A. Sealfon. The much-reviled gathering of the Tailhook Association might make a nice catch. It would show patriotism and faith in the power of redemption. The Modern Language Association's conference, last held in Toronto, is always welcome.
But let's be realistic. It may not be easy to replace an extravaganza like the Grammys, which not only brings in millions of dollars but also allows the city to show itself off before a global television audience of 1.5 billion.
Then again, who knows? Maybe the Mayor has a $40 million surprise up his sleeve. Maybe the Grammys will stay put. Anything can happen in a city as hot as New York, where even a report about flourishing prostitution can be seen as good news. Moralists may take offense. But if prostitutes do well, it means conventioneers and tourists are pouring into town.
ON a different track, the city's fortunes are also reflected in the huge number of out-of-towners applying to the leading private colleges here, Columbia and New York University. The latest figures were announced this month, and they are truly startling.
Columbia College has 12,111 students seeking a mere 955 places in the class of 2002. Applications are up by 39 percent just since 1995. N.Y.U. reports having received about 24,500 applications for 3,000 freshman spots, a 16.5 percent increase from 1997 and a remarkable rise of 115 percent in six years.
Certainly, the two institutions are attractions in themselves. But give Mr. Giuliani credit. Both schools say that the safer, cleaner and livelier New York on his watch is where young people want to be, with their parents' blessing. For L. Jay Oliva, N.Y.U.'s president and a history professor, it evokes visions of pre-Renaissance Paris and Florence.
"Universities in cities have returned to their medieval roots," he said. "They're places of choice for people from all over."
Some might say his school has done almost too good a job. It has drawn so many students from other places that New York City supplies only 20 percent of its undergraduates. To help keep the N.Y. in N.Y.U., the school recently created 20 scholarships for locals, with money from the real-estate developer Lew Rudin, class of '49. It's a start, Dr. Oliva said, to make sure that New York does not lose more ground.
Of course, should the city fall on hard times, the universities might be sitting less pretty, too. "But you also know," Dr. Oliva said, "that this city bounces and rebounds," which, to return to the original subject, is probably worth remembering should this personalized tiff with the Mayor cause the Grammys to hit the road.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Solution for Byproduct of Uranium

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: PADUCAH, Ky., Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Federal Government has been storing a uranium byproduct for so long that some of the 28,000 cylinders stacked in an open yard here are labeled "M.D.," for Manhattan District, leftovers from the project that built the first atom bomb.
After years of studying what to do with its 1.2 billion pounds of the byproduct, depleted uranium in a toxic compound known as uranium hexafluoride, the Energy Department has chosen a solution and this week opened hearings on the plan. 
 The plan is to empty the more than 46,000 cylinders stored at processing plants here in Paducah in the far west of Kentucky near the Illinois border, at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and at Piketon, Ohio, and chemically convert the uranium into safer, more stable forms -- "when economically feasible." That means when the department finds a buyer for the material. And that, say experts, probably means never.
"Is there somebody we can sucker into this?" John A. Volpe, manager of the radiation health and toxic agents branch of the Kentucky Health Department, said at the first hearing, on Thursday. "Maybe somebody inside the Beltway -- there isn't anybody out here."
Presenting options, Charles E. Bradley Jr., the Energy Department program manager for the uranium, listed a variety of possible uses for the uranium cited over the years. But, Mr. Bradley acknowledged, "none of these have yet panned out."
While the department looks for a market to defray the cost of processing the material, estimated at $2 billion to $4 billion, the cylinders, which weigh up to 14 tons each, are sinking into the dirt, where they rust even faster. When a cylinder rusts through, a toxic smoke leaks out.
Today a crew of workers, with a hoisting machine adapted from the logging industry, gingerly lifted one 30-year-old cylinder off its rotting wooden supports, gave it a quick inspection and stacked it nearby on a new concrete stand. The cylinder was one of about 35 they would move today, with thousands already moved and thousands ahead, the leftovers from more than half a century of making uranium fuel.
Removing toxic hydrogen fluoride from the compound and converting the uranium to an oxide or metal form would cost up to an estimated $80,000 a cylinder. Scraping and repainting the cylinders -- most of which are 4 feet in diameter and 12 feet long -- would cost about $1,600 each. So instead they build concrete supports and re-stack them.
Recently the Government signed a contract to paint about 10,000 cylinders in the next 5 years. But at that rate it would take more than 40 years to paint them all, and the new paint lasts only 10 to 12 years.
The material is what is left after a gaseous diffusion plant removes as much as possible of the uranium that is easy to split in a reactor, U-235. That leftover is U-238. For a while nuclear engineers hoped to build breeder reactors, which could turn U-238 into a useful fuel, plutonium. But no one is building breeders.
Another possible reason for saving the material was to scavenge the remaining U-235 in it by using a new processing method. But virgin uranium is so cheap, and the demand so much lower than once projected, that such use is doubtful, too.
Some engineers still hope that the depleted uranium, which is 30 percent denser than lead, could be used in industry, perhaps as shielding for spent nuclear fuel. The material itself is slightly radioactive.
But people outside the Energy Department doubt that a market will develop. With no attractive alternatives -- and with the Government explaining that no serious accidents have occurred and none are likely but that hydrogen fluoride can damage lungs or cause death -- reaction at the hearing was not friendly.
"We are faced with a critical health, environmental and economic crisis that could have been avoided," said Kristi Hanson, a resident of Brookport, Ill., across the Ohio River from Paducah.
Eugene E. Hoffman, a metallurgist who retired from the Energy Department Oak Ridge operations office in 1996, has studied the cylinders. "Their uses are fictitious," Mr. Hoffman said at the hearing.
He urged converting the material before the area is struck by an earthquake. Even without an earthquake, Mr. Hoffman said, the cylinders are now so rusty that the walls of some are no longer thick enough to ship them legally over highways.
Other hearings are set for Tuesday in Oak Ridge, Thursday in Piketon, Ohio, and March 10 in Washington.
Even though some of the material is half a century old, it is considered a resource material rather than a waste, and so Federal law does not require a plan for disposing it.
Engineers here say that while the rust may be ugly, only seven cylinders have leaked. The cylinders stand in undulating rows where they have caused depressions in the ground. On warm days the cylinders snap and pop as the contents go from a solid to a gas to a solid.
The Federal Government is spending $41 million this fiscal year on cleaning up chemical and radiological problems around the site, and wants $71 million for the effort by 2001. But that plan does not address the cylinders.
Carl R. Frode, Jr., the Environmental Protection Agency expert assigned to the environmental restoration efforts at Paducah, assessed the situation this way: "You can't leave the uranium cylinders sitting out there and say, 'Bye, we're done.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: A cylinder of a uranium byproduct being moved to a more stable location at an Energy Department plant in Paducah, Ky. The department is holding hearings on a plan to convert the material into a safer form. (Christopher Berkey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE ALLIES;
Europeans Offer Praise For Accord With Iraq

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 23

 BODY:
European allies warmly hailed the accord brought back from Baghdad tonight by United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan.
Even before President Clinton had given his view on the agreement, President Jacques Chirac of France approved of it. In a 35-minute telephone call, the two leaders agreed that it was all right, said Mr. Chirac's spokeswoman, Catherine Colonna. 
 "According to the information now in their possession, the accord which was signed appears to comply entirely with the United Nations resolutions and abides by the recommendations made by the five permanent members of the Security Council," she said.
More skeptically, the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, expressed the hope that noncompliance by Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, would not again produce weeks of diplomatic impasse and hesitation to use force.
"It is absolutely essential that we are not back in this position in a few weeks' or a few months' time," Mr. Blair emphasized tonight, saying that Britain would push for a Security Council resolution authorizing a military response if Mr. Hussein failed to live up to the terms of the accord reached this weekend.
Foreign Secretary Robin Cook added, "If there had been no pressure on Saddam, we would not have got a deal out of Saddam."
Foreign ministers of the 15 European Union countries, meeting in Brussels today, gave their blessing to the accord.
"It seems that the decisive appeal from the international community has been met, the appeal for unlimited access to all inspection sites," said the German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel.
The German Defense Minister, Volker Ruhe, speaking more cautiously, said, "The text has to be examined, and above all, we need to see in practice that Saddam Hussein holds to the promises he has made."
Gunter Verheugen, a foreign policy spokesman for the German Social Democratic opposition in Parliament, said: "World opinion will mean that this deal must be accepted. The Americans would find themselves in dangerous isolation if, pointing to some trifling detail or another, they insisted on a military strike."
Russia, which had opposed the use of force in the crisis, welcomed Mr. Annan's success. "We worked constantly," President Boris N. Yeltsin said. "From the very beginning we were for a diplomatic solution to the crisis."
An official Russian Foreign Ministry statement that said the agreement allowed international inspectors "full, unfettered access across the entire territory of Iraq."
But allied pressure on the United States and Britain to go easy on Iraq is expected to increase if Mr. Hussein does abide by the agreement to let arms inspectors into the "sensitive" sites from which he had previously barred them.
The French Defense Minister, Alain Richard, said that if Iraq abided by the terms of the agreement, and United Nations weapons inspections showed Iraq no longer had any nuclear, biological or chemical weapons capability, economic sactions against it should be lifted.
This, French officials say, is the only long-term incentive for Mr. Hussein to comply with the arms agreements.
Having pushed hard for both President Clinton and Mr. Hussein to agree to give Mr. Annan one last chance at diplomacy, Mr. Chirac has an enormous stake in getting the United States to accept the deal, American diplomats said. He met with Mr. Annan at dinner in Elysee Palace tonight.
France participated in the 1991 war to get Iraq out of Kuwait, but with 55 percent of the French public opposed to siding with the United States in the latest crisis, according to a poll published by the daily Le Figaro this morning, there would have been little understanding here if the United States rejects the agreement.
French newspaper and radio and television reports over the weekend portrayed Mr. Annan's trip as an effort to defuse a crisis between Baghdad and Washington.

HEADLINE: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE IMPLICATIONS;
Buying a Deal as Hussein Buys Time

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton had no real choice today.
Unwilling from the start of the latest confrontation between Washington and Baghdad to contemplate a military or a military and political campaign to drive Saddam Hussein from power, the President cast the Iraq crisis as a test of wills not between the United States and Mr. Hussein but between the United Nations and Mr. Hussein. 
 The overriding issue, Mr. Clinton declared only last week, was whether the Iraqi President would "allow the U.N. inspectors to complete their mission with full and free access to any site they suspect may be hiding materials or information related to Iraqi weapons-of-mass-destruction programs."
Now, presented with an agreement bearing the imprimatur of Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations, Mr. Clinton could hardly turn his back on it and send the bombers in.
So he bought the deal, even as he spoke of "details" that still have to be worked out and emphasized what he called "a big if": the question of whether Mr. Hussein would keep his word. The President said he would keep United States forces at a high level of preparedness, and use them if necessary.
In the short term, Mr. Clinton has avoided a risky military involvement that could have proved costly in the coin of diplomacy as well as domestic politics. In the longer term, it is not clear that he has permanently averted military action.
Nor is it clear that Iraq will soon be even reasonably free of weapons of mass destruction.
The details, officials said, could prove highly troublesome, particularly a provision that diplomats would accompany the inspectors to some sites.
"Who's going to choose the diplomats?" a senior State Department official asked. "Precisely what will their function be? Will they be able to influence how the inspectors go about their job, and where? This is a concession to Saddam, and he may find a way to make mischief with it."
Once again, the Iraqi leader has retreated, but he has bought time to move war materiel and perhaps to hide it more effectively. Few in Washington believe tonight that the last chapter of the story has been written.
Although Mr. Hussein has promised for the first time since the Persian Gulf war in 1991 to permit full access to all suspected sites, there is no assurance than he will ultimately permit it.
Unless he has undergone a conversion almost as dramatic as Saul's on the road to Damascus, he will try to preserve his arsenal. He may revert to his long-established pattern of stalling, obstructing and redefining terms. But on the other hand, he may adopt new tactics in pursuit of an old strategy.
"He clearly hasn't undergone a conversion," said Richard Haass of the Brookings Institution, who dealt with the Middle East at the National Security Council in the Bush Administration. "He will almost certainly continue to try to cheat and keep his weapons. But this time he may not try to obstruct the weapons inspectors. He may not be able to, and he may not have to.
"My guess is that during this four-month stalemate he will have dug deeper holes and found other ways to hide the stuff from inspection."
If the inspectors are obstructed, Mr. Clinton will find himself right back where he has been this month. He suggested today that since Mr. Hussein has been given this last chance to live up to his word, any violations would swing world opinion much more solidly behind United States military intervention.
Perhaps. But to accomplish that, the President would have to do a much better job of convincing the skeptics -- the French and the Russians, many in the Arab world and an indeterminate but clearly substantial slice of the American public -- that Mr. Hussein is indeed a menace to world stability in a class with Hitler, as members of his Administration have said.
At home, Mr. Clinton is likely in the coming weeks to face a continuing barrage of criticism from conservatives, many of whom believe that the Iraqi problem will be solved only when Saddam Hussein is removed from office.
This week's editorial in The Weekly Standard, one of the main conservative journals of opinion, is headlined "Attack Iraq." It argues that "a comprehensive military and political offensive aimed at removing Saddam" would have represented "a better and more easily defined course of action than the course President Clinton chose, and such a strategy remains a better course of action for the future."
Prominent Republican lawmakers agree, like Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, who said this morning, "One way or another we're going to have to topple Saddam Hussein" to get rid of the weapons of mass destruction. But neither he nor other hawkish Republicans would explicitly call for the use of American troops to get the job done.
By hitching the nation's policy to the United Nations, Mr. Clinton has also left himself vulnerable to attack from those who distrust it. Although he made guardedly positive comments about the agreement, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said the President had put himself in a box.
"This is another example of how the Administration's foreign policy is subcontracted to others," he told a group of reporters at the Capitol.
But on the international front, Mr. Clinton may find himself faced with a challenge of a different sort. If Mr. Hussein has succeeded in hiding the materials needed to make weapons of mass destruction -- and experts warn that they are easily concealed -- the inspectors may find little or nothing. And if that happens, French and Russian diplomats are likely to press at the United Nations and elsewhere for the lifting of economic sanctions against Iraq.

HEADLINE: FLORIDA TWISTERS: THE DAMAGE;
Lives and Homes Destroyed In a Night of Deafening Fury

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: SANFORD, Fla., Feb. 23

 BODY:
Joel Heaton's luck finally abandoned him shortly after midnight today.
It was then that the black funnel of a tornado roared down on Freddie's Fish Camp, about five miles east of this Central Florida city, and carried away a house trailer with Mr. Heaton in it. 
 Next door, a trailer housing another single man, Fred Padgett, also sailed away with its occupant. But Mr. Padgett splashed down in the marshy waters of the St. Johns River, a few hundred yards from land. Rescuers found him before dawn, suffering cuts and broken ribs but alive, clinging to an overturned houseboat.
By evening, however, there still was no trace of Mr. Heaton, whose nickname Lucky was testimony to his history of escaping close calls. Police divers searched the murky waters near the fish camp, where anglers, mostly rawboned men who grew up in these parts, keep boats and fish for large-mouth bass in the headwaters of the river.
Tornadoes always leave caprice amid destruction, and that was the case here in Seminole County, where the police said 11 people died and scores were injured when a line of twisters danced across Central Florida around midnight.
In a neighborhood south of the Sanford jetport, a wide swath of houses and mobile homes were destroyed, while structures across a street lost barely a shingle.
The hardest-hit neighborhoods were those along a southern path to the jetport, where clusters of housing owned by people of modest means stood. Dozens of residences were smashed into rubble, with muscle cars and stout sports vehicles tossed aside like a child's playthings.
Carmen Rivera, 38, and her 12-year-old daughter, Diane, had moved into a mobile home three days ago after moving here from Bridgeport, Conn. They were aware of tornado warnings last night but were unprepared for the two minutes of terror that dipped out of the sky. The first sign of danger, Mrs. Rivera said, was the shrieking wind and windows that rattled so hard that the family knew it was experiencing more than a heavy thunderstorm.
"We were clinging to each other when the windows blew out and one wall ripped away," she recalled today as she sat in the First Presbyterian Church in downtown Sanford, where an emergency shelter was set up to provide for the newly homeless.
Across town, Brad Fauver, surveyed the ruined heap of what the day before had been an unoccupied two-story house he had remodeled. Only splintered wood and a partial foundation were left.
"I guess I did my remodeling a little too soon," Mr. Fauver said.
Sanford is considered the first population center in Central Florida, about 30 miles northeast of Orlando, where palm trees and scrub palmetto dissolve into the tall oak trees draped with Spanish moss more typical of the northern tier of the state.
Most tourists who pass through Sanford, population 36,000, are passengers on the Auto Train -- Sanford is the southern terminus of the rail system that transports cars and their drivers between here and Virginia. A devastating freeze 13 years ago laid waste to the orange groves that covered the landscape from horizon to horizon, and they and the citrus economy never recovered.
But the sprawl of the Orlando area is spilling into southern Seminole County, and the new jetport here has become the fascination of package charter flights from Britain that deliver one million tourists a year bound for Walt Disney World and other Florida destinations, local officials said.
Hurricanes occasionally sweep through this part of the state, but few residents were ready for tornadoes in late February, a season when dusty, chilly winds are expected but not the tropical storms now delivered by El Nino far away in the Pacific Ocean.
Freddie's Fish Camp is off State Road 46, where the St. John's River meets Lake Jessup. The camp lies unprotected on a spit of land flanked on three sides by water, about two acres in all, with 12 year-round residents in trailers and a small fleet of older vessels and weather-scarred houseboats.
The proprietor, Rod Goddard, 58, said he was dozing off shortly after midnight when he heard "a whistling sound coming harder and harder and harder."
"You could hear this roar and the power lines going down," Mr. Goddard said. "My wife ran out the door, and I was trying to get into my pants and follow her when it hit. The windows blew out, and the force slammed me against the wall. I couldn't get out the door."
Trees twisted and snapped, and mundane objects like lawn mowers and mailboxes became deadly missiles, he said. His black Chevy 1500 pickup truck parked in the yard took several direct hits that shredded metal fenders, crushed windows and left the vehicle pockmarked with battlefield-like wounds.
Nearer the river, a resident who identified himself only as Ernie had sought shelter in a tin-roofed pavilion on concrete pilings. He said he scrambled under a concrete picnic table as the tornado bore down, lifting the structure.
"The roof was sucked right into the sky, and debris was flying all around me" he said.
When he could crawl from beneath the branches of a tree that had landed on the picnic table, the fish camp had been transformed into a jumble of beached or overturned boats frozen in his sight by flashes of lightning.
When the survivors could gather to assess the damage no one could account for Mr. Heaton or Mr. Padgett. As the hours passed, hope that Mr. Heaton, like Mr. Padgett, would be found alive began to dim.
"We called him Lucky because he had driven a pickup truck off the road into ditches a couple of times and walked away," Ernie said as he stood barefoot and watched the police divers search. A strong western wind had picked up and dragged a new cover of clouds overhead.
"It doesn't look like he was so lucky this time" Ernie added, his eyes scanning the wind-whipped river a final time before he walked away.

LENGTH: 501 words

HEADLINE: The Reagan Riddle

 BODY:
As President, Ronald Reagan projected optimism, conviction and nostalgia for a simpler time in America. Now retired and afflicted, he is poignantly beckoning Americans once again to recall a moment when Presidential leadership itself seemed more simple and open than it is today. The President who stood for irreducible verities like opposing Communism and unleashing "the magic of the marketplace," as he un-self-consciously put it, has been vividly captured by the two-part documentary broadcast on PBS last night and tonight. No less impressive is the program's acknowledgment that the man in the middle remains an enigma.
The program is only the latest of several recent displays of affection for Mr. Reagan. As his 87th birthday approached, normally fractious Republicans in Congress united to name an airport after him in the capital city he reviled. Cover stories in Forbes and The Weekly Standard asserted that the current economic boom should be ascribed to a Presidency that ended nine years ago. Almost everyone seems to believe that he will be known as the leader who vanquished the "Evil Empire," a phrase that shocked the mainstream when he uttered it. 
 It does Mr. Reagan's memory a disservice to suggest that his leadership was flawless or his legacy uncomplicated. He advocated balanced budgets but never submitted one. His program favored the rich over the poor, and his approach to social policy was brutish. His sweeping tax cuts of 1981 were followed by tax increases in his own term and then under Presidents Bush and Clinton, with little ill effect. The President who savagely opposed the missile treaty negotiated by his predecessor, Jimmy Carter, managed to live under its terms. His resolution in foreign policy was compromised by trading arms for hostages in Iran.
Mr. Reagan's great gifts are nonetheless worth celebrating. From the time of Teddy Roosevelt, only a handful of the nation's chief executives have pushed through their programs by sheer force of personality. At a time when many had concluded that the job was too much for one man to handle, he charted where he wanted to go, and thereby expanded the possibilities of the office itself.
Several moments in the PBS program are startling. There is the discovery by Edmund Morris, whose long-awaited biography of Mr. Reagan is due later this year, that the President's capabilities slipped steadily from the time he was shot in March 1981, for instance. But most striking is the essential loneliness and intellectual slightness of a man who had few if any intimate friendships beyond that with his wife and was blissfully unquestioning about himself and his beliefs.
"You're not going to figure him out," declares Ron Reagan Jr., in a virtual challenge to the film makers. "That's the first thing you need to know. I don't think he's figured himself out." That may be beside the point. Mr. Reagan figured out a few big, simple truths about the country, which is why Americans remember him fondly today.
