HEADLINE: BASKETBALL: KNICKS NOTEBOOK;
Williams Is in Line To Sign a Third Time

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: PURCHASE, N.Y., Feb. 23

 BODY:
You can bench him, you can put him on the injury list and you can even trade him. But you cannot get rid of Herb Williams. He is the Power Forward Who Will Not Go Away.
Showing more resilience than the Jason character from the Friday the 13th films, the 40-year-old clubhouse sage and Madison Square Garden cult hero may be within a day of rejoining the Knicks. Again. 
 "As soon as he clears waivers, we would like to come back to New York if they're interested," George Andrews, Williams's Chicago-based agent, said today. "We're talking to other people, but it wasn't exactly our plan to leave. So we wouldn't mind coming back."
On Thursday, the Knicks traded Williams for the second time in three seasons. Philadelphia, which acquired Williams in the deal for Terry Cummings, did not want him to count against its salary cap and promptly waived him. The same scenario applied in a trade with Toronto two seasons ago, and Williams returned to the Knicks a few days after playing one game for the Raptors.
With a roster spot open and team officials intimating they would like to have him return, Williams could sign with the Knicks after he clears waivers Wednesday morning.
He will not be in uniform Tuesday when New York is host to the Golden State Warriors, but he could be in time for Thursday's game against Milwaukee at the Garden.
Proving how wacky economics are in the National Basketball Association, being cut should actually improve Williams's finances. His $700,000 for this season was guaranteed, and a clause in his contract increased that by 15 percent when he was traded. If he rejoins the Knicks, he will sign a new contract, probably for $272,500 -- the pro-rated share of the minimum salary for the rest of the season -- and will end up making slightly less than $1 million.
After sitting for most of the season, Williams had a break-out game against Charlotte on Feb. 10. He played 15 minutes and had three blocked shots. The oldest player in the league, Williams has only played in 14 games and scored 15 points. But Coach Jeff Van Gundy relied upon Williams for advice and he was enough of a locker-room presence that several players voiced displeasure to the coach when he was traded.
"I think he just wants to show that there's still some life in the body," Andrews said. "He's probably got the fresh legs on the team right now, considering he really didn't play the first part of the season. Herb believes in this team. He was just starting to get some minutes.
"He's like that old car sitting in your garage. You got to kick it to get the carbon out once in a while, but it still works."
 
Buck Williams Starts Rehab
 Buck Williams, who underwent minor surgery on his left knee last week, was back at Purchase College and already beginning to rehabilitate the injury today.
The team has speculated that Williams will return between three and six weeks after the surgery -- which involved shaving away loose cartilage in the knee -- but Williams is not saying when he will be back.
"I've become a swimmer," he said, referring to his rehabilitation treatment.
Meanwhile, Larry Johnson (contusion in his right thigh) and Chris Childs (sprained left ankle) did not practice today, and both are listed as day to day. Childs limped noticeably as he left the gym at SUNY-Purchase, favoring the ankle he twisted in the second quarter of Sunday's game against Houston. Johnson was still sore after injuring his thigh in the third quarter.
 
Warriors Change Chemistry
 The Warriors, who have won three of their last five games, are still only 11-42. But Jeff Van Gundy claims the changes they made before the trading deadline -- acquiring Jim Jackson, Clarence Weatherspoon and Jason Caffey -- have helped change the team's chemistry.
"They've changed so much, they have a different enthusiasm level now," Van Gundy said. "They've made great trades, really good trades. I loved Caffey. Great rebounder. They've gotten rid of guys that didn't want to be there, which I think cleans up their locker room."
The Warriors and Coach P. J. Carlesimo are awaiting a decision in the Latrell Sprewell case.
"The thing I respect is how well he has been able to handle it, to keep coaching," Van Gundy said of Carlesimo. "And you watch their team and they have stabilized because of that."

HEADLINE: Despite Intern, President Stays In Good Graces

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET with JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
Most Americans are inclined to think that President Clinton, despite his denials, had an affair with a former White House intern. But, in the statistical equivalent of a collective shrug, most call it understandable for the President to lie about his sexual conduct, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Half the public wishes that the investigation into Mr. Clinton's relationship with the intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, would simply be dropped. By three-fourths majorities on each question, Americans said that the press had spent too much time on the issue and that they just did not want to hear about it. 
 Those surveyed sharply distinguished between private and professional conduct in the Oval Office. Many Americans expressed disappointment in Mr. Clinton's personal behavior as President, calling it worse than they expected. But an overwhelming majority, 84 percent, agreed with the proposition that "someone can still be a good President even if they do things in their personal life that you disapprove of."
Having been confronted with some details about Mr. Clinton's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky over four weeks of accusations and piecemeal disclosures, the public is in no mood to let glimpses of the President's private life lower its opinion of his job performance.
With half of even Republicans and conservatives saying they are pleased with the job he is doing, Mr. Clinton has achieved the highest public approval ratings of his Presidency in the joint New York Times/CBS News Poll. His ratings have improved among all demographic groups.
Pulled aloft by record levels of public satisfaction with the economy and the direction the country is taking, the President's overall job approval rating is now 68 percent, up from 56 percent just before he delivered his State of the Union Message last month.
In another record high, 57 percent of the public view Mr. Clinton favorably, while 29 percent view him unfavorably. The telephone poll, conducted among 1,153 adults from Thursday through Saturday, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Despite their qualms about his truthfulness and personal conduct, people do not hold the President responsible for the crisis engulfing the White House. Fifty-seven percent of respondents blame Mr. Clinton's political enemies for "creating the current situation." Only 33 percent blame Mr. Clinton.
"I wasn't the biggest Clinton fan," said Patrick Lynch, a 30-year-old bartender in Glenside, Pa., who was interviewed after taking part in the poll. "But when I see all the things that he's been able to do, it just seems that someone is going to great lengths to ruin his day. Presidents in the past have done much worse."
Even among those who think Mr. Clinton is lying about his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, nearly 4 in 10 think that the investigation into the relationship should be dropped.
Fifty-eight percent predicted that the Lewinsky matter would not interfere with Mr. Clinton's ability to function effectively as President.
Judging from the poll, the White House has plenty of political breathing room as it pursues its chosen strategy for dealing with Mr. Clinton's crisis, withholding information and attacking the independent prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr.
There is little public impatience about the President's resolute silence regarding Ms. Lewinsky. Just over three-quarters of the people surveyed, 77 percent, said Mr. Clinton should wait until the investigation was completed before addressing the accusations that he had an affair with her and then sought to cover it up.
Sixty-four percent called the accusations against Mr. Clinton a private matter having to do with his personal life rather than a public matter involving his job as President. Previous polls have suggested that Americans have hard experience of their own in working through the problem of adultery, with majorities saying they have known someone who was unfaithful.
"It kind of brings me down on him as a person," said Bob Vasina, a 40-year-old financial analyst in Binghamton, N.Y., addressing the accusation of sexual misconduct. "But as far as doing his job, I think it's a separate issue and doesn't affect my opinion at all. I think there are many people doing very good jobs doing what he is alleged to have done on the side."
Mr. Starr's own favorability rating remains dismal, with three times as many people expressing a negative opinion of him as offering a positive one. Perhaps taking a cue from White House attacks, 59 percent agreed with the proposition that Mr. Starr was "mostly conducting a partisan investigation to damage Bill Clinton." A month ago, only 47 percent said he was being partisan.
While saying they were uninterested in whether Mr. Clinton and Ms. Lewinsky had had an affair, the public was less dismissive of the accusation that he had encouraged her to lie about it. Sixty-one percent said it was important for the public to know whether or not he had done so.
But even if it turns out that Mr. Clinton obstructed justice by lying under oath or urging Ms. Lewinsky to lie, most Americans think that matter should be dropped or that he should simply admit it and apologize. Only 21 percent favor his resignation in that situation, while 12 percent say the Congress should begin impeachment proceedings.
White House aides said Mr. Clinton's high approval rating was consistent with their internal numbers, as it is with other public polls. While they are pleased with the rise in the President's ratings, some Clinton advisers predicted that the high numbers could not be sustained, with Republicans and conservatives likely to be the first to desert him.
But, even given those anticipated defections, one Administration official argued that Mr. Clinton, through his campaigning and governing since mid-1995, has gradually built up a large enough loyal following to guarantee a bulwark of support.
"We could get Reagan down to 51 or 52," the official recalled by way of comparison, "but it was like hitting a rock with a jackhammer getting him below 51 or 52."
It is clear that the economy, considered to be in good shape by an astonishing 88 percent of the public, is a central source of the President's popularity.
Fully three-fourths of the public is pleased with Mr. Clinton's handling of the economy, a higher proportion than has approved of any President's economic stewardship since pollsters began asking this question in 1971.
"Whether it's the economy, Social Security or education," Rahm Emanuel, a senior adviser to Mr. Clinton, said of the American people, "they know that when he gets up in the morning he rolls up his sleeves and works on the issues that affect their lives. And they've see that again and again for the last five and a half years."
Since accusations first surfaced about Ms. Lewinsky, the White House has been at pains to show Mr. Clinton as preoccupied with the people's business. Given that strategy, the timing of the crisis was favorable for the President, since it came just before his State of the Union address and the presentation of his budget proposal.
The domestic crisis also came as President Saddam Hussein was provoking another impasse over weapons inspections in Iraq. The public gave Mr. Clinton high marks for his handling of that matter, with a majority saying he had tried hard enough to achieve a diplomatic solution even before Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General, announced an agreement with Iraq on Sunday. Most Americans said Mr. Clinton had explained the situation well enough for them to understand why the United States might take action.
Given their choice, most Americans said before Sunday that they would prefer to see diplomacy resolve the crisis. But if Mr. Hussein refused to back down and permit weapons inspections, 66 percent said they were in favor of bombing. Reflecting a widely held frustration with Mr. Hussein's tenacious hold on power, 58 percent said the bombing should continue until he was toppled.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Thursday through Saturday with 1,153 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for self-identified Democrats, Republicans, or independents taken as a group it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON SAYS IRAQ IS PROMISING UNCONDITIONAL ACCESS TO SITES

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that Iraq had agreed to allow United Nations weapons inspectors immediate and unconditional access throughout the country, and he began to seek British, French and Russian support for a Security Council resolution that would warn Saddam Hussein of serious consequences if the deal is violated.
In a news conference today, Mr. Clinton indicated that the agreement, reached by Secretary General Kofi Annan and President Hussein, would restore free and unfettered inspections by the United Nations Special Commission, known by its acronym, Unscom. 
 Mr. Clinton said, "If fully implemented, and that is the big 'if,' this commitment will allow Unscom to fulfill its mission." Transcript, page A10.
But Mr. Clinton also warned that the details and procedures of the agreement need to be clarified by Mr. Annan. Most importantly, he said, Iraq's promise would have to be tested before the crisis could be considered over.
If Iraq reneges this time, Mr. Clinton said, "everyone would understand that then the United States and hopefully all of our allies would have the unilateral right to respond at a time, place and manner of our own choosing." In other words, although he did not say it directly, he made clear that the United States reserved the right to respond with military force.
Washington's plan is for the American aircraft carriers and troops to stay in the Persian Gulf region, perhaps for months. "At this point it would be premature to declare peace and start bringing the troops home," an official said today.
Some of the gaps in the agreement, which consists of two pages and an annex, were larger than the President implied, officials said.
The agreement is vague in several areas, including exactly how presidential sites, properties that Iraq has declared off-limits, would be inspected and what would be the precise role of Richard Butler, the chairman of the special commission. Text of the agreement, Page A10.
The officials were also unhappy that the agreement commits the weapons inspectors to respect Iraq's national security, sovereignty and dignity. If the clause is linked to the special procedures yet to be established, the Iraqis may refuse inspections on the grounds of "national security."
A senior American official acknowledged the problem, but said: "What matters more than the clarifications is the testing. You can't know if the words are a problem until the implementation is tested."
But a senior French official agreed that Mr. Hussein had made "a clear commitment to grant unconditional access for inspectors, an agreement that is strong and in writing," that violation of the agreement "will mean military action," and that "everyone in the Security Council agrees we don't want to be in a new Iraqi crisis every six weeks."
For the first time since the Persian Gulf war ended in 1991, Mr. Clinton said, Mr. Hussein has acknowledged that he must keep his commitment to allow weapons inspectors working for the special commission into any site without time limits.
"But the proof is in the testing," Mr. Clinton said, and if Mr. Hussein reneges again on his commitments, "there will be serious consequences."
American officials said that "serious consequences" is a diplomatic term that is understood to mean military action. Senior American and Western officials said that a new United Nations Security Council resolution was being drafted, to be put forward this week, that it would codify the agreement and warn Mr. Hussein of the consequences.
While the Americans do not expect France or Russia to sign a blank check, officials of both countries said today that there is no confusion about the military ramifications of the resolution.
Mr. Clinton spoke today with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, President Jacques Chirac of France and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to discuss Mr. Annan's agreement and a subsequent resolution.
"If Saddam were to violate this thing now, even the Russians would not stand up for him," a senior Administration official said.
Another senior official said, "We've made clear, and the French and Russians accept, that they won't be able to hold back military action, and they recognize that, and they are prepared to join us in issuing a stiff warning to the Iraqis."
French officials said they expected American troops to remain on station in the gulf for two or three months while the agreement is tested, but American officials said they expected to be able to test it "sooner rather than later."
Mr. Annan is expected to try to clarify these gaps and other points when he briefs the Security Council on Tuesday, upon his return after a stop in Paris. Knowledgeable French officials said tonight that some "oral agreements" were clear but were not easily put into writing.
Among them, an official said, was the French suggestion that the inspection of the eight presidential sites be carried out by a new, sixth subcommittee of Unscom headed by someone appointed by Mr. Annan, but who would report to Mr. Butler, preserving Unscom's authority.
"It seems what Annan got from Saddam includes this," the official said. "But we want to hear it from him directly."
The agreement now states simply that the special groups will include experts drawn from Unscom and the International Atomic Energy Agency, which inspects nuclear matters, and would include diplomats appointed by the Secretary General. Numbers and procedures are not delineated, and the text speaks only of "specific, detailed procedures which will be developed given the special nature of the presidential sites."
Mr. Annan went to Baghdad with instructions to delineate presidential residences within the eight presidential sites, which include many other buildings. It was unclear in the text, officials said, if he had succeeded, or whether these "special procedures" had to apply to the larger sites and not merely the palaces or residences.
But the text of the agreement, after standard references to the sovereignty and dignity of Iraq, does say that "the Government of Iraq reconfirms its acceptance of all relevant resolutions of the Security Council," and that "the Government of Iraq undertakes to accord Unscom and the I.A.E.A. immediate, unconditional and unrestricted access in conformity with the resolutions."
Toward the end, the text also says, as Iraq wanted, that the lifting of tough economic sanctions imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 is "obviously of paramount importance."
But criticism of the deal was quick to come, with some Republicans saying Mr. Clinton had abdicated the making of foreign policy to the United Nations and could once again be snookered by Mr. Hussein.
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, voiced concern that the Administration had "subcontracted" its foreign policy to Mr. Annan.
"I was worried that this initiative by Annan was going to put the President in a box, and that's exactly what's happened," Mr. Lott said. "He's in a very difficult position now to say, 'Oh, no, this is not good enough.' "
The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said he had no qualms with the United Nations acting as a mediator. "I think as long as the Secretary General is operating within a framework established by the American President, we have nothing to fear," he said.
With Congress just returning from a 10-day recess, Democrats and Republicans gave guarded comments before having examined the details of the agreement. "We can only judge those details when we see them," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut.
"I have grave misgivings about this," Mr. Lieberman continued. "But if in fact there is an agreement in writing that provides for unlimited access by U.N. inspectors to all of the sites in Iraq, then I think it's going to be very hard for us to do anything but to let that agreement go into effect."
Other senators complained that Mr. Hussein had badly outmaneuvered the United States. "From the outset, the U.S. believed this was a military contest, and Saddam Hussein believed it was a political fight," Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who just returned from a visit to Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Oman, said in an interview. "In retrospect, he was probably right. It may be incredible for most Americans to accept, but Saddam Hussein actually won the public relations battle."
Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, spoke for many of his colleagues when he listed questions about unresolved issues:
"What is the long-term policy, and where do we go in the long run here? What will the force deployment level be? How will we guarantee compliance? What happens if he doesn't comply down the road? How do we avoid this ratcheting up on an annual basis and sort of continual tweaking that Saddam Hussein seems to enjoy putting the United States to?"

HEADLINE: Professors Fear to Grade Harshly;
Math Is Still Tough

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Just Because Grades Are Up, Are Princeton Students Smarter?" (front page, Feb. 18) does not provide the full story. 
 A study published in 1991 in the Journal of Economic Perspectives showed the effects of grade inflation on course choice at several United States colleges and universities. It concluded that not only have grades risen in the last quarter-century but also that the rise has not been uniform: certain departments (English, political science, arts and music) inflate grades more than others (mathematics, chemistry, economics).
This split is especially problematic for encouraging the study of the physical sciences and other low-grading disciplines. Students may retreat from a subject based on inflated grades elsewhere.
The obvious solution is the uniform deflation of grades across all departments. But no single university will enforce grade deflation unless alldo.
 
K. TIM RAY
Chicago, Feb. 19, 1998
 
The writer is a student at the University of Chicago.

HEADLINE: Professors Fear to Grade Harshly;
Maybe They Earned It

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Feb. 18 front-page article portrays Princeton as a glorified summer camp where a 4.0 grade point average is the norm. Anecdotal evidence like the comments of four students who referred only to a few English classes cannot properly represent the university as a whole. 
 Princeton should not be singled out simply because it chose to investigate a national trend. Grade inflation is an issue that affects many universities, and Princeton is by no means the most egregious offender. You failed to mention one other hypothesis: quite possibly some students work hard and deserve the high grades they earn.
 
CHRISTINE B. WHELAN
Editor in Chief
The Daily Princetonian
Princeton, N.J., Feb. 18, 1998

HEADLINE: Professors Fear to Grade Harshly;
New System Needed

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You report (front page, Feb. 18) that Dartmouth College, in order to combat grade inflation, will be providing the mean grade and class enrollment along with students' grades on college transcripts. Such policies do little to address the limits of a linear grading system, which reduces education to the level of a horse race. 
 If the goal of grades is to provide an honest evaluation as well as a system of ranking, then a revision of the system is required. There are alternatives like the narrative evaluations used at Hampshire and Antioch Colleges and the portfolio assessments used by some secondary schools.
Thoughtful changes to the grading system at Princeton could have a positive effect on schools throughout the country.
 
JENNIFER KIERNAN
Madison, Wis., Feb. 19, 1998

HEADLINE: Arrogance on NATO

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, Feb. 17), in arguing against NATO expansion, makes strong points about Russia, nuclear weapons and the big world picture yet overlooks others. 
 Russian history shows a pattern of imperialism and aggression. The vulnerable countries of Eastern and Central Europe could be fair game once again in the future. Imagine that it's 2003, and Russia's economy and world prestige continue to founder. A neo-nationalist regime concludes that re-establishing the Soviet Union and its satellites is necessary.
With awesome tank forces and mobile ground units, a move by Russia into a weakly defended Budapest, Warsaw or Prague overnight is again plausible. There would be lots of screaming from the United Nations and Western countries, but Russian troops would already be dug in and a puppet leadership installed as the screaming continued.
However, if these countries were NATO members, the Western response would be immediate. Russia is the aggressor in the face of weakness. In the face of a formidable defense, it can be expected to stay home.
 
RICHARD J. HOLLAND
Tucson, Ariz., Feb. 17, 1998

HEADLINE: U.S. Says 2 Chinese Offered Organs From the Executed

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

 BODY:
In an undercover operation that officials say could confirm suspicions about human rights abuses in China's prisons, Federal authorities in New York City have arrested two men, including one who claimed to be a former Chinese prosecutor, on charges of conspiring to arrange transplants of kidneys and other organs taken from the bodies of executed Chinese inmates.
Federal officials said yesterday that the case could provide the first evidence documented by the United States Government of what Chinese dissidents have long described as a thriving -- and in the United States, at least, illicit -- trade stemming from the harsh treatment of prisoners there. 
 The two men, Cheng Yong Wang, who described himself as a former prosecutor on Hainan Island, China, and Xingqi Fu, a Chinese citizen who lives in Flushing, Queens, were arrested on Friday after an F.B.I. agent posing as a medical executive met with them in New York.
During the meeting, Mr. Wang offered to sell kidneys from prisoners who had been executed in China and arrange for American patients to have the transplant operations in China, according to a Federal complaint filed in District Court in Manhattan. Mr. Wang told the undercover agent that working with Mr. Fu he could also supply corneas, at $5,000 a pair, to doctors who wanted to transplant them in the United States, and that he could obtain pancreases, livers, lungs and skin, the complaint said.
The F.B.I. mounted the sting operation shortly after receiving a tip from a well-known human rights activist, Harry Wu, who said in an interview that he secretly videotaped a meeting with Mr. Wang on Feb. 13 in which Mr. Wang first discussed kidney transplants.
Mr. Wu, identified in the complaint only as Person A, added that Mr. Wang also said he could guarantee access to the organs of at least 50 of the 200 prisoners executed on the island province of Hainan each year. Mr. Wu said Mr. Wang told him that the kidney transplant operations would cost $20,000 to $30,000 at Chinese hospitals, much less than they would cost in American hospitals.
The State Department said in a recent report that there have been credible allegations from human rights groups and former Chinese inmates that the organs of some executed prisoners have been removed and sold. Mr. Wu, who spent 19 years in Chinese labor camps for criticizing China's leadership and is now an American citizen, has been urging the Clinton Administration for several years to put pressure on the Chinese Government to halt the practice.
Despite a scattering of press reports suggesting that people from other Asian countries have eagerly sought such transplants, the Chinese Government has long denied that the practice is widespread. Chinese officials contend that the transplants occur on a limited basis, and only when the prisoners or their families have given their consent.
But Mr. Wu said Mr. Wang disputed this in one of their conversations, saying that prisoners generally "have no political rights, so we don't ask." A State Department spokesman said yesterday that "we're naturally concerned about these allegations, and we're looking into it."
Mr. Wu and other rights activists, including Amnesty International of London, also have expressed concern that as the number of death sentences rises in China, to an estimated 6,000 a year, even people convicted of crimes like robbery and counterfeiting are being sentenced to death, and this could help expand the trade in body parts. The press office at the Chinese Embassy in Washington did not return a call for comment yesterday.
Mr. Wang and Mr. Fu were charged with conspiring to sell human organs, a practice that is illegal under Federal law, which requires that any organs used in transplants be donated. The Federal complaint did not say whether Mr. Wang, who has been in the United States since May 1997, had arranged any sales or transplants, and law enforcement officials would not discuss that or whether they had verified that Mr. Wang had been a Chinese official.
Initial court records offered few details about the two defendants, who were arrested on Friday and taken on Saturday before a Federal magistrate judge in Manhattan. The magistrate ordered both men held without bond until further proceedings this week.
At a hearing yesterday, Marcia R. Isaacson, an assistant United States attorney, said Mr. Fu and his wife were Chinese citizens. Court papers said Mr. Fu earned $600 a month from a laundry he operates in Queens.
After the hearing, the magistrate, Ronald L. Ellis, ordered Mr. Fu released on $100,000 bond. Mr. Fu's lawyer, David B. Levitt, declined to comment. Mr. Fu's wife, Susan, said: "They wronged him. He never did any illegal thing."
Mr. Wang's lawyer, Oliver A. Smith, declined to comment other than to say that "we act on the assumption that the Constitution still works and he's presumed innocent."
Mr. Wang, who is scheduled to appear in court tomorrow for a bail hearing, listed himself in a court financial disclosure form as unemployed and said that he had about $3,000 in savings.
Mr. Wu said he got involved in the case after hearing about Mr. Wang from someone he would not identify. Mr. Wu said he arranged to meet Mr. Wang on Feb. 13 in a suite at the San Carlos Hotel in Manhattan.
Mr. Wu, who posed as a director of a dialysis center, said that Mr. Wang showed him documents indicating that he had been the deputy chief of criminal prosecutions for Hainan Province. An associate of Mr. Wu said Mr. Wang said he was on leave and would return to that job.
With a friend's video camera taping the meeting from inside a box, Mr. Wu said he signed a contract agreeing to supply Mr. Wang with a commission of 25 percent of the costs of each kidney transplant.
Mr. Wu then called the F.B.I., which taped a telephone conversation between a second informant and Mr. Wang on Feb. 17. According to the Federal complaint, Mr. Wang said in this conversation that he and Mr. Fu expected to earn a big profit on the sale of the corneas.
The F.B.I. brought its sting to a quick close on Friday, when an agent who introduced himself as another director of the dialysis center met with both Mr. Wang and Mr. Fu. As part of his marketing pitch, Mr. Fu assured the agent that any lungs they supplied "would come from nonsmokers," the complaint said.
The issue of transplanting organs from executed Chinese prisoners has been of great concern to the international transplant community, said Ronald M. Ferguson, chairman of the department of surgery at Ohio State University Medical Center and president of the American Society of Transplant Surgeons.
He and other American doctors said yesterday that even with the most sophisticated medical technology, organs like kidneys, which are in great demand worldwide, would survive only a short time and would need to be transplanted quickly. But the doctors said it would be possible to ship corneas long distances.
Mr. Wu said most of the kidney transplants so far in China have been done in military and other Government-run hospitals.
"If they don't have a national policy, no one could make it available." he said. "So the Chinese Government is responsible for all these inhuman practices."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Kohlberg Kravis Is Seen Pulling Out of Oxford Deal
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm, is no longer involved in the effort to provide Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed care company, with badly needed capital, people close to the talks said last night. Another buyout firm, Texas Pacific Group, is now said to be moving ahead with a financing plan.
Kohlberg Kravis and Texas Pacific had been negotiating with Oxford for weeks to provide company with more than $600 million in debt and equity to help it through its recent financial problems. Page D2. 

Nasdaq Hits a Record
The Nasdaq played catch-up with other major stock indexes by reaching a record, 1,751.76, up 23.63 points. The technology stocks that dominate the index soared as investors brushed aside concerns about the impact of Asia's economic woes on American corporate profits. Other indexes were mixed, however, with the Dow industrials down a bit but the S.& P. slightly higher. D12.
 
The price of crude oil fell nearly 5 percent, to $15.37 a barrel, after an agreement negotiated by the United Nations defused the prospect of United States air attacks on Iraq. D12.
 
$2.3 Billion Bank Deal
The Union Planters, Tennessee's largest bank holding company, said that it would acquire Magna Group for $2.3 billion in stock to expand its reach in the St. Louis area. D2.
 
Layoffs at Data Base Company
Sybase, a provider of data base software that reported poor financial results last month, said it had dismissed 600 employees. D15.
 
Monsanto Pays Cotton Farmers
Monsanto has begun paying settlements to some Mississippi Delta farmers who contend that a strain of cotton that the company genetically engineered to withstand herbicides failed to survive, resulting in withered green bolls instead of fluffy white tufts. Monsanto, a $9 billion company that has bet its future on biotechnology, has denied wrongdoing. D9.
 
Airline Alliance to Span Pacific
American Airlines and Japan Airlines are expected to announce an alliance that would enable the carriers to sell tickets on each other's flights. D10.
 
Tough Choices for Greenspan
While market interest rates have fallen sharply in the last 10 months, the Federal funds rate has been steady at 5.5 percent. After adjusting for lower inflation, the real rate is actually more than half a percentage point higher than it was a year ago. The economy's strength in the face of a relatively high real rate is one of the issues facing Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, as he begins a report to Congress. Market Place. D11.
 
Labor Peace, at a Price
Fears that labor unrest would set back chances of an economic recovery in South Korea are fading. But many foreign investors are concerned that change in the country's rigid labor practices, which they regard as indispensable to getting the economy back on its feet, will be agonizingly slow. News analysis. D4.
 
Pinpointing Light-Truck Dangers
A Federal study found that sport utility vehicles kill an unusually high number of drivers of other vehicles because of their weight, their stiffer frames and the fact that they ride higher off the road than cars. A13.

HEADLINE: FLORIDA TWISTERS: THE OVERVIEW;
AT LEAST 38 DIE AS TORNADOES RIP CENTRAL FLORIDA

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: KISSIMMEE, Fla., Feb. 23

 BODY:
A series of tornadoes ripped swaths about 50 miles wide across Central Florida early today, killing at least 38 people and leaving patches of destruction that state officials said were as bad as anything they saw in the wake of Hurricane Andrew. It was the deadliest swarm of tornadoes on record in the state.
In addition to the dead, more than 260 people were injured and hundreds more left homeless as an undetermined number of tornadoes cut northwest across the state from midnight to 1 A.M. with winds of 158 to 260 miles an hour. 
 Rescue workers and witnesses described scenes of horror and heroism, from an 18-month-old who died after being sucked from his father's arms to a 11-year-old vacationer from England, who pulled her cousin, from their bedroom moments before their family's rented Dodge van was hurled through the wall and landed upside down on their bed.
Though local officials issued warnings late Sunday, most people here seemed to have been caught by surprise. Many of the victims had been asleep and died when they were hurled through the air or crushed by collapsing structures, state officials said.
The worst damage was centered on four counties -- Orange, Osceola, Seminole and Volusia -- where mobile home parks took the brunt of the storm and were reduced to piles of debris. No damage figures were available but 14 counties in Northern and Central Florida were declared Federal disaster areas, making them eligible for Federal aid. Seven counties suffered direct hits from the tornadoes, state officials said, while the other seven have experienced flood damage in recent months and were bracing for more as additional rain was expected.
The twisters tore off roofs and side walls from permanent structures, flipped over cars and mobile homes, and left at least 25,000 people without electricity. One strip mall in Osceola County was "completely leveled." said Kelley Thomason, a spokeswoman for the county emergency operation center.
At least 130 people sought refuge in public shelters. More than 300 homes were damaged or destroyed, many by the giant oaks, pines and other trees that were uprooted, but one state emergency official called the estimate "probably very, very low." Major tourist attractions like Walt Disney World, Universal Studios and Sea World, and hotel and motel strips were spared damage but many tornado victims were winter visitors in recreational vehicles.
In many areas like rural Seminole County, where cattle were counted among the missing, the tornadoes jumped over some homes and destroyed others. Within a few feet of houses splintered and in shambles were houses without so much as a shingle missing.
Witnesses said some mobile homes "exploded" under the awesome force of the wind.
Terry Tipton, 27, and her family walked in a daze amid the debris left by the storms, which took the life of her father, Tom Tipton, who had been sleeping inside his mobile home in Sanford when the tornado blew his trailer off its supports and smashed it into hundreds of pieces against nearby trees. All that remained were the concrete front steps and back patio.
To the south, Claire Roberts, 11, was vacationing from Liverpool, England, with relatives, but today only two of the exterior walls of the four-bedroom villa with a swimming pool the family had been renting were left standing. Their rented Dodge Caravan was tossed onto the bed of 6-year-old Emma Smith, Claire's cousin, seconds afer Claire pulled her from the room.
"I heard my brother, Daniel, screaming, and I sat up in bed," Claire recalled as she sat in the cafeteria of Horizon Middle School here, where the Red Cross had established a makeshift shelter for victims. "My mum was screaming too, and all the windows were smashed. I got Emma out of bed and then the van smashed through the window."
After their narrow escape, the two girls were trapped briefly in the hallway outside the bedroom when a doorway collapsed and debris pinned them to the floor. Claire's mother, Diane Roberts, pulled Emma from the debris by her hair and then helped her own daughter escape.
Members of both families suffered cuts and scrapes, but no serious injuries. They were released from a local hospital about mid-morning and moved to the shelter. They had planned three more days of sight-seeing, but yesterday they were ready to go home.
"She's a hero," said Emma's mother, Catherine Smith, hugging Claire and choking back a sob.
The tornadoes came after an active period of storms in Florida attributed to El Nino. Officials from the National Weather Service said they were produced by thunderstorms that formed in the Tampa Bay area.
"Based on our radar screens, we can tell where the thunderstorm path will be with great accuracy, but we don't know when a tornado will touch the ground," said Scott Spratt, a meterologist with the weather service in Melbourne.
Mr. Spratt said there were "numerous tornado touchdowns," up to a dozen. But he said he did not know how many of those were by the same tornado. Ranked 0 to 5 on the Fujita-Pearson Tornado Scale, today's tornadoes caused damage worthy of categories 3 and 4, with winds of up to 260 miles per hour, Mr. Spratt said. That made them the harshest tornadoes since 1966, when 11 people were killed, he said. Two tornadoes in 1962 killed 17 people, he said.
"This shows that El Nino is very dangerous for Florida" Mr. Spratt said.
Today's tornadoes were the deadliest in Florida since the National Weather Service started keeping detailed records a half-century ago, and were the deadliest storms since 1992, when Hurricane Andrew raked Florida and Louisiana, killing at least 32 people there and in the Bahamas.
Officials with the Federal Emergency Management Agency were already here assessing damage from flooding in the last two months, when the next emergency struck. The agency director, James Lee Witt, accompanied Gov. Lawton Chiles and members of Florida's Congressional delegation in surveying the damage.
President Clinton said he would tour the state on Wednesday to survey the damage.
At the Ponderosa Park Campground for recreational vehicles near here, where eight people died and 50 others were injured, search crews with dogs looked throughout the day for six people reported missing. Debris from the park was wrapped around trees and flung onto the Florida Turnpike close by.
A Ponderosa resident, William Asbill, 33, sat in a wheelchair in the lobby of the Osceola Regional Medical Center emergency room. Beside him were two small plastic bags filled with wet clothes, all he had salvaged from his wrecked camper. Two television sets in the lobby broadcase live pictures of the damage, some of the shots from helicopters, but Mr. Asbill, his head swathed in a huge bandage, paid no attention.
"I woke up with the wind smashing the windows," he said. "Then it hit, turned me upside down, cut my ear off. My camper was upside down. My neighbor's camper was on top of it. It blew all the windows out of my van. Crushed my motorcycle. It's under the camper."
By the time he got over the shock, Mr. Asbill's left ear dangled by a thread of skin. He pressed it to his head, and a surgeon later reattached it.
When the wind and lightning came, Mike Cowart, his girlfriend, Gloria Jones, and their 20-month-old son, Cody, were inside a 27-foot camper at the Ponderosa.
"The wind woke me up and I looked out the window and it was regular lightning," said Mr. Cowart, 40. "Next thing I knew the lightning was turning blue and I saw the twister coming right at us. I grabbed Gloria and Cody and put them on the floor and covered them. Next thing, I was flying through the air inside the camper. It was spinning side over side about five times. Then it slammed into a pine tree and stopped, wheels up. I thought we were going to die. I kicked the door open and got them out."
Mr. Cowart returned for his boots and Cody's slippers. It took 42 stitches to close a gash in his left hand. He said he moved his family to the camp two months ago from Orlando. Mr. Cowart is an unemployed heavy equipment operator and had no insurance for the camper or his family's belongings.
Cody suffered a bruised head and Ms. Jones a nasty bump on her chin.
"Trailers were wrapped around trees," Ms. Jones said. "Pieces of metal were twisted everywhere. Our pick-up truck was five feet away from the camper, and it only had a cracked windshield and a flat tire. We were lucky."

HEADLINE: The Newest Temps in Law Firms: Lawyers

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
After practicing law in California for 10 years, Gideon E. Mark realized that he preferred problem solving to confrontation and wanted to be a management consultant instead of a litigator. He got a master's degree in business from Columbia University but could not pay for the additional schooling he needed to switch professions.
So two years ago, Mr. Mark became a temp. 
 He joined the ranks of thousands of other New York lawyers who have temporary assignments at law firms and corporate legal departments, and wound up making more than $100,000 last year. Now he is a full-time student at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University as well as a part-time legal temp in the New York office of Sonnenschein Nath & Rosenthal, a large Chicago law firm.
"I would not say I am treated as an equal, but on the other hand I am not treated with disrespect," said Mr. Mark, now 38, alluding to the law firm. But to him these are acceptable trade-offs. "My temp job is paying for Harvard," he said. "It's worked out very well."
Not long ago, it was unheard-of for partners and associates in fancy New York law firms to work alongside lawyers provided by temp agencies, and even today partners at many law firms are unwilling to admit publicly that they are supervising lawyers that they themselves did not hire, train and inculcate with their firm's traditions.
But the hiring of temporary lawyers, which started as a trickle more than 10 years ago, is suddenly a growth industry. Nationwide, the temp lawyer business is growing at a rate of 30 percent a year, almost three times as fast as the staffing industry as a whole. Peter Yessne, the editor of Staffing Industry Report, an industry newsletter, says the temp lawyer business is making an estimated $500 million a year, with up to $200 million of that sum in the New York metropolitan region, the largest market for temp lawyers in the nation.
The growing acceptance of legal temps owes a lot to the downsizing that occurred at many law firms during the recession of the early 1990's, after the rapid expansion of the 80's. That experience has made the firms wary of overstaffing, even in more prosperous times.
Corporate clients have also become increasingly vocal about skyrocketing legal costs, and often demand that firms hold down fees by using contract help, especially for routine work like reviewing documents. A firm may bill as much as $350 an hour for an experienced associate, while the top rate for a temp lawyer is about $95 an hour.
"It's a wonderful way to control costs for the client," said Alan J. Pomerantz, a partner at the New York law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges. "The key is to make sure that you screen these people very well."
To cut costs, the 62 law firms retained by the Prudential Corporation must agree to hire temps from the Wallace Law Registry of Hartford when they need to bring in extra lawyers, said Bill Fellers, the vice president for administration in the company's legal department in Newark. The legal department itself has 25 to 30 temp lawyers at a given time, he said.
Some of the people who work as temps are mothers of young children, like Jennifer L. Warren, a Yale Law School graduate who is filling in for a lawyer on maternity leave at a large cable television entertainment company. "If I were to sign on to a job full time in a permanent capacity," said Ms. Warren, 37, "I'd feel like I'd be putting my job before my family."
Employment agencies say that many temps are experienced lawyers who are making midlife career changes or want more flexibility than a full-time associate is likely to get. Still others are sole practitioners seeking additional income or recent graduates of less-than-elite law schools trying to jump-start their careers.
Brad Hildebrandt, the chairman of Hildebrandt, a Somerset, N.J., consulting company specializing in the legal field, said that some law firms were hobbled by an "elitist attitude" toward temps. "If you approach it by thinking that only mediocre people would do this," he said, "you don't understand the labor force."
In early 1995, Elie Gordis and Jay B. Horowitz, both associates at the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, were researching the possibility of starting a temp agency for lawyers and paralegals. They placed newspaper advertisements seeking applicants and drew 800 responses the first week, they said.
"The quality of the resumes made us realize we could do this," Mr. Gordis said.
In two years, they had expanded their offices in midtown Manhattan to 4,000 square feet, from 1,500, and last month their company, Strategic Legal Services, was acquired by Staffmark, a national staffing company in Fayetteville, Ark. Mr. Gordis and Mr. Horowitz will continue to run their old company.
One lawyer they placed was Victoria L. Watson, a former colleague at Skadden, Arps. After her father died, leaving her with a financially troubled restaurant in Cape May, N.J., she took a leave from the firm and soon realized she could no longer practice law full time and run the restaurant. Since then, she has worked as a temp at two New York firms. As part of her arrangement, she gets the summer off to spend in Cape May.
"I'm making a lot less money than I would be at Skadden," Ms. Watson, 42, said, "but I've learned how to live on less money. Between money and freedom, I think freedom is winning out."
Some New York law firms said they were not comfortable with the idea of using temporary legal help. "For the nature of our business, we can't bring people in when we don't know how good the person is," said Michael S. Mullman, a managing partner at Tenzer Greenblatt, a firm with 85 lawyers. "Our clients are paying us substantial fees."
But a number of other employers willing to talk about their contract lawyers said they were very satisfied with the service.
White & Case recently signed 100 temp lawyers to work on an antitrust case involving 10 million pages of documents, said Owen C. Pell, the administrative partner of the New York firm's litigation department.
"By using the temp lawyers effectively, I was able to focus my people on the really important stuff," Mr. Pell said. "We had a great result."

HEADLINE: Mancur Olson, 66, a Professor And Author of Economics Books

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Mancur Olson, 66, an economist at the University of Maryland widely admired for his research on how groups that represent specialized interests affect economic growth, died last Thursday. He lived in University Park, Md.
The cause of death was a sudden heart attack, the university said.
Mr. Olson graduated from North Dakota State University and was a Rhodes Scholar at University College, Oxford, before he earned a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard in 1963. His first academic job, as an assistant professor at Princeton University, was followed by a two-year period in Washington as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. But most of his career was spent at the University of Maryland, where he joined the economics department in 1969 after leaving the Government. 
 His first book, "The Logic of Collective Action," published in 1971, was a seminal work in the then-new field of "public choice," the study of how economic decisions are made within organizations -- governments, unions and the like -- that are not subject to the direct discipline of the marketplace. But his most widely debated book was "The Rise and Decline of Nations," published in 1982, an ambitious effort to explain why economies eventually stagnate.
"There have been whole conferences devoted to Olson's work," said a Maryland colleague, Thomas Schelling. "But he was one of those strange economists who was always better known among political scientists and sociologists."
Mr. Olson put his insights to practical use, creating the University of Maryland's Center for Institutional Reform and the Informal Sector in 1990. Working with grants from the Agency for International Development, the center has advised 30 countries ranging from Russia to Egypt.
Surviving are his wife, Alison; a daughter, Ellika, of Blacksberg Va.; two sons, Severin and Sander, both of College Park, Md., and a brother, Gaylord, of Grand Falls, N.D.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 5, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Feb. 24 about Mancur Olson, an economist, misidentified the North Dakota hometown of a surviving brother, Gaylord. It is Buxton.

HEADLINE: Clinton Budget Will Only Add to the Surplus

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Social Security and Abracadabras" (Op-Ed, Feb. 18): 
 John F. Cogan, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, asserts that President Clinton's budget spends the projected surplus, reverses course on the end of the era of big government, raises the Federal tax burden, and breaks the budget rules. This is wrong.
With Washington in a frenzy to spend the budget surplus, the President rallied the country around reserving every penny of it until we have strengthened Social Security. A closer look shows that our budget actually adds $800 million to the surplus over the next five years.
By doing that, we continue the fiscal discipline that has sparked an investment-led expansion. Unlike in the 1980's, the public sector is now shrinking, and the private sector is growing faster.
President Clinton has delivered lower taxes and smaller government. Spending as a share of the economy is the lowest in 25 years, and the typical American family of four now faces the lightest Federal tax burden since 1976.
Our budget builds on that success, offers new tax cuts and sticks to tough rules that make us pay for every dollar we spend. Will Congress do the same?
 
FRANKLIN RAINES
GENE SPERLING
Washington, Feb. 24, 1998
 
The writers are, respectively, director of the Office of Management and Budget and director of the National Economic Council.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
No doubt about it now: During 1997 air fares took the biggest annual jump in four years.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
AMERICAN EXPRESS has confirmed what business travelers have contended for months: During 1997 air fares underwent the largest annual increase in the last four years.
The company, which has been following air fares for six years, found that the typical business fare -- a three-day advance purchase ticket -- in the 215 domestic city pairs it tracks rose 16 percent last year over 1996. Fares in 1996 jumped 9 percent over 1995, while fares in 1995 rose 3 percent over 1994. 
 Since American Express began surveying fares, the highest year-to-year increase came in 1993, a 22 percent surge over 1992, following a recession and a fare-restructuring trial by carriers. The only time fares have fallen since American Express began monitoring them came in 1994, when they dropped 6 percent.
At least one Wall Street analyst believes the rate of these increases might actually moderate in the not-too-distant future. Sam Buttrick, airline analyst for Paine Webber, said: "We may have hit the near-term ceiling on high-end business fares, for political if not economic reasons. There seems to be a rising chorus in Washington about the level of business fares and the competitive practices of major airlines."
In fact, next month the Department of Transportation will issue a proposed competition policy for the airline industry. One of the main issues that will be covered will be domination of hubs by established carriers, which is seen by many as the primary reason for fare escalation.
Among other recent airline developments, UAL's United Airlines is starting one daily nonstop flight between Bradley International Airport in Hartford and the carrier's hub in San Francisco on April 5. The flight, on an Airbus A319, will be the only nonstop transcontinental service out of Hartford.
Also, the Virgin Group's Virgin Atlantic has started "drive through" check-in for business-class passengers departing from Newark International Airport. Passengers, who receive limousine service to the airport, can check in from their car when they arrive at a special enclosed counter outside the terminal; their luggage is also collected and processed there. Security procedures are conducted before boarding. Gareth Edmondson-Jones, a spokesman for Virgin, said the carrier hoped to eventually institute the service at its seven other United States gateways.
 
Hotel Update
The 96-year-old Algonquin Hotel, a historic New York City landmark that is popular with some business travelers, is undergoing a $5.5 million restoration that will be completed by May. Home of the famous Round Table of literary lions earlier in the century, the 165-room hotel, owned by the Camberley Hotel Company, is being redecorated in the turn-of-the century Arts and Crafts style. Both public and guest rooms will be furnished with English and American antiques, and hall corridors will be decorated with wallpaper that replicates cartoons from The New Yorker, whose editors and writers were Round Table devotees. Fitness and business centers will also be added.
Gordon Campbell-Gray, the British hotelier and former owner of the Draycott in London, will open a new hotel there, to be called One Aldwych, in June. Situated at the corner of the Strand and Aldwych, the hotel is in a fully renovated 1906 landmark building by Mewis & Davis, the architectural firm that designed the Ritz hotels in London, Paris and Madrid. The hotel will have 105 rooms -- including 12 suites, two with private gyms and one with a fireplace and dining room; a private screening room; two meeting rooms; a health club and swimming pool, and two restaurants. All guest rooms will be furnished with electrical outlets that accommodate non-European appliances, as well as high-speed Internet connections. Guests will be assigned private phone and fax numbers. Room rates will range from $295 to $400 a night through the end of August, when they will increase to $380 to $485. Suites will begin at $525 initially, then rise to $650.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Fed Chairman's Testimony Before House Panel

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before the House Banking Committee: 
 The key question going forward is whether the restraint building from the turmoil in Asia will be sufficient to check inflationary tendencies that might otherwise result from the strength of domestic spending and tightening labor markets. The depth of the adjustment abroad will depend on the extent of weakness in the financial sectors of Asian economies and the speed with which structural inefficiencies in the financial and nonfinancial sectors of those economies are corrected. If, as we suspect, the restraint coming from Asia is sufficient to bring the demand for American labor back into line with the growth of the working-age population desirous of working, labor markets will remain unusually tight, but any intensification of inflation should be delayed, very gradual, and readily reversible. However, we cannot rule out two other, more worrisome possibilities. On the one hand, should the momentum to domestic spending not be offset significantly by Asian or other developments, the U.S. economy would be on a track along which spending could press too strongly against available resources to be consistent with contained inflation. On the other, we also need to be alert to the possibility that the forces from Asia might damp activity and prices by more than is desirable by exerting a particularly forceful drag on the volume of net exports and the prices of imports. . . .
Without doubt, lenders have provided important support to spending in the past few years by their willingness to transact at historically small margins and in large volumes. Equity investors have contributed as well by apparently pricing in the expectation of substantial earnings gains and requiring modest compensation for the risk that those expectations could be mistaken. . . .
But we must be concerned about becoming too complacent about evaluating repayment risks. All too often at this stage of the business cycle, the loans that banks extend later make up a disproportionate share of total nonperforming loans. In addition, quite possibly, 12 or 18 months hence, some of the securities purchased on the market could be looked upon with some regret by investors. As one of the nation's bank supervisors, the Federal Reserve will make every effort to encourage banks to apply sound underwriting standards in their lending. Prudent lenders should consider a wide range of economic situations in evaluating credit; to do otherwise would risk contributing to potentially disruptive financial problems down the road.
A second area of concern involves our nation's continuing role in the new high-tech international financial system. By joining with our major trading partners and international financial institutions in helping to stabilize the economies of Asia and promoting needed structural changes, we are also encouraging the continued expansion of world trade and global economic and financial stability on which the ongoing increase of our own standards of living depends. If we were to cede our role as a world leader, or backslide into protectionist policies, we would threaten the source of much of our own sustained economic growth.
A third risk is complacency about inflation prospects. The combination and interaction of significant increases in productivity-improving technologies, sharp declines in budget deficits and disciplined monetary policy has damped product price changes, bringing them to near stability. While part of this result owes to good policy, part is the product of the fortuitous emergence of new technologies and of some favorable price developments in imported goods. However, as history counsels, it is unwise to count on any string of good fortune to continue indefinitely.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Greenspan's Comments and Scuttled Merger Dampen Market

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Rising Treasury bond yields and the scuttling of what was expected to be the largest merger ever dampened enthusiasm for stocks yesterday.
Stocks were dragged lowered after comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, dashed the bond market's hopes that the Fed would lower interest rates sometime soon. 
 In testimony before Congress, Mr. Greenspan said that the effects of Asia's economic crisis on American companies might be partly offset by rising labor costs in the United States. Analysts and investors interpreted the remarks as a sign that the Federal Reserve would not lower short-term interest rates to stimulate economic growth.
Bond prices fell sharply, causing the yield on the 30-year United States Treasury bond to jump 6 basis points, to 5.96 percent. Those rising yields increased the attractiveness of bonds as an investment and caused some investors to shed stocks and buy Treasuries, said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker in Baltimore. Stock investors were also disheartened by the breakdown of merger talks between SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome.
They announced after the market closed on Monday that the talks had ended.
"Those elements that had been driving the market -- particularly takeovers -- became unglued," Mr. Cripps said. The breakup of the drug deal "interjected a degree of uncertainty" and alerted investors to the risks of investing in takover stocks because "not all takeovers that are rumored out there happen," Mr. Cripps said.
Drug company shares including Merck, Pfizer, American Home Products and Eli Lilly fell on the news and helped to push both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 index lower. The Dow fell 40.10 points, to 8,370.10. The S.& P. 500 slipped 7.58 points, to 1,030.56.
Those declines dragged the Amex pharmaceutical index, which has been one of the year's best perfomers, down 2.5 percent yesterday. The index is up 13.06 percent this year. After reaching a new closing high on Monday, the Nasdaq composite index slumped 13.05 points, to 1,738.71, with shares of Intel, Worldcom, Cisco Systems and Dell leading the declines.
Earnings disappointments also cast a pall on the market.
Nike shares closed down 3 9/16, to 43 1/8, after the company warned that fiscal third-quarter earnings may fall below analysts' expectations because of larger-than-expected order declines in Asia and retailers' price cuts on its products.
The revenue shortfalls will cause Nike to lay off workers and cut costs, said Rick Anguilla, director of investor relations at Nike. Previously, the company had layoffs in the 1994 fiscal year.
The company said it expects diluted earnings per share to be between 24 cents and 28 cents a share, below analysts' forecasts of 38 cents.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Injects a Note of Caution on the Good Times

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned investors and lenders today against assuming that economic good times would last forever and suggested they could be underestimating the risks confronting the economy's powerful seven-year-old expansion.
Saying he wanted to add some cautionary notes to an otherwise upbeat assessment of the economy on a day that brought new evidence of stable prices and buoyant consumer confidence, Mr. Greenspan said "events in the months ahead are not likely to unfold smoothly," especially given the financial turmoil in Asia. 
 He gave no clear indication of whether the central bank felt it must raise or lower interest rates this year, saying in testimony to a House panel that the economy remained balanced between potential inflationary pressures and forces that could lead to recession and falling prices.
While acknowledging the ideal combination of strong growth, low unemployment and price stability over the last year, Mr. Greenspan said the country should battle "complacency about inflation prospects." He said banks and investors in particular might want to re-examine their relentlessly optimistic outlook.
"All too often at this stage of the business cycle, the loans that banks extend later make up a disproportionate share of total nonperforming loans," Mr. Greenspan said, referring to loans paid delinquently. "In addition, quite possibly, 12 or 18 months hence, some of the securities purchased on the market currently could be looked upon with some regret by investors."
By many measures, lenders and investors in the stock market are demanding less in the way of protection against risks by historical standards, Mr. Greenspan said.
"The implication is that the market is saying that there is something different about this particular economic environment," he said. "I am not inclined to go that far."
His remarks had a dampening influence on the financial markets, partly countering the effects of the latest evidence of the economy's healthy performance, which showed no overall inflation in January and a surging level of consumer confidence.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 40.10 points, to 8,370.10, partly dragged down by a slump in the bond market. Bond prices weakened after Mr. Greenspan gave no indication that the Fed would cut interest rates anytime soon.
The Consumer Price Index was unchanged last month, the Labor Department said, the first time in four years that the monthly gauge of price pressures did not rise on a seasonally adjusted basis. For the last 12 months, the inflation rate was just 1.6 percent. The lack of inflation last month partly resulted from a drop in oil prices, but even after excluding volatile food and energy prices, inflation edged up just two-tenths of a percent in January.
The January figures were the first calculated by the Bureau of Labor Statistics using a revised market basket of consumer goods that takes into account changing consumer behavior and changes in technology. Economists said the changes, including the addition of expenses like cellular phone services and steps to account for the improving quality of computers, would shave small amounts off the price index over the course of the year but had no effect in January.
The combination of robust growth, low unemployment and dormant inflation helped push consumer confidence in February to its highest level since 1968, said the Conference Board, the research organization that conducts a widely followed monthly survey.
In his testimony before the House Banking Committee's monetary policy subcommittee, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged the economy's "exemplary" performance last year and its continued strength early this year.
But he reiterated his projection that the effects of the financial turmoil in Asia were likely to slow growth in the United States this year.
So far, though, the Federal Reserve has been unable to determine how much the economy will slow, he said.
Indeed, the central bank confronts two conflicting possible situations: that Asia's problems will not slow growth enough in the United States to avert an upturn in inflation driven by rising labor costs, and that Asia's problems will slow the economy too much, tipping the United States into recession and leading the general price level to decline.
Confronted with what he called these "finely balanced though powerful forces" tugging and pulling at the economy, Mr. Greenspan suggested the Fed was uncertain whether it would need to raise or lower interest rates this year.
Mr. Greenspan said one of the major developments in the economy in the last year has been an increase in the growth rate of productivity, or output per hour worked. Productivity growth has fallen gradually over much of the last 25 years, a trend that now shows some signs of reversing.
But while productivity has helped dampen inflation, Mr. Greenspan said strong demand for goods and services continued to force employers to scramble for new workers at a time when unemployment, at 4.8 percent, is near a quarter-century low. As a result, wage gains are accelerating -- good news for workers but historically a warning sign of incipient inflation.
"Should demand for new workers continue to exceed new supply, we would expect wage gains increasingly to exceed productivity growth, squeezing profit margins and eventually leading to a pickup in inflation," Mr. Greenspan said.
The question now, the Fed chairman said, was whether the crisis in Asia would slow growth in the United States sufficiently to avert that inflationary outcome. An expected downturn in exports to Asia would create a "discernible drag" on growth in the United States, Mr. Greenspan said, but he added that the Fed did not yet have a sense of how sharp the downturn would be.
As a result, he said, the Fed's economic forecasts for the year are particularly tentative. Fed policy makers see growth slowing this year to between 2 and 2.75 percent, compared with 3.8 percent last year, with unemployment and inflation remaining at around current levels. Fed economists, along with most of their counterparts in the private sector, have been predicting a slowdown in growth for the last several years, and have been regularly confounded by the economy's resilience.

HEADLINE: Citing Improving Economy, Moody's Raises City's Bond Rating

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
A major Wall Street credit-rating agency raised New York's long-term creditworthiness yesterday, citing the city's improving economy and City Hall's prudent budget management.
The announcement, by Moody's Investors Service, increased the city's rating to A3, up one notch from Baa1, where it was since 1991. That kept New York ahead of other big cities like Philadelphia and Detroit and behind Los Angeles, Chicago and Boston. 
 The upgrade was not unexpected and, in fact, the city's bonds had been trading at the higher level for several months, experts said. But the news -- coupled with a recent announcement by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the other major credit agency, that it was considering raising the city's rating -- was an important psychological endorsement of the city's financial condition.
"The city's finances are probably as good as they've been since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's from a credit-rating perspective," said Robert A. Kurtter, a senior vice president at Moody's. Mr. Kurtter added that although the new ranking was the same one that the city held from 1988 to 1991, the city's financial underpinnings were not so solid then because its employee payroll and the cost of its social programs were spiraling upward.
Moody's tempered its report by saying that the city's economic growth still lagged the rest of the nation's and that it faced enormous challenges, including a "high and growing debt burden, a history of structural budget imbalance and a cyclical economy."
But the agency's decision to issue the upgrade months before the city's adoption of a final budget for the next fiscal year gave a symbolic boost to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's stewardship over the city's multibillion-dollar budget. Just three years ago, S. & P. had cited the Mayor's use of fiscal gimmicks when it downgraded the city's' rating.
"We've worked hard to achieve this upgrade," said Randy M. Mastro, Deputy Mayor for Operations. "It's a reflection that Moody's realizes this Mayor is committed to keeping this city on this kind of sound financial course in the future."
The Moody's upgrade had been anticipated since last July, when the agency gave the city a positive credit outlook. But its timing -- months before the adoption of a final budget in June -- surprised some officials and investors. S. & P., for example, is waiting to see what shape the budget takes following negotiations between the Mayor and City Council before making its announcement.
Mr. Kurtter said that Moody's decided to make its announcement yesterday because, if history was any indication, City Council leaders and Mr. Giuliani would agree on a budget that resembled the preliminary version the Mayor presented last month. In that, he proposed using 73 percent of this year's $1.2 billion surplus to help close next year's budget gap. That idea drew mostly positive feedback from City Council leaders.
Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the Council, said that coming negotiations would produce a budget that was "fiscally responsible."
The rating change affects the $30 billion in general-obligation bonds the city has issued over the years to finance the construction and renovations of projects like bridges, roads and buildings. In theory, the city's improved bond rating would save millions of dollars by making its bonds attractive to more investors and allowing the city to offer them with less interest. Many institutions, like banks and mutual funds, do not invest in bonds with a rating lower than the A level.
"Most New Yorkers who trade bonds live here," said Duncan K. Smith, a senior managing director at Lebenthal & Company, which deals heavily in the city's bonds. "We're pretty much in agreement that the quality of life in the city has improved, unless you have kids in the public schools, which is one of the city's big problems."
Mr. Smith said that the city's bonds had been trading at the higher level for several months and that many traders received confirmation that the bonds deserved such a rating last fall, when it became clear that the city would enjoy a huge surplus for the second straight year.
