HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
New Diagnostics for Building Facades

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
As the recent partial collapse of the facade of a building at Madison Avenue and 55th Street and other incidents around the city have shown, problems with construction and weathering can cause brickwork to peel away from the main part of a structure.
As a result of the recent accidents, the city appears ready to stiffen facade inspection requirements and expand them to the entire outside of a building, not just the part overlooking sidewalks. 
 This, in turn, is prompting some property managers to adopt new technologies to measure more accurately the condition of brick facades. Fiber optic devices can look inside walls through relatively small holes, making it unnecessary to chop out whole sections, and a laser measuring system can produce precise written and visual reports on the location and, over time, changes in location of each section of brick in a facade. If those bricks appear to be in a different position in subsequent inspections, managers would have reason to suspect that something is amiss.
Engineers say modern construction spaces brick facades one to two inches from the main structure of a building to add a layer of insulating air that acts much like a two-pane storm window.
Although it appears from the outside that the brick walls are continuous from bottom to top, in practice there is a steel shelf at each floor, so the bricks at the bottom do not have to bear the entire weight of those higher up, explained Anthony Pagnotta, an engineer with HLW International, a New York architectural and engineering firm.
To tie the bricks to the main structure of the building, bricklayers are supposed to use thousands of strips of metal, called wall ties, that are fixed in the building and are inserted into the mortar that binds the individual bricks together. It is good practice to use the ties on every other course of brick vertically and about six inches apart horizontally, Mr. Pagnotta said.
City officials said it was a lack of these ties that helped cause the partial collapse of a facade on the building at 540 Madison Avenue late last year.
But other things can go wrong, most of them involving water. If rain seeps between the bricks and collects inside the air gap, the wall ties and supporting shelf can corrode, destabilizing the facade.
City regulations require landlords to hire a qualified architect or engineer to visually inspect the front and the first 20 feet of the side walls of a building more than six stories tall. They are to look for cracking, rust stains and other signs of distress.
But some managers say they want earlier warnings so they can make repairs before problems spread and become more expensive. "Any property manager who relies on city minimum inspections is crazy," said Bill Porceller, a manager at the Sage Realty Corporation. Measuring with a laser, he said, produces a report that positions the brick facade within one-sixteenth of an inch, which is more precise than is possible with a visual inspection.
Others say detailed examinations of facades are most economically used when trouble has already developed. "The laser is a great technology, but it is best used when you have a problem," said John Santora, senior managing director of Cushman & Wakefield, which manages 60 million square feet of property in the New York metropolitan region.
Lon Best, the president of A Best Contracting Company, which specializes in facade repairs, said that during an inspection the laser light source is installed near the brick wall, sending out a vertical wall of light parallel to the wall. With this in place, workers on a scaffold position an instrument directly over the laser beam and measure from there to the surface of the bricks with a ruler.
With this information and follow-up inspections, a building manager or owner can decide whether parts of the wall are shifting because of deterioration or whether the undulations in a wall are the result of the original construction because they do not change from year to year. Mr. Best said that a planned $4 million repair of 425 Park Avenue, at 55th Street, was cut to $360,000 as a result of a laser survey.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "HOW IT WORKS: Reading a Building's Face"
Engineers are using lasers to inspect the facades of buildings and monitor deviations over time.
 
1. ALIGN TO LASER -- Working across the building at about every half floor, surveyors align a device called a catcher to a beam from a laser attached to the building.
 
2. MEASURE DISTANCES -- With a slide ruler, they then measure and record the distance between the laser beam and the wall.
 
3. ESTABLISH SURVEY POINTS -- Measurements are documented to establish an initial surface of surveyed points that future inspectors can reread and compare to detect movement.
 
4. ALIGN LASER TO WALL -- Two rods attached to the building's steel structure on either side of the laser are marked where the beam hits them. The next time the laser is activated, the points are used to align the beam for future readings.
 
(Sources: A Best Contracting; Anthony Pagnotta, HLW International)

HEADLINE: Canada Presents Balanced Budget, the First in Almost 30 Years

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 24

 BODY:
After several years of cutting deeply into some of Canada's most cherished social programs, the Government today introduced the first balanced budget in nearly 30 years, cautiously promising to restore some services and lower taxes without returning to the big spending that first put the budget in the red in 1970.
The budget, the equivalent of $104 billion (United States), increases spending on education and health and offers modest tax cuts to 5 million lower-paid Canadians. 
 Officials forecast balanced budgets for the next two years as well, and pledged to direct up to $2 billion a year toward reducing Canada's $410 billion debt.
The budget offers Prime Minister Jean Chretien a chance to stake out a more active role for his Liberal Government after many years in which spending for universal health care, welfare and education had to be curtailed. The cuts often had a painful effect on those parts of Canadian life that people here believed made Canada a more compassionate nation than the United States.
Balancing the books also allows Mr. Chretien to divert attention from the growing discord in the French-speaking province of Quebec. Separatist leaders have stepped up their attacks on the federal Government since Ottawa challenged the legality of Quebec secession in the Supreme Court last week.
Quebec leaders say they are prepared to call provincial elections this spring, which could be followed by a third divisive referendum on separation.
But as the budget was presented in the House of Commons this afternoon, the Liberals glowed confidently behind Finance Minister Paul Martin.
"We today are living a turning point in our history," Mr. Martin declared. "Never again will we allow the specter of overspending to haunt this land."
Mr. Chretien's balanced budget comes just three weeks after President Clinton announced the first balanced budget for the United States in 30 years.
Cautious accounting allowed both leaders to get spending under control. They also benefited from improving economic conditions that generated additional tax revenues and lowered interest payments to such an extent that balanced budgets were reached years before they had been expected.
When Mr. Chretien took office in November 1993, he inherited a deficit of nearly $30 billion.
The Canadian leader, elected to a second term last year, has made it clear that after slashing social spending to eliminate the deficit, he wants his Liberal Party Government to regain some of the compassion for which past Liberal governments have been known. In particular, he is establishing a $2 billion scholarship fund that will provide 100,000 college students up to $2,100 a year for the 10 years, starting in 2000.
Preston Manning, leader of the opposition Reform Party, said that instead of increasing spending, the Government should have focused on giving taxpayers real relief. The new budget raises the personal exemption for low- and moderate-income taxpayers. A surtax imposed by the previous Government to help wipe out the deficit will be lifted for 13 million middle-income taxpayers.
But many Canadians feel the cost of balancing the budget has been too high. Unemployment continues at 8.9 percent, about twice the United States average. School spending has declined, hospitals have been closed and nursing staffs have been reduced because of budget cuts.

HEADLINE: Grand Central Gets Northern Exposure;
The Terminal Is Looking Uptown With a New Maze of Passageways

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
While no one was looking, Grand Central Terminal grew four blocks longer.
When the transformation is complete, travelers should be able to enter or leave the terminal directly through a glass-walled pavilion at the corner of Park Avenue and 48th Street. Or on 47th Street, near Madison Avenue. Or through the arcades of the Helmsley Building, at Park Avenue at 46th Street. 
 For the 40,000 commuters whose destinations are north of Grand Central -- half the rush-hour ridership on the Metro-North Railroad -- these entrances will reduce travel time by up to 15 minutes, railroad officials said. They plan to have some entrances open later this year, with the whole project completed in January.
The new entrances, connected to underground passageways and walkways, will fundamentally reorient Grand Central to the north, reflecting the uptown shift in Manhattan's center of economic gravity since the terminal was built 85 years ago resolutely facing south, with its most sumptuous facade and monumental entrance on 42d Street.
But what may be most remarkable about the five-year, $95 million construction project, known as North End Access, is that it has happened almost without notice.
Even as passengers scurried to catch the 5:44 to Stamford or the 5:56 to Dobbs Ferry, an army of workers has been creating a three-level labyrinth through the double-deck railyard beneath Park Avenue. To commuters, the only visible traces have been glass-block bulkheads sprouting on the platforms. This low public profile has actually been cultivated by Metro-North, a division of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
"We knew this would be a long project and we knew we would come up against unforeseen obstacles," said Donald N. Nelson, the railroad's president until March 5, when he is to leave to become an executive at Conrail. "It was not a project we wanted to tout until we were ready to open it up."
In fact, Mr. Nelson's caution was well founded. The project was originally supposed to cost $70 million and take only three years, but it has been repeatedly delayed by the unexpected challenges involved in threading the new pedestrian system through the ganglia of Grand Central and surrounding buildings. And even more dexterity was needed to do so without curtailing passenger service.
"When you boil it all down, it's fairly straightforward work erecting steel and pouring concrete," John R. Seaboldt, the project manager for Metro-North, said. "When you try to do it around an operating railroad, that's the biggest challenge."
The basic layout of the plan is simple. Two walkways running parallel to the tracks will take the place of passenger platforms along Tracks 22 and 31. Two passageways will cut across, perpendicular to the tracks: one, created from an old mail and baggage transfer tunnel, runs under 45th Street below the lower-level tracks, while the other, a newly constructed mezzanine, runs under 47th Street between the upper and lower tracks.
Along the passageways will be mosaic, glass and bronze panels depicting cosmological ideas about the night sky. The work, by Ellen Driscoll, was commissioned by the M.T.A. Arts for Transit program. Ceilings in the passageways will be painted blue, echoing the constellation-studded ceiling over the main concourse.
"The route should have some degree of recall of Grand Central Terminal itself," said John Belle of Beyer Blinder Belle, the architects responsible for design, in association with STV Inc., the overall architects and engineers on the project.
Already at the west end of the 45th Street passageway, buff-colored terrazzo walls have been installed. But the east end of the 47th Street passageway is still a gaping incision, with trains rumbling above and below, framed by jagged edges of steel girders that have been cut away.
In this Stygian setting, it is not hard to imagine muggers on the prowl. But Mr. Nelson said as many as seven Metro-North police officers might be assigned to patrol the north end. And Mr. Seaboldt said there will be closed-circuit cameras along the brightly lit passageways, and at every stairway and elevator. There will also be a police office near the 47th Street entrance.
"We expect we have covered all the bases with respect to security," Mr. Seaboldt said.
The passages, which can be locked off from the rest of the terminal, might be open from 5:30 A.M. to 11:30 P.M. on weekdays, with shorter hours on weekends and holidays.
Assuming that the system is well received and heavily used, however, would that not drain thousands of potential customers away from the retail and restaurant complex being built within the landmark terminal? LaSalle Partners, the retail developers at Grand Central, would not hazard a guess publicly -- nor, indeed, say anything at all. Paul F. Kastner, the marketing director, referred all questions to the M.T.A.
Mr. Nelson said he did not foresee a problem. "The revitalized terminal is going to attract so many additional people that it will more than make up for the loss of those who go out the north end," he said.
The notion of opening up the northern end of Grand Central goes back at least to the 1970's; one plan in the 1980's called for eight new entrances. Work on the current, more modest approach began in earnest in 1994.
Many construction delays occurred because of differences between actual conditions and those documented in existing plans: three layers of steel plates where blueprints showed two, cross-bracing where drawings showed none, an unmapped level of groundwater below 45th Street and uncharted electrical conduits and utility lines almost everywhere.
"There are hidden gems that keep getting discovered," said Alfred Klein, vice president of STV. (He allowed that "gem" was not the word generally used by workers for the contractor, Yonkers Contracting Company, when they came across an unexpected piece of steel.)
Nothing was easy. Temporary chutes had to be built through abandoned elevator shafts and street gratings to deliver concrete. A 16-inch steam line serving the huge Met Life Building had to be shifted north.
Then there was the X that marked the spot of perhaps the greatest structural challenge. The X was a railroad crossing under a giant girder that had to be cut in order to link the 47th Street passageway on one side to the platform for Tracks 29 and 30 on the other side.
The girder could not be cut unless it was reinforced from below. Because of the crossing, however, there was no room to erect extra columns under the girder. Complicating matters further, the girder carried the weight not only of the upper-level tracks but also supported columns coming down from the street.
"We were not going to take out Park Avenue," Mr. Seaboldt said, with an engineer's understatement.
Instead, the answer was to design and fabricate two entirely new girder sections, 32 feet long and weighing 15 tons each, with a hump in the middle about 12 feet high. They were brought into the terminal on a specially modified railroad car.
While he is obviously proud of the accumulated expertise, Mr. Seaboldt is unsure how applicable it will be after next year. "I don't know whether this is a learning experience or not," he said, "because I don't think we're going to be doing this again."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Retreat After Fed Chief Dims Hopes for Rate Cut

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell sharply yesterday after the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, delivered a cautionary message on the economy that indicated that the central bank was unlikely to change its current monetary policy any time soon.
The market's response to Mr. Greenspan's comments, which came during his semiannual report to the House Banking Committee's monetary policy subcommittee, made it clear that many investors had been looking for the Fed to cut interest rates in the near future. 
 But Mr. Greenspan said policy was "on hold," in part because uncertainties in the outlook in the United States and in Asia made it more difficult than normal to gauge the direction of the economy. That, he said, meant that a pre-emptive strike, in which the Fed changes policy well before a trend gathers steam, would have to be delayed.
"It is quite conceivable to me that even though we would like to be pre-emptive, we may not be able to be pre-emptive, largely because there are certain types of events in world economies which are very difficult to anticipate," Mr. Greenspan said. "So we may find ourselves being less pre-emptive than we would like to be."
His comments led to a selloff, especially in the short end of the market, where the yields on two-year notes had fallen below the Fed's 5.5 percent target for overnight loans between banks, known as the Federal funds rate, which has been held at that level since last March.
The yield on the expiring two-year note jumped to 5.54 percent, from 5.42 percent on Monday, and yesterday's auction of a new two-year note suffered, with the new issue awarded at 5.537 percent and ending the day's trading at 5.54 percent.
The price of the 30-year bond, which was down more than one point during the day, finished off 26/32 at 102 11/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.96 percent from 5.90 percent.
"The market had definitely been building in an ease in interest rates," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "Now the market is building in a neutral stance."
Neil M. Soss, the chief United States economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, said that Mr. Greenspan had given a balanced picture of the economic outlook but that bond investors were expecting a rosier -- at least for them -- view: that the Asian turmoil would slow growth enough in the United States to keep inflation in check and even allow the Fed to cut interest rates.
Mr. Greenspan may have helped promote this view when he testified before the Senate Budget Committee on Jan. 29. At that time, he said that the Asian turmoil would begin to slow the American economy before spring was over. But he left out the qualifiers that he added in yesterday's testimony, leaving investors the opportunity at the time to hope for a rate cut.
Yesterday, he reiterated that the Asian crisis would slow growth in the United States. But he also warned, "We cannot rule out two other, more worrisome possibilities." One was that growth here would not be slowed much by Asia, increasing inflation pressures. The other was that Asia could dampen growth much more than expected. And Mr. Greenspan made clear that it would be hard to decide quickly which alternative was actually occurring.
The fall in bond prices yesterday was also helped by a report that consumer confidence jumped to a 30-year high in February, providing investors with another piece of data that indicates that the hoped-for economic slowdown has not materialized yet. That report and Mr. Greenspan's comments easily offset the positive news yesterday on inflation for January, when the Consumer Price Index was unchanged, pulling the inflation rate for the last 12 months down to 1.6 percent.
In when-issued trading ahead of today's auction of five-year notes, the new issue was being offered at a price to yield 5.63 percent.

HEADLINE: Mondale to Visit Jakarta to Press Suharto on I.M.F. Reform Plan

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
President Clinton has asked former Vice President Walter F. Mondale to travel to Indonesia this weekend, the White House said today, as Mr. Clinton's second special envoy to see President Suharto in the past month.
Mr. Mondale's trip will come about 10 days before Mr. Suharto's widely expected re-election for another five-year term by a Parliament that he closely controls. 
 Administration officials said Mr. Mondale would seek to reassure Mr. Suharto, 76, that the United States would seek to help Indonesia through its economic crisis, which has led to an 80 percent devalution of the country's currency and sporadic rioting. But he is also expected to tell Asia's longest-serving leader that Indonesia must begin to carry out the reform plan that Mr. Suharto signed with the International Monetary Fund last month.
Today Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told reporters that Mr. Mondale's trip was intended to re-establish a dialogue with Mr. Suharto on Indonesia's reform efforts.
"I think that in Korea and Thailand, Governments have worked very well toward implementing the I.M.F. programs," Mr. Rubin said. "I think they are on a very constructive path. In Indonesia you obviously have a somewhat difficult situation."
Until a few days ago Mr. Suharto was planning an economic experiment that would peg the country's beleaguered currency, the rupiah, to a fixed exchange rate with the United States dollar. The plan was strongly opposed by the United States and other Western nations, who feared that it was unworkable at a time of both economic and political instability in Indonesia.
The plan, they said, would have forced Indonesia to deplete its $20 billion in foreign currency reserves to protect the exchange rate. After those reserves were gone, they feared, the currency would again devalue.
But Mr. Mondale's trip, officials said, will chiefly deliver a political message: that Mr. Suharto must choose his next Cabinet carefully, avoiding longtime cronies, and create an economic team that the markets will perceive as willing to work with the I.M.F. program.
Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawerence H. Summers traveled to Jakarta on a Presidential mission in January to warn Mr. Suharto that Indonesia was failing to comply with the conditions for the $43 billion in loans from the I.M.F.

HEADLINE: China Breaks the Ice to Offer Political Talks With Taiwan

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Feb. 24

 BODY:
After two and a half years in deep freeze, China sought today to thaw its relations with Taiwan by offering to resume talks on the future of the island. Beijing still regards Taiwan as a rebel province and still threatens to retake it by military force.
The invitation, in a letter received today in Taiwan, says, "We are willing to discuss procedural matters regarding opening political talks across the Taiwan Strait, and we are prepared to resume discussions of economic and technical issues." 
 In a muted response, Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council in Taiwan, described the letter as "positive."
Taiwan's leaders are feeling growing pressure from the United States to renew contacts with Beijing. But while Taiwan officials say they are ready to talk, they adamantly insist that discussions be limited to topics like commercial relations and travel links; political issues are not on the table.
Since Mao Zedong's armies marched into Beijing in October 1949, and then quickly captured the rest of the mainland, sending Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Army fleeing to Taiwan, the two sides have been formally at war. Only in 1993, after virtually all of Taiwan's diplomatic relations with the world had evaporated, including those with Washington, and as China was beginning to exert growing influence on Asia, did both sides agree to meet.
While Beijing has repeatedly declared that Taiwan is an integral part of China, Taiwan espouses a belief in a single China while insisting that Taiwan remain "an independent, sovereign state."
Even so, the two sides gingerly approached one another in 1993 to discuss issues like fishing disputes, cultural exchanges and scientific cooperation.
Mention of any political issues, much less the inflammatory question of reunification, was avoided. But the Chinese Government underlined every invitation to Taipei with a reminder that it has never abandoned the option of using force to regain the island.
Taiwan struck back by orchestrating an elaborate public relations campaign in Washington to win a visa for President Lee Teng-hui to visit Cornell University, his alma mater, in June 1995.
Beijing reacted with fury, immediately ending contacts with Taipei.
Then, in March 1996, just as Taiwan was preparing for its first democratic presidential election, Beijing fired missiles into waters off the island's north and south coasts and conducted huge military exercises in Fujian Province, just across the straits. The exercises were widely seen as an effort to intimidate Taiwan's voters.
Now, with relations between Beijing and Washington far warmer, Taipei's leverage on Washington is slipping. And Taiwan's business community, which has $30 billion to $60 billion in investments on the mainland, is also pressing the Government to speed its discussions with Beijing.
In recent interviews in Taiwan, many officials and opinion-makers said they thought the Clinton Administration, using visits by former senior American officials and comments from American representatives in Taipei, was trying to nudge Taipei back to the negotiating table.
"I agree that there is pressure from Washington," said Huang Chao-sung, president of The China Times, the largest paper in Taiwan. "We think it's because of Clinton's visit to China," a reference to a planned trip by President Clinton to Beijing later this year.
Last month a procession of former Clinton and Bush Administration officials came through Taipei, all bearing a message from Beijing: sit down and talk. The most prominent mission was led by the former Defense Secretary, William J. Perry, who was sponsored by the private National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, and who arrived after meeting senior officials in Beijing.
"The message was, 'They're ready to talk,' " said a senior official who had notes of Mr. Perry's visit.
American diplomats in Taipei at the nominally private American Institute in Taiwan contend that Washington is not attempting to push Taiwan toward the negotiating table, but they say that resuming discussions would ease tensions.
Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who represented his country in Washington before joining the cabinet last year, said he did not think Washington was exerting formal pressure.
"I don't think the United States would want to make us feel pushed or hastened or pressurized into any talks," Mr. Hu said in an interview. But he added, "They would express an earnest desire to see the earliest possible resumption of dialogue."
Mr. Hu argued that Taiwan had to tread cautiously. "We have to be very careful," he said. "We don't have that many cards in our sleeves."
Although talks have been stalemated for 31 months, Taiwan is drawing closer to the mainland in other ways: More than 43 percent of Taiwan's outside investment is on the mainland, and about 300 mainland academics, performing artists, scientists and business people visit each month.

HEADLINE: Words of Kim Dae Jung: Call for Reconciliation

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Kim Dae Jung's inaugural address today, as translated by the South Korean Government:
At this very important juncture, we have run into a foreign exchange crisis that is the most serious national crisis since the Korean War. We are faced with a crisis that could bankrupt our country. Burdened by enormous debt, we are anxious to settle the maturing foreign debts that are surging over us every day. 
 It is, indeed, a stupefying situation that we find ourselves in. The reason we are managing to escape from catastrophe is because of the cooperation from all of you, my fellow countrymen, united with patriotism, and because of the assistance of our friends, including the United States, Japan, Canada, Australia and the European Union nations, as well as the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
Consumer prices and unemployment will rise this year. Incomes will drop and an increasing number of companies will go bankrupt. All of us are being asked to shed sweat and tears now.
We must calmly and squarely look back to find out how we arrived at this state of affairs. This unfortunate development was able to take place because political, economic, and financial leaders of this country were tainted by a collusive link between politics and business, and because of government-directed banking practices, and because large business groups set up a large number of uncompetitive subsidiaries. . . .
I earnestly appeal to the opposition, which is the majority party in the National Assembly; we will never be able to overcome today's crisis without cooperation from you. I will consult with you on all issues; you, in return, must help me if only for one year -- this year -- when the nation is standing on the bring of disaster. I believe my wishes are shared by all the citizens.
My fellow countrymen, right now this country is undergoing a time of frustration and a crisis in all areas, including politics, the economy, society, national security and South-North relations. To overcome these, we must carry out comprehensive reform.
Political reform must precede everything else. Participatory democracy must be put into practice; the people must be respected as masters and must act like masters. Only then can national administration become transparent and corruption disappear. I will do whatever it takes to realize politics by the people and politics in which the people truly become the masters.
This Government of the people will not indulge in political retaliation of any kind. It will not condone discrimination and preferential treatment of any kind. I firmly pledge here and now that there will not be a government for one region, or discrimination against a province any longer.
The Government will be made more efficient by bearing its share of the pain. A large portion of the power and functions that have been concentrated in the central Government will be transferred to the private sector and local autonomous governments. On the other hand, we will make strengthened efforts to protect the lives and property of the people. We will also endeavor to protect the environment and expand social welfare. . . .
Inter-Korean relations must be evolved on the basis of reconciliation and cooperation as well as the establishment of peace. The Cold War-style South-North relations that have not allowed members of separated families, for over half a century, to ascertain even whether their own parents and brothers and sisters were alive or dead, let alone carry on dialogue and exchanges, must end as soon as possible. I cannot but feel boundless shame before our ancestors who maintained one unified country for more than 1,300 years.
The path toward resolution of South-North problems is already open. It lies in the enactment of the South-North Basic Agreement, adopted on Dec. 13, 1991. The authorities in the South and the North have already reached complete agreement on three issues, namely reconciliation, exchanges and cooperation, and non-aggression between the South and the North. . . .
I earnestly appeal to North Korean authorities. Many members of separated families have grown old and are passing away. We must let those separated from their families in the South and the North meet and communicate with each other as soon as possible. On this point, I take note of some positive signs North Korea has shown of late. I also hope that the two sides will expand cultural and academic exchanges as well as economic exchanges on the basis of separating the economy from politics.
I hope that interaction between the South and North will expand in many fields based on the South-North Basic Agreement. First of all, I propose an exchange of special envoys for carrying out the South-North Basic Agreement. I am ready to agree to a summit meeting, if North Korea wants. . . .

HEADLINE: College Endowments Top $150 Billion On the Wings of a Soaring Economy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Robust investment returns coupled with strong donations to higher education have created a financial boom for American colleges and universities, 25 of which now have endowments of $1 billion or more.
The total value of all of their endowments grew 21.9 percent in the academic year that ended last June, topping $150 billion -- $27 billion more than the year before. 
 Among the new billionaires are Duke, Case Western Reserve and Johns Hopkins universities.
The University of Virginia, one of a small but growing number of public institutions entering the major leagues of fund-raising, is doing so well that it is increasing the goal of its current fund-raising campaign to $1 billion by the end of the century from $750 million.
The huge increase in the value of stocks, real estate and other university endowment assets is not merely a change on paper. Income from endowments pays for financial aid, faculty salaries, graduate fellowships, advanced information technology and new buildings and services like a library extension at Dartmouth College and a new art exhibition space at Virginia.
Development officers are jubilant about the gains.
"We're experiencing some happy times," said Bill Nugent, president of the University of Illinois Foundation. "We more than doubled our endowment in four years. The $1 billion drive we started in 1992 now stands at $980 million. The money is coming in at the rate of $25 million a month, so we should reach our goal by the end of March."
Thomas Kinnear, the vice president for development at the University of Michigan, which completed a billion-dollar drive last September with an overrun of $413 million, said, "The mine was a lot richer than we thought it was."
Yale University has done so well in fund-raising that its development officer, Charles Pagnam, said he could afford to relax.
"We kicked off a $1.5-billion drive in 1992," Mr. Pagnam said, "and ended it last June with $1.72 billion. Now it's important that we take a little bit of a rest."
Most of the major fund-raisers are private universities like Harvard, Cornell and Stanford; a few are public, like Michigan and Illinois.
A handful of others, including Virginia, sometimes call themselves "state assisted" because only a small part of their income derives from state appropriations. Virginia receives only about 11 percent of its income (including money for University Hospital) from the state.
Academic fund-raisers are not troubled by the prospect of a stock market decline.
"We're hedging against that with a very conservative and varied portfolio," Mr. Nugent said. "If the market does go down, it will probably be down from the 20 percent growth that we see today to a more normal 6 percent. That might mean we just wouldn't be able to grow so fast."
Last year the average investment return rate for colleges and universities was 20.4 percent, an increase over the average 1996 return of 17.2 percent, according to an annual study conducted by the National Association of College and University Business Officers.
The study notes that college and university endowments have achieved double-digit return rates on their investments six times in the 1990's. The highest rate of return ever reported since the study began in 1974 was in 1986, when the average rate was 26.9 percent.
Thomas M. Reardon, the vice president of development for Harvard, which is now 85 percent of the way toward its goal of raising $2.1 billion by the end of the century, said the stock market rise was chiefly responsible for the money coming in ahead of schedule.
"With the market up," Mr. Reardon said, "if you have a pledge outstanding there's certainly an advantage to paying it off earlier. That also allows the university to have the full impact of the gift sooner."
But some development officers play down the performance of the market. Mr. Kinnear of Michigan said: "I'm not aware of any giver who contributed just because of the rise of the market. Many of the larger gifts, probably 90 of them who gave a million or more, had sources of income other than the market, so they were unaffected by its rise."
Another factor in the boom is more aggressive fund-raising by state-supported colleges and universities in response to a decline in state support in the early 1990's. Most of these drives have been remarkably successful. Virginia is a good example.
"With the collapse of state funding between 1991 and 1993," John T. Casteen, Virginia's president, said, "we were faced with making desperate financial choices. The state contribution fell from $128 million in 1989-90 to $109 million three years later, and by 1993 we came to understand that the State of Virginia -- unlike Michigan, Texas and California -- was not going to be putting the money back."
Mr. Casteen added: "Furthermore, because of state restrictions and reductions, our faculty salaries were no longer competitive. In one extreme case in the mid-1990's, seven senior professors in the department of economics left. We had to decide whether we wanted to see the university disintegrate or pursue an earlier plan we had started to develop in 1990 to become one of a handful of the dominant public universities. We decided to take the latter course and be in the top tier regardless of state support."
Richard Chait, a professor of higher education at Harvard, listed yet another reason for the growth in endowments.
"The smart money," Mr. Chait said, "sees that knowledge will be to the 21st century what natural resources and raw materials have been to the 20th century, and if you're a corporation or a wealthy individual who wants to generate intellectual capital to meet that change, what better place to support than a university?"

SECTION: Section B; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

HEADLINE: U.S. Trails the World in Math and Science

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
The most comprehensive and rigorous international comparison of schooling ever undertaken reveals American high school seniors to be among the industrial world's least prepared in mathematics and science, prompting educators and political leaders, including President Clinton, to call for a re-examination of the nation's approach to teaching quantitative skills.
Particularly devastating, the American officials said, was the bleak performance of the best American students in advanced subjects. In physics and advanced mathematics, not one of the countries involved -- including less well-off nations like Greece, Cyprus and Latvia -- scored lower than the United States. 
 "This study has burst another myth," said William H. Schmidt, an educational statistician from Michigan State University who coordinated the American portion of the study. "Our best students in mathematics and science are simply not world class. Even the very small percentage of students taking Advanced Placement courses are not among the world's best."
The results seemed particularly jarring given the continuing dominance of the United States in a global economy based increasingly on information and technology. Some wondered whether American colleges and universities were making up for the gaps.
The data, released yesterday, are from the Third International Mathematics and Science Study, which in the spring of 1995 tested samplings of 4th, 8th and 12th graders. More than 40 countries participated in the 8th-grade portion and about half that number in each of the other two sections. The Asian nations, traditional high performers, did not take part in the high school portion.
The fourth-grade results, released in June, showed the United States to be above the international average and were hailed as evidence that the attention paid in recent years to improving schools was paying off.
The eighth-grade results, released seven months earlier, had raised some concern because Americans dipped below the international average in mathematics although they scored above it in science.
But the latest results, for high school seniors, are being greeted with shock and dismay by large numbers of educators and officials who see them as evidence of a fundamental national failing.
"There is something wrong with the system and it is our generation's responsibility to fix it," President Clinton said yesterday in response to the results of the study. "You cannot blame the schoolchildren."
Education Secretary Richard W. Riley said the results confirmed what the Administration has been saying: that the country needs clearer, firmer academic standards and better prepared science teachers.
Conservative lawmakers have opposed the national tests on grounds that they would represent a centralization of education, which they view as more properly controlled locally.
While versions of the international study in the 1960's, 70's and 80's produced equally poor results for American high schoolers, they were largely discounted because of perceived societal and educational differences between the United States and other countries. This time, officials say the differences have narrowed, and those that remain were statistically accounted for.
Those who carried out the study said there were no clear or simple explanations for the low level of American performance. "It is not class size or homework or social life or television," said Ina V. S. Mullin of Boston College, co-deputy director of the study. "Around the world, everybody watches television."
The examination given to the 12th graders consisted of four parts: general mathematics, which includes fractions and percentages, graphics and some algebra; general science, which includes earth science, life science and physical science; advanced mathematics, which includes calculus, geometry and equations, and physics.
Students were selected to represent their nations; 23 countries participated in some part of the exam. To account for margins of error, results were clustered into groups.
In general knowledge of mathematics, American 12th graders did better than those in only two countries, Cyprus and South Africa. Students in four countries, Italy, Russia, Lithuania and the Czech Republic, performed at the same level as those in the United States. Fourteen countries outperformed America, led by the Netherlands and Sweden. The results were similar for science.
The advanced mathematics assessment was given to students who had taken or were taking pre-calculus, calculus or Advanced Placement calculus, and the advanced physics assessment to students who had either taken or were taking physics or Advanced Placement physics. In advanced math, 11 countries outperformed the United States and no country performed more poorly; in physics, 14 countries did better than the United States and none did worse.
One ray of light was performance by American students who took Advanced Placement calculus. When these students -- about 5 percent of those in the nation -- were separated out and measured against students abroad in advanced mathematics, they did slightly better than the international average. But in physics, when the same statistical exercise was done, Americans were still below the international average.
One of the nagging problems worldwide seen in the study was a sex gap favoring boys in math and science. Boys significantly outperformed girls in mathematics and science in all 21 countries tested in the fields except Cyprus, South Africa and the United States.
Pascal D. Forgione Jr., the United States Commissioner of Education Statistics, said that previous explanations for the country's comparatively poor performance no longer held true. In the past, Mr. Forgione said, other countries tended not to keep the less academically oriented youngsters in school whereas the United States did, meaning different populations were being tested. Also, the American high school population was seen as more diverse. The international studies were often dismissed as a comparison of apples and oranges.
Now, Mr. Forgione said, "the gap between our kids finishing their schooling and those of other countries has closed. And the level of diversity in other countries now matches that of ours."
Many experts argued that American pupils start out ahead of their foreign peers in elementary school but as they move through middle and high school are challenged less and less because the curriculum tends to be repetitive. In other countries, the curriculum in middle school enters more advanced fields, like geometry and chemistry.
Only a handful of American states require mathematics or science through all four years of high school. Last year, the New York State Board of Regents toughened graduation standards, requiring students planning to graduate in 2005 and beyond to take three years each of mathematics and science and pass college preparatory exams in five subjects.
New York City schools have started programs to prepare students for the more rigorous standards, including weekend and evening tutoring in math and science.
The study released yesterday was sponsored by the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement, an international cooperative of research centers based in Amsterdam.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Scuttling of Drug Merger Contributes to Stock Drop
Stocks fell, dragged lower by the collapse of what was expected to be the largest corporate merger ever, between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, and by rising bond yields.
The Dow industrials fell 40.10 points, to 8,370.10, while the Nasdaq composite index slumped 13.05 points, to 1,738.71, one day after reaching a new high. Page D8. 

Greenspan Words Send Bonds Lower
Bond prices fell sharply, sending the yield on the 30-year Treasury up to 5.96 percent from 5.90, after the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, delivered a cautionary economic message that indicated that the central bank was unlikely to change its monetary policy soon. D8.
 
Interpublic to Buy Hill, Holliday
The Interpublic Group, the big advertising agency company, agreed to acquire Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, a midsized Boston-based agency that specializes in clients in fields like financial services, health care and technology. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D5.
 
The top executives of the major tobacco companies told Congress that they would never agree to modify their advertising and marketing practices unless the lawmakers gave the industry substantial protection against lawsuits. A16.
 
Continental and Pilots Reach Deal
Continental Airlines and its pilots reached a tentative agreement on a contract, clearing a potential obstacle to a recently announced alliance with Northwest Airlines, a person close to the talks said. D7.
 
Novell Battles Back
Novell reported its first operating profit in four quarters, exceeding estimates, but sales were well below the level reported a year earlier as the computer networking company struggled to complete a turnaround. D2.
 
Disney Holders Reject Proposal
Disney shareholders rejected a move to redefine what constitutes an independent director. A big shareholder had questioned whether some independent directors had too many ties to Disney and its chairman, Michael D. Eisner. D6.
 
Wal-Mart's Profit Increases
Quarterly earnings rose 18 percent at Wal-Mart Stores, bolstered by lower inventory costs amid strong holiday sales of jewelry, Christmas decorations and toys. D6.
 
Mondale Heads to Indonesia
The Clinton Administration has asked former Vice President Walter F. Mondale to travel to Indonesia to reassure President Suharto that the United States will seek to help Indonesia through its economic crisis. A6.
 
Malaysia Shifts Preference Policy
Asia's economic crisis has forced Malaysia to stop promoting indigenous Malays over Chinese, who are a minority but have more economic power. D4.
 
Thailand Raises Taxes
The Government of Thailand raised taxes on products including gasoline, cigarettes and beer, as it struggles to close a budget deficit while the economy creeps along at the slowest rate since the 1960's. D4.
 
Owner of TV Stations in Sale
Sinclair Broadcast Group agreed to acquire Sullivan Broadcast Holdings, which owns 13 TV stations, for about $800 million. D5.
 
Questions at EMI Music
The future of EMI Music's management structure seems more uncertain than ever, despite an effort to reassure investors after a succession plan collapsed. D5.
 
Big Charge for Waste Management
Waste Management is taking a $1.5 billion charge to reflect accounting changes that are aimed at quieting investor skepticism about the reliability of its financial reports. The charge caused a big quarterly loss. D2.

HEADLINE: Nike Earnings Won't Beat Expectations

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Nike Inc., the world's largest sports shoe maker, said today that its earnings for the latest quarter would be lower than Wall Street expectations and that it was planning job cuts.
Citing order cancellations in the Asia Pacific region and close-out sales in the United States, Nike said it expected diluted earnings of 24 cents to 28 cents a share for its third quarter, ending on Saturday. 
 That compares with the Wall Street consensus of 38 cents a share, according to First Call, and earnings for its second quarter of $141 million, or 48 cents a share. The second-quarter earnings were also well below analysts' expectations.
Nike said it was examining its overall cost structure and planned "realignments and reductions in its global work force, aimed at improving profitability." The company said this would probably result in a revamping charge in the fiscal year ending May 31.
The Asian financial crisis has been cutting into Nike's profits and battering the stock. The company also had a $1.4 billion inventory glut at the end of the previous quarter. Nike also said earnings for the full year would be below the previously stated range of $2 to $2.15 a share. In the last full fiscal year, Nike earned $796 million, or $2.68 a share. Nike's stock closed today at $43.125, down $3.5625. The news was released after the stock market closed.

HEADLINE: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE WAY IT HAPPENED;
Fingerprints on Iraqi Accord Belong to Albright

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Early on Sunday morning, Feb. 15, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright boarded a small C-20 Air Force plane at Andrews Air Force base and flew to New York for a secret meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan at his Sutton Place town house.
Ms. Albright was carrying a confidential paper that laid out the "red lines," or American requirements for his mission to proceed. In her meeting with Mr. Annan, the two diplomats discussed what eventually became Iraq's agreement with the United Nations to open its so-called presidential sites to weapons inspectors. 
 The conversation, which lasted for almost two hours, also resolved weeks of debate by President Clinton and his top security aides over the best way to settle the most recent crisis with Iraq, according to senior Administration officials.
And it demonstrated that Washington was far more actively involved in planning the United Nations chief's mission than it previously acknowledged.
During intense discussions, Mr. Clinton and his national security advisers moved away from from a plan to hit Mr. Hussein with the biggest military strike of the Clinton Presidency. They concluded that in the absence of solid international and domestic support, it was best to mount yet another diplomatic effort.
As the crisis grew, Bill Richardson, the United States representative to the United Nations, strongly opposed Mr. Annan's mission, arguing that the chief United Nations diplomat was too likely to give in to Iraqi demands and that an agreement with President Saddam Hussein could not be trusted.
At the Pentagon, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen was skeptical. For months he had argued passionately about the threat of Iraq's chemical and biological weapons. When Mr. Hussein refused to allow inspectors access to the presidential sites in December, Mr. Cohen made the case for a prompt military strike.
The discussions were so far-reaching that at one point Vice President Al Gore suggested that the Administration consider designating Mr. Hussein a war criminal, a proposal that prompted a debate on its risks and merits.
Ms. Albright and Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, told Mr. Clinton that Mr. Annan's trip was a potential opportunity and not a trap. Together, the two aides developed the American "red lines" for the mission. During one meeting at the White House, the President made clear that the Administration would support Mr. Annan's trip -- but only if Washington's requirements were met.
"You can't have Kofi going there and the United States not support it and then have military action," a senior White House official quoted Mr. Clinton as saying. "The President said: 'Look, I don't want him negotiating. It's our military that is getting the inspectors back in. I want a clear consensus among the international community, a consensus on his instructions before he goes to Baghdad.' " And, Mr. Clinton reportedly added, "I want a written statement with a signature."
Iraq had been testing the will of the inspectors since a Security Council resolution passed at the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991 gave them unlimited access to Iraq with the aim of eliminating its weapons of mass destruction.
But the debate reached a critical point in November, when Mr. Cohen sounded the alarm over Iraq's suspected cache of chemical and biological weapons. Mr. Cohen, a Republican and former lawmaker who served on the Senate Armed Services and Intelligence Committees, had long warned about the spread of weapons of mass destruction and highlighted it in his speeches.
He was not counting on diplomacy to solve the problem. Last November, when the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, brokered a diplomatic settlement to resolve an earlier crisis over the inspections, the Pentagon predicted that it was just a matter of time before Mr. Hussein blocked the inspectors again.
It took only a few weeks. In mid-December, Iraq told Richard Butler, the chairman of the United Nations Special Commission, that it planned to exclude the inspectors from the presidential sites.
 
Pentagon Ready To Attack in December
The Pentagon was ready to act. The plan was to launch a military strike against Iraq before Ramadan, the Muslim holy month, which began on Dec. 31.
"The Pentagon was on a clear track to take action before the holiday and had a plan to do it," an Administration official said.
Mr. Clinton also seemed ready this time for military action, an official said.
Not everybody in the Administration was prepared to act that quickly. There were many unsolved issues. The Administration had not consulted extensively with Congress or lined up support among its allies. Nor had it won over the public.
According to the Pentagon, the next opportunity to strike Iraq would come after Ramadan ended on Jan. 29.
By late January, Mr. Clinton had signed off on a military plan that could be carried out should diplomacy fail. But in Moscow and Paris, there was opposition to a military strike. Both the Russians and the French worked hard -- separately and together -- to head of an American attack.
A French official paraphrased President Jacques Chirac as telling the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, in a phone conversation: "You know, Boris, you and I are trying to avoid a war over there. Bill wants to strike. Maybe you and I have a role to play."
Some of the closest Arab allies of the United States, including Saudi Arabia and Egypt, agreed, and made their opposition to military action clear.
By early February, there was strong international pressure for sending Mr. Annan to Baghdad, but the Administration initially urged him not to go.
In a meeting with Security Council representatives from France, Russia, Britain and China on Feb. 11, Mr. Richardson said he could not see the value of a mission to Baghdad by Mr. Annan, participants in the meeting said. It did not seem to matter to him that Mr. Annan was in the room.
By the time Ms. Albright met the Secretary General four days later, the American position had changed.
She, along with Mr. Berger, knew that if the United States was the lone holdout on an Annan mission, Washington would appear isolated. It could not stop Mr. Annan from going to Baghdad on his own authority.
The State Department was also concerned about the effect of bombing on the Middle East peace effort and on American relations with the gulf Arabs. If the Secretary General went to Baghdad, won Iraqi agreement and then Iraq reneged, the United States would be able to make a stronger case with its allies for military action.
Sitting in Mr. Annan's town house over lunch, Ms. Albright laid out the "red lines:" The inspectors must have "operational control" over all investigations of suspected biological and chemical weapons sites in Iraq. They would also have to have unrestricted access to all sites and must serve as the sole judge of Iraqi compliance.
If Mr. Annan reached an agreement with Mr. Hussein, she added, the United States wanted it in writing. Its violation would have "the severest consequences," she said, alluding to punishing air strikes already planned by the Pentagon.
In heated discussions in the Security Council, the Russians gave up their demand that the inspections of presidential sites should be limited; the United States agreed to the French idea for the appointment of diplomatic "chaperones" for the inspectors for the presidential sites and the postponement of a military strike.
But much to Washington's dismay, the Council could not agree on written instructions for Mr. Annan.
Before Mr. Annan left, Sir John Weston, the chief British representative, read him words of "advice" based on what he said was "a level of agreement." The advice met the American requirements. But Mr. Annan insisted that he needed some room to negotiate and would not be a mere messenger.
 
A Dozen Hours Of Annan-Aziz Talks
From the moment Mr. Annan arrived in Baghdad on Friday, he knew that the Iraqis were serious about making a deal, his aides said. Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, insisted that he and Mr. Annan talk privately that night instead of waiting until their first scheduled meeting in the morning.
It was the start of a dozen hours of meetings with Mr. Aziz, Mr. Hussein's English-speaking aide who had signaled in telephone conversations with Mr. Annan that Mr. Hussein was ready to negotiate seriously. By Saturdaymorning, Mr. Annan realized how difficult the negotiations would be.
He presented Mr. Aziz with the outline of an agreement that was based loosely on the "advice" he had received from the Security Council.
Mr. Aziz did not seem happy. And when the meeting broke up, the two men summoned all their aides for a formal two-and-a-half-hour encounter.
Mr. Aziz accused the inspectors of being too intrusive, according to a participant in the meeting, saying they wanted to wander through Mr. Hussein's residences and rifle through his personal belongings, something he said no sovereign leader could tolerate.
At the end of the meeting, Mr. Annan thanked his host for his "frank expose," adding, "We will try to do the best job; we can try to do an honest job," a United Nations official quoted him as saying. He called the inspections "a sacred requirement for us."
Mr. Annan dismissed much of what Mr. Aziz said as posturing for colleagues, and from then on, the two men met one on one.
But they could not agree on the most sensitive issue: how intrusive inspections of the presidential sites would be.
Mr. Aziz insisted throughout the day that inspection of those sites be conducted only once and last only 60 days. When the meetings broke up at 2 A.M., there was no deal.
At one point, Mr. Annan called Ms. Albright in Washington to tell her that the Iraqis would not budge and that he might not be able to get them to do more. She told him the restrictions on presidential site inspections were a "deal-breaker," an Administration official said.
Mr. Annan also called Mr. Primakov to ask for his intervention. The Russian Foreign Minister, who has known Mr. Hussein for three decades, called Mr. Aziz and told him that, indeed, there could be no time constraints placed on the inspectors.
Given Russia's decades of support for Iraq, that was a serious setback for Iraq.
Mr. Annan told Mr. Aziz that no country in the Security Council would support such a limitation. "I simply cannot agree to anything that implies it be a time-limited exercise," an aide to Mr. Annan paraphrased him as saying.
But Mr. Annan was so discouraged that late on Saturday night he asked an aide to draft two statements by the next morning -- one that expressed satisfaction that a diplomatic agreement had been reached, another that expressed deep "regret" that the mission had failed.
Mr. Annan approved both statements. The issue was still not resolved by noon Sunday, when Mr. Annan and three aides were picked up at the pink stucco villa where they were staying and driven in government limousines to a location not disclosed to them. Their destination: the Republican Palace, Mr. Hussein's primary residence on the banks of the Tigris River and, ironically, one of the buildings off-limits to weapons inspectors. There Mr. Hussein, who had shed his military uniform for a dark blue business suit, greeted his guests warmly, posing with them for pictures.
Mr. Annan was described by aides as respectful of Mr. Hussein, calling him a leader who needed to take a bold step for peace.
"He made clear to Saddam that he had a tremendous responsibility and that he should have no illusions about what the consequences would be if there should be no agreement," a United Nations official said. But Mr. Annan added, "I cannot back away from my bottom line."
 
Deal Is Struck For Full Access
After three hours of talks that focused not only on the inspections but also on Mr. Hussein's insistence on a deadline for lifting economic sanctions against Iraq, they struck a deal allowing inspectors immediate and unconditional access throughout the country. It also provides for diplomatic chaperones on inspecting the eight presidential sites.
In his news conference today, Mr. Annan praised the Iraqi leadership for its "courage, wisdom, flexibility."
"Homage to Saddam" was how one diplomat at the United Nations described the news conference.
In Washington, the Administration tentatively embraced the agreement it helped formulate, adding that important ambiquities needed to be resolved. But to some officials, the new agreement seems more like a temporary truce than a final settlement of the bitter inspection issue.
Mr. Clinton said the agreement might, at long last, enable the United Nations inspectors to carry out their mission.
But picking up the theme of the Adminstration's "red lines," he also warned that if the accord collapsed, the United States was poised to strike "at a time, place and manner of our choosing."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Regulators Approve Niagara Rate Plan

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
After several false starts in recent weeks, state regulators yesterday unanimously approved the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation's rate plan, which the utility claimed it needed to avoid bankruptcy.
Large industrial and commercial users would see rates drop by up to 25 percent over three years under the plan. Utility executives hope that will stimulate the economy throughout Niagara Mohawk's service territory in upstate New York. 
 Residential and small commercial customers would get far more modest rate decreases of 3.2 percent over the first three years of the five-year plan.
Critics say "Power Choice" does little to open up the market to competition and leaves New York's rates about 40 percent above the national average.
John F. O'Mara, chairman of the State Public Service Commission, conceded that he would have liked to see a greater rate decrease for residential users, but he called the plan the "best available solution."
The commission's approval of the Niagara Mohawk proposal brings to six out of the seven investor-owned utilities in New York that have established revamping plans. All have been constructed along the same general lines: holding current rates steady or rolling them back and requiring the utilities to give customers a choice of electricity suppliers.
In return, the utilities have got the right to venture into other, potentially more lucrative, business ventures.
Niagara Mohawk provides gas and electricity to 2 million customers in upstate New York.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Interest on State Bonds Is Lowest Since 1971

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The state sold $410 million in bonds yesterday to pay for programs ranging from historic preservation to assistance for people with disabilities, and the interest rate, 4.77 percent, was the lowest since 1971, state officials said.
Mary Lou Murphy, a spokeswoman for the State Treasury Department, attributed the low interest rate to the state's strong bond ratings. Moody's Investors Service gave New Jersey an Aa1 rating, the second highest of 19 classifications. That is the same rate the state has had since 1992. 
 But factors outside the state also played a role in the low interest rate on the bonds. James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, noted that interest rates on long-term Treasury bonds are also hitting record lows.
The rating was based in part on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed budget for the 1999 fiscal year, which for the first time in several years has not relied on borrowing, refinancing and other one-time methods of raising revenue, said Renee Boicort, a Moody's analyst.
But Ms. Boicort said Moody's credit outlook for the state remains negative, reflecting concern that New Jersey is not prepared for an economic downturn.

HEADLINE: Opposition in South Korea Blocks Leader's Choice for Premier

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 25

 BODY:
President Kim Dae Jung faced his first political crisis today just a few hours after he was inaugurated, when the political opposition blocked his choice for Prime Minister and delayed formation of a Cabinet.
Negotiations are under way, and Mr. Kim may coax enough votes in the National Assembly to allow approval of his Prime Minister. But the incident underscored the difficulties that Mr. Kim will face while ruling the country with a party that commands a minority of the votes in the National Assembly. 
 The nominee for Prime Minister, Kim Jong Pil, is an odd figure in today's South Korea, in part because he represents much of what President Kim does not. While Kim Dae Jung was a lifelong democracy campaigner, Kim Jong Pil started out as a military officer and was the architect of the 1961 coup that led to more than a quarter-century of harsh military rule.
Kim Jong Pil, who even his critics acknowledge is brilliant and charming, was also the founder of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, which was responsible for brutal repression for more than two decades. The agency in 1973 -- after Kim Jong Pil had left it -- kidnapped Kim Dae Jung in Japan and apparently planned to kill him, until the United States intervened.
Still, Kim Dae Jung and Kim Jong Pil joined forces in the election campaign last year for what both sides generally agree were reasons of opportunism rather than policy: it was the only way that they could get elected.
Kim Dae Jung almost certainly would not have won the presidency without the support of Kim Jong Pil, and their deal stipulated that if elected Kim Dae Jung would become President and Kim Jong Pil would become Prime Minister.
The Grand National Party, which in the past controlled the presidency and still controls a majority of the National Assembly seats, boycotted today's session -- meaning that there was no quorum and no action could be taken -- because it opposes Kim Jong Pil. It argues that Kim Jong Pil is a figure from Korea's repressive past and that he lacks the experience to revive the economy.
"It's improper to ram through the appointment of Kim Jong Pil as Prime Minister," Maeng Hyung Kyu, a party spokesman, said today. "We urge the Government to select a wise figure who will help the nation overcome its present crisis."
Kim Dae Jung and his associates argue that the voters knew about the arrangement, and that the appointment of Kim Jong Pil to be Prime Minister is thus the voters' will. They say that Kim Jong Pil will not withdraw his candidacy and that they will try to get enough defectors from the opposition to win approval for Kim Jong Pil.
"I sincerely hope that there will be agreement over the appointment of Kim Jong Pil as Prime Minister," Kim Dae Jung told dinner guests tonight. Referring to the opposition, he added, "I also hope that I will receive cooperation so that I can fulfill the tasks of the presidency."
The prospect of a political battle sent the Korean stock market tumbling, with the main stock index closing down 4.5 percent.
The delay in selecting a Prime Minister has also forced a postponement in the announcement of the Cabinet, which is nominally chosen by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister's job has far less weight than the President's, but if the President dies then the Prime Minister takes over -- and that is a consideration since President Kim is 74 and beginning a five-year term.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Rise After Greenspan's Testimony Is Shrugged Off

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities gained for the first time in six days yesterday, as the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, concluded two days of Congressional testimony by saying little else to alarm investors in bonds.
Bond prices had slumped on Tuesday as Mr. Greenspan, speaking before the House Banking Committee, warned the financial markets not to be complacent about the outlook for inflation and investors concluded that no cut in interest rates by the Fed was likely in the near term. Yesterday he repeated much the same message, this time to the Senate Banking Committee, but investors apparently concluded that the market had moved too far in recent sessions. 
 The gains were also supported by a solid reception for the Government's auction yesterday of a new five-year note.
As a result, the price of the 30-year bond rose 18/32, to a price of 102 29/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.92 percent, from 5.96 percent on Tuesday. Still, bonds with shorter maturities lagged behind the 30-year bond, held back by the belief that the Fed will keep interest rates steady for the time being. Yields on shorter-term securities are already near the 5.5 percent of the Federal funds rate, the Fed's main monetary policy lever.
"The reality is that the market always overreacts to Greenspan comments," said Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla. Though Mr. Greenspan is always vigilant about inflation, Mr. Pugliese said, the Fed chairman also said that the United States economy had not yet felt the impact of the Asian economic crisis, which is expected to keep inflation in check by lowering prices -- first of imports, and later of domestic goods that compete with them.
In the bond market, "the last two days and the next few will probably be the best buying opportunity for quite some time," Mr. Pugliese said. "The long-term trend for bonds is for higher prices and lower yields," he said. "The economy has shown it can operate at near full capacity without generating inflation."
Evidence of the robust economy could be seen yesterday in a report from the the National Association of Realtors, which said that resales of homes increased by seven-tenths of a percent in January, to a record high annual rate of 4.40 million units.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "Quite obviously housing has yet to display any signs of slowing."
"The key question going forward is whether the restraint building from the turmoil in Asia will be sufficient to check inflationary tendencies that might otherwise result from the strength of domestic spending and tight labor markets," Mr. Fine said.
Yesterday's auction of $11 billion in new five-year notes came in better than the sale of two-year notes on Tuesday, with the yield coming in as expected at 5.605 percent. While the level of noncompetitive bidding was weaker than the average during the last 12 auctions and below the level of the January auction, the bid-to-cover ratio -- which measures the total bids with the value of the auction -- was decent at 2.72 to 1, traders said. Tomorrow the Treasury will sell $12 billion of 52-week bills and $23 billion of 44-day cash management bills.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Devalue the yuan? China doesn't seem about to do that.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
CHINA faces slower growth, increased pressure from Asian competitors for its export markets and a desperate need to create real jobs for millions now ungainfully employed in bloated state enterprises. Devaluing its currency, the yuan, could ease some of these pressures. Last week Lee Hsien Loong, the Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore, told The Wall Street Journal that Chinese "devaluation can't be entirely ruled out."
But the closer one looks at the case for devaluation, the weaker it seems. The political and economic downside from devaluation is so great that China-watchers are nearly united in their conviction that at least for the immediate future the yuan is as good as gold. "The guys running China aren't bluffing," argued Gregory Chow, an economist at Princeton University. "There is no chance they'll devalue." 
 A devaluation, the textbook argument goes, would begin by easing work force strains. With productivity exploding and displaced rural workers flooding the cities, China needs rapid economic growth simply to keep the unemployment rate from rising. The issue has taken on fresh urgency as Zhu Ronghi, the brains behind China's current economic planning, struggles to detach cash-hemorrhaging state enterprises from their artificial financial supports.
Chinese devaluation would also prevent the loss of markets to Thai, Indonesian, Malaysian and Philippine manufacturers that now have an advantage thanks to the recent depreciation of their local currencies. And it would give heavy industry in China's state sector a better chance of competing against imports. "There's no question pressure for devaluation will come from both provincial leaders looking for export growth and the state enterprise managers," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International.
But the arguments for ignoring the textbooks are formidable. Devaluation would make imports more expensive and slow the rise of living standards. Put it another way: the number of hours a Chinese teen-ager would have to labor making Beanie Babies to buy a Honda motor scooter or an airplane ticket to Hong Kong would increase sharply.
Devaluation would also have less impact on export volume than is widely assumed. For starters, Mr. Hormats notes, much of the potential for export growth in southern Asia is in apparel. But volume is artificially constrained by European and American import quotas. And virtually all Asian apparel exporters are already bumping up against their limits.
Equally important, suggests Rudi Dornbusch, an economist at M.I.T., devaluation is a moving target. "China recognizes that as a large actor it almost inevitably invites a reaction from other countries, forcing second helpings -- competitive devaluations -- from everyone else," he said. The export-stimulating effect of cheapening the yuan might even be fully offset by a cheaper rupiah, baht and ringit.
Note, too, that devaluation would put immense pressure on Hong Kong to abandon its anchor to the United States dollar. In theory, there is no reason Hong Kong's currency should be especially affected by the yuan: Hong Kong, a giant financial services and marketing center for the region, doesn't compete much with the rest of China. But any weakness in Beijing would probably cause speculators to test Hong Kong's commitment to its currency board. And to survive the assault, Hong Kong would have to cope with higher interest rates and an even deeper recession -- not to mention a serious loss of face for the city's masters in Beijing.
In the final reckoning, though, the best reason to believe China won't devalue anytime soon is that it won't have to. Unlike countries with freely convertible currencies, China is under no obligation to trade dollar reserves for yuan with anyone who asks. And unlike Indonesia, Korea or Thailand, it has plenty of reserves to pay those who do have contractual claims to foreign exchange. Mr. Dornbusch estimates that China's war chest of dollars and yen is three times the foreign debts of its banks and six times the nation's entire foreign debt coming due in the next year.
Nor is this picture likely to change anytime soon. By estimates of Goldman, Sachs, China will continue to run a balance-of-payments surplus, implying that its reserves will increase in the near term.
Few analysts argue that China will be able to ride out the Asian economic storms without getting damp. Indeed, the almost inevitable decline in China's growth rate spells real trouble for a ruling elite whose political legitimacy depends on its economic success. But trouble hardly translates into a self-induced currency crisis.
"China has big economic problems," Mr. Dornbusch said. "Devaluation would only add to them."
