HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE PUBLIC;
Clinton Finds Support in a Town's Prosperity

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY and JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: WESTFIELD, N.J., Feb. 25

 BODY:
With his 6-year-old brow creased in concentration, Jimmy Reardon raised his feet and began to pedal. His bicycle teetered in uncertainty before striking that magical moment of balance, and he glided across the high school parking lot here with the cheers of his proud father, James Reardon, ringing in his ears.
Mr. Reardon, a computer consultant enjoying a sunny day in sweat pants and a Seton Hall University baseball cap, has few complaints these days. 
 The value of his house in this affluent town is rising, the school system in which his son is enrolled is among the best in the state, and his job is going well. He wants nothing to disturb his family's peace -- including any fallout from the possible indiscretions of his President.
"I'm not the biggest Bill Clinton fan in the world," said Mr. Reardon, a Democrat who voted for Mr. Clinton in the 1992 and 1996 elections. "But the results are great. People are working. The economy is good. There are jobs. I don't think people really care about what is going on in his personal life."
Mr. Reardon, 39, said he did not want his support for the President's job performance to be construed as an endorsement of Mr. Clinton's personal behavior.
"I don't really respect him personally," Mr. Reardon said. "He's got flaws. But over all he's a good leader, and he's got the country as a whole in a good position."
The musings of a father on a lazy Sunday afternoon are similar to the views of his neighbors here in Westfield, a suburb of older, gracious homes about 25 miles west of Manhattan. They also mirror the results of a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll, which found that President Clinton is enjoying record approval ratings, even as he is dogged by accusations that he had a sexual relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, a former White House intern.
Those poll results indicate a seeming paradox: Many of the same people who believe those accusations nevertheless approve of the Clinton Presidency. But the trade-offs and nuances behind those attitudes became clear in more than three dozen recent interviews here -- at a church pancake breakfast, in a diner, in a beauty salon.
Most residents and merchants said they drew distinctions between Mr. Clinton's public duties and his private matters. They said his private life, no matter how unsettling, should not be of public concern -- in part because they personally knew people whose troubled private lives had not interfered with their ability to do their jobs. Ultimately, they said, President Clinton is doing a good job, a conclusion they based in part on the healthy economy.
How, they asked, could the nation risk change at a time of peace and prosperity?
Most people said they did not believe that the President was telling the entire truth about Ms. Lewinsky, nor would it bother them if he was lying about the relationship. But several people said they would be deeply troubled if they learned that Mr. Clinton or his aides had tried to obstruct justice by encouraging the intern to lie in the Paula Corbin Jones civil lawsuit. Even so, most said they would not want to see Mr. Clinton impeached or forced to resign over a case rooted in accusations of sexual misconduct.
Lawrence A. Goldman, a lawyer and a Democratic town councilman, paused before saying that he believed the Lewinsky matter did not rise to the level of an impeachable offense.
"How many people can look themselves in the mirror and say to themselves that if they were involved in an extramarital affair, they would be willing to step up and be forthcoming," Mr. Goldman said. "Not only to their spouse but to the rest of the world."
But that all-forgiving support is not universal.
"I don't care if he's sleeping with her," said Gene Jannotti, 51, a computer consultant who votes Republican, as he sat drinking coffee in a window seat at Bruegger's Bagels shop on Saturday morning. "If he truly lied, if he got her to change her testimony, then he does not deserve to be President."
Yet the consensus among most of those interviewed was to have the country move beyond the Lewinsky matter, mostly out of concern that further investigation could bring about changes in the White House and uncertainty about the future -- from the economy to an Al Gore Presidency.
 
A Case Transcends Political Allegiances
"At this point, there are so many other things to worry about," said Mr. Reardon's wife, Theresa, 34, as she watched their 3-year-old daughter, Tara, ride by on a bicycle with training wheels. "This is not the time to be really harping on this. Just let it go."
Images of children at play are common in Westfield, a predominantly white town of 29,000 in Union County with the sense of place that comes from wealth and community pride. People here celebrate the town's high school swimming teams, its distinction as the hometown of the illustrator Charles Addams, its restoration of the 130-year-old town bell. They tend not to dwell on the troubles, like the recent arrests of four people on prostitution charges, or the granddaddy of all local scandals: the case of John Emil List, who in 1971 killed five family members and then disappeared -- only to be captured 18 years later in a Virginia suburb, where he was living with a new wife and a new identity.
Westfield's political history is rooted in Republicanism. Although more than half of the voters describe themselves as independent, the town traditionally votes straight Republican. In the 1992 Presidential election, George Bush defeated Mr. Clinton in Westfield. But in 1996, Mr. Clinton became the first Democratic Presidential candidate in memory to carry the town -- although by fewer than 200 votes. That same year, the town also elected its first Democratic mayor in more than 80 years.
The Lewinsky case seems to transcend the political allegiances of Westfield, with many people here responding to it in acutely personal ways. One woman became choked up when she recalled a relative whom she greatly admired, but who had become involved in an extramarital affair; how, then, she asked, could she judge Mr. Clinton. And a local merchant became so angry in listing what he considered to be the President's many moral failings that he had to take several moments to calm himself.
Many people in town clearly have spent a lot of time considering the moral and political implications of a tawdry case that has an Administration on the defensive. And to hear their opinions, one need only trace Sunday's sweet aromas to the school auditorium of Holy Trinity Catholic Church, where dozens of parishioners had gathered for a fund-raising pancake breakfast after the morning's Masses.
 
A Generation Change On Morality Issues?
During a lull between the 9 o'clock children's Mass and the 10:30 Mass, the Knights of Columbus member who organized the breakfast, Frank Muggeo, struggled with what he felt was the elemental question: Did the President have an extramarital affair? All other matters -- whether the President is lying now, whether he encouraged the intern to lie -- pale in comparison for Mr. Muggeo, a Republican.
"I don't understand that,"he said, shaking his head in bafflement. "Are we just accepting this as standard? That bothers me. It shows a poor, weak, moral code of ethics."
Mr. Muggeo, an engineer, did not want to give his age and was only slightly more forthcoming on what he thought should happen next in the Lewinsky case.
"One day I think one thing, the next day I think something else," he said slowly. "If he did commit these acts, he really should step down. He should be a role model."
But a few tables away, Jennifer Murphy, 39 years old and bouncing the youngest of three daughters on her knee, scoffed at the idea that Americans should look to their President for moral as well as political leadership. Unseemly accusations against a President might have been taken more seriously by a previous generation, Ms. Murphy said, but not anymore.
"We are just not as judgmental about what goes on behind closed doors," said Ms. Murphy, a Democrat. "We have become more tolerant about people's private lives. People have been desensitized by the sexual exploits of politicians and celebrities because it has been so in our face -- everyone from J.F.K. to Frank Gifford."
Sitting around a fold-out table with other parents her age -- some of whom, like her, had moved from New York City and Hoboken in search of better public schools -- Ms. Murphy began to nurse Madeline, her 6-month-old daughter. But she had more to say: that she thinks the President is telling the truth "like a lawyer," but that "I don't think it's anybody's business" whether he had a relationship with Ms. Lewinsky.
But for all the latitude Ms. Murphy and her friends gave the President, they acknowledged that the public's generosity of spirit rose and fell with the economy.
"I think people have a higher tolerance of immoral behavior when the economy is doing fine," she said as she cradled her daughter in her arms.
A Republican across the table agreed.
"If inflation went up to 10 percent," said Steven Dreyer, 39, "there would be a lot more concern about this situation."
Throughout the town, "this situation" brought sly smiles to faces, followed by expressions of concern about an issue cast in gray. The prospect of change worries young and old, Republicans and Democrats, and appears to be the primary reason why many people say they wish that the Lewinsky matter would disappear. They worry that the undermining of the Clinton Presidency -- by the news media, by the independent counsel, or by the President's own actions -- could jeopardize this moment of relative prosperity.
 
In a Good Economy, A Generosity of Spirit
"Let's assume he is impeached," said Martin Kaplan, 74, a Democrat who owns a downtown store that sells antique and decorative arts. "When things are not steady, the stock market will go down. The economy is gone for about two years. It takes that amount of time for it to get back. Meanwhile, everyone is suffering. And who are they going to get instead?"
Mr. Kaplan added: "He is doing an excellent job. He is a great politician, along with his wife. She knows him like a book. She has been through this before. Regardless of what he did -- I will assume that he did whatever he did -- I don't care. Is there any man who tells the truth about sex? It is so stupid it is not even funny."
Some of that fear of change comes from not knowing what to make of Vice President Al Gore, who would assume the Presidency if Mr. Clinton were forced to step down. Selma Wasserman, 64, a Democrat, struggled with this possibility after completing a Monday morning exercise class at the downtown Y.M.C.A. building.
"I like Gore very much, but I can't see him as the President," Ms. Wasserman said. "I really don't have confidence in him taking over. That is another problem I have with this. I feel badly about saying that. I don't know why. He doesn't have the charisma. He doesn't have the get-up-and-go."
The uncertainty regarding Mr. Gore, in fact, was strong enough to force grudging acceptance of Mr. Clinton and his supposed peccadilloes among some of the President's harshest critics, like Paul Busch, 56, a disgruntled-Democrat-turned-disgruntled-Republican-turned-independent.
"I think he's degraded the Presidency more than any of his predecessors, right back to Washington," said Mr. Busch, who works in government affairs for AT&T. "I don't want to see him impeached only because I have less regard for Al Gore than I have for Clinton."
At the same time, many people did not hesitate to volunteer opinions about Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel leading the investigation into the Clinton Presidency. They do not like him -- from Mikki Oraison, 50, a special education teacher sipping coffee at Starbucks ("Is Ken Starr out to win against the President? Is it an ego thing? Possibly.") to Jack B. Dunn, ruminating after breakfast at Vicki's Diner ("He may be acting like this for publicity and probably also for money later on.").
"I think he's starting to get on everyone's nerves," said Stacey Lawrie, 33, as she left a toddler's dance class at the Y.M.C.A. with her daughter, Caitlin, 3. "He didn't bother me until I read the first articles in Newsweek, from cover to cover. He is calling in everyone's friends, relatives. With all the supposed leaks, accusations. Move it along."
 
Tough Assessments Of Kenneth Starr
 But Joanne Muldoon, a Republican draped in a plastic cape while stylist Simon Higgins tended to her brown hair at the Visage salon, said that her Westfield neighbors were missing the point. "What Ken Starr is looking for, I think, is very serious," said Ms. Muldoon, 39, a former teacher who stays at home with her three children. "The least of it is a sex scandal. The higher issue is obstruction of justice."
The more Ms. Muldoon talked, the more pointed her argument became, her words laced with sarcasm.
"They like to paint themselves as victims. They felt no qualms about trashing Monica Lewinsky. 'She is so wonderful. We are going to get her a job.' Now she is a liar."
In the end, Ms. Muldoon said that while she would like "to see him just hang on in misery and have a lame-duck Administration," she thought that he had committed impeachable offenses. "Justice should be served," she said.
Mr. Higgins, 25, who had listened silently while brushing color into her hair, spoke up. "I think what happened, happened," he said. "But I just don't think that people should think he is doing bad as President because of it. That is his private life, and it should be dealt with privately. Everybody's private life should be dealt with in a separate way."
While many in Westfield tended to agree with the hairstylist, some still expressed a sense of something lost. "It has nothing to do with his Presidency," said Natalie Lark, 70, a retired nurse. "But I think that people have gotten away from church, from God. Their morals are down. I blame television. I blame movies."
Hy Abramowitz, who said he was in his 80's, framed the matter not in a religious context but in a humorous one. "I'm a Republican," he said, smiling. "But I say this much. You had Roosevelt. You had Kennedy. They all had lovers. They're men. You know, men are like dogs."
His wife, Sarah, who had just finished an exercise class at the Y.M.C.A., started to laugh. "They all had," she said. "So what? Everybody. They all had."
Mr. Abramowitz, moving his arm toward his wife, added: "We have only been married 63 years . As far as his love life, it has nothing to do with his political life. Forget about it. Ken Starr? It's a lot of malarkey. It will pass over. If he wants to have a love life, let him have it."
But when asked what he thought the Lewinsky matter said about the nation's moral standards, the easy smile disappeared from his lined face.
"I feel sorry for the younger generation," he said."My grandson, my children. "

HEADLINE: Storms Expected to Raise Price of Produce

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: PLANT CITY, Fla., Feb. 25

 BODY:
The rainstorms that pummeled Florida and California this winter are starting to have an economic impact beyond the human misery and dislocations caused by deadly flooding, mudslides and tornadoes.
The cost of a few damaged crops like strawberries here in Central Florida has shot up in recent weeks. But the real shock to consumers may not be felt for another month when experts warn of possible drops in the production and quality of vegetables like lettuce, broccoli and cauliflower. 
 Planting delays forced by muddy fields and steady rain in the Salinas Valley, the California region that produces about three-fourths of the iceberg lettuce on grocers' shelves in April, are creating the prospect of a spring "lettuce gap," said state, Federal and industry officials.
Artichokes, tomatoes, cabbage and other perishable winter crops are also under stress but may reach full production if extended dry periods give farmers time to pick and ship them to market.
"Consumers are going to face higher prices for specific vegetables this spring because of interruptions in planting and the possibility of harvesting problems," said Keith Collins, chief economist for the United States Department of Agriculture.
The outlook for summer farm production, when the bulk of American agriculture is planted and harvested, remains good, Mr. Collins said, but not without nagging concerns.
"A potentially bigger problem could occur if the El Nino system ends," he said, "and extended hot and dry weather takes its place over most of the farm belt this summer."
A severe drought followed the last severe El Nino onslaught in 1983, creating farm shortages and very high prices, Mr. Collins noted. But he said experts disagreed on when El Nino would retreat and what weather pattern would replace it.
A drought could have effects more widespread than usual, he said, because surpluses of major grains like corn are at the lowest levels in recent history. A setback in the corn harvest, Mr. Collins warned, could place pressures on feed for the livestock industry.
Meanwhile, consumers in much of the country are benefiting from lower heating costs as the same El Nino weather pattern that battered California and Florida has helped spread abnormally warm weather over much of the country.
"Heating demand is 10 percent below normal," said Jon Davis, a meteorologist with Smith Barney. "That's phenomenal. Even a 3 or 4 percent deviation from normal is generally considered a significant event in the markets."
Natural gas prices have also dropped by nearly half since the fall, when unusually warm temperatures in the West and Southeast created a huge demand on electricity.
"El Nino definitely has been the main contributor," said Michael Barbis, who tracks the natural gas industry for UBS Global Research.
Home heating oil, after a general drop in crude oil costs, sells today for about $1 a gallon compared with $1.17 a year ago, industry officials said.
What's more, a decline in weather-related travel delays has saved countless hours of labor and costs because airplanes, trucks and cars have operated without the usual seasonal impediments of snow and ice in many states.
Winter clothing and snowblower sales have slowed, but in many places retail stores are getting an early start on selling sportswear. Golf courses and other outdoor services are unseasonably robust.
Florida tourist destinations continue to insist that all the rain this winter and Monday's tornadoes -- which killed 39 people in Central Florida and destroyed millions of dollars' worth of property -- has not hurt tourism. Maureen Gonzalez, a spokeswoman for the Peabody Hotel in Orlando, said that there had not been a single cancellation of a reservation and that all 891 rooms were filled with people attending a convention of the American Dermatological Association.
But it seems too early to measure the impact on potential travelers to Florida who have seen or read news of the weather here and decided to stay home or go elsewhere, or those who curtailed their visit in the state.
Florida and California both have tourist attractions that draw many of their own residents. In California, tourism has been a mixed picture this season, with the number of hotel cancellations reported to be higher than usual in San Francisco and other coastal destinations but with total demand continuing the strength of recent years.
But for fruit farmers like Carl Grooms of Plant City, nature's devastation is clear in this strawberry-rich region east of Tampa.
"This is a normal strawberry," Mr. Grooms said, holding up a scarlet, heart-shaped berry redolent with a fresh, sweet smell.
"And this," he said, picking up a smaller, gnarled berry between a thumb and forefinger, "is garbage."
With a snap of his fingers, the smaller berry squished into a piece of watery pulp that he threw to the ground with disgust.
"About 20 percent of the fruit we pick can't go to market, and some of what does is being rejected because some of the berries are rotten by the time they receive it," said Mr. Grooms, a third-generation farmer.
And although there was much sunshine today in Plant City and in Oxnard, Calif., the other center of winter strawberry cultivation in the United States, the land was still wet in both places as anxiety ran deep about the weather.
"I've never seen anything like this in my life," Mr. Grooms said.
His 72 acres contain 1.5 million plants, and last year he shipped to market 220,000 bright yellow cartons, each containing 12 pints of strawberries under the Fancy Farms label.
"We've picked since Thanksgiving," he said, "and so far we've shipped 100,000 flats and maybe we can pick another 50,000 in the weeks ahead."
Even worse growing conditions in Oxnard drove up his wholesale price to about $10 a carton, Mr. Grooms said, more than twice the $4 he received last year. But he was concerned that a poor crop would be costly to his bottom line, saying, "The shopper in the supermarket may turn her nose up at berries that may be smaller than usual and deformed."
Paul D'Arrigo, chairman of D'Arrigo Brothers, a large wholesale produce buyer in the Bronx, agreed that shoppers might not like some of the fruits and vegetables showing up in markets this spring.
"The quality of some items is already down," Mr. D'Arrigo said. "But January and February is a lousy produce season without much demand. In a month or so I expect prices are going to go up when a real void develops in the lettuce market because of California's problems and before Texas and Eastern harvests are available in late spring."
Mr. D'Arrigo and others said shortages would create higher prices if the quality of produce was marred by poor growing conditions. There is already evidence that at least part of the crops from California and Florida will be smaller than in normal growing years and bear external evidence of damage by the elements.
In Florida, shipments of fresh citrus fruit have slowed because wet groves have hindered picking in what is a record growing year, industry officials said. Juice quality has been affected by soggy groves that cut the acid content of oranges, making them taste more watery, said Bobby McKown, executive vice president of Florida Citrus Mutual, which represents an industry that accounted for $3.4 billion in sales last year.
Of more concern is the potential threat to groves south and southwest of Orlando, where the ground is not as sandy as in the rest of the state's citrus belt, meaning that drainage is more of a problem.
"A lot of trees in these groves have been flooded for an extended period, and there is some evidence of root damage," Mr. McKown said.
A tree with a damaged root system may yield its present crop but become barren in the future, he said. Mr. McKown emphasized that there was not yet any determination that significant numbers of trees in the affected groves -- which may represent about half of all orange trees in the state -- had suffered root damage. But the discovery was unsettling and would worsen if the groves were hit by more rainfall in the normally dry months ahead.

HEADLINE: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE C.I.A.;
C.I.A. Drafts Covert Plan to Topple Hussein

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency has been drafting plans for a major program of sabotage and subversion against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Government officials say.
Four prior covert operations, involving everything from radio propaganda to paramilitary plots, have failed to dislodge the Iraqi leader, just as smart bombs, cruise missiles and stiff economic sanctions have failed. 
 The C.I.A.'s new plan, months in the making, must still be approved by President Clinton. That approval is by no means certain, and some of his key advisers are skeptical of the plan.
The debate over the need for new covert action has intensified in the last few weeks, with senior members of Congress openly calling for the C.I.A. to destabilize President Hussein. But some of the President's advisers consider the new plan no more likely to succeed than the agency's earlier efforts, and they are likely to argue against approving it, the officials said.
The plan, still in the draft stage, has not yet been put into final form for a decision by the President. The fact that officials are disclosing it shows the depth of their doubts.
The Director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet, has told Mr. Clinton that the plan is risky, the officials said, and the President's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, is skeptical of the C.I.A.'s ability to undermine Mr. Hussein.
The plan calls for enlisting Kurdish and Shiite agents to destroy or damage key Iraqi pillars of economic and political power, like utility plants or Government broadcast stations, the officials said. At the same time, the plan calls for increasing political pressure on Iraq through propaganda programs like a "Radio Free Iraq" broadcast to Baghdad.
The plan aims to try to undermine President Hussein by showing Iraqi citizens that he is not invincible, strengthening his opponents inside Iraq and trying to ignite a rebellion within his inner circle.
"This is not a propaganda operation," one senior Government official said of the C.I.A.'s plan. "This is a major campaign of sabotage."
For the plan to go forward, the President must sign a written order, known as a "finding." If it is approved as now conceived, it could become one of the biggest covert actions since the end of the cold war, costing tens of millions of dollars a year, officials said.
Since the Persian Gulf war in 1991, the agency has backed Kurdish dissidents in the north of Iraq, Shiite Muslim groups in the south, Iraqi exiles in London and Iraqi military defectors based in Jordan. These operations, which have cost about $100 million, have had little or no success.
Most recently, in August 1996, President Hussein sent tanks into northern Iraq to destroy a C.I.A. base staffed by American intelligence officers and Kurdish agents, arresting and executing scores of Kurds.
But now influential senators -- notably John McCain, an Arizona Republican; John Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, and Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican and a former chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee -- are calling on the agency once more.
"It may well be that a covert action or covert actions might succeed in deposing Saddam Hussein," Senator Specter said Monday on the Senate floor. He said a covert action -- along with the establishment of an Iraqi government-in-exile, expansion of "no flight" zones to cover all of Iraq and a naval blockade -- could help "bring Saddam Hussein to his knees."
But the Iraqi opposition is fragmented, "plagued by divisions," in the words of Wafiq Samoraei, a former head of Iraqi military intelligence based in London.
"It is lacking in sufficient support in Baghdad-controlled Iraq to be a significant factor in internal politics in Iraq," said Kenneth Katzman, a Iraq expert at the Congressional Research Service and a former C.I.A. analyst of Persian Gulf politics.
The diplomatic, political and economic structures that can conceal C.I.A. officers and agents -- a United States embassy, a network of political contacts, a bevy of businessmen going in and out of the country -- do not exist in Iraq. That makes it exceedingly hard for agents to penetrate the inner circle surrounding President Hussein, who controls tens of thousands of soldiers and spies whose sole duty is to preserve his power.
The two major opposition groups in exile, the Iraqi National Congress, based in London, and the Iraqi National Accord, based in Amman, Jordan, have been riven by dissent. The Kurds, the world's largest stateless ethnic group, have bases in northern Iraq but also are bitterly divided. Shiite groups in the south of Iraq, some with ties to Saudi Arabia, some with ties to Iran, have proven politically impotent in the past.
Covert operations aimed at subverting Mr. Hussein's Government date back to the Bush Administration. Immediately after the gulf war, President Bush ordered the C.I.A. to support a coup against the Iraqi leader. The Kurds and Shiites were openly encouraged to rise up against him. The opposition was crushed.
Then the agency supported the Iraqi National Congress from 1992 to 1996. The group achieved little. In 1995, after some key Iraqi military officers defected, the agency shifted its support to the Iraqi National Accord. But in the summer of 1996, President Hussein's military and intelligence services crushed the small clique of Iraqi military officers working with the group and destroyed a C.I.A. base in northern Iraq.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Lawmakers Approve Africa Trade Plan

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Legislation aimed at promoting growth in sub-Saharan Africa by offering trade and investment incentives was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee. 
 The measure is being pushed by a bipartisan group and has the backing of President Clinton, who is scheduled to make his first visit to Africa as President next month.
The measure, expected to be taken up by the full House within the next two weeks, offers the prospect that goods from the 48 countries of sub-Saharan Africa will have greater access to the United States market. It would offer duty-free coverage to a variety of products as a first step.

HEADLINE: Power Deregulated. Consumers Yawn.;
California's Effort to Promote Plan For Electricity Is Off to a Slow Start

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
They've tried everything.
For the public, California officials have run a commercial that shows a motorcycle cop oblivious to the cars rocketing by him because he is so engrossed in thoughts of electricity deregulation. 
 For the state's 2.3 million Hispanic households, they've created a Spanish-speaking dancing dog named Chispita who stares into the television camera, spins around and declares, "I am as fast as a spark of electricity."
To get the attention of blacks, who their research indicates "spend little time thinking about electricity," they've developed an animated character called Electron Man as an "entertaining vehicle to deliver the educational message."
They've even recruited a Los Angeles radio talk show host, Michael Jackson, to promote a toll-free number that fields questions about the coming changes in 11 languages, including Tagalog, Hmong and Laotian. And before beginning their current $73 million media blitz, they held three years of hearings, then slashed electricity bills by 10 percent to let energy users know something big was in the works.
But try as they might, California officials just haven't been able to get consumers excited about the deregulation of the electricity industry. On March 31, after a three-month delay due to computer glitches, California will become the first state in the nation to throw the market open to something close to full competition -- and for the last five months, a host of marketers have inundated homes and businesses with pitches for cheaper and more efficient power delivery.
Yet, so far, a minuscule 25,000 customers out of 9.9 million have switched providers. Most Californians remain confused about the purposes of the program and doubtful about the payoff, if any, for them. As a result, they are taking a wait-and-see attitude.
"Consumers are being bombarded with all kinds of offers," said Jeff Dennard, a senior vice president for Makovsky & Company, a consulting group that is working with utilities. "Many are scared to switch."
Their reluctance is bad news for the people who are promoting deregulation as a way to lower energy prices and introduce competition to one of the last bastions of monopoly in the nation. It is also a setback for the nearly 300 marketers who have jumped into the fray in the hopes of getting a slice of a $20 billion pie (though so far only 30 have been given approval to do business). And because California has long been viewed as a national trend-setter in everything from popular culture to demographic trends, the public's nervousness poses a challenge to the 20 other states that are in the early stages of deregulating their own utility industries.
In New York, Consolidated Edison plans to start a pilot program on June 1 to allow 63,000 of its 3 million customers to choose alternate suppliers, and already, consumers are getting pitches from marketers and newspaper ads about the project. But similar experiments in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Vermont encountered public responses every bit as tepid as California's.
"What we're going to see over the next four years is utter and complete confusion," said Erika B. Seamon, who has been working as a consultant to utilities with Kucvmarski & Associates, a management consulting firm in Chicago. What is happening in California is having an effect nationwide, she added.
Part of the problem is that most consumers have little incentive to study the brochures that arrive in the mail or to listen to the telemarketing pitches that seem to intrude just as they are sitting down to dinner. The savings on monthly bills that average $50 to $75, after all, amount at most to a few dollars.
Eventually, after a four-year transition period in which the costs of paying off old power plants that are no longer cost competitive are spread among all customers, the savings could become much more substantial. Industry executives predict an additional 10 to 15 percent cut in the bills of residential and small commercial customers. Larger industrial and commercial customers are expected to see rates drop 20 to 30 percent.
Most people, though, remain skeptical that they will enjoy even that meager reward. And most are unfamiliar with the utility industry and how deregulation will work. Under the California plan, anyone who pays a $100 fee and fills out a form can buy electricity from generating companies or a state power exchange, sell it to consumers and pay utility concerns a fee to deliver it, maintain lines and collect bills.
Moreover, said Mr. Dennard of Makovsky & Company, "There is also the residual knowledge that things did not go as advertised in telephone deregulation. Many are still wondering whether they are doing better after telephone deregulation." Even though telephone and airline deregulation did indeed foster innovation and lead to lower prices for most consumers, many people still find it difficult to grasp why the same should hold true for electricity. In a national survey in December by Makovsky & Company, 62 percent of those questioned predicted that utility deregulation in their states would lead to higher prices.
It does not help that many marketers indulge in hard-sell techniques or even outright fraud. Some tout freebies that are hard to evaluate, according to analysts. Some promise low rates without making it clear they will load on various charges and fees to make up the difference. And some contend that the electricity they deliver will come only from solar power, dams or other environmentally benign sources.
In recent weeks, California regulators have suspended the licenses of dozens of marketers until they provide more information on how they will deliver the power they are selling. In one case, the Public Utilities Commission banned a company founded by a 19-year-old entrepreneur, saying it had signed up 8,000 customers for $300 each, even though it had no supply agreements with utilities.
More commonly, marketers use perfectly legal ploys that some consumers nonetheless find misleading. When the Enron Corporation, a Houston-based energy giant with ambitions to become a national natural gas and electricity marketer, sent a mailing to Phil Branon offering a 10 percent rate cut and two weeks of free electricity if he switched from the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, the state's largest utility, he jumped at the chance.
But then Mr. Branon, who puts out a trade newsletter called Infoworld in San Francisco, did a little digging and discovered that neither offer had much value. The 10 percent savings was an automatic bonus -- mandated by the State Legislature and paid for by a special bond issue -- for every energy user in the state.
And after reading the fine print of his contract, he realized that he would get the free electricity, worth about $25, only if he stayed with Enron for a year.
"I felt like someone had pulled the wool over my eyes," he said. "I'm going to switch back." Gary Foster, a spokesman for Enron's marketing arm, said the offer was straightforward and contained no misleading information.
If the wariness of consumers like Mr. Branon is putting a crimp in California's deregulation plan, unexpected resistance from another quarter -- industrial and commercial customers -- is an even greater disappointment.
Most marketers had aimed at these big energy users as the quickest path to profits because signing up just a few would have given them the same economy of scale as recruiting thousands of homeowners and small businesses. But instead of grabbing the first money-saving deal, many such customers are using the prospect of deregulation to do in-depth studies of their energy needs.
"We see deregulation as destabilizing and potentially confusing," said Mick Spilsbury, an executive vice president of the Union Bank of California, the third-largest bank in the state, which spends $10 million a year on natural gas and electricity. "We have to get better educated before we get tied into a four-year deal that looks good today but four years from now everybody will be telling me we signed a bad deal."
Because of the expense and effort to come up with a serious proposal, he said, only two companies -- Enron and the marketing affiliate of San Diego Gas and Electric called Edison Source -- have made a serious effort. "They have not come beating our doors down," he said.
Mr. Spilsbury's caution is echoed at other companies. Glen Lewis, a regional procurement manager for Del Monte Foods, one of California's largest employers, said there were still too many unknowns about how deregulation would actually work. "It's such a dynamic thing right now," he said. "We're going to go slow and look at things gradually."
Some marketers have gotten the message and are wooing big corporate customers through painstaking analysis of their energy-consumption practices, rather than just by promising lower rates. To win a multi-year, $180 million account to supply electricity to 800 McDonald's restaurants in California, for example, the staff of P.G.& E. Services, the marketing arm of Pacific Gas and Electric, spent months looking into every corner of the company's operations.
"They want more than just prices," said Faye Worthy, the director of national commercial accounts for P.G.& E. Services, who spent endless hours alongside McDonald's executives and franchisees. "They're looking for someone who really understands their business."
Robert D. Glynn Jr., the utility's chairman and chief executive, said "You have to have the staying power and the fortitude to survive the early years."

An article in Business Day yesterday about the deregulation of the electricity industry in California misidentified the utility marketing company that sought Union Bank of California as a customer. It was Energy Pacific, a joint venture of the Enova Corporation and Pacific Enterprises; it was not Edison Source.

LENGTH: 1079 words

HEADLINE: Taipei Journal;
For Heaven's Sake, Don't Fly a U.F.O.

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
Ho Hsien-jung cradled a bloated aluminum saucer on his lap and looked worried.
"We are scientists," he fumed, carefully placing the shining saucer alongside others on a shelf in his narrow living room. "Our research into U.F.O.'s is scientific. All these other people are cheats. They're cheating people." 
 As chairman of the Chinese Flying Saucer Research Association, Mr. Ho has good reason to be concerned: a growing number of people in Taiwan are reporting sightings of flying saucers and he has never seen one. Moreover, these sightings have been used by a growing number of religious prophets who promise everything from a fast-approaching apocalypse to instant wealth, alarming authorities at a spreading pattern of religious and financial fraud.
Many people here say they have been fleeced of their life savings by these cult leaders, who are preying on a society that has gone through tumultuous political and economic transformations in the last decade: from dictatorship to democracy, from developing country to one of the strongest economies in Asia.
"From ancient times to the Qing dynasty," which ended in 1911, "there are historical records showing more than 1,000 U.F.O. sightings," insisted Mr. Ho, leafing through a detailed listing of historical texts describing mysterious objects and lights in the sky. "But in Taiwan," he continued, "you can't really see U.F.O.'s. They don't come to Taiwan very often. Taiwan is just a small island. They can't see it from outer space."
Undeterred by such assertions from Taiwan's pre-eminent saucer authority, a former medical professor named Chen Heng-ming spent last year busily assembling devotees into his sect, the God Saves the Earth Flying Saucer Association.
Perhaps because Taiwan is so small, Mr. Chen has taken about 100 of his followers to the wide open ranges of Texas where they will, in the words of a follower, Wu Chun-sheng, "be meeting God, who would arrive on a flying saucer to save them." From Dallas, the believers will be whisked to Mars neat year in flying saucers. Living a year in a flying saucer, she said, "would be like 10 years on earth."
Interplanetary travel, however, appears to come with a price tag. The parents of several sect members have complained to the police that their children gave Mr. Chen huge sums of money for the privilege of a saucer ride.
In Texas, the authorities are reportedly worried that he intends to orchestrate a mass suicide in the fashion of Heaven's Gate, an American sect in which dozens of members committed collective suicide in San Diego last year.
In articles with blaring headlines here, Mr. Chen has repeatedly assured the people of Taiwan that he has no intention of committing suicide; indeed, he said, he and his 100 or so followers were just "waiting to ride a flying saucer into heaven," a trip that would start on March 31, 1999, at precisely 10 P.M.
While Mr. Chen was scuttling off to Texas for his promised encounter of the third kind, a man named Wu Tai-chung has been corralling members into his own sect, the Sky and Earth Enlightenment Association, by assuring them that he arrived from outer space to save them from planetary Armageddon. Brandishing photographs taken in Taiwan's central mountain district, Mr. Wu told his growing number of followers that the dots of sun glare marring the pictures were in fact "points of inner energy" from outer space; merging with those dots would, Mr. Wu declared, allow believers to soar into outer space on a flying saucer.
Like the rides offered by Mr. Chen, the ticket to salvation by saucer is no bargain.
"We believed, we completely believed," said Tai Chiu-fen, a 38-year-old mother of seven and owner of a car repair shop. "We got involved because my husband had these headaches and we were told he didn't have to have medicine and he would get better. We were very curious and decided to try it."
She and her husband gave Wu Tai-chung the equivalent of about $312,000, she said. "We have no money left. We spent it all, or rather, we were cheated of it all."
As the flying saucer cults spread, national authorities and officials in Taipei, a city of six million, are becoming increasingly alarmed at people's gullibility.
"This so-called religious problem is a social problem," said Chen Shui-bian, Taipei's Mayor, in an interview in his spartan office. "In Taiwan society many people do not have faith in themselves. They feel they can't place their faith in ordinary things, including science and technology, so they put it into these religions."
"These religions," he continued, "are not real religions. They are just another form of deception. People get deeply involved. It's not a question of education because a lot of professors, Ph.D.'s, they can believe in these type of things."
Mrs. Tai, who gave all her money to the Sky and Earth sect, reluctantly agreed with her Mayor when asked why she turned to Mr. Wu's group. Sighing deeply, she explained: "The pressure on our life is very heavy. We all seek spiritual sustenance. I believed in him. He had pictures. He showed them to us. Everyone said it was true, it was real."
She added: "He said that if you want to travel this road, you can't take belongings from this world. No possessions. Only then can you reach this force."
So uneasy are the Taiwan authorities about the spread of these cults that prosecutors have begun criminal investigations into whether adherents have been defrauded.
Liao Cheng-hao, the Minister of Justice, said in an interview that the reasons for the spread of the cults was "very, very easy to understand," adding: "People feel empty and are searching for a kind of civilized society. They are all looking for the true religion. But these flying saucer cults are a relatively strange phenomenon."
For Mr. Ho, for whom flying saucers are a serious business, there is no mystery about them. "If there's a U.F.O. in the sky, you can see it," he said. "It has a shape, a form, It has mass. All the others are cheats."
Despite the spread of cults claiming links with beings on flying saucers, Mr. Ho said he was determined to soldier on with his work. "Our research is scientific," he said. "How could we be affected by these cults? How could this hurt our reputation?"
"Religion itself is very mysterious," Mr. Ho said. "Adding U.F.O.'s only makes it more attractive. But if you're using U.F.O.'s in your religion, your religion has got real problems."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Viacom Posts a Less-Than-Expected Loss

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Viacom Inc. lost less money in the fourth quarter than analysts had expected, and the company's results are likely to improve further because of the record-setting success of the film "Titanic."
Viacom said yesterday that its MTV and Showtime cable operations performed well during the fourth quarter. Moreover, results at Viacom's Blockbuster video store chain are rebounding: Rental revenue at stores open at least a year rose in the quarter for the first time in almost two years. 
 "Titanic," released in this country by the Paramount Pictures division, has already generated a record $919.8 million in revenue since its release in late December.
"What made this quarter better was the cable assets," said Barry Hyman, an analyst with Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum Inc., which has a "buy" rating on Viacom's stock. " 'Titanic' is what we have to look forward to."
In the fourth quarter, Viacom's loss from continuing operations, before a gain, was $102 million, or 29 cents a diluted share. That was better than the loss of 35 cents a share that analysts, on average, had expected. A year earlier, the company had earnings from continuing operations of $17 million, or 1 cent a share.
Including a pretax gain of $1.2 billion from the sale of its share in the USA Networks cable business, Viacom had profit from continuing operations in the latest quarter of $597 million, or $1.60 a share. Net income was $573 million, or $1.54 a share, in contrast with a loss of $227.4 million a year earlier, or 68 cents a share.
Viacom's class B shares, which are widely traded, rose $1.75, to $46, on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The improvements at Blockbuster and the success of "Titanic" have lifted the shares 50 percent since October.
Analysts believe the stock could reach the mid-$50 range in a few months, especially if Viacom proceeds with the sale of part of its Simon & Schuster publishing business and its stake in Spelling Entertainment Group.
Viacom wants to use money from asset sales to reduce its $8 billion debt, already cut by more than $2 billion last year. That could allow it to make acquisitions in its core film and cable television businesses.
Revenue in the fourth quarter increased 5.9 percent, to $3.61 billion from $3.41 billion. Cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, rose 6.7 percent, to $510 million from $478 million.
Leading the way in the quarter was MTV Networks, which includes the MTV, VH1 and Nickelodeon cable channels. The division had a 25 percent rise in cash flow, to $220 million. Showtime Networks had a 14 percent gain.
MTV Networks benefited from higher advertising, driven by the strong economy, and increased subscription fees.
Despite the increase in same-store rental revenue at Blockbuster, cash flow fell 36 percent, to $123 million. Blockbuster has suffered from two years of shifting strategies and management changes, but a new executive team has won praise for focusing on Blockbuster's core rental business while forging agreements with some studios to reduce the costs of films.
Viacom's film business, led by Paramount Pictures, reported a 51 percent decline in cash flow, to $39 million, primarily because of lower syndication revenue for television programming. The quarter a year earlier was strong because it included hits like "Mission: Impossible" and "Beavis and Butt-Head Do America."
"Titanic" was released too late in the quarter to have much impact on the results. Paramount owns the domestic rights to the film, while the News Corporation's 20th Century Fox owns the international business.

HEADLINE: Union Pacific Predicts Loss and Cuts Its Dividend

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Union Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest railroad company, forecast a first-quarter loss yesterday, announced plans to issue as much as $1 billion in securities and cut its dividend by more than half as it struggles to untangle an eight-month rail logjam.
Shares of Union Pacific fell $6.5625, or 11 percent, to $52.0625, in heavy trading. Earlier, the stock touched a 16-month low of $49. The share price has fallen about 26 percent since July. 
 Wall Street analysts said the announcements came as a surprise because the company said last month that it was profitable.
Union Pacific said its outlook changed in recent weeks because its strategy of running trains in a single direction on one track was not working. That strategy was the company's latest ill-fated attempt to resolve congestion resulting from its $5.4 billion acquisition of the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation in 1996.
"They need more than a Band-Aid approach," said Doug Rockel, an analyst with Furman Selz. "It's good news for shippers but a negative announcement for shareholders," at least initially.
The company has yet to determine the form of the equity-based securities it will issue or when it will do so, a spokesman, Gary Schuster, said. But it said it planned to use the proceeds to expand rail yards and tracks, especially in the hardest-hit gulf region.
The company reduced its quarterly dividend to 20 cents a share from 43 cents. That move is expected to save $230 million a year.
Richard K. Davidson, the chairman and chief executive, said Union Pacific's business could be hurt "perhaps a little bit into the second quarter while we get this thing back on its feet."
The Standard & Poor's Corporation cut its rating on Union Pacific's commercial paper and said it might lower its corporate credit, senior secured and unsecured debt ratings. Moody's Investors Service downgraded the company's senior unsecured debt rating.
Union Pacific has lost sales as it failed to deliver goods on time and shippers turned to other railroads or trucks.
The company's expenses have also risen as it has paid overtime crews and incurred other costs to try to clear up its lines.
Economists say the logjam has cost businesses in the United States about $2 billion, with as much as half the damage in Texas. Shippers are pressuring Federal regulators to consider ordering Union Pacific to sell some track to give shippers more alternatives for rail transportation.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Middle-Income Complex Planned for Rockaway

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Believing that the market for rental apartments for middle-income tenants is improving on the Rockaway peninsula in Queens, a developer is building the first such project in the area in over a decade.
The $13.5 million development will have 130 apartments ranging from studios to three-bedroom units in five four-story brick buildings. It will take shape over the next 10 months on an empty patch of land at 2229-2259 Dix Avenue, between McBride Street and Beach Channel Drive in Far Rockaway. 
 The developer is Dix-McBride L.L.P. of Astoria, Queens, headed by George Fakiris, who has built some 70 apartment buildings with 18,000 residences, mostly rentals, throughout New York City in the last 25 years. He is financing the project with his own money and an $8.25 million construction loan from EAB, a Uniondale, N.Y., bank owned by the Dutch banking giant ABN Amro Bank, N.V.
The project is moving ahead at a time when there is renewed interest in redeveloping the former resort area, which fell into decline after World War II. About 16 percent of the land, or about 700 acres, in the area is vacant. Much of this stems from the razing of hundreds of acres of bungalows, modest homes and hotels from Beach 32d to Beach 73d Streets in 1965 as part of city urban renewal plans that never materialized.
But in the last three years, as the economy revived, planning resumed. Jonathan L. Gaska, district manager for Community Board 14, which helps guide growth in the area, said that in that time about 70 residences, mostly two-family homes, have been or are being built in the area.
More development is planned. At an old urban renewal site along Jamaica Bay between Beach 35th and Beach 51st Streets in the Edgemere section, there are plans for 800 housing units, primarily two-family homes, to be built under New York City's New Homes Program. Under it, the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development will work with the nonprofit New York City Housing Partnership to choose a developer to build, with city and state subsidies, homes affordable to buyers with incomes between $32,000 and $70,000 a year.
The Edgemere project, to be developed in four phases, will also include up to 100,000 square feet of retail space, a new elementary school and 13 acres of parks. Construction of the first phase, 132 residences, is expected to begin in 2000, following site acquisition, which is to start in the fall. Construction of new streets and sewers is to begin in the summer of 1999, city officials said.
Plans were also announced in June for another urban renewal area, along the Atlantic Ocean from Beach 25th to Beach 73d in the Arverne section. A Canadian company, the Heathmount Arts and Entertainment Corporation, wants to build a 2.7 million-square-foot entertainment, sports and hotel complex, to be called the Technodome. Issues like the cost and extent of road and sewer improvements the area would need to accommodate the project are still being discussed.
Meanwhile, work continues on Dix-McBride's Dix Avenue project, begun in December. Mr. Fakiris bought the three-acre site for $1.1 million three years ago with the intention of building rentals for low-income tenants. That plan was abandoned when he was unable to get public subsidies to help finance the project.
He said he pursued the current project because of the new development planned in the area and what he sensed was "a big demand for apartments for middle-income tenants, which no one is building."
In addition, under the city's 421a abatement program, which provides partial tax exemptions to developers who build multiple dwellings on vacant, underused sites, property taxes will be kept to a minimum for 15 years.
Mr. Gaska said the community board had opposed the low-income rental project because it was important to the area's revival to encourage housing for middle-income families. He said the district is home to about 5,000 public housing units, and of its population of 106,000, about 30 percent receive public assistance.
"If successful, the Dix Avenue project will be a shot in the arm that could help turn that part of Far Rockaway around," Mr. Gaska said, adding that it, along with the plans for the urban renewal sites, "show that people want to invest here." But if the Dix Avenue project is not successful, he said, "the concern is that it will be converted into housing for low-income tenants."
Robin J. Cohen, senior vice president for the real estate lending division at EAB, added that the bank lent the money to the developer because the projected rents would be affordable to middle-income people, who are moving into the area.
Rents for the apartments, with 443 to 882 square feet on average, are expected to range from $550 to $1,100 per month. There will also be a playground and underground and surface parking for 200 cars. The complex will be gated and have security cameras. Leasing is expected to begin late in July.

GRAPHIC: Map of Far Rockaway shows site of development: A developer is building 130 apartments in five buildings. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Faces Hard Choice as Suharto Balks at Economic Reform

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has concluded that President Suharto of Indonesia has once again sent the effort to rescue his country wildly off track, ignoring most of the commitments he signed six weeks ago with the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Suharto's continued refusal to enact the economic and political reforms he committed to in return for a $43-billion bailout presents the Clinton Administration and the monetary fund with a tough choice. They must either threaten to suspend the huge rescue program and risk the further collapse of the Indonesian economy -- and further outbreaks of violence -- or let Mr. Suharto undermine the fund's credibility by taking its money and ignoring its dictates. 
 Today, Administration officials were still debating how stiffly to word their warnings to Mr. Suharto when former Vice President Walter F. Mondale sees the 76-year-old leader early next week. Mr. Mondale is the second personal emissary President Clinton has sent to see Asia's longest-serving leader, and one senior official preparing him for the trip called the mission "a last-ditch effort to let him know that his country is heading into chaos, and he's throwing away the life ring."
In his agreement with the monetary fund, Mr. Suharto said he would break up many of the cartels -- run by his family and friends -- that dominate Indonesia's economy, close down failing banks and take a series of steps to restore the confidence of investors who have fled the country. But the cartels have remained open, often under different guises, and the banks have done little other than announce that they cannot pay their international debts.
"We are still trying to send the message to Indonesia that it is in their overwhelming interest to implement the reforms to keep Indonesia from dissolving into further financial chaos," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said several days ago.
But the selection of Mr. Mondale and the daily meetings at the White House, rather than at Mr. Rubin's office in the Treasury, reflect how Indonesia's troubles are now regarded as a political crisis wrapped around a currency crisis. Mr. Clinton's four telephone calls with Mr. Suharto were described by one top official as "unsatisfying at best."
Between calls, Mr. Suharto has fired the central bank chief, who was pressing the monetary fund's reform agenda, and promoted the nomination of an old friend, B. J. Habibie, as Vice President, in a parliamentary election in two weeks.
Mr. Habibie is regarded as one of the "crony capitalists" whose Government-subsidized businesses are a target of the I.M.F. But American officials appear to have given up hope that Mr. Suharto would choose another candidate; they are concentrating now on preventing him from placing other close friends in top economic positions.
So Mr. Mondale, who met Mr. Suharto once before more than 20 years ago, is facing the task of derailing those moves, without seeming to directly interfere in Mr. Suharto's choices.
Today, Mr. Mondale and President Clinton had a long talk about his mission, White House officials said. A White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said Mr. Mondale would "push for both economic and political reform as a way of working through the Asian economic crisis."
Mr. Mondale seems unlikely to directly threaten that the monetary fund could cancel the $43-billion "stabilization program," officials familiar with his briefings say, in part because they are trying to sidestep a direct confrontation with the often-prickly Indonesian leader.
In fact, it is unclear how much of a message he will be able to send. Mr. Clinton's last emissary, Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, sat through a lengthy monologue by Mr. Suharto that filled much of their 90-minute session. "It was classic Suharto," one official familiar with the session said.
But there are signs that Washington and the I.M.F. are looking for face-saving ways to win Mr. Suharto's cooperation. In the past few days, the fund has told Indonesia it can continue to subsidize sales of basic foodstuffs, rather than risk seeing their price continue to rise. "We have no wish to see food riots," a senior monetary fund official said.
Mr. Mondale, officials say, will express a limited American support for Mr. Suharto, in part because the State Department is arguing that there is no credible alternative leader for the country.
In his talks with President Clinton, Mr. Suharto has seemed less concerned about his own hold on power or the sporadic rioting that has already taken a half-dozen lives than about the continued decline of his country's currency, the rupiah.
A week ago he told Mr. Clinton that he was considering a plan to fix the value of the rupiah through a system called a currency board because the I.M.F.'s strategy had failed. But the currency plan would have undercut many of the provisions of the agreement with the monetary fund and given Mr. Suharto's children and friends a brief window to get their money out of the country at a favorable exchange rate.
After receiving protests from Mr. Clinton and from leaders in Japan and Europe -- as well as a direct threat that the fund would reconsider its aid program -- Mr. Suharto backed away from his currency plan, at least temporarily. But the argument over the rupiah, notes Jeffrey Sachs, the Harvard economist who has been highly critical of the fund's plan, "was a distraction that took up three valuable weeks when both sides could have been doing a lot of more useful things."
"Both sides have made a hash of this whole thing by not addressing the real problems," Mr. Sachs said, noting that the fund agreement "doesn't solve the basic problems of the failing banks, the sinking currency or the crushing foreign debt."
If Mr. Suharto is going to indicate a change of course, he may not have much time. On March 15, just four days after the Indonesian Parliament is set to re-elect him for another five-year term, the monetary fund must decide at a meeting here whether to send the next installment of its aid. A fact-finding team from the fund is in Jakarta now to evaluate Indonesia's progress.
American officials, who could effectively veto the disbursement of funds, say they have not yet taken a position on whether to keep money flowing to Mr. Suharto's Government. But privately, many doubt that, no matter what the Indonesian leader does, they can afford to take the risk of cutting him off. They said they feared that if the West appeared to turn its back on Indonesia, the economy would melt down so fast that the panic could spread to Thailand, South Korea and other economies that are finally showing signs of stabilization.
"We don't have a lot of leverage," one official said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Oil Service Companies Surge; Dow Hits 8th Recent High

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The stocks of oil service companies surged yesterday in the wake of the Halliburton Company's agreement to acquire Dresser Industries for $7.7 billion in stock. Some industry analysts said they believed that the agreement could lead to a stampede among other companies to find partners.
Arvind S. Sanger, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said yesterday that some competitors could be disadvantaged by the combination, which would create another giant in the oil service sector, along with the current leader, Schlumberger Ltd. "It could increase the pressure for consolidation, but it's not imperative that others merge to prosper," he said in an interview at an energy conference sponsored by Donaldson in New York. 
 The gains in oil services stocks helped push the market up broadly. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 32.89 points, to 8,490.67, the eighth new high in the last 12 trading days. Other major market indexes also rose to new highs, with the Nasdasq composite index up 10.63 points, to 1,777.11, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks up 5.77 points, to 1,048.67. The Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks also rallied, rising 3.05 points, to 461.54. The index is now just 3.67 points from its all-time high of 465.21 reached Oct. 13.
The rally lifted stocks ranging from Boeing, which was up 211/16 , to 5315/16 , to Philip Morris, up 1 5/8, to 42 5/8. It was fueled by the same factors that have been carrying stocks higher for some time: low interest rates, low inflation and the prospect of continued growth in corporate earnings. In addition, despite this week's warnings from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, investors seem to think that the impact from the Asian economic turmoil will be minimal. Among the leading performers in oil services yesterday were Baker Hughes, which rose by 3 7/8, or 10.5 percent, to close at 40 5/8. Cliffs Drilling rose 2 1/8 a share, to 39 5/8, and Varco International also rose 2 1/8, to 24 3/8.
Mr. Sanger said Halliburton's acquisition of Dresser could increase the pressure on several of the smaller and midsize companies, including Cliffs, Varco, and Parker Drilling, which rose 13/16 , to 113/16 .
Though Mr. Sanger said the combination of Halliburton with Dresser was an excellent fit, he cautioned that pressure could lead to "me-too" deals that might not make sense. He said that some companies could end up overpaying and then not get the savings and synergies that they had hoped for in a merger.
At the conference, representatives of some drilling companies painted a rosy picture of tight supplies for their equipment, which is used to find oil, to bring existing fields into production and to increase production on fields. In response to the strong demand, which has come even though oil prices have fallen by about a third since last fall, services companies have begun to build new rigs, they said.
The demand for drilling equipment has been so strong that several executives said that they had been able to get new contracts for rental of their equipment at much higher rates than in previous deals.
C. Russell Luigs, the chairman and chief executive of Global Marine, a major drilling company in Houston that is one of the largest providers of equipment in the Gulf of Mexico, said at the conference that in the last seven weeks the company has been able to negotiate new contracts for 13 rigs at considerably higher rates than in the previous contracts.
He said that what was driving the oil industry to keep up spending for exploration was that significant new oilfields had been found in deep water in the Gulf of Mexico in recent years and, more recently, off the coast of West Africa.
Mr. Luigs said that the company had a large backlog of demand for equipment and that even though the industry was gearing up to build new rigs there would still be tight supplies in the future. The strong demand has led to an intense competition within the industry for workers. And oil services companies have been scouring the world to buy used equipment and investing heavily in new capacity to build rigs.
This has put pressure on the companies to raise capital and to find skilled managers to oversee their growth. All of this has also led somecompanies to seek merger partners.

HEADLINE: Durable Orders Rose by 0.7% Last Month

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Commerce Department said today, indicating that the Asian economic crisis had little impact on American manufacturers.
The increase was below the 1 percent gain that analysts, on average, had expected. Still, it was the sixth gain in eight months and contrasted with December's revised decline of 5.5 percent. 
 Excluding transportation equipment -- an expensive airplane order can skew results -- durable goods orders increased three-tenths of 1 percent in January.
The month's data suggested that the expansion in the manufacturing sector had not yet been slowed by declining demand from the troubled Asian nations, said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation. "This continues to say that the economy is on a healthy growth path," he said. "The Asian economic hurricane has not been sighted in this report yet."
Still, Mr. Sohn said it would be only a matter of time before manufacturers began to feel the pinch from slackening Asian demand for their products. "The momentum is fairly healthy now, but by midyear orders could fall off the cliff," he said.
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, agreed that the full impact of the Asian turmoil had not yet been felt. But, he said, "today's report shows that manufacturers will weather the storm successfully as long as strong domestic demand continues." He added, "And every indication is that domestic demand will remain solid in coming months."
The Government said the backlog of unfilled orders increased half a percent in January, the fifth increase in the last seven months. A growing backlog often suggests that businesses are unable to meet demand with current plants and employment levels. Shipments fell 1.4 percent, the third drop in four months.
In another economic report, the Labor Department said today that initial claims for state unemployment insurance rose by 10,000 last week, to a seasonally adjusted 320,000. Analysts had expected a gain of only 1,000.
The four-week moving average for jobless applications, considered a more reliable gauge of labor market conditions than the volatile weekly figures, rose 5,000, to 309,250.

HEADLINE: Labor Chief Visits to Rally Unions and Hear Workers' Hopes

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O's president, brought the labor movement's road show to the Big Apple yesterday to hear what was on the minds of New York City's workers -- and they gave him an earful.
New York's never-timid workers addressed him the way they would a governor or even a president, urging him and the labor movement to help fix their problems, large and small: inadequate child care, expensive housing and insecurity on the job. 
 A hospital cook at a crowded town meeting at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in upper Manhattan, Edward Welch, told Mr. Sweeney that unions needed to do more to make housing affordable, especially for part-time workers.
At the same session, Hugh McCabe, a driver at the hospital, urged labor leaders to stop the hospital from contracting out cafeteria and housekeeping work to private companies -- moves he said had caused considerable layoffs.
In an earlier session in Brooklyn, at a Crown Heights day care center, Yim Man Mui, a garment worker, complained about the high cost and low availability of child care, noting, through a translator, that she spent about one-third of her wages on child care.
Linda Bullock, another union member, also bemoaned the child care shortage, telling Mr. Sweeney, "You sign up your child for day care when he's 2 1/2 and by the time you're called off the waiting list, he's 8 years old."
In bouncing around the city like a pinball during a visit that was part of his tour of 14 cities to hear what workers had to say, Mr. Sweeney soaked up dozens of such comments and pledged to take them into account when the 13-million-member labor federation shapes its agenda. He also met with Pakistani limousine drivers struggling to form a union as well as with union organizers who congratulated him for injecting some energy into the long-lethargic movement.
Sounding like a Congressman visiting his home district, Mr. Sweeney told the audience of 300 union members at Columbia-Presbyterian, "I'm personally a lot more interested in what you think here in New York than what all the experts think back in Washington because I firmly believe that the strength and wisdom of our movement lies here with rank-and-file union members like all of you."
In his visit, Mr. Sweeney, a Bronx native whose father was a bus driver, made clear that the city holds a special place in his heart -- and in the nation's labor movement. He said that a long-planned campaign to unionize tens of thousands of workers in hospitals, nursing homes and walk-in clinics should serve as a model for unions around the nation.
Dennis Rivera, president of 1199, the National Hospital and Human Service Employees Union, who was Mr. Sweeney's host at Columbia-Presbyterian, hinted that he would announce the multimillion-dollar organizing drive as soon as 1199's members voted next month on a planned merger with the Service Employees International Union.
Mr. Sweeney said New York City's labor leaders were providing another model for the nation with an ambitious plan, announced yesterday, to create a multi-union fund to build child care centers and finance child care slots. As part of that campaign, union leaders said that they would lobby Albany to finance 50,000 more child care slots and would pressure employers in contract negotiations to contribute to the multi-union child care fund.
"What you're doing is the first of its kind in the country," Mr. Sweeney said. "They're all models of what we should be doing."
If there was any theme in Mr. Sweeney's day, it was child care. He spent the morning blessing the effort by a dozen unions -- including 1199, the teachers and state, county and municipal employees -- to make child care one of the local labor movement's main thrusts.
Brian M. McLaughlin, president of the New York City Central Labor Council, said, "We hope we can make a successful push on child care the way the labor movement successfully pushed once upon a time on such fundamental issues as the eight-hour day, minimum wage and occupational safety and health."
In an interview on a school bus that was bumpily carrying him from Crown Heights to Columbia-Presbyterian, Mr. Sweeney made clear that the purpose of his visit was not merely to listen. He said he hoped his presence would not only cause workers to warm to labor's message but also persuade them to get more involved in union activity, especially in the push to recruit more members.
It was a feel-good day for Mr. Sweeney because even as workers occasionally scolded him to encourage him to do more, they enthusiastically praised him for reviving labor and paying attention to their concerns.
"I'm very excited about the visit," said Willie Mae Terry, a medical assistant at Columbia-Presbyterian. "It shows unity. It's people getting together."
Mr. Sweeney's message resonated with what was clearly a hometown crowd. He talked of making health insurance more affordable, of raising the minimum wage and of reducing the pay disparity between men and women.
At Columbia-Presbyterian, the crowd, made up of members of 1199, applauded thunderously when he said, "Everybody seems to agree that with corporate profits and executive salaries going up and with the stock market and the economy booming, it's time working families shared a bigger slice of the pie."
Mr. Sweeney used a similar applause line at recent town meetings he held in Atlanta; Kansas City; Topeka, Kan., and Toledo, Ohio
In Topeka, workers complained to him that local jobs had been lost because of the North American Free Trade Agreement. In Toledo, workers complained of heavy overtime, inadequate pensions and unaffordable health insurance.
Thirty-five minutes into the meeting at Columbia-Presbyterian, half the audience suddenly drifted away. Mr. Rivera rushed to the microphone to explain that it was due to the age-old tension between employer and employee.
"You see many of our members are leaving," he told Mr. Sweeney. "It's not a matter of disrespect. It's their lunch hour, and if they don't go back to work, they'll be written up."
